Despite the division in reactions to Trump's victory, a large majority (79%) of voters, including similar proportions of men and women, as well as Trump and Clinton supporters, still expected a female president in their lifetime [1]. ![The image displays a bar chart showing the percentage of voters who answered "Yes" or "No" to a specific question (not given in the image).](image2)

While the majority of voters were surprised by Trump's victory, and emotions were divided along party lines, there was widespread expectation across both Trump and Clinton voters that there would be a female president in the future [1, 5].

Since the start of the year, there has been a seven percentage-point rise in the share expressing concern that anti-terror policies have not gone far enough [10]. Americans' ratings of the government’s efforts to reduce the threat of terrorism are now lower than at any point since the September 2001 terrorist attacks [2].

Evaluations of the government’s job reducing the threat of terrorism are more positive among those with a postgraduate degree than among other educational groups [5]. Older and less educated Americans are somewhat more likely than younger and more highly educated Americans to give the government low marks for the job it is doing reducing the threat of terrorism [9].  ![The table shows survey results on opinions about the balance between civil liberties and national protection across different age groups](image2). As illustrated in the table, 71% of those aged 65+ believe that policies have not gone far enough to protect the US, compared to 43% of those aged 18-29 who feel policies have gone too far in restricting civil liberties.

Compared to early 2015, assessments of government efforts to combat terrorism are more negative across the political spectrum [3]. Both Republicans and Democrats have become more likely to say that the government’s anti-terrorism policies do not go far enough to protect the country since Snowden’s disclosures in 2013 [4].  ![The image is a line graph comparing two perspectives over a period from 2004 to 2015](image3). As shown in the graph, there has been a shift in public opinion over time regarding whether the government has gone too far in restricting civil liberties or not far enough to protect the country.

Public perceptions of government efforts to combat terrorism have become more negative over time, with older individuals and those with less education being more critical, and these perceptions vary significantly based on political affiliation and age group.

Younger adults are more concerned about the U.S. going too far in getting involved in situations like Iraq and Syria, while older age groups worry about the U.S. not doing enough [1]. Adults under 30 are also more split on whether government policies place too many restrictions on civil liberties, whereas older adults are more concerned about security [3]. ![The table shows the distribution of opinions on the balance between civil liberties and national protection across different age groups.](image2)

Older and less educated Americans tend to rate government efforts against terrorism more negatively [2, 6].  However, assessments of government efforts to combat terrorism have become more negative across the political spectrum since early 2015 [7]. Evaluations are more positive among those with postgraduate degrees [9]. Those 50 and older tend to view government efforts to reduce the terrorist threat negatively, while younger adults are more likely to view them positively [10]. ![The table displays how different demographic groups perceive the performance of government efforts.](image3)

Over time, concern over government restrictions on civil liberties has fallen [8]. There's been a shift in public opinion, with more Americans now concerned that anti-terror policies haven't gone far enough to protect the country [5]. ![The line graph illustrates how public opinion has shifted over time regarding the balance between protecting the country and restricting civil liberties.](image5)

Age and political ideology both significantly influence perceptions of government efforts to reduce the terrorist threat, with younger individuals and those on the left generally expressing more concern about civil liberties, while older individuals and those on the right prioritize national security.

Older Americans are more critical of the government's efforts to reduce the threat of terrorism [2, 4]. For example, a majority of those 50 and older (57%) feel the government is not doing well in reducing the terrorist threat, while younger adults (18-29 years old) are more split, with 46% giving the government a negative rating and 53% a positive rating [4]. This difference in perception is also reflected in concerns about civil liberties, as older adults are more concerned that anti-terrorism policies have *not* gone far enough to protect the country, while younger adults are more split between concerns about policies restricting civil liberties and not going far enough to protect the country [10].

![The table displays survey results on opinions about the balance between civil liberties and national protection across different age groups.](image5)

Adults under 30 are almost evenly split in their concerns, with 43% worried about too many restrictions on civil liberties and 44% concerned that policies don't go far enough to protect the country [10]. In contrast, older demographics express greater concern for security over civil liberties, particularly those 65 and older, where 71% feel that policies have not gone far enough [10]. This disparity highlights a generational divide in how Americans weigh the balance between national security and individual freedoms in the context of anti-terrorism measures.

![This table appears to show survey results about how different demographic groups perceive how well something is performing or being done.](image4)

In 2015, older Americans were more critical of the government's performance in reducing the terrorist threat and were more concerned that anti-terror policies had not gone far enough, while younger Americans were more divided in their assessment and concerns about civil liberties.

Americans are increasingly concerned that anti-terrorism policies do not go far enough to protect the country [1, 5]. This sentiment has grown since 2013, following Edward Snowden’s disclosures about NSA surveillance programs [2, 4]. The shift is evident across different political affiliations, with Republicans showing a more pronounced increase in this concern [4].

The level of concern varies across age groups, with older adults (65+) expressing the greatest concern that policies do not go far enough ![Older adults are more concerned that anti-terrorism policies do not go far enough.](image4). While younger adults (18-29) are more divided in their opinions [8].

Comparing different global issues, Americans' concern about ISIS has increased significantly between 2014 and 2015 ![Americans are most concerned about ISIS as a major threat.](image1).

However, Americans' ratings of the government’s efforts to reduce the threat of terrorism are now lower than at any point since the September 2001 terrorist attacks [6]. More now say the government is doing not too well or not at all well in reducing the threat of terrorism (52%) than say the government is doing either very or fairly well (46%) [6].

In conclusion, since 2013, Americans across different age groups and political affiliations have generally shifted towards greater concern that government anti-terrorism policies do not go far enough, although younger adults are more divided, and government anti-terrorism efforts receive lower ratings overall [1, 2, 4, 6, 8].

Public perception of the U.S. military campaign against ISIS has generally been negative, but there's growing optimism about its ultimate success [1, 4].  Assessments of the campaign's current progress remain largely unfavorable, with 58% viewing it as "not too well" or "not at all well" [4]. This negative sentiment has persisted over the past year, but approval for the U.S. military effort remains steady, with a majority (64%) in support [6, 4]. ![The percentage of people who rated "Not too/at all well" versus "Very/Fairly well" over several time periods.](image4)

Despite the negative views on the campaign's current state, there is increasing confidence in its eventual success [1, 7].  The percentage of people who believe the U.S. and its allies will "definitely or probably succeed" has risen from 55% in July to 66% in December [9]. ![The survey results about the opinions of the success of the U.S. and its allies in the campaign against Islamic militants in Iraq and Syria.](image5)

Partisan divides exist in assessments of the campaign against ISIS [2]. While a higher percentage of Democrats (45%) believe the campaign is going at least "fairly well" compared to independents (33%) and Republicans (26%), majorities across all political affiliations predict ultimate success [2]. Specifically, 65% of Republicans, 72% of Democrats, and 62% of independents anticipate a successful outcome [2]. ![The percentage of Republicans, Democrats, and Independents who perceive ISIS as major threats.](image1)

In conclusion, while initial perceptions of the U.S. military campaign against ISIS were negative, there has been a notable increase in the belief that the U.S. and its allies will ultimately achieve success, with some differences in assessment across political affiliations.

There is a notable partisan divide regarding perceptions of Islam and its potential encouragement of violence [7, 9]. A significant percentage of Republicans, around 68%, believe Islam is more prone to encourage violence, a figure that has remained relatively stable [5, 9].

In contrast, the percentage of Democrats who share this view is considerably lower, with only 30% associating Islam with a higher likelihood of encouraging violence [5, 9]. This represents a decrease from 42% in 2014, aligning with previous Democratic opinions [5, 9].

These diverging opinions have resulted in the widest partisan gap observed on this issue to date [9]. Overall, public opinion is divided, with 46% believing Islam is more likely to encourage violence, while 45% disagree, showing little change from previous years ![Opinions on whether Islam encourages violence compared to other religions from 2002-2015](image4).

Assessments of government efforts against terrorism have become more negative across the political spectrum [6]. While a majority of Democrats (64%) still rate the government's efforts positively, this is a decrease from 85% earlier in the year [6]. Independents' positive ratings have fallen by 25 points, and only 27% of Republicans now view the government's efforts favorably, a significant drop from 63% [6]. These shifts in perception highlight a growing discontent with the government's handling of the terrorist threat, irrespective of political affiliation [6].

Partisan divisions are evident, with Republicans more inclined to believe Islam encourages violence, while Democrats are less so; negative assessments of government efforts to combat terrorism have risen across the political spectrum.

Americans are divided on whether Islam is more likely to encourage violence than other religions, with $46\%$ saying it is and $45\%$ saying it is not [5]. The share of the public associating Islam with violence has decreased since September 2014 [5].

The partisan divide regarding Islam encouraging violence is significant [8]. A historical high of $68\%$ of Republicans believe Islam encourages violence more than other religions, while only $30\%$ of Democrats share this view, a decrease from $42\%$ in September 2014 [8].  Independents are split, with $45\%$ believing Islam encourages violence and $45\%$ disagreeing [9]. ![Independents are split, with 45% believing Islam encourages violence and 45% disagreeing](image1)

Ideological divides are also stark, with $77\%$ of conservative Republicans believing Islam is more likely to encourage violence, while $73\%$ of liberal Democrats think it is not [7]. There has been a 14-point decrease in the share of liberals associating Islam with violence since 2014 [2].

Regarding which party can better handle terrorism, $46\%$ of the public favor the Republican Party, compared to $34\%$ who favor the Democrats [6]. Republicans maintain a considerable advantage over Democrats in public perception regarding handling terrorism [6]. ![The Republican Party is favored by 46% of the public to handle terrorism better, compared to 34% for the Democratic Party](image3)

Perceptions of Islam encouraging violence vary significantly across political affiliations, with Republicans largely viewing Islam as more violence-prone, while Democrats' views have softened, even as Republicans are seen as better equipped to handle terrorism.

Perceptions of the scrutiny of Muslims in the U.S. vary significantly across different political and demographic groups. Liberal Democrats are the most likely to reject increased scrutiny of Muslims, with 87% opposing it [2]. Conversely, conservative Republicans stand out as the only group in which a majority (57%) supports greater scrutiny of Muslims [3].

![Conservative Republicans are more likely to support greater scrutiny of Muslims](image3)

Independents and moderate/liberal Republicans largely believe that Muslims should not face additional scrutiny [6]. Younger adults (18-29) overwhelmingly reject the idea of increased scrutiny of U.S. Muslims, with 80% opposed [8]. Similarly, non-white individuals are more likely than whites to oppose such scrutiny [9, 10].  Specifically, 74% of blacks and 66% of Hispanics believe that Muslims should not face greater scrutiny, compared to 57% of whites [10].

![Younger adults are less likely to support greater scrutiny of Muslims](image2)

Regarding the importance of terrorism as a national issue, Republicans are more likely to prioritize it than Democrats or Independents [4]. A survey conducted in December 2015 shows that terrorism was mentioned by 18% of respondents, a significant increase from 1% the previous year [image5].  Republicans (41%) mention terrorism, defense issues, national security, or ISIS more frequently than independents (28%) and Democrats (23%) [4].

![Terrorism is more important to Republicans](image4)

These differences in perceptions of scrutiny and the importance of terrorism may stem from varying political ideologies and concerns about national security.

In summary, perceptions of scrutiny towards Muslims differ significantly across political and demographic groups, correlating with the perceived importance of terrorism as a national issue, with Republicans being more concerned about terrorism and more supportive of increased scrutiny.

Americans' concern over terrorism has increased significantly, with 29% citing terrorism, national security, or ISIS as the most important problem, up from only 4% the previous year [7]. This rise marks the highest level of concern since February 2003 [7]. This shift in public perception is further illustrated in ![Terrorism concerns have sharply increased from 2014 to 2015.](image1), highlighting a substantial increase in concerns related to terrorism and national security.

However, evaluations of the government’s efforts to reduce the threat of terrorism have declined across the board [5]. Overall, more Americans now believe the government is not doing well in reducing the threat of terrorism (52%) compared to those who think it is doing well (46%) [3]. This negative sentiment represents a 26-point drop since January [3]. The decline in positive ratings is evident across political affiliations, as shown in [4]. Democrats, Independents, and Republicans all express less confidence in the government's anti-terrorism efforts compared to early 2015 [4].

Significant partisan divides exist regarding the most important problem facing the nation [1]. Republicans are more likely to prioritize terrorism and national security-related issues, while Democrats and Independents cite these issues less frequently [1]. ![This image visualizes the different levels of concern about issues by political affiliation.](image3) reveals the differences in issue prioritization among Republicans, Democrats, and Independents.

Age and education also play a role in shaping perceptions [10]. Older Americans and those with less education tend to view the government's efforts against terrorism more negatively [8]. ![This table illustrates how perceptions of government efforts differ across demographics.](image4) shows the varying levels of approval based on age, education, and political affiliation.

In summary, Americans are increasingly concerned about terrorism, but their confidence in the government's efforts to combat this threat has declined, with significant differences in perception across political and demographic groups.

Republicans and Democrats show significant differences in their concerns regarding terrorism and the economy, according to recent survey data. Republicans are more likely to prioritize terrorism and national security, while Democrats tend to focus on other issues such as partisan gridlock [5, 7].

The survey results highlight that a substantial percentage of Republicans mention terrorism, defense issues, national security, or ISIS as the most important problem facing the nation [5]. ![The table shows that Republicans prioritize issues such as terrorism, defense/national security, and immigration more than Democrats.](image1) As of December 2015, terrorism was mentioned by 18% of respondents, a significant increase from 1% the previous year [image4]. In contrast, Democrats are more concerned with issues like partisan gridlock and division within the country [7]. While economic issues are a concern across the board, they appear to be of less relative importance to Republicans compared to terrorism and national security [image4].

These differing priorities are also reflected in how each group assesses the government's efforts [6]. A sizable portion of the public believes the Republican Party is better equipped to handle the terrorist threat at home [8]. This divergence in viewpoints underscores the partisan divide on the most pressing issues facing the nation [5].

In conclusion, Republicans prioritize terrorism and national security more than Democrats, while Democrats focus on issues such as partisan gridlock, and both groups have differing views on the importance of economic issues.

Republicans are more inclined to view terrorism as a critical issue compared to Independents and Democrats [6]. Specifically, 41% of Republicans cite terrorism, defense issues, national security, or ISIS as the most important problem, while fewer Independents (28%) and Democrats (23%) share this concern [6].

This difference in viewpoints extends to their assessment of the government's efforts in reducing the terrorist threat. A significant portion of Republicans mention immigration as the most important problem (14%) compared to Independents (7%) or Democrats (3%) [2]. Democrats are more likely than Republicans to cite partisan gridlock and division in the country as key issues [2].

![The table highlights the different levels of importance that Republicans, Democrats, and Independents place on issues such as defense, immigration, terrorism, and the economy.](image3)

Views of how the government is handling the terrorist threat differ across political affiliations [9]. Assessments of government efforts to combat terrorism are more negative across the political spectrum compared to early 2015 [4]. The decrease in positive ratings is notable among Republicans, with only 27% saying the government is doing well, a sharp decline from 63% at the beginning of the year [4]. Democrats are the only partisan group in which a majority (64%) say the government is doing at least fairly well [4].

![The table shows the percentage of different demographic groups who view the subject positively or negatively, or who responded "Don't Know".](image2)

In summary, Republicans prioritize terrorism more than Democrats or Independents, and they are also more critical of the government's efforts to reduce the terrorist threat [6, 4].

Independents hold distinct views compared to Republicans and Democrats. When it comes to government size, independents are divided, with 47% preferring a smaller government and 44% favoring a bigger one ![Independents are almost evenly split on their preference for government size.](image1). This contrasts with Republicans, where 74% prefer a smaller government, and Democrats, where 73% favor a bigger one [1].

On the issue of government regulation, independents again show a divided stance, with 48% viewing regulation as necessary to protect the public interest and 43% believing it does more harm than good ![Independents are divided on whether government regulation is harmful or necessary.](image1). A majority of Republicans (61%) think government regulation of business does more harm than good, while a majority of Democrats (65%) feel it's necessary to protect the public interest ![Independents are divided on whether government regulation is harmful or necessary.](image1).

Regarding the fairness of the U.S. economic system, a majority of independents (70%) believe the system unfairly favors powerful interests [3]. This is a view shared by large majorities of Democrats (85%) and Democratic leaners (81%) [3]. Republicans hold a different perspective, with 63% believing the U.S. economic system is fair to most Americans [6]. GOP leaners are more divided, with 49% saying the system is generally fair and 46% saying it unfairly favors powerful interests [6].
![Most independents think the economic system unfairly favors powerful interests.](image4)

In summary, independent voters differ from Democrats and Republicans in that they are more divided on issues such as government size and regulation, but largely agree with Democrats that the U.S. economic system unfairly favors powerful interests.

Over the past two decades, negative views of opposing parties have risen among both Republicans and Democrats [1]. This trend extends to independents who lean towards a party [1].
![This image visualizes increasing unfavorable views of the opposite party from 1994 to 2018.](image4)
Among independents, those without a party preference are more likely to view both parties unfavorably [8]. Currently, 37% of independents without a lean hold unfavorable opinions of both the Democratic and Republican parties, while only 11% view the Democratic Party favorably and 9% view the GOP favorably [2].
![This image shows the percentage of people who have favorable or unfavorable opinions of the Republican and Democratic parties.](image3)
However, the percentage of independents with negative views of both parties has decreased in recent years, with 36% holding this view in 2015 [9]. In 2018, 12% of the people are unfavorable to both parties. ![This image shows the trend in public sentiment towards political parties over time.](image1)
Independents who lean towards a party tend to have a "strong partisan imprint" [10], often mirroring the views of those who identify with that party [4, 5]. Notably, intense dislike of the opposing party has grown among these leaners, similar to the trend among strong partisans [7]. The share of Democratic-leaning independents with very unfavorable opinions of the Republican Party quadrupled from 8% in 1994 to 37% in 2018, and a similar trend is observed among Republican leaners towards the Democratic Party, increasing from 15% to 39% [6].

In summary, while unfavorable views toward both parties are most common among independents without a lean, these views have decreased recently; conversely, negative views of the opposing party have sharply increased among independents who lean towards a major party.

Over the past two decades, negative views of opposing parties have grown among both Republicans and Democrats, as well as independents who lean toward a party [8]. The share of Democratic-leaning independents with very unfavorable opinions of the Republican Party has increased significantly from 8% in 1994 to 37% in 2018. A similar trend is observed among Republican leaners, with unfavorable opinions of the Democratic Party rising from 15% in 1994 to 39% in 2018 [2]. ![The graph illustrates increasing polarization over the years, with growing unfavorable views of the opposite party among partisan groups.](image4)

Currently, 87% of Republicans view the Democratic Party unfavorably, and 81% of Republican-leaning independents share this view [3]. Among Democrats, 88% view the GOP unfavorably, with 84% of Democratic leaners holding the same opinion [3].  These unfavorable views are near all-time highs within both parties [3]. ![The image is a data visualization that shows the percentage of people who have favorable or unfavorable opinions of the Republican and Democratic parties, broken down by different political affiliations.](image1)

Independents who do not lean toward either party are more likely to have unfavorable views of both parties [10], with 37% holding this view [6]. While most GOP leaners view the Republican Party favorably (55%), only 24% view both parties unfavorably [5]. The percentage of independents viewing both parties negatively has decreased in recent years, from 36% in 2015 [9].

In summary, unfavorable views toward the opposing party have increased across different political affiliations over time, and independents show varying levels of favorability and unfavorability toward both parties depending on their leaning.

Republicans and Democrats diverge significantly in their views on China's handling of the coronavirus outbreak [4]. A significant percentage of Americans, around three-quarters, believe that China's initial response in Wuhan contributed substantially to the global spread of the virus [5]. The image shows that a total of 64% of respondents think China did a bad job [2].

However, this perception is notably different between Republicans and Democrats, as seen in the image ![A bar chart showing different views on something categorized as "Bad" or "Good" across demographic groups.](image1). Republicans are far more critical, with $73\%$ believing China's early handling greatly contributed to the spread, compared to only $38\%$ of Democrats sharing the same sentiment [5]. The division is further highlighted in another image, indicating that $82\%$ of Republicans/leaning Republicans think China did a bad job, versus $54\%$ of Democrats/leaning Democrats [10].

These partisan differences extend to the preferred course of action regarding U.S.-China relations. A considerable percentage of Republicans $(71\%)$ are inclined to hold China accountable for its role in the outbreak, even if it strains economic relations, whereas only $37\%$ of Democrats share this view [9]. This is visually represented; ![A chart comparing views on prioritizing holding China responsible versus prioritizing strong U.S.-China relations.](image5), highlighting the divergence in opinions.

In summary, Republicans are significantly more critical of China's handling of the coronavirus outbreak and are more inclined to prioritize holding China accountable, even at the expense of worsening U.S.-China relations, compared to Democrats.

Republicans are significantly more critical of China's handling of the COVID-19 pandemic compared to Democrats [10]. A survey conducted in June-July 2020 reveals that $82\%$ of Republicans and Republican-leaning independents believed China had done a bad job dealing with the coronavirus, compared to $54\%$ of Democrats and Democratic-leaning individuals [10]. Furthermore, Republicans are about twice as likely to think China has done a "very bad job" (${\bf\tilde{6}1\%}$) compared to Democrats ($30\%$) [10]. Older Americans also tend to be more critical [1, 7].

![This image shows the percentages of people from different age groups and political affiliations who think something is "bad" or "good."](image4)

This difference in perception extends to whether the U.S. should hold China accountable for the outbreak, even if it harms economic relations; $71\%$ of Republicans favor holding China responsible, while only $37\%$ of Democrats agree [3].  The initial handling of the outbreak in Wuhan is largely blamed for the global spread of the virus [7]. A majority of Americans believe China's initial handling contributed either a great deal ($51\%$) or a fair amount ($27\%$) to the global spread [7]. Republicans are especially critical as $73\%$ believe China's early handling contributed a great deal, versus $38\%$ of Democrats [7].

![This image visualizes the different opinions on whether the U.S. should hold China responsible for the COVID-19 outbreak or prioritize strong U.S.-China relations.](image1)

Over time, negative views of China have increased across the political spectrum [4]. While opinions were more divided in the spring of 2019, by 2020, $63\%$ of Republicans and $73\%$ of Democrats believed bilateral economic ties were bad [4].  Views on whether the U.S. should hold China responsible, even if it worsens economic relations, have also shifted, as shown in the trends from 2005 to 2020 for both Republicans and Democrats.

![The graph illustrates the changing percentages of Republicans and Democrats over time.](image2)

In summary, Republicans are more critical of China's handling of COVID-19 than Democrats, and negative perceptions of China have increased among both groups over time.

Most Americans believe that China's initial handling of the coronavirus outbreak in Wuhan contributed to the global spread of the virus [4]. Specifically, around three-quarters of Americans attribute the global spread to China's early response, with a significant portion believing it contributed "a great deal" ![The chart indicates that 51% of respondents believe China's handling of the coronavirus outbreak contributed "a great deal" to the global spread, while 27% believe it contributed "a fair amount."](image2).

There's a notable divide in opinion along political lines. Republicans are more critical, with $73\%$ assigning a "great deal" of blame to China, compared to only $38\%$ of Democrats [4]. This partisan divide extends to overall views on China's handling of the outbreak, where Republicans are significantly more likely to rate China's response as "bad" compared to Democrats [8]. ![The bar chart shows that 82% of Republicans/Leaning Republicans think China did a "bad" job handling the coronavirus, compared to 54% of Democrats/Leaning Democrats.](image3).

Furthermore, half of Americans believe the U.S. should hold China accountable for its role in the pandemic, even if it damages economic relations [5, 7]. However, a notable percentage, $38\%$, prioritize maintaining strong U.S.-China relations, even if it means overlooking China's role in the outbreak [7]. Once again, political affiliation plays a significant role, with Republicans being about twice as likely as Democrats to favor holding China responsible, even at the expense of economic relations [7]. ![The survey data indicates that 51% of Americans believe the U.S. should hold China responsible for its role in the coronavirus outbreak, even if it leads to worsening relations.](image1).

Americans' views on China's role in the coronavirus outbreak and U.S.-China relations are significantly divided, with Republicans being more critical of China and more inclined to prioritize accountability over maintaining strong relations compared to Democrats.

Americans' views of China have soured, especially concerning China's handling of the COVID-19 outbreak and the state of bilateral relations [5]. A significant majority, 73% of U.S. adults, now hold an unfavorable view of China, marking a 26 percentage point increase since 2018 [5]. This negative sentiment is tied to the perception that China mishandled the initial outbreak and subsequent spread of COVID-19 [5].

![The graph shows the percentage of people who say they have a favorable or unfavorable opinion of China from 2005 to 2020.](image4)

Around two-thirds of Americans believe China did a poor job managing the coronavirus outbreak, and a substantial 78% attribute a great deal or fair amount of blame to the Chinese government for the global spread of the virus [7]. As a result, those who think China handled the outbreak poorly are significantly more likely to have negative views of the country [9].

![The image is a horizontal bar chart showing the proportion of responses to a question.](image5)

While half of Americans believe the U.S. should hold China accountable for its role in the coronavirus outbreak, even if it harms economic relations, 38% prefer prioritizing strong U.S.-China relations [2, 10]. Moreover, about seven in ten Americans view current economic ties between the two countries in bleak terms, marking a 15 percentage point increase since May 2019 [8].

Overall, American perceptions of China have become increasingly negative, driven by concerns over China's handling of COVID-19 and its broader impact on U.S.-China relations.

Americans' negative views of China have increased significantly across different demographics, especially among older adults and Republicans [2, 3, 6, 9]. Negative views of China have reached historic highs, with 73% of Americans holding an unfavorable view [2].

Older Americans (50+) consistently express more negative views toward China than younger age groups, with 81% holding unfavorable views [3]. ![Older Americans are more likely to view China unfavorably](image4). This trend is also reflected in their perceptions of China as an enemy rather than a partner [8]. The percentage of older Americans with negative views has increased by 10 percentage points since March [3]. The line graph depicts an upward trend for all age groups, with those aged 50 and older showing a particularly sharp increase in unfavorable views of China from 2005 to 2020 ![Views of China have become increasingly negative among all age groups over time](image3).

Republicans consistently hold more unfavorable views of China than Democrats, with 83% of Republicans expressing unfavorable views compared to 68% of Democrats [6]. ![Republicans are more likely to view China unfavorably](image5). A partisan divide has reemerged, with Republicans being 10 points more likely than Democrats to have no confidence in Xi Jinping [1].
Americans' negative perceptions of China have risen sharply, with older adults and Republicans expressing the most unfavorable views.

In the U.S., political affiliation significantly shapes views on foreign policy. Republicans show a greater inclination towards Israel as a key partner compared to Democrats, while Democrats emphasize Canada and Mexico more [8]. Although both parties generally agree on the UK as the most important partner, Republicans are more favorable toward close ties with Russia compared to Democrats [4].

Views on Germany, however, remain relatively consistent across party lines, with both Republicans and Democrats ranking Germany as a significant foreign policy partner [8].

![Views on Germany are similar among partisans in the U.S., with both sides ranking Germany fifth on the list of most or second-most important foreign policy partners.](image1)

In Germany, political leanings also influence foreign policy preferences, albeit with some nuances. Supporters of the CDU/CSU are more inclined towards greater cooperation with the U.S. than those who support the Greens and the SPD [3]. Moreover, those on the ideological right in Germany generally hold more favorable views of the U.S. overall [3].

Interestingly, preferences for cooperation with Russia differ notably between the eastern and western regions of Germany, with East Germans expressing nearly twice the desire for collaboration compared to Americans [5]. This regional divide underscores the lasting impact of historical and political contexts on foreign policy attitudes within Germany [7].

Political affiliations in both the U.S. and Germany play a crucial role in shaping preferences for foreign policy partners and desired cooperation levels.

Germans are almost twice as likely as Americans to want greater collaboration with Russia [3]. In the U.S., increased cooperation with Russia is more favored among Republicans (41%) than Democrats (32%), and in Germany, it's more common among those in the former East Germany (75%) than in the former West (63%) [3]. Preferences also differ between West and East Germans, as illustrated in the opinions regarding relationships with the U.S. and Russia. ![East Germans are more inclined towards Russia, while West Germans favor the U.S.](image4)

However, when it comes to China, attitudes diverge. Germans are about twice as likely to prefer a close relationship with the U.S. over China (50% to 24%), whereas Americans are almost equally divided (41% prefer Germany, 44% prefer China) [10].

Political party affiliations also play a role. Democrats in the U.S. are more likely to want greater cooperation with Germany than Republicans [9]. ![Democrats in the U.S. lean more towards cooperation with Germany compared to Republicans; CDU/CSU supporters in Germany show more willingness to cooperate with the U.S. than SPD and Green supporters.](image3) Similarly, in Germany, supporters of the CDU/CSU are more willing to cooperate with the U.S. than those who support the Greens and the SPD [9]. These preferences align with data on the international image of the U.S., where those on the ideological right in Germany tend to view the U.S. more favorably overall [9].

In summary, Germans are more inclined towards cooperation with Russia compared to Americans, while opinions on China are more divided; these preferences are further shaped by political party affiliations in both countries.

Democrats in the U.S. are more inclined towards greater cooperation with Germany than Republicans [1]. This is mirrored in Germany, where CDU/CSU supporters favor cooperation with the U.S. more than supporters of the Greens and SPD [1]. ![The image is a chart comparing political party alignment with some numerical percentages in the U.S. and Germany.](image1) As the image shows, 75% of Democrats/Lean Democrat are in favor of cooperation compared to 63% of Republicans/Lean Republican in the U.S. In Germany, 57% of CDU/CSU are in favor, compared to 47% of SPD (Social Democratic Party) and 45% of the Greens.

When it comes to Russia, Germans are almost twice as likely as Americans to want greater collaboration [3]. Increased cooperation with Russia is more common among Republicans in the U.S. (41%) than Democrats (32%), and more common among Germans in former East Germany (75%) than in the former West (63%) [3]. There are partisan differences in the U.S. regarding close relationships with Russia or Germany [5]. Approximately 66% of Democrats prefer close ties with Germany, compared to 57% of Republicans [5]. Conversely, 31% of Republicans prefer close relations with Russia, compared to 21% among Democrats [5].

Attitudes diverge concerning a rising China. Germans are about twice as likely to prefer a close relationship with the U.S. over China (50% to 24%), whereas Americans are almost equally divided (approximately 41% prefer Germany, 44% prefer China) [6]. However, younger Americans are more likely to want a closer relationship with China over Germany [10]. For example, 58% of Americans aged 18 to 29 prioritize a close relationship with China, compared to 32% who say the same about Germany [10]. ![The image is a comparative chart showing the percentage of people from different age groups in China and Germany.](image2)

Political party preferences significantly shape attitudes toward international cooperation, with Democrats in the U.S. and CDU/CSU supporters in Germany favoring closer ties with each other, while views on Russia and China are more divided along political and regional lines.

Germans are almost twice as likely as Americans to want greater collaboration with Russia [2]. Increased cooperation with Russia is more common among Republicans in the U.S. (41%) than Democrats (32%) [2].
![Germans in the former East Germany are more likely to favor increased cooperation with Russia.](image1)
In Germany, people living in former East Germany (75%) are more likely to favor increased collaboration with Russia than those in the former West (63%) [2]. Additionally, conservative Americans and Germans on the right of the ideological spectrum are more likely than their counterparts on the left to view Russia favorably [9]. Therefore, political affiliations influence attitudes toward cooperation with Russia in both the U.S. and Germany.

Americans and Germans diverge on which country they consider the world's leading economic power [2].  Half of Americans identify the U.S. as the leading economic power, while a considerable percentage names China [2]. Contrastingly, a majority of Germans see China as the leading economic power, with far fewer naming the U.S [2].

This difference extends to their views on international organizations.  Germans tend to view entities like the EU more favorably than Americans do [8]. The image highlights how opinions on the UN, EU, and Russia vary among conservatives, moderates/centrists, and liberals/those on the left in both the U.S. and Germany.  ![The chart illustrates varying opinions on the UN, EU, and Russia among different political orientations in the U.S. and Germany.](image1)

There is also a notable difference in how Americans and Germans perceive the importance of the U.S. military presence in Germany to the security of the United States [5].
The evaluation of the relationship between the U.S. and Germany differs sharply between the two countries [6].
Overall, Germans hold more positive views of the EU, Russia, China, UN, and NATO compared to Americans [8]. ![The chart illustrates the differences in approval ratings of the EU, Russia, China, UN, and NATO between the U.S. and Germany.](image5)

In summary, Americans and Germans differ significantly on which country is the world's leading economic power and generally, Germans hold more favorable views towards international entities compared to Americans.

Americans and Germans exhibit notable differences in their opinions regarding international organizations and economic powers [10].  Germans generally hold more positive views of these entities than Americans. This is especially evident in their perceptions of the EU, with approximately 70% of Germans favoring it compared to about 50% of Americans [10]. ![Germany has a higher approval rating for the EU, Russia, China, UN, and NATO compared to the U.S.](image1)

There is a considerable divergence in how Americans and Germans perceive the world's leading economic power [7].  Half of Americans identify the U.S. as the leading economic power, while a similar proportion of Germans believe it is China [7].  ![The chart compares perceptions of the world's leading economic power, with Americans favoring the U.S. and Germans favoring China.](image2) These differing views are also shaped by political ideologies within each country [3].  Conservative Americans are more likely to view Russia favorably, while liberals tend to favor the UN and EU [3].  ![The chart shows the opinions of Americans and Germans towards the UN, EU, and Russia.](image4) Moreover, regional factors also play a role, as Germans in former East Germany tend to view Russia more favorably and the EU less favorably than those in the former West [5].

In summary, Americans and Germans diverge in their views on international organizations and economic powers, influenced by factors such as political ideology and regional background.

Americans are more inclined than Germans to believe in the necessity of military force [4]. Approximately 80% of Americans think using force is sometimes necessary to maintain global order, whereas only about 50% of Germans share this view [4].

Attitudes toward defense spending also differ, with fewer Americans feeling that European allies need to increase their defense spending [3]. In Germany, public opinion is divided between increasing or maintaining current defense spending levels [5].
![Germans are divided on whether to increase or maintain their country's defense spending.](image1)
Germans are split on whether to increase or maintain their defense budgets, while fewer Americans think European allies should increase their defense spending [3, 5]. This represents a change in attitudes since 2017 [1, 5]. Despite these differences, younger people in both the U.S. and Germany hold more positive views of the U.S.-German relationship [2]. Specifically, in the U.S., 82% of those aged 18-29 view the relationship positively, compared to 73% of those 65 and older [2]. Similarly, in Germany, 40% of young people have a positive view, while only 31% of older adults agree [2].

In summary, Americans are more likely to support the use of military force and are less inclined to believe that European allies should increase defense spending compared to Germans; however, young people in both countries generally hold positive views of the U.S.-Germany relationship [2, 4].

Americans are more inclined than Germans to support the use of military force [6]. Approximately eight-in-ten Americans believe that military force is sometimes necessary to maintain global order, while only about half of Germans agree ![The image is a horizontal bar chart comparing the percentage of people in the U.S. and Germany who agree or disagree with an unspecified statement or question](image3). This divergence extends to defending NATO allies, where 60% of Americans believe in using military force against a potential Russian attack, contrasted by an equal percentage of Germans who oppose such intervention [9].

Differences are also apparent in how each country views defense spending and military presence.  While half of Germans see U.S. military bases as important for their country’s national security, 45% disagree [5].  Moreover, Americans consider their military bases in Germany as vital to their security interests more so than Germans do [3].

![The image is a chart comparing the opinions of people from the U.S. and Germany on an unspecified issue about whether something should or should not be done](image1)

Regarding defense spending, Americans are more inclined to maintain current spending levels by European allies [2]. Public opinion in Germany is divided between increasing or maintaining current levels of spending on national defense [10]. Although fewer Americans now see the need for European allies to increase defense spending, Germans themselves are split on increasing or maintaining their budgets [8].

In summary, Americans are generally more supportive of military intervention and prioritize defense spending and military presence differently than Germans.

Both Americans and Germans show evolving opinions on defense spending, with partisan divides within each country influencing these perspectives. As of 2019, half of Americans felt that European allies should maintain their current defense spending levels, marking a shift from 2017 when $45\%$ believed they should increase it [5]. Similarly, German public opinion is divided on increasing or maintaining defense spending, with about four-in-ten holding each view [7]. The trend in the U.S. shows a decline in the percentage of both Republicans and Democrats who believe that European allies should increase their defense budgets, as shown in ![The line graph shows trends for Republican/Lean Rep and Democrat/Lean Dem from 2017 to 2019.](image2).

Partisan gaps are evident in both countries. In the U.S., Republicans are more inclined to favor increased defense spending in Europe compared to Democrats [8]. In Germany, supporters of the CDU/CSU are generally in favor of increasing defense spending, while those of the Green party are more skeptical, and SPD members fall in the middle [1, 4]. This is further illustrated in ![The chart shows the defense spending increase preferences for CDU/CSU, SPD and Greens parties.](image4), where CDU/CSU shows the highest support at 51, compared to SPD at 41 and Greens at 28. The differences in the U.S. and Germany regarding defense spending are summarized in ![The comparative bar chart depicts the public opinion of Americans and Germans on national defense spending over the years 2017, 2018, and 2019.](image5).

In summary, opinions on defense spending have shifted in both the U.S. and Germany since 2017, with partisan lines influencing the specific views within each nation.

Between 2017 and 2019, views on national defense spending shifted in both the United States and Germany. In the U.S., fewer Americans felt that European allies should increase their defense budgets, with the percentage dropping from $45\%$ in 2017 to $35\%$ in 2019 [4]. A greater percentage of Americans felt their allies in Europe should maintain the same level of defense spending in 2019 compared to 2017, with 50% holding this view in 2019 compared to 37% in 2017 [4]. In Germany, a similar trend occurred. In 2017, half of the public was content with the country’s defense spending [10]. By 2019, opinions were divided, with about four-in-ten supporting an increase and a similar proportion favoring maintaining current spending levels [10]. The comparative bar chart illustrates these changes in public opinion regarding national defense spending in both the U.S. and Germany over the years 2017-2019. ![The chart illustrates changes in public opinion regarding national defense spending in both the U.S. and Germany over the years 2017-2019.](image1)

Partisan differences are evident in both countries. In the U.S., Republicans are more likely than Democrats to favor increased defense spending in Europe [3]. However, even among Republicans, the percentage who believe U.S.’s European allies should increase their defense budgets decreased by 14 percentage points between 2017 and 2019 [3]. This line graph visually summarizes the trends from 2017 to 2019 for both Republicans and Democrats. ![This line graph visually summarizes the trends from 2017 to 2019 for both Republicans and Democrats.](image3)
In Germany, supporters of the CDU/CSU are generally in favor of increasing defense spending [9]. However, only $28\%$ of Greens supporters express the same sentiment, showing greater skepticism [9]. SPD members fall in the middle, with $41\%$ supporting increased defense spending [9]. These numerical values are associated with the different political parties. ![These numerical values are associated with the different political parties.](image5)

Overall, between 2017 and 2019, fewer Americans supported increased defense spending by European allies, while German public opinion was divided between increasing or maintaining their defense budgets, with partisan divisions influencing these views in both countries.

In both the U.S. and Germany, political affiliations play a significant role in shaping opinions on increasing defense spending [5].
![The chart shows the percentage of people who voted for CDU/CSU, SPD and Greens in the 2017 Bundestag elections who say Germany should increase its defense spending.](image3)
For instance, in Germany, supporters of the CDU/CSU are generally in favor of increased defense spending, while those affiliated with the Greens tend to be more skeptical [5]. Only 28% of Greens supporters advocate for raising defense spending [5]. SPD members fall in the middle, with 41% supporting an increase [5].
![The graph illustrates trends in opinions on increasing defense spending among Republicans and Democrats in the U.S. from 2017 to 2019.](image5)
In the U.S., Republicans are more inclined to support increased defense spending in Europe compared to Democrats [3]. However, support among Republicans for increasing the defense budgets of European allies has decreased by 14 percentage points between 2017 and 2019 [3]. A more modest decline in this view is also observed among Democrats [3]. These trends indicate a shift in opinions over time within both political groups, with a general decrease in support for increased defense spending [3].

Political affiliations influence opinions on increasing defense spending, with differing views among parties and a decreasing trend in support over time.

In Germany, age significantly influences the perception of U.S. military bases. Younger Germans are more likely to doubt the importance of these bases for their national security, as roughly six-in-ten Germans ages 18 to 29 think U.S. military bases in Germany do not contribute to German national security [9]. Conversely, 61% of those 65 and older believe the bases are important to Germany’s defense [9].

![Younger Germans are less likely to view the bases as important.](image5)

This divide is evident when comparing the views of different age groups on whether U.S. military bases are important for Germany’s national security [5]. The older Germans are more likely to see U.S. military bases in their country as important [5]. This contrasts with the younger population's skepticism [9].

In the U.S., political affiliation dictates who people think is the most important foreign policy partner [4]. While both Republicans and Democrats agree that the UK is their most important partner, Republicans are keener on Israel as a partner (26%) than Democrats (9%) [4]. Democrats also place more emphasis on Canada and Mexico for their top foreign policy affiliate [4].

![Republicans favor UK and Israel more, while Democrats favor UK, Canada, and Mexico.](image4)

Views of Germany are similar among partisans in the U.S., with both sides ranking Germany fifth on the list of most or second-most important foreign policy partners [4]. Democrats and Republicans are about as likely to name Germany as a top foreign policy partner, but Republicans are keener on Israel [7].

Age in Germany and political affiliation in the U.S. significantly shape perceptions, with younger Germans questioning the importance of U.S. military bases and political affiliations in the U.S. influencing preferences for foreign policy partners.

Americans' views on global engagement are significantly divided along political and ideological lines [6, 9]. Republicans, especially conservative ones, largely believe the U.S. should focus on its own problems rather than assisting other nations, as shown by the fact that about three-quarters of Republicans share this sentiment [5].

Conversely, Democrats are more inclined to support the U.S. helping other countries, although this view is more prevalent among liberal Democrats than their moderate or conservative counterparts [8].

Education also plays a role, with more educated Americans being more supportive of international assistance. Six-in-ten postgraduates believe the U.S. should aid other countries, while those with less education are more in favor of focusing domestically [10].

Views on the U.S.’s handling of the coronavirus outbreak also differ along party lines, with Democrats being more critical than Republicans [9]. Evaluations become more divided when considering ideological lines [9]. More educated Americans are also more critical of how the U.S. has dealt with the disease [3].  ![Those with higher levels of education are more supportive of helping other nations deal with their problems.](image3)

Political affiliation and educational background significantly shape opinions on U.S. global engagement and handling of international issues, with Democrats and those with higher education being more supportive of global involvement.

Americans' opinions on the U.S.'s handling of the coronavirus outbreak are significantly divided along party lines [3, 8]. A large majority of Democrats and those leaning towards the Democratic party are critical of the U.S. response, while a similar proportion of Republicans and Republican-leaning individuals praise it [3]. ![The chart shows opinions on a scale from "Only fair/poor" to "Good/excellent" across various demographic groups.](image3) This partisan divide is evident when comparing the views of Democrats and Republicans [10].

Education level also plays a role in shaping these perceptions. More educated Americans tend to be more critical of the U.S.'s handling of the pandemic [2].  ![The bar chart shows the percentages of various demographics' views on whether the U.S. should deal with its own problems or let other countries deal with their own problems.](image4) Those with postgraduate degrees are more likely to view the U.S. response negatively compared to those with a high school degree or less [2].

However, when it comes to China's handling of the virus, education appears to have less influence [4].  Instead, a majority across all educational groups express criticism towards China's handling of the pandemic [4]. Older Americans, who generally hold less favorable views of China, are particularly critical [7]. ![The image is a chart showing political leanings towards Democratic/Lean Democrat and Republican/Lean Republican in various countries.](image2) Nearly two-thirds of Americans overall believe China has not done a good job in dealing with the coronavirus outbreak [6].

In summary, political affiliation greatly influences Americans' views on the U.S.'s handling of COVID-19, while education level has some impact; in contrast, views on China's handling are largely critical across educational backgrounds, with older Americans being the most critical.

Americans' opinions on how different countries handled the COVID-19 outbreak reveal significant partisan divides [4, 8]. When evaluating the U.S.'s handling of the pandemic, there's a notable split along political lines, with only $27\%$ of Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents rating it as good or excellent, compared to $71\%$ of Republicans and Republican-leaning independents [8].

![The image is a chart showing political leanings towards Democratic/Lean Democrat and Republican/Lean Republican in various countries.](image2)

This partisan gap is evident when assessing the U.S.’s response to the coronavirus outbreak, with those believing the U.S. can learn from other countries being less positive in their evaluation [5]. A smaller percentage of this group ($44\%$) rates the U.S.’s handling as excellent or good, compared to those who think the U.S. can't learn much from overseas ($63\%$) [5].  Regarding China's response, majorities across all education levels believe China did not handle the pandemic well [7]. However, Republicans are more likely than Democrats to hold this view [9].  Conservative Republicans, in particular, are very critical, with eight-in-ten saying China did not handle the crisis effectively [9].

![The image is a horizontal bar chart comparing opinions on a scale of "Only fair/poor" to "Good/excellent" across various demographic groups.](image3)

Political affiliations significantly shape the perception of the U.S. and China's handling of the COVID-19 pandemic, with Republicans generally more critical of China and more positive about the U.S. response compared to Democrats.

There is a notable partisan divide regarding the perception of the U.S.'s ability to learn from other countries in handling the coronavirus outbreak [6]. Democrats are more inclined to believe that the U.S. can learn a great deal from other nations, with 60% holding this view, while only 28% of Republicans share this sentiment [6]. This difference is further emphasized when considering the extremes within each party, as 67% of liberal Democrats believe the U.S. can learn a great deal, compared to just 25% of conservative Republicans [5].

![Partisan divisions exist in trusting information from the WHO](image1)

This divergence in perceptions is connected to how each political group assesses the U.S.'s handling of the pandemic and how they view international organizations [1, 9]. Those who believe the U.S. can learn from other countries are less likely to rate the U.S.'s handling of the outbreak positively [1]. Simultaneously, trust in organizations like the WHO is also divided along partisan lines, with Democrats showing significantly higher trust levels compared to Republicans [10]. For instance, 86% of liberal Democrats trust information from the WHO, while only 27% of conservative Republicans do [10]. Similarly, views on the WHO's handling of the pandemic split along partisan lines [9].

In summary, Democrats are more inclined to believe that the U.S. can learn from other countries' handling of the coronavirus and generally exhibit higher levels of trust in international organizations such as the WHO and the EU, in stark contrast to Republicans.

The American public is largely divided on how the pandemic will affect U.S. influence, with about three-in-ten believing it will be bolstered, while the same share thinks it will be weakened [4].  About half of Americans believe China will emerge with less influence [2, 6]. Clear partisan gaps exist, with Republicans being about twice as likely as Democrats to believe the U.S.'s international influence will be strengthened [3].

![The image shows a bar chart displaying survey results about people’s perceptions on a particular topic.](image1)

Education also plays a role, as Americans with higher education levels are more likely to think the country’s global influence will recede [10].  These partisan and age divides are similar to other attitudes about China, with older Americans and Republicans especially likely to have a negative opinion [5].  

![The image is a bar chart comparing opinions from the U.S., the EU, and China.](image3)

These differences in perception regarding the future influence of the U.S., EU, and China are shaped by political affiliation and education level.

There are clear partisan and age-related divisions in how Americans perceive the future global influence of both the U.S. and China after the coronavirus outbreak [1, 4, 6]. Republicans are more inclined to believe that the U.S.'s international influence will strengthen, whereas Democrats are more likely to anticipate a weakening [1].  There are also differences within the Democratic party, as liberal supporters are more likely than conservatives and moderates to foresee a decline in U.S. influence [1].

![The image shows a bar chart displaying survey results about people’s perceptions on a particular topic](image1)

Education levels also play a role, with those having higher education more often predicting a decline in U.S. global influence [9].  Regarding China's influence, about half of Americans believe it will decline, but a notable partisan divide exists [3].

![The image is a bar chart showing survey results on three categories: "More," "About the same," and "Less."](image4)

Republicans are more likely to anticipate a diminished global role for China compared to Democrats [4, 7].  Older Americans (65+) are also more inclined than those under 30 to foresee China having less global influence [4]. These divisions mirror broader attitudes towards China, where older Americans and Republicans tend to hold more negative opinions [7].  A majority of both Republicans and Democrats believe that the EU’s international influence will remain largely unaffected by the coronavirus outbreak [2].

In summary, perceptions of the U.S.'s and China's future global influence after the coronavirus outbreak vary significantly along political and demographic lines, with Republicans and older Americans generally more pessimistic about China's influence and more optimistic about the U.S.'s.

Nearly two-thirds of Americans believe that China has not effectively managed the coronavirus outbreak, with a significant percentage considering their handling "poor" [3]. A significant portion of Americans anticipates a decline in China's influence on the global stage following the coronavirus outbreak, with 50% believing China will have less influence [2, 9]. This sentiment is further illustrated in the image, showing that more people believe China will have less influence (50%) compared to those who think its influence will remain the same (31%) or increase (17%) ![The image shows that more people believe China will have less influence (50%) compared to those who think its influence will remain the same (31%) or increase (17%).](image3).

Partisan divisions significantly shape these perceptions. Republicans are more inclined to hold negative views of China and are more likely to believe that China's international influence will diminish as a result of the outbreak [4, 5, 7]. For example, Republicans are more likely than Democrats to say China has not done a good job dealing with the outbreak [7]. This divide extends to views on the U.S.'s role in addressing global issues, as illustrated in ![The image is a line graph depicting the growing partisan divisions over the U.S.'s role in solving world problems from 2013 to 2020.](image4) showing the diverging opinions between Republicans and Democrats regarding the U.S.'s focus on its own problems versus engaging in international affairs [10]. As indicated in ![China's performance on the scale ranging from "Poor" to "Excellent."](image5), China's performance in handling the coronavirus outbreak receives mixed reviews, with a notable proportion rating it as "poor."

Americans generally hold a negative view of China's handling of the coronavirus outbreak, and these perceptions are significantly influenced by partisan affiliations.

Americans hold differing views along partisan and ideological lines regarding the U.S.'s role in addressing global challenges [3, 6]. Republicans are more inclined to believe that the U.S. is doing too much to aid in resolving global issues, a sentiment that has seen a widening partisan gap since 2013 [5].

Democrats, on the other hand, are more inclined to think the U.S. should assist other nations [4]. Clear partisan divisions emerge when considering whether the U.S.'s international influence will be strengthened because of the crisis, with Republicans being twice as likely as Democrats to believe it will. Conversely, Democrats are about four times more likely than Republicans to anticipate a weakening of American influence [10]. There are also different opinions within the Democratic party, as liberal Democrats are more likely than moderate and conservative Democrats to foresee a decline in U.S. international influence because of the pandemic ![A graph shows the percentages of U.S. adults who think that the US has less influence in the world because of the coronavirus outbreak, broken down by party affiliation and ideology.](image1) [7, 10].

In summary, partisan views diverge significantly, with Republicans favoring a reduced U.S. role in global problem-solving and anticipating stronger international influence post-coronavirus, while Democrats lean towards greater involvement and foresee a potential decline in U.S. influence [5, 10].

Americans generally believe the U.S. can learn from other countries in managing the coronavirus [3, 5]. However, significant partisan divides exist regarding the extent of learning and the U.S.'s broader role [8].  Liberal Democrats are far more inclined to think the U.S. can learn a great deal from other nations, with $67\%$ holding this view compared to only $25\%$ of conservative Republicans [4]. ![The image shows the contrast in opinions, with liberal democrats being more likely to think the U.S. has done a poor job, can learn from other countries, and that the U.S. will have less influence.](image5)

Education also plays a role, as individuals with higher education levels are more likely to believe in learning from other countries [2, 9].

There are sharp partisan differences on views about foreign policy [6]. While $81\%$ of liberal Democrats think the U.S. has done a fair or poor job handling the outbreak, only $22\%$ of conservative Republicans agree [6]. Furthermore, $64\%$ of liberal Democrats believe the U.S. should help other countries, compared to much smaller percentages among Republicans [10].

Partisan views significantly differ, with Democrats more optimistic about learning from other countries and supporting international assistance, while Republicans are less convinced of the need for either.

Americans are divided on whether the U.S. should focus on its own problems or help other countries [2]. Republicans lean towards dealing with domestic issues, while Democrats are more inclined to assist other nations [4, 6].

For example, while about three-quarters of Republicans want the U.S. to deal with its own problems [6], a majority of Democrats believe the U.S. should help other countries [4].

![Views on helping other countries based on political party affiliation](image1)

Views also differ based on education levels, with those having higher education being more supportive of the U.S. helping other countries [9].  Specifically, a majority of those with some college experience and those with no more than a high school diploma say the U.S. should deal with its own problems [9].

In summary, political affiliation and education level are significant factors influencing views on whether the U.S. should prioritize its own problems or help other countries.

Perceptions of the U.S.’s role in solving world problems are significantly divided along political lines [1]. A majority of Republicans (62%) believe the U.S. does too much, while a plurality of Democrats (48%) think the U.S. does too little [3]. This partisan divide is more pronounced today than in previous years [6].  ![The bar chart illustrates varying opinions across demographics regarding whether the U.S. should prioritize its own issues or assist other nations.](image2)

Specifically, 76% of Republicans and those who lean Republican think the U.S. should focus on its own problems, compared to only 23% who believe the U.S. should help other countries [8]. Among Democrats and those who lean Democratic, 53% believe the U.S. should help other countries, while 46% think the U.S. should focus on its own issues [7]. This view is further divided by ideology within the Democratic party, with 64% of liberal Democrats supporting international assistance, compared to 44% of conservative and moderate Democrats [7].

The change over time is also evident, as illustrated in the trends from 2013 to 2020, Republicans increasingly feel the U.S. does "Too much" to solve world problems, with the percentage rising from 52% in 2013 to 62% in 2020 ![The line graph illustrates the shift in Republican opinions from 2013 to 2020, showing increasing belief that the U.S. does too much to solve global issues.](image3). Conversely, Democrats have shifted towards believing the U.S. does "Too little," increasing from 16% in 2013 to 46% in 2020 ![The line graph depicts the changing Democratic opinions from 2013 to 2020, highlighting a growing sentiment that the U.S. does too little to address global issues.](image5).

In summary, political affiliation significantly influences perceptions of the U.S.’s role in solving world problems, with Republicans largely favoring domestic focus and Democrats leaning towards international assistance, and these views have diverged further over time.

There's a notable partisan divide regarding the U.S.'s role in addressing global challenges, with 62% of Republicans believing the U.S. does too much, compared to only 26% of Democrats [1]. This partisan gap has widened since 2013 [1].

![Republicans are more likely to think that the U.S. does too much in helping address global challenges.](image1)

A majority of Republicans (62%) think the U.S. is doing too much to solve world problems, while a plurality of Democrats (48%) believe the U.S. does too little [3]. This divergence extends to how the U.S. has handled the coronavirus outbreak, with most Democrats critical (73%) and most Republicans supportive (71%) [2].

Regarding domestic versus international focus, 60% of Americans believe the U.S. should prioritize its own problems [8].  Specifically, about three-quarters of Republicans advocate for the U.S. to focus internally [10]. While more than half of Democrats think the U.S. should assist other countries, a notable 46% still believe the U.S. should focus on its own issues [5]. A further divide exists within the Democratic party itself, with 64% of liberal Democrats supporting international aid, compared to 44% of conservative and moderate Democrats [5].

![Those with higher education levels are more supportive of helping other nations.](image2)

Education also plays a role, with more educated individuals being more supportive of helping other nations deal with their problems [6]. Six-in-ten postgraduates support international assistance, while college graduates are evenly split [6]. Additionally, more educated Americans are more critical of the U.S.'s handling of the pandemic [9].

In summary, views on U.S. global engagement and domestic issues are significantly shaped by political affiliation and, to some extent, by educational attainment.

Americans have varying degrees of confidence in President Biden's ability to handle China, and this confidence level is notably the lowest when compared to other foreign policy issues [1, 2, 7]. Around half of Americans express confidence in Biden's ability to deal effectively with China (53%) [2]. However, this contrasts with the higher confidence levels for issues like improving relationships with allies (67%) [2].

Certain demographic groups exhibit more confidence than others; for instance, women (59%) are more confident than men (48%), and Black (82%) and Hispanic adults (70%) show greater confidence compared to White adults (43%) [3].  Partisan divisions play a significant role, with 83% of Democrats expressing confidence, compared to only 19% of Republicans [4].
![The image is a bar chart showing the percentage of people who believe in varying degrees of effectiveness (from "Not at all" to "Very") on different foreign policy and global issues](image1).

Furthermore, Americans express considerable concern regarding specific issues in the U.S.-China relationship [10]. Cyber attacks from China are viewed as a very serious problem by 65% of Americans, with an additional 26% considering it somewhat serious, totaling 91% [4]. Similarly, China's growing military power is a major concern, with 52% viewing it as very serious and 34% as somewhat serious, totaling 86% [4, 8]. The loss of U.S. jobs to China and China's policies on human rights are also significant concerns, with 53% and 50% respectively, viewing them as very serious problems [4, 8, 9].

![The image is a bar chart showing survey results on various perceived serious issues related to China.](image4)

In summary, while about half of Americans are confident in Biden's ability to deal with China, significant concerns persist regarding issues such as cyber attacks, military power, human rights, and job losses, indicating a gap between confidence in leadership and the perceived seriousness of the challenges posed by China.

Confidence in President Biden's ability to handle China varies significantly among different demographic groups. Women, Black adults and Hispanic adults express more confidence than men and White adults [10]. Those with a college degree also show more confidence compared to those with less schooling [10]. Partisan divides are substantial, with Democrats showing far greater confidence in Biden on China compared to Republicans [3].

![Confidence levels in Biden's ability to deal with China varies across demographics.](image2)

Older Americans are more likely to view China-related issues as very serious problems compared to younger adults [4].  Areas of significant concern for Americans regarding the U.S.-China relationship include cyber attacks, the loss of U.S. jobs, China’s growing military power, and human rights policies [5].

![Americans express substantial concern about cyberattacks, military power, job losses, and human rights regarding China.](image3)

While around half of Americans are confident in Biden's ability to deal with China, this is the lowest confidence level among six tested foreign policy issues [2, 9]. For instance, more Americans have confidence in Biden to improve relationships with allies [2].

![Americans have varying degrees of belief in the effectiveness of Biden's handling of different foreign policy issues, with dealing with China having the lowest combined "Somewhat" and "Very" effective rating.](image5)

In summary, confidence in Biden's ability to handle China differs across demographics and political affiliations, with primary concerns focusing on cyberattacks, job losses, military power, and human rights.

Confidence in President Biden's ability to handle China differs significantly across demographic and political lines. A notable partisan divide exists, with 83% of Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents expressing confidence, compared to only 19% of Republicans and Republican leaners [4, 8]. Conservative Republicans show even less confidence (10%) than moderate or liberal Republicans (30%) [4]. This partisan split is further visualized in the chart, illustrating the percentage of people with Democratic or Republican leanings who view China as a threat ![The chart compares the perception of threats from various countries between Democrats and Republicans.](image1).

Women (59%) show more confidence than men (48%) in Biden's ability to deal with China [6]. Black (82%) and Hispanic adults (70%) also express more confidence than White adults (43%) [6]. Additionally, those with a college degree expect Biden will be able to deal effectively with China at a higher rate than those with less schooling (60% vs. 50%, respectively) [6]. These confidence levels across different demographic groups are represented in a bar graph, showing levels of confidence among different demographic groups ![This image represents confidence levels across different demographic groups.](image3).

Americans express substantial concern regarding several specific issues in the U.S.-China relationship [5].

Confidence in President Biden to handle China differs significantly along partisan lines [3].  A large majority of Democrats (83\%) express confidence, while only a small fraction of Republicans (19\%) share this view [3]. Conservative Republicans show even less confidence (10\%) compared to moderate or liberal Republicans (30\%) [3].

![The image is a bar graph showing levels of confidence among different demographic groups.](image1)

Looking at specific concerns, cyber attacks from China are a primary worry, with approximately two-thirds of Americans considering them a very serious issue [7].  This concern has increased since 2020 [7].  The loss of U.S. jobs to China is also a major issue for many Americans [8].

![The image is a bar chart showing survey results on various perceived serious issues related to China.](image2)

Older Americans are generally more concerned about China-related issues compared to younger adults [6].  There are partisan differences, with Republicans showing increased concern about issues like job losses to China compared to Democrats [9].  The U.S. trade deficit with China is seen as a very serious problem by about four-in-ten Americans [5].
