![The image is a series of line graphs that depict the percentage of people who consider certain issues related to China as a very serious problem for the U.S., split by political affiliation.](image3)

Confidence in Biden's ability to handle China is strongly divided along partisan lines, with cyber attacks and job losses being major concerns for Americans.

Americans hold critical views regarding China's handling of both the COVID-19 pandemic and its approach to personal freedoms [2, 7]. Specifically, 54% of Americans believe China has done a bad job dealing with the COVID-19 outbreak [7]. A significant 90% of adults in the U.S. think the Chinese government does not respect the personal freedoms of its people [6]. This perception is consistent across different age, education, and political groups [6].

When it comes to U.S. priorities in its relationship with China, Americans prioritize human rights over economic relations. ![Americans think China does not respect personal freedoms of its people.](image1)
As indicated in the graph, 70% of Americans believe the U.S. should promote human rights in China, even if it harms economic relations [image1]. Only 26% think the U.S. should prioritize economic relations, even if it means not addressing human rights issues [image1].

Overall, Americans view China unfavorably regarding both its handling of the pandemic and its respect for personal freedoms, and they prioritize human rights over economic benefits in the U.S.-China relationship.

Americans generally prioritize promoting human rights in China over strengthening economic ties, even if it harms economic relations [3]. Conservative Republicans and liberal Democrats largely share this view [5, 6].

The data shows that 70% of Americans believe the U.S. should prioritize promoting human rights in China, even if it harms economic relations [3]. ![This bar chart indicates that 70% of the respondents believe the U.S. should prioritize promoting human rights in China, even if it harms economic relations.](image4)

Within the Republican party, conservative Republicans are more inclined to prioritize human rights compared to moderate or liberal Republicans [6, 9]. Similarly, liberal Democrats are more likely to emphasize human rights over economic dealings in U.S.-China relations compared to moderate or conservative Democrats [6, 9]. This is further illustrated in the image, which breaks down the opinions within each political affiliation. ![This image shows that 77% of conservative Republicans prioritize human rights, while 66% of moderate/liberal Republicans do so; 76% of liberal Democrats prioritize human rights, while 64% of conservative/moderate Democrats do so.](image3)

Most Americans want the U.S. to get tougher with China on trade, rather than focusing on building stronger relationships [9]. This sentiment is particularly strong among Republicans and those who lean Republican, especially conservative Republicans [9]. While a majority across different political affiliations prioritize human rights, specific approaches to dealing with China on trade and economic policies vary [9].

In general, most Americans prioritize promoting human rights in China over economic relations, with notable differences in emphasis between conservative Republicans and liberal Democrats.

Americans generally prioritize promoting human rights in China over strengthening economic ties, even if it harms economic relations [7]. A significant majority, $70\%$, favor human rights [7].
![Americans favor promoting human rights in China even at the expense of economic ties.](image1)
This preference is held by about seven-in-ten Democrats and Republicans [10]. Notably, conservative Republicans are more inclined to prioritize human rights than moderate or liberal Republicans, and liberal Democrats are the most likely to emphasize human rights over economic dealings [10].

However, when it comes to economic and trade policies, more Americans generally want the U.S. to get tougher with China rather than focus on building a stronger relationship [6].  As shown in the figure, the view of "get tougher" is particularly strong among Republicans and Republican-leaning independents, with $72\%$ favoring this approach [6].
![The bar chart illustrates public opinion on whether to "get tougher" or "build a strong relationship" with China, broken down by demographic categories.](image5)
Specifically, $81\%$ of conservative Republicans advocate for a tougher stance [6]. In contrast, around six-in-ten Democrats and Democrat-leaning independents would rather focus on building stronger ties with China [6]. The prevailing sentiment among Republicans is to get tougher, while Democrats tend to favor building stronger ties [6].

In general, Americans across the political spectrum prioritize human rights in China, but Republicans are more inclined to favor a tougher stance on trade with China, while Democrats prefer to build stronger economic relationships.

Americans hold varied opinions regarding the efficacy of tariff policies, with a larger percentage believing they are ultimately detrimental to the U.S. [5]. A significant $64\%$ of Americans perceive the economic relationship between the U.S. and China as unfavorable [6].

Increased tariffs on Chinese and other foreign products are viewed differently across party lines, with about half of Republicans considering them beneficial for the U.S., a sentiment particularly strong among conservative Republicans [2]. Democrats, conversely, predominantly view these tariffs as detrimental to the U.S. [2]. ![This bar chart illustrates how Republicans and Republican-leaning individuals are more inclined to view increased tariffs on Chinese and other foreign products as beneficial for the U.S., whereas Democrats and Democrat-leaning individuals tend to view them as detrimental.](image5)

Notably, when considering economic and trade policies with China, a greater proportion of Americans favor a tougher stance rather than focusing on building a stronger relationship [1, 8]. This preference is especially pronounced among Republicans and those leaning towards the Republican party, with $72\%$ advocating for a more assertive approach [1].  Conservative Republicans, in particular, show even stronger support for this position, with $81\%$ favoring a tougher stance [1].  Conversely, approximately six-in-ten Democrats and those leaning towards the Democratic party prefer to prioritize building stronger ties with China [1].  Younger individuals, aged 18 to 29, also show a greater inclination towards building a stronger relationship with China compared to their older counterparts [10]. ![The bar chart indicates that most Americans, especially within the Republican party, prefer a tougher stance on trade with China, while Democrats are more inclined to build a stronger relationship.](image3)

These divisions in opinion extend to the perceived impact of current economic relations between the U.S. and China.  A majority of Americans believe that the current economic relations between the U.S. and China are bad [6].

U.S. political affiliations significantly influence perceptions of trade policies with China, impacting their preference for either a tougher stance or building stronger relationships.

There are clear partisan divisions when it comes to views on tariffs and international students [2, 10]. Republicans are more inclined to see tariffs on foreign goods as beneficial for the U.S., while Democrats generally disagree [1].  About half of Republicans believe tariffs are good for the U.S., with this view being especially strong among conservative Republicans [10].  Republicans who identify as moderate or liberal are more divided in their assessment [10]. In contrast, most Democrats consider tariffs to be detrimental to the U.S. [10].

![Republicans are more likely to view tariffs as beneficial for the U.S., while Democrats are more likely to view them as detrimental.](image3)

Regarding international students, the majority of both Republican and Democratic supporters view them positively; however, a larger percentage of Democrats and Democrat-leaning independents $(92\%)$ hold this positive view, compared to Republicans and Republican leaners $(67\%)$ [2].   ![Democrats are more likely than Republicans to view international students as an asset.](image1) Although most Americans generally have a positive view of international students, opinions are more divided when it comes to students specifically from China [8]. A greater percentage of Republicans support limiting the number of Chinese students studying in the U.S [8].  

In summary, Republicans are more likely to support tariffs and limiting Chinese students, while Democrats generally hold the opposite views.

Americans are divided on limiting Chinese students from studying in the U.S. [6]. Generally, 55% of Americans support limiting the number of Chinese students, while 43% oppose such restrictions [6].
![The image is a chart displaying survey results on opinions toward an unspecified topic, categorized by various demographics in the U.S.](image4)
Age plays a significant role, as older Americans are more inclined to support these limitations [3]. Seven-in-ten Americans aged 50 and older favor limiting Chinese students, while younger adults aged 18 to 29 mostly oppose this idea [3].
![The image is a bar chart showing levels of confidence in a certain topic, divided by different demographic groups.](image1)
Older Americans also tend to have less confidence in the Chinese president, Xi Jinping [10]. 53% of those 65 and older express no confidence in Xi, compared to only 35% of those aged 18 to 29 [10]. Republicans are more likely than Democrats to support limiting the ability of Chinese students to study in the U.S [1]. These opinions may reflect concerns about economic competition and global dominance [2].

In summary, support for limiting Chinese students in U.S. universities is higher among older Americans and Republicans, which correlates with a lack of confidence in Chinese leadership.

Since 2018, American perceptions of China have become significantly more negative [5, 8]. This shift is evident in the increased percentage of Americans who feel "cold" toward China, rising from 46% in 2018 to 67% in 2021 [8]. Republicans and Democrats both show this increase in negative sentiment, though the partisan gap has widened [7].

![The graph illustrates increasing negative sentiment and prioritization of limiting China's power among Republicans, Democrats, and the total population from 2018 to 2021.](image2)

Several factors contribute to these changing perceptions. Human rights concerns are frequently cited by Americans when they think about China [10]. A substantial portion of Americans prioritize promoting human rights in China, even if it harms economic relations [1].

![This image shows that a majority of people support promoting human rights in China even if it harms economic relations.](image1)

Specifically, China’s policies on human rights are considered a serious problem by half of American adults, with concerns about the treatment of Uyghurs in Xinjiang [1, 6]. Economic issues also play a significant role, as many Americans view the economic relationship with China as fraught, with concerns over job losses and China's growing technological power [9, 6]. Many Americans think limiting China's power and influence should be a top foreign policy priority [4].

![This bar chart shows the percentage of people who associate certain words or phrases with China; human rights, economy, and political system are the most frequently cited concerns.](image3)

Overall, the shift in American perceptions of China from 2018 to 2021 is marked by increased negativity driven by concerns over human rights, economic issues, and China's growing influence [5, 9, 6].

Americans have several significant concerns regarding China, with many of these issues intensifying over time [3, 10]. When Americans think of China, human rights and the economy are top of mind [2]. There is also a general sense that economic ties between the two countries are problematic, with a substantial number of Americans viewing the relationship as somewhat or very bad [1].

![Americans are concerned about human rights and the economy.](image4)

Several specific issues stand out as major sources of worry. Cyber attacks from China, the loss of U.S. jobs to China, China’s growing military power, and China’s policies on human rights are described as very serious problems by at least half of Americans [9]. ![Americans think China is doing a bad job dealing with global climate change.](image1) Concerns about China’s policy on human rights have risen, with half of Americans now considering it a very serious problem [10]. Moreover, an overwhelming majority of Americans believe that China does not respect the personal freedoms of its people [10]. There are also concerns about China's approach to global issues like climate change [8]. A broad majority thinks China is doing a bad job dealing with global climate change [8].

![Most people have "cold" feelings toward China.](image5)

Over the past few years, certain issues in the U.S.-China relationship, including cyber attacks, job losses, and China’s growing technological power, have increasingly been seen as major problems [10]. These growing concerns also reflect in confidence levels in President Biden's ability to handle China compared to other foreign policy issues [4, 5].

In general, Americans are concerned about various issues related to China, including human rights, economic practices, and cybersecurity, and these concerns have been increasing over the past few years.

Since 2008, most Latino subgroups have grown more optimistic about their finances [1]. In 2015, 23% of Latinos predicted they would fare "a lot" better, marking the largest share since 2004 and a 12 percentage point increase since December 2011 [4]. Eight-in-ten Latinos (81%) expected their family's financial situation to improve in the coming year, a 14 percentage point increase since 2008 [10].

![This bar chart illustrates different demographic groups and their financial optimism, showing the change from an earlier period to a later one.](image1)

Economic optimism among Latinos with some college education grew roughly twice as fast (+20 percentage points) compared to those with a high school diploma (+9) or less education (+11) [2].  Both Latino men (+18 points) and Latina women (+11) are more optimistic than seven years prior [6]. Optimism about future economic prospects has risen faster among Latinos than in the general population [9]. The share of Latinos expecting their family finances to improve is up 14 percentage points, from 67% in 2008 to 81% in 2015, while for all Americans, this optimistic view rose by 6 percentage points to 61% during the same period [9]. This difference is highlighted in the comparison between Hispanics and the general public, showing Hispanics' optimism increasing from 67% to 81% compared to the general public's increase from 56% to 61% from 2008 to 2015 ![The bar chart compares financial expectations between the general population and Hispanics from 2008 to 2015.](image3).

Younger Latinos experienced more significant gains in financial optimism than older Latinos [5, 7]. Nine-in-ten Hispanic adults under 30 expected their financial condition to improve, a 13-point rise, while those 65 years or older saw a 7-point increase [5].

![This segmented bar chart illustrates the expectations of financial improvement based on current financial conditions.](image4)

Overall, financial optimism among Hispanic subgroups has increased significantly from 2008 to 2015, outpacing the general population, with variations based on education and age.

Hispanics generally hold optimistic views regarding their children's financial future [7, 8]. About 72% of Hispanic adults anticipate their children will surpass their own financial achievements ![Most Hispanics expect their children to be better off financially, with slight variations across different demographic subgroups.](image5).

Those who have a positive view of their current financial standing are more inclined to predict financial improvements for their family in the coming year [3]. The expectation of children being better off financially is consistent among those with some college experience (69%) and those with less than a high school education (71%) [5]. Interestingly, high school graduates show even greater optimism, with 79% believing their children will be better off [5].

Older Latinos (ages 65 and older) are more pessimistic (52%) about their children's financial prospects compared to younger Latinos (ages 18 to 29), where 75% hold optimistic expectations [9]. ![This chart shows expectations regarding financial changes based on current financial conditions.](image2)

In summary, Hispanics are largely optimistic about their children's financial future, with optimism influenced by their current financial situation and, to some degree, by their level of education and age.

Latinos have shown increasing optimism about their financial futures, particularly when considering the prospects for their children [3, 5, 8]. Fully 72% of Latinos expect their children to be better off financially than they themselves are now [3].

Since 2011, there has been a notable increase in positive perceptions regarding family finances among Hispanics [2]. The percentage of Latinos expecting their finances to improve rose from 67% in 2011 to 81% in 2015 [2, 7].  This rising optimism among Latinos contrasts with the general public, showcasing a more significant increase in positive financial expectations within the Hispanic community [7]. The attitudes or opinions of Hispanic individuals have remained generally higher and increased to a greater extent than the general public's from 2004 to 2015, whatever topic the graph represents ![The data indicates that Hispanic opinions or attitudes have remained generally higher and increased to a greater extent than the general public's over this time period on whatever topic the graph represents.](image4).

Despite this growing confidence, government data presents a mixed economic scenario [6]. While the Hispanic unemployment rate has declined since the Great Recession, falling from 12.8% in early 2010 to 6.4% in late 2015 and 5.6% in early 2016, it still remains above the 5% low recorded in late 2006 [6]. The graph highlights two recession periods with shaded areas; the unemployment rates for Hispanics are consistently higher than non-Hispanic rates throughout the period from 2000 to 2015 ![The graph shows fluctuations in unemployment rates, with Hispanic rates consistently higher than non-Hispanic rates throughout the period.](image5).

Financial metrics for Hispanic households, including income, poverty rate and wealth are not on par with the overall metrics for U.S. households ![The image visually demonstrates the economic disparity between Hispanic households and the broader U.S. population in terms of income, poverty rate, and wealth.](image1). The poverty rate for Hispanic households is 23.6%, which is significantly higher than the rate for all U.S. households at 14.8%[image1].

In summary, while Latinos express increasing optimism about their financial future and that of their children, unemployment rates, although improving, remain higher than pre-recession levels and higher than those of non-Hispanic workers.

The Hispanic community has experienced a mixed economic trajectory, marked by both progress and persistent disparities. Despite a decline from a high of 12.8% during the Great Recession to 6.4% in late 2015, the Hispanic unemployment rate remains above its 2006 low of 5% [6]. As shown in ![The graph illustrates Hispanic unemployment rates being consistently higher than non-Hispanic rates from 2000-2015.](image5), Hispanic unemployment rates have been consistently higher than non-Hispanic rates [6]. This is further complicated by the fact that median household income for Hispanics has stagnated since the Great Recession, remaining essentially unchanged at $42,491 in 2014 [3].

The economic sentiment among Hispanics, however, presents a more optimistic view. A Pew Research Center survey from December 2015 indicated that 35% of Hispanics believed economic conditions were good or excellent, surpassing the 25% of whites who held the same view [9]. Moreover, 34% of Hispanics anticipated improved economic conditions in the coming year, approximately twice the rate observed among other American groups [9]. This positive outlook is reflected in expectations for future generations, with 72% of Latino adults believing their children will be better off financially [5]. As illustrated in ![The pie chart shows that 72% of people feel their children will be better off.](image3), a significant majority of Latinos expect their children to surpass their own financial well-being [5].

However, this optimism contrasts with the economic realities depicted in ![The graphs compare income, poverty, and wealth between Hispanic and all U.S. households, highlighting significant disparities.](image2), which illustrates the disparities in income, poverty rates, and wealth between Hispanic households and the general U.S. population [3]. These disparities are further compounded when considering personal financial situations within the Hispanic community, where those with higher education levels and U.S. nativity are more likely to report positive financial situations [4]. As shown in ![The graph compares attitudes of Hispanics and the general public from 2004-2015, showing Hispanic opinions generally higher.](image4), Hispanic opinions have generally remained higher and increased more than the general public's over time.

While unemployment rates have improved since the Great Recession, they still remain higher than pre-recession levels and those of non-Hispanic workers [6].

In summary, despite a more optimistic economic outlook among Hispanics, persistent unemployment disparities and stagnant income levels contribute to significant wealth gaps compared to the general U.S. population.

The Hispanic community has experienced a mix of economic progress and ongoing challenges. While unemployment rates have improved since the Great Recession, they remain above pre-recession levels and higher than those for non-Hispanic workers [1]. The unemployment rate for Hispanics was 6.4% in the last quarter of 2015, which is above the 5% low in 2006 ![The image is a line graph showing the quarterly unemployment rates for Hispanic and non-Hispanic groups from 2000 to 2015.](image5).

Median household income for Hispanics has stagnated since the Great Recession, remaining essentially unchanged at $42,491 in 2014 [7].  In comparison, the median income for all U.S. households was $53,700 in 2014 ![The image consists of three line graphs comparing financial metrics for Hispanic households and all U.S. households over time.](image2).

The Hispanic poverty rate, at 23.6% in 2014, is also higher than the rate for all U.S. households, which stood at 14.8% [7, image2]. Additionally, Hispanic households experienced the largest percentage decline in net worth through 2009 among major racial or ethnic groups, and unlike white households, their net worth continued to fall after the recession [7]. In 2013, the median wealth for Hispanic households was $13,700, significantly lower than the $81,400 for all U.S. households [image2].

Despite these challenges, Latinos have become more optimistic about their personal finances and future since the Great Recession [2, 3]. Their views on their financial situations are more positive now than in 2004, while the general public's view is lower [9].  Additionally, Hispanics are more upbeat about national economic conditions compared to other groups [10].

The Hispanic community faces greater economic challenges than all U.S. households in terms of income, poverty rate and wealth, but they maintain a positive outlook on their financial well-being.

Between 2008 and 2015, Latino perceptions of their economic well-being generally increased [1, 7, 8]. Specifically, there were improvements in personal finance ratings among most Latino demographic subgroups [7, 8, 10]. For example, about half (48%) of Latinos ages 18 to 29 reported being in excellent or good financial shape in 2015, which is a 27 percentage point increase from 2008 [6].

Notably, Latino views of their financial situation are more positive than they were in 2004 [9]. ![The line graph illustrates that the percentage of favorable opinions among Hispanics increased from 76% in 2004 to 81% in 2015, while the general public's favorable opinions increased from 70% to 61% during the same period.](image4)

However, in 2015, about half (53%) of Latinos still felt that their family income was not keeping up with the cost of living [3].  ![The bar chart indicates that in 2015, 53% of Hispanic adults felt their income was falling behind the cost of living, compared to 49% of White adults and 51% of Black adults.](image1) This perception remained relatively unchanged between 2014 and 2015 [4].

Overall, between 2008 and 2015, Latino groups experienced improved perceptions of their personal financial situations, even though many still felt their income was not keeping pace with the cost of living.

Internet usage and device ownership among seniors differ significantly from the general adult population.  While a substantial portion of seniors do not engage with the internet [1], those who do often make it a regular part of their lives [4, 8]. ![Internet usage decreases with age, broadband access also declines with age](image2) As age increases, both internet usage and broadband adoption decrease [5, 6].  For instance, smartphone ownership declines significantly in the older age brackets [2], and device ownership among older adults differs from the population as a whole [10].  

Compared to all adults, seniors have lower adoption rates for cell phones, internet, and broadband [5].  Specifically, only 18% of those aged 65 and over own a smartphone, compared to 55% of all adults [3].  Additionally, while 86% of all adults use the internet, only 59% of adults 65+ do so [5]. ![Smartphone and tablet ownership is lower among seniors compared to all adults](image3)

However, among seniors who do use the internet, a large percentage incorporate it into their daily routine [8].  A significant 71% of older adults who use the internet go online every day or almost every day, and an additional 11% go online three to five times per week [4]. ![Older internet users go online frequently](image1) This indicates that while initial adoption rates may be lower, those seniors who embrace the internet tend to use it frequently [8]. 

Internet usage and device ownership are lower among seniors compared to all adults, but those seniors who do use the internet tend to make it a regular part of their daily routine.

Older adults exhibit unique patterns in device ownership compared to the general population [2, 9]. While smartphone ownership is lower among older adults, tablets and e-readers are just as popular [7]. For all adults, 55% own a smartphone and 43% own a tablet or e-reader, whereas for those aged 65 and over, 18% own a smartphone and 27% own a tablet or e-reader, showing older adults owning more tablets or e-readers than smartphones `![Older adults own more tablets/e-readers than smartphones](image4)`.

Despite lower overall internet usage compared to younger demographics, a significant portion of seniors who do use the internet make it a regular habit [3, 10].  Among older adults who use the internet, 71% go online every day or almost every day, and an additional 11% go online three to five times per week [10]. This suggests that while adoption rates may be lower, engaged older adults are frequently online, although internet usage and broadband availability decrease with age `![Internet usage and broadband availability decrease with age](image5)`. Even though only 27% of all Americans ages 65 and older are social networking site users [1],  seniors who are online tend to integrate it into their daily routines [8].

Device ownership among older adults reveals a preference for tablets and e-readers over smartphones, and those who are online tend to engage frequently.

Device ownership varies considerably between older adults and the general population, with seniors lagging in smartphone adoption but showing reasonable adoption of tablets or e-readers [7, 1, 5].  While only $18\%$ of seniors are smartphone adopters, far below the national rate of $55\%$, $27\%$ own either a tablet, an e-reader, or both [1, 5].
![The graph compares device ownership between all adults and seniors, showing seniors lag in smartphone adoption but have reasonable tablet/e-reader ownership.](image3)
Looking at internet adoption over time, seniors have increased their internet usage from $35\%$ in 2008 to $59\%$ currently [4]. This is still substantially lower than the $86\%$ of all U.S. adults who go online [4]. The rate of seniors using the internet has increased over time, but still trails behind the general adult population.
![The graph illustrates the increase in internet adoption among seniors and all adults from 2000 to 2013, showing a significant, but lagging, increase for seniors.](image4)
Furthermore, $46\%$ of online seniors use social networking sites, which accounts for $27\%$ of the total older adult population [10]. Internet and broadband adoption rates among seniors are influenced by factors such as age, education, and income, with those 80 years or older, having lower incomes, or lacking college education being less connected [3].
![This table presents data on internet and broadband usage among seniors, broken down by age, education, and income levels.](image1)
In summary, seniors have lower rates of smartphone adoption compared to the general adult population, but internet usage among seniors has been growing, although it still lags behind the general population.

Seniors' device ownership and social networking habits reveal interesting patterns. While internet adoption is increasing among seniors [1, 2], their usage rates still lag behind the general population ![The line graph illustrates the increase in internet usage among all adults and seniors from 2000 to 2013.](image4). Only a portion of online seniors, about 27% of the total older adult population, engage with social networking sites [4]. This indicates that while more seniors are getting online, social networking is not universally adopted.

Interestingly, seniors show a preference for tablets and e-readers over smartphones [9, 10], with 27% owning a tablet or e-reader compared to 18% owning a smartphone ![The bar chart compares smartphone and tablet/e-reader ownership between all adults and seniors.](image1). Despite only 27% of older adults using social networking sites, those who do tend to socialize more frequently [7]. As shown in the pie chart, 27% of seniors use SNS, while 32% go online but do not use SNS, and 41% do not go online at all ![The pie chart breaks down online usage among seniors into those who use social networking, those who go online without social networking, and those who do not go online.](image2). This suggests that device preference does not directly translate to social networking usage.

Device ownership among seniors, particularly tablets and e-readers, doesn't necessarily correlate directly with their social networking usage, as a significant portion of online seniors do not engage in social networking.

Internet and broadband adoption rates among seniors are steadily increasing but still lag behind the national average [5]. In 2013, 59% of seniors reported using the internet, a notable increase from 35% in 2008, yet still lower than the 86% of all U.S. adults who go online [2]. This divide is further influenced by age, education, and income, with younger, higher-income, and more educated seniors showing adoption rates closer to the general population [3, 7, 8].

For instance, internet use and broadband adoption significantly decrease around age 75 [3].  ![The table shows percentages of older adults online and with broadband, broken down by age, education, and income.](image5) Seniors aged 65-69 have higher adoption rates compared to those 80 and older; 74% of those aged 65-69 go online, while only 37% of those 80+ do so [image5]. Similarly, broadband adoption is at 65% for the 65-69 age group but drops to 21% for those 80 and older [image5]. Education plays a crucial role, with 87% of senior college graduates going online compared to only 40% of those with a high school diploma or less [image5]. Income also correlates strongly with adoption rates; 90% of seniors with a household income of $75,000 or more use the internet, while only 39% of those with incomes less than $30,000 do so [image5]. Affluent and well-educated seniors adopt the internet and broadband at substantially higher rates [1].

These factors create a digital divide within the senior population, where older, less educated, and lower-income individuals are much less likely to be online [10].

Internet and broadband adoption rates among older adults vary significantly based on age, education, and income, generally trailing behind the adoption rates of the general adult population.

Seniors' adoption of technology varies significantly based on income and education.  For instance, among seniors with an annual household income of $75,000 or more, $90\%$ go online and $82\%$ have broadband at home, whereas only $39\%$ of seniors earning less than $30,000 annually go online, and $25\%$ have broadband [9]. This divide is further illustrated in the image, which shows that for seniors earning less than $30,000, only 39% go online and 25% have broadband, compared to 90% and 82% respectively for those earning $75,000 or more. ![This image shows the percentage of people aged 65 and older who go online and have broadband at home, categorized by age, education, and household income.](image3)

  Similarly, education plays a crucial role: $87\%$ of seniors with a college degree go online, and $76\%$ are broadband adopters, compared to just $40\%$ of seniors who have not attended college going online, and only $27\%$ having broadband [7, 9]. As depicted in the image, the adoption rates for cell phones and smartphones also reflect these disparities, with higher adoption rates among seniors with more education and higher incomes. ![The table shows the percentage of people aged 65 and older who own cell phones and smartphones, broken down by age, education, and household income.](image5)  The adoption of smartphones among seniors also reflects these disparities, with only 8% of seniors with income less than $30,000 adopting smartphones, compared to 42% of those with income of $75,000 or more [5].

Internet, broadband, cell phone, and smartphone adoption rates among seniors are notably higher with increased income and education levels.

Internet and broadband adoption among seniors is significantly influenced by income and education [1, 3]. Seniors with higher education levels and incomes are more likely to adopt the internet and broadband [1]. For instance,  seniors who have graduated from college are around three times as likely to own both an e-book reader and a tablet as are seniors who have not attended college ![E-reader and tablet usage among seniors is correlated with education and income levels.](image1).

This trend extends to smartphone ownership, where adoption rates are lower among older adults but vary considerably by income and education [5]. Just 18% of seniors are smartphone adopters, which is well below the national adoption rate [10].  However,  smartphone ownership is fairly low along the entire age spectrum of the older adult population, but decreases substantially for seniors in their mid-70s (  $\mathbf{\dot{\lambda}_{10}\%}$   of 75-79 year  olds own a smartphone), and  becomes nearly non-existent  among seniors in their 80s and  beyond (just  $5\%$   of those 80  and older are smartphone  owners) [8].

Compared to the general population, older adults, even with similar income levels, often have lower smartphone adoption rates [6].   Nationally, tablets and e-book  readers are  most popular  among college graduates and  higher-income Americans , and  this is also true among seniors [7]. Seniors who have graduated  from college are around three  times as likely to own both an e- book reader and a tablet as are  seniors who have not attended  college, and those with an  annual household income of   $\S75{,}000$   or more per year are  around four times as likely to  own each device as are those  with a household income of less  than  $\S30,\mathbf{ooo}$   per year [7]. While cell phone ownership is common among seniors, smartphone adoption lags, particularly among those with lower income and education levels, and older age groups [4].
Internet and smartphone adoption rates among older adults are strongly influenced by income and education, with lower rates observed among those with lower income and education levels compared to their more affluent and educated peers and the general population.

Internet and broadband adoption rates among seniors are significantly influenced by their level of education [7]. Seniors who are college graduates exhibit higher rates of both internet usage and broadband adoption ![College-educated seniors have the highest rates of going online and broadband adoption.](image2). Conversely, seniors with a high school education or less tend to be less connected [4]. For instance, a substantial 87% of college graduates aged 65+ use the internet, with 76% having broadband at home, while only 40% of seniors with a high school diploma or less use the internet, and just 27% have broadband [See image2].

Similarly, smartphone ownership is also strongly correlated with educational attainment among older adults ![Seniors with a college degree are more likely to own smartphones.](image5). As the data indicates, smartphone adoption increases with higher levels of education, highlighting a digital divide within the senior population [7]. A notable 35% of seniors who are college graduates own smartphones, compared to only 10% of those with a high school education or less [See image5].

In summary, internet usage and smartphone ownership among seniors are positively correlated with higher educational attainment.

Seniors' technology adoption varies significantly depending on education and income. For internet and broadband, there's a clear disparity as indicated by the statistics: 90% of seniors with an income of $75,000 or more go online, while only 39% of those earning less than $30,000 do so [3]. Similarly, 82% of higher-income seniors have broadband at home, compared to just 25% of lower-income seniors [3]. Seniors with a college degree show much higher adoption rates, with 87% going online and 76% having broadband, while those without a college education have adoption rates of 40% and 27% respectively [1, 3].  ![The table illustrates that internet and broadband adoption among seniors is strongly correlated with education and income.](image3)

Cell phone ownership is more widespread among seniors. Overall, 77% of seniors own cell phones, but smartphone adoption lags significantly behind at just 18% [7, 9]. As shown in the table, even among the most affluent seniors (those with an annual income of $75,000 or more), smartphone ownership is at 42% [10]. This is still lower than the smartphone adoption rate among high-income adults in the general population [2]. Additionally, seniors with a college degree are more likely to own smartphones (35%) compared to those with a high school diploma or less (10%) [2].  ![The table breaks down cell phone and smartphone ownership among seniors based on age, education, and income, highlighting disparities across these demographics.](image2)

In summary, while cell phone ownership is common across various demographics of seniors, internet, broadband, and smartphone adoption are significantly influenced by education and income levels.

Seniors with higher educational attainment and income levels are more likely to adopt broadband at home [7, 10].  Specifically, 76% of seniors with a college degree are broadband adopters, whereas only 27% of seniors who have not attended college have broadband at home [2, 10].

![Seniors with higher education levels are more likely to go online and have broadband at home.](image2)

The disparity is also evident when comparing income levels. A significant 82% of seniors with an annual household income of $75,000 or more have broadband at home, compared to just 25% of those earning less than $30,000 annually [10]. These figures highlight a digital divide among seniors based on socioeconomic factors.

Broadband adoption at home among seniors is significantly influenced by both their educational attainment and household income.

Seniors who have graduated from college are around three times as likely to own both an e-book reader and a tablet as are seniors who have not attended college [4]. Tablet and e-book reader adoption among seniors is significantly influenced by education level, as seen in the data where 30% of college graduates aged 65+ use e-book readers and 31% use tablets, compared to only 12% and 11%, respectively, among those with a high school education or less ![College graduates are more likely to use e-readers and tablets among the 65+ age group.](image3).

Furthermore, the trend of technology adoption over time varies across different age groups, with the 65+ group showing the lowest initial usage but a consistent increase from 2006 to 2013 ![Technology usage among different age groups increased from 2006 to 2013.](image4). This demonstrates that while education plays a significant role in the adoption of tablets and e-readers among seniors, overall technology adoption is increasing across all age groups, albeit at different rates.

In summary, higher education levels correlate with increased adoption of tablets and e-book readers among seniors, and technology adoption trends show increasing usage across all age groups over time.

Educational attainment significantly shapes how individuals perceive the impact of technology on their careers [6]. Workers with higher levels of education are more likely to view technology as a positive force, enhancing their work and offering career advancement [6]. For instance, college graduates are more inclined to say technology has made their work more interesting (64% vs. 38%) and increased their career opportunities (53% vs. 32%) compared to those with only a high school diploma or less [10].

![Individuals with higher education levels are more likely to feel that their education made their work more interesting and increased their opportunities for advancement](image1)

Conversely, those without a college education are less likely to see technology in such a positive light [6].  Only 38% of workers with a high school diploma or less feel that technology has made their jobs more interesting, and just 32% believe it has increased their career advancement opportunities [7]. This disparity highlights how the benefits of technology often accrue more to those with higher education levels [1].

![Workers express mixed opinions on how today’s technologies have impacted their own jobs and careers](image8)

Looking ahead, the public anticipates widespread advances in automation technologies, with driverless vehicles being a prime example [2, 3].  A significant majority (66%) believes that most vehicles will be driverless within the next half-century, with some (9%) predicting this will happen within the next 10 years [2].

![The image shows the public's predictions for when driverless cars will be common, ranging from less than 10 years to never.](image2)

Educational attainment greatly influences perceptions of workforce technologies, and the public widely anticipates the development and adoption of driverless car technology in the coming decades.

Workers with different education levels hold different views on how workplace technology impacts their careers [8]. Those with at least a four-year college degree have significantly more positive views compared to those with high school diplomas or less [4, 10]. For instance, there is a 45-percentage point difference in the share of workers with college degrees (90\%) and those with high school diplomas or less (45\%) who feel office productivity tools have positively impacted them professionally [4].

![College graduates generally view technology's impact on their careers more favorably than those with less education](image1)

Conversely, nearly one-quarter (24\%) of workers with high school diplomas or less state that none of the six technologies measured in the survey has positively impacted their jobs or careers, compared to just 2\% of college graduates [4]. Many Americans anticipate the increasing adoption of automation technologies [1]. A large majority ($94\%$) are aware of driverless vehicle development, and roughly two-thirds expect most vehicles to be driverless within the next half-century [1].

In summary, college-educated workers generally have a more positive perception of technology's impact on their careers compared to those with less education, while a significant portion of Americans foresee the widespread adoption of driverless cars in the coming decades.

Many Americans expect automation technologies to advance significantly in the coming decades, with driverless vehicles being a prime example [6]. Fully 94% of Americans are aware of driverless vehicle development, and about two-thirds expect most vehicles to be driverless within 50 years [6].

However, when it comes to current experiences with technology in the workplace, views are mixed [1, 2]. A substantial share of workers indicate that technologies such as word processing or spreadsheet software (70%), smartphones (67%), and email or social media (60%) have had a positive impact on their own careers [4].
![Workers perceive word processing, smartphones, and email as having a largely positive impact.](image1)
Yet, the benefits of these tools are most likely to accrue to workers with high levels of formal educational attainment [1, 8]. Moreover, workforce automation has already impacted a minority of today’s workers in the form of lost jobs or wages, leading some to view technology negatively [1]. While some workers find that technology has made their work more interesting (53%), others feel it has made their work less interesting (12%), or had no major impact (34%) [7].
![Many workers feel that technology has made their work more interesting.](image5)

In summary, while there's broad anticipation and awareness of future automation like driverless vehicles, current experiences with workforce technologies are viewed with mixed opinions, varying based on education and the specific technology in question.

Workers' perceptions of workplace technologies are significantly influenced by their level of education [7]. Generally, workers express more positive views than negative ones regarding the impact of technology on their careers [5]. About half of workers (53%) find that technology has made their work more interesting ![The image shows that 53% of workers feel that technology has made their work more interesting, while 12% feel it has made their work less interesting, and 34% feel it has had no impact either way.](image2). A significant difference emerges when comparing college graduates to those with high school diplomas or less. For instance, a notable gap exists in how these groups perceive the impact of office productivity tools; 90% of college graduates view word processing and spreadsheet software as having a positive impact, compared to only 45% of those with a high school diploma or less ![The image shows that college graduates are more likely to view technologies such as word processing software, smartphones and email positively, compared to those with less education.](image4).

Workers with higher education levels are more inclined to believe that technology has increased their career opportunities and made their jobs more interesting [3]. Specifically, 64% of college graduates find that technology has made their work more interesting, compared to only 38% of those with a high school diploma or less ![The bar chart illustrates how education level affects perceptions of work factors, showing that college graduates are more likely to find their work more interesting and see increased opportunities for advancement due to technology.](image3). Similarly, 53% of college graduates believe technology has increased their opportunities for career advancement, whereas only 32% of those with a high school diploma or less share this view [2].  The middle educational tier–those with some college but no four-year degree–tend to have attitudes midway between these two groups [4]. In general, 46% of workers feel that technology has increased their opportunities for career advancement ![The image shows that 46% of respondents believe technology has increased their career opportunities, 13% believe it has decreased them, and 40% believe it has had no impact.](image1).

In summary, higher education levels correlate with more positive perceptions of workplace technologies and their impact on job interest and career advancement.

Workers' views on technology's impact vary significantly based on education [3]. College graduates are more likely to see technology as a positive force, making their work more interesting and increasing career opportunities [6, 7, 8].  ![The image is a bar chart showing the effects on opportunities.](image2) This contrasts with those with high school diplomas or less, who are less likely to perceive technology positively [6].

College graduates are substantially more likely to report that technology has made their work more interesting (64% vs. 38%) and increased their opportunities for career advancement (53% vs. 32%) [1].  ![This image is a bar chart comparing the effects of education level on work factors.](image5) This difference highlights how technology's benefits are not uniformly experienced across different education levels [2]. A substantial portion (24%) of workers with high school diplomas or less believe that none of the six measured technologies have positively impacted their jobs, compared to only 2% of college graduates [5, 9].

Educational attainment significantly influences the perceived impact of technology on making work more interesting and increasing opportunities for advancement, with college graduates reporting a more positive influence than those with lower levels of education.

Workers' views on how technology impacts their careers vary significantly depending on their education level [5].  Those with higher education tend to view technology more positively [6]. College graduates are more likely to report that technology has made their work more interesting and has increased their opportunities for career advancement [9].  ![College graduates are more likely to find their work more interesting due to technology](image3) Specifically, 64% of college graduates find that technology has made their work more interesting, compared to only 38% of those with a high school diploma or less [9]. Similarly, 53% of college graduates believe technology has increased their career advancement opportunities, whereas only 32% of those with a high school diploma or less share this view [9].

![The bar chart illustrates the perceived impact of various technologies on different educational groups, indicating that higher education levels correlate with more positive views.](image1) The differences in perception are most pronounced with office productivity tools, such as word processing and spreadsheet software [10]. A substantial 90% of college graduates feel these technologies have positively impacted them professionally, compared to only 45% of workers with a high school diploma or less [10]. Many non-college educated workers feel that these technologies have not impacted their careers in any meaningful way [7]. For example, 44% of workers with a high school degree or less say that word processing or spreadsheet software has not impacted their professional lives, and 35% say the same about email or social media [7].

In summary, higher levels of education correlate with more positive perceptions of technology's impact on job opportunities and work interest.

Americans familiar with the concept of machines doing human jobs express both enthusiasm and worry [6]. Those with higher awareness are more likely to find the concept realistic and express enthusiasm, but they still have substantial concerns [6].  For example, among those who have heard a lot about the concept, 48% think it seems extremely realistic, while only 14% of those who have heard a little and 4% of those who have heard nothing share this view [7].  Moreover, 47% of those with high awareness express enthusiasm, compared to 30% and 18% among those with lower levels of familiarity [7].

Despite the enthusiasm, worry remains significant across all awareness levels [3]. ![The image shows a survey about enthusiasm and worry, revealing a mix of feelings with worry being more prominent.](image1) Roughly three-quarters of Americans who have heard a lot about this concept (76%) express some level of worry, which is comparable to those who have heard a little (72%) and those who have not heard anything (69%) [9]. This suggests that increased awareness does not necessarily alleviate concerns about machines taking over human jobs.

When considering the outcomes of widespread automation, Americans generally expect more negative than positive results [5]. A large majority (76%) anticipates increased inequality between the rich and poor [8, 10], and 64% expect people to struggle to find purpose in their lives [10]. ![The image shows survey results, indicating widespread concern about increased inequality.](image4) Only a small percentage (25%) believe that the economy will create many new, well-paying jobs for humans [1, 8].

Despite these concerns, Americans strongly favor policies that limit robots and computers to jobs that are dangerous or unhealthy for humans, with 85% in favor [2].  This indicates a desire to harness the benefits of automation while mitigating potential negative impacts on human workers. ![The image shows the public favoring policies that limit machines to dangerous jobs.](image2)

In summary, while increased awareness of automation leads to greater enthusiasm and a sense of realism, it does not diminish concerns about potential negative outcomes like increased inequality and job displacement; most Americans expect negative outcomes from machines taking over human jobs.

Democrats generally show more support than Republicans for a universal basic income and a national service program if machines significantly displace human workers [2, 5, 9]. ![The image illustrates the percentage of Democrats and Republicans who support various policies, with Democrats generally showing more support for guaranteed basic income and national service programs.](image3) However, limiting machines to dangerous or unhealthy jobs receives strong support across party lines [9]. Specifically, 77% of Democrats favor a universal basic income, compared to only 38% of Republicans [2].  Similarly, 66% of Democrats support a national service program, while only 46% of Republicans do [2].  Despite these differences, both Democrats (60%) and Republicans (54%) largely agree there should be limits on how many jobs businesses can replace with machines [4, 9].  ![The image illustrates the percentage of Democrats and Republicans who support imposing limits on the number of jobs businesses can replace with machines.](image4)

A significant majority of Americans, regardless of political affiliation, support limiting robots and computers to jobs that are dangerous or unhealthy [9].  Notably, 85% of Americans favor this policy, with 47% strongly in favor [6]. ![The image shows that the majority of survey respondents favor limiting machines to dangerous or unhealthy jobs.](image5) This indicates a strong consensus on prioritizing human safety and well-being in the context of automation [6].

In general, there is strong bipartisan support for limiting machines to dangerous or unhealthy jobs, but Democrats are more inclined to support broader government interventions like universal basic income and national service programs compared to Republicans.

Partisan affiliation significantly impacts views on government obligations to assist workers displaced by automation [1, 3]. Democrats are more inclined to believe the government should provide support, even if it necessitates higher taxes, while Republicans generally believe individuals should be responsible for their own financial well-being, regardless of automation's impact [3]. ![Democrats are more inclined to believe the government should provide support, even if it necessitates higher taxes.](image4)

Educational attainment also plays a role, particularly regarding limits on job automation [2, 10]. Those with lower educational attainment are more supportive of limiting the number of jobs businesses can replace with machines [10]. ![Those with lower educational attainment are more supportive of limiting the number of jobs businesses can replace with machines.](image4) While opinions diverge on government intervention, there's more alignment between Republicans and Democrats regarding the need to limit the number of human jobs that can be replaced by machines [7].

In summary, political affiliation strongly influences views on government responsibility for displaced workers, while educational attainment impacts opinions on limiting job automation.

Political affiliation significantly shapes American views on policies concerning workforce automation and job displacement [1]. Democrats are more inclined to support a universal basic income and a national service program compared to Republicans if machines replace human jobs [1, 2, 10]. ![Democrats are more in favor of guaranteed basic income, national service program, while both parties agree on limiting machines to dangerous or unhealthy jobs](image4).

Notably, there is a substantial difference in the perception of the government's role in supporting workers displaced by automation, with 65% of Democrats believing the government should provide support, even if it means higher taxes, while 68% of Republicans think individuals should be responsible for their own financial well-being [4]. ![A larger percentage of Democrats believes the government has an obligation to take care of displaced workers, while more Republicans think individuals should be responsible.](image3). Despite these divisions, there is more alignment between parties on limiting the number of human jobs that businesses can replace with machines [6, 10].

In summary, political affiliation strongly influences American opinions on policies addressing workforce automation and job displacement, particularly regarding government intervention and support for displaced workers.

Workers express mixed views on technology's impact, with benefits often favoring those with higher education [1]. A small percentage of Americans have already experienced job or wage losses due to automation [2].  ![The bar chart illustrates the percentages of U.S. adults across different age groups who have experienced job loss or reduced pay/hours due to automation](image3). Younger adults (18-24), Latinos, part-time workers, and those with lower incomes are more likely to be affected by workforce automation [2].

Workers with more education generally hold more positive views of workplace technologies [3].  ![This chart shows that workers with higher education levels are more likely to report that technology has made their work more interesting and increased their opportunities for advancement](image4). Those lacking a college education are less likely to view technology positively [5]. Educational differences significantly influence perceptions of technology's impact on careers [8]. College graduates are more likely to find their work made more interesting and have increased career opportunities due to technology [8]. In contrast, only 38% of workers with a high school diploma or less find their jobs more interesting because of technology [10].

Overall, attitudes toward workforce automation and the perceived impact of technology vary significantly based on age and education level.

Workers generally have mixed feelings regarding how technology has affected their jobs [3, 8]. Some view technology positively, while others see it as damaging to their career prospects [4]. ![Most people think word processing or spreadsheet software has a positive impact on their jobs.](image5)

Notably, education level seems to be a significant factor in these differing perceptions [1, 5, 6]. College graduates are more likely to express that technology has made their work more interesting and has increased opportunities for career advancement [1, 5]. As an example, 64% of college graduates say that technology has made their work more interesting, compared to only 38% of workers with a high school diploma or less [1]. Also, 53% of college graduates say technology increased career advancement opportunities compared to 32% of those with a high school diploma or less [1]. ![College graduates are more likely to find that technology has made work more interesting and increased opportunities for advancement.](image4)

Conversely, individuals without a college education are less likely to view technology as a positive influence [2, 6]. Just 38% of workers with a high school diploma or less say technology has made their jobs more interesting [9], and only 32% feel that it has increased their opportunities for career advancement [9].

Perceptions of workforce automation and technology's impact differ significantly across demographics and education levels, with those having higher education generally viewing technology more positively.

Workers hold diverse opinions regarding the influence of technology on their jobs and careers [9]. Overall, they express more positive views than negative ones concerning technology's impact [10].

![Workers generally feel that technology has made their work more interesting.](image1)

Roughly half of workers (53%) feel technology has made their work more interesting, while a smaller percentage (12%) find it has made their work less interesting [2]. Similarly, a plurality of workers (46%) believe technology has increased their opportunities for career advancement, whereas 13% feel it has decreased them [2]. However, these benefits are more likely to be seen by workers with higher education levels [1, 3, 6]. For instance, only 38% of workers with a high school diploma or less say technology has made their jobs more interesting, and just 32% feel it has increased career advancement opportunities [7]. Workers without a college education are much less likely to have positive attitudes toward current technologies [8]. Technologies like word processing, spreadsheet software, and smartphones have had a positive impact on many careers [9].

In conclusion, higher education levels correlate with a more positive perception of technology's impact on job interest and career advancement, while specific technologies like word processing also play a role in shaping these perceptions.

Social media content evokes a range of emotions, with amusement being the most common [7]. A large portion of users, 88%, report encountering content that makes them feel amused, with 44% frequently experiencing this emotion [7].

However, the frequency of experiencing specific emotions varies across age groups.  Younger adults (18-29) are more likely to encounter content that makes them feel amused (54%) compared to older adults (65+) (30%) [1].  Conversely, older adults encounter amusing and anger-inducing content with similar frequency: 30% and 24% respectively [1, 5].

![The chart depicts how different age groups react emotionally, particularly highlighting that younger people (18-29) tend to report stronger emotions across all categories compared to older age groups.](image2)

Interestingly, younger users are also more likely to experience loneliness and depression from social media content [9]. 15% of users aged 18-29 report frequently feeling lonely, compared to only 4% of those 50 and older [5].

![The image is a bar chart showing the frequency of different emotions experienced.](image3)

In addition to amusement, many users frequently encounter overly dramatic or exaggerated posts (58%) and posts where people make accusations without knowing all the facts (59%) [2].  Despite negative encounters, a comparable share of users frequently encounter content that makes them feel angry (25%) and content that inspires them (21%) [6].

Different age groups react with varying emotional intensities to social media content, with amusement being the most frequently experienced emotion across all users.

Social media users across different age groups report experiencing a range of emotions, with anger being a common one [1]. However, younger adults (18-29) are more likely to encounter content that makes them feel lonely compared to older adults [1].
![The image is a horizontal dot plot displaying survey data about the emotional responses of different age groups to humorous or amusing content.](image1)
Younger social media users also report feeling amused more often, but also experience loneliness and depression [3]. In fact, younger adults are twice as likely to encounter amusing content than content that makes them angry [7].
![The image is a bar chart showing the frequency of different emotions experienced.](image2)
Older adults (65+) encounter amusing and angry content with similar frequency [1, 7]. Social media users frequently encounter overly dramatic or exaggerated posts and people making accusations without all the facts [5].
![The image is a bar chart that displays how frequently certain types of posts occur, based on survey responses.](image4)
Different age groups on social media experience varying emotional responses and are frequently exposed to dramatic content and argumentative posts.

Social media users across different age groups report varying emotional responses [7].  Younger adults (18-29) are more likely to feel lonely, with 15% reporting frequent loneliness compared to older adults [7]. Conversely, older adults are less frequently amused, with similar shares feeling amused (30%) and angry (24%) ![The chart depicts how different age groups react emotionally, particularly highlighting that younger people (18-29) tend to report stronger emotions across all categories compared to older age groups.](image2).

Regarding gender, men are more likely than women to perceive mean or bullying content (29% vs 19%) and deceptive behavior (24% vs 13%) on social media platforms ![The data suggests differences in perceptions between men and women regarding these online behaviors.](image4). However, most men (52%) and women (56%) report seeing an equal mix of supportive and bullying behavior [2].

Frequently encountered content includes overly dramatic or exaggerated posts (58%) and people making accusations without all the facts (59%) [4, 8]. The "anger" emoticon is now the most common reaction to posts by members of Congress [1].  Majorities of social media users frequently see people engaging in drama and exaggeration, jumping into arguments without having all the facts [8].

Different age groups and genders vary in their emotional responses and perceptions of behavior on social media, with frequent exposure to dramatic content and arguments.

Social media users encounter a mix of positive and negative behaviors [8]. Overall, 54% see an equal mix of kindness/support and meanness/bullying, but there are differences between men and women: 29% of men report seeing more meanness/bullying compared to 19% of women [10]. Conversely, 24% of women see more kindness/support, while only 17% of men do [10]. However, most men (52%) and women (56%) still report an equal mix ![The data suggests differences in perceptions between men and women regarding these online behaviors](image3).

Age also plays a role in the emotions experienced on social media.  Younger users (18-29) report feeling amused more often (54%) compared to older users (65+) (30%) [5].  Similarly, younger users report feeling angry, connected, inspired, depressed, and lonely more frequently than older users ![Younger people (18-29) tend to report stronger emotions across all categories compared to older age groups](image4).

Certain types of posts are very common. A large percentage of users frequently see posts that are overly dramatic or exaggerated (58%) and posts where people make accusations without all the facts (59%) [9]. Many also at least sometimes encounter posts that seem to be about one thing but are actually about something else [6]. The majority of users frequently see dramatic/exaggerated posts and those making accusations without all the facts ![The majority of users frequently see dramatic/exaggerated posts and those making accusations without all the facts](image5).

In summary, social media experiences vary by age and gender, with younger users reporting more frequent and intense emotions, and men and women differing in their perceptions of supportive versus bullying behavior; exaggerated or argumentative posts are commonly encountered.

Men and women perceive online behaviors differently, with men being more likely to see bullying and deception, as shown in the survey data ![The image shows the percentage of each gender who see certain behaviors](image1). Specifically, 29% of men reported more often seeing people being mean or bullying compared to 19% of women [10]. Additionally, 24% of men indicated they more often see deceptive behavior, while only 13% of women shared this perception [5]. However, majorities of both men (58%) and women (67%) see an equal mix of deceptiveness and attempts to correct misinformation [5].

Social media users frequently encounter drama and exaggeration [7], with 58% of users reporting they frequently see posts that are overly dramatic or exaggerated, and 59% frequently see people making accusations without having all the facts ![The image shows percentage of users seeing certain types of content frequently](image4) [3]. This exposure to exaggerated content and argumentative behavior is a common experience for social media users [3].

These perceptions of online behavior align with the types of content users frequently encounter, such as overly dramatic posts and arguments [3]. The vast quantities of data that social media companies possess allows these platforms to deliver individually targeted content in an automated fashion [2].

Men are more likely than women to perceive bullying and deception on social media, which correlates with the frequent exposure to dramatic and argumentative content for all users.

Men are more likely than women to perceive bullying and deception on social media, while women tend to see more kindness and support [4, 8]. As the image illustrates, 29% of men reported frequently seeing mean or bullying content, compared to only 19% of women; conversely, 24% of women reported frequently seeing kind or supportive content, compared to 17% of men ![Men are more likely to see bullying while women are more likely to see kindness online](image2).

Social media companies use vast amounts of user data to deliver individually targeted content [2]. Users' comfort with this targeted approach depends on the context [1].  For example, a significant majority of users find it acceptable for social media sites to use their data to recommend local events, while a smaller majority approves of using their data to suggest potential friends [3].  

However, comfort levels vary across demographics. Men are about twice as likely as women to report seeing deceptive content on social media (24% vs. 13%) [10]. Therefore, targeted content about the efforts they see other users making to spread – or correct – misinformation, around two-thirds of users (63%) say they generally see an even mix of people trying to be deceptive and people trying to point out inaccurate information [10].

These differences in perception suggest that social media platforms could refine their algorithms to cater to these gender-specific experiences. Considering that men are more prone to noticing deceptive content, platforms could prioritize showing them content that fact-checks or debunks misinformation. On the other hand, given that women report seeing more supportive content, platforms could highlight positive and community-building content for them.  By understanding and responding to these differing perceptions, social media platforms can create more relevant and engaging experiences for all users.

Men and women perceive online behavior differently, which suggests social media platforms can tailor content based on gender.

Social media users' comfort levels with how their data is used are context-dependent [8]. A majority of users are comfortable with social media sites using their data to recommend events in their area [3, 4], as shown in ![The chart illustrates varying comfort levels across age groups regarding data usage for recommendations and advertisements, with recommending local events being the most accepted](image1).

However, comfort levels decrease when data is used for other purposes.  When social media data is used to deliver messages from political campaigns, user comfort drops significantly [1, 3, 5].

Older users are generally less accepting of social media sites using their data for various reasons beyond recommending events [10].  For instance, younger users are more comfortable with platforms suggesting people they might know compared to users ages 65 and older [6, 10].

Overall, users are more comfortable with data use that provides direct, personal benefits, such as event recommendations, but are wary of its use for advertising or political messaging.

The public generally harbors skepticism towards the fairness of automated programs, with none being viewed as fair by a clear majority [7]. This skepticism is evident in the contrasting views on different automated systems. For instance, while $54\%$ of people believe that personal finance score programs are effective, only $32\%$ consider them fair, marking a significant 22-percentage-point difference [1, 8]. ![The chart illustrates the difference between the percentage of people who find each system effective versus fair.](image3)

This disparity is further highlighted when compared to other systems like automated parole scoring, where perceived effectiveness and fairness are closely aligned [4]. In fact, the automated scoring of people up for parole is the only system where the percentage of people who find it fair exceeds the percentage of those who find it effective, as illustrated in the table, with 50% considering it fair compared to 49% considering it effective [4].

The reasons behind the lack of acceptance for personal finance scores include concerns over privacy violations, inaccurate representation, and unfair discrimination [9]. ![This bar chart shows that the majority of U.S. adults find it unacceptable for companies to use automated personal finance scores due to privacy concerns and potential inaccuracies.](image2) These concerns contribute to the broad sentiment that algorithms may reflect human biases, with a significant portion of Americans believing that computer programs will always reflect some level of human bias [6].

Differences in perceived fairness across automated systems highlight the nuanced and contextual nature of public trust in these technologies.

Views on the ethical standards of top Trump administration officials are notably low compared to past administrations [1]. A majority of the public, around 58%, expresses less trust in what Trump says compared to previous presidents [9]. ![The chart compares survey results on how U.S. adults feel about a certain topic, divided by political affiliation and ideology.](image2)

Partisan divides are significant: while 58% of Republicans trust Trump more than previous presidents, 94% of Democrats trust him less [6, 2]. The public's negative views on the ethical standards of Trump administration officials are lower than those of officials in the previous five administrations [7]. ![This chart shows the percentage of U.S. adults who trust what Donald Trump says less than they trusted what previous presidents said, broken down by political affiliation.](image4)

The ethical standards of top Trump administration officials are rated as excellent or good by only 39% of the public, with 59% rating them as not good or poor, which is lower than evaluations for past presidents dating back to Reagan [4]. These opinions are sharply divided along party lines, with 76% of Republicans viewing the ethical standards as excellent or good, while 90% of Democrats view them as not good or poor [10].  Distrust in Trump's statements has increased since April 2017 [5].

In summary, Trump's ethical standards and trustworthiness are perceived lower than those of previous presidents, particularly among Democrats, while Republicans generally maintain a higher level of trust.

Public perception indicates a majority feels Trump has a responsibility to release his tax returns [3]. A significant portion of the public, $58\%$, expresses less trust in what Trump says compared to previous presidents [10].

Republicans view Trump's trustworthiness differently than Democrats, as the chart indicates that most Republicans trust what Trump says more than previous presidents, while almost all Democrats trust Trump less ![The chart visually illustrates differences in responses between Republicans/Lean Republicans and Democrats/Lean Democrats.](image3). Distrust in Trump's statements has increased since April 2017 [7].
  
Compared to previous administrations, views of the ethical standards of top Trump administration officials remain at record lows [2, 4]. The public is also less inclined to say it's too early to judge Trump's success compared to similar points in the presidencies of Obama, Bush, and Clinton [6]. Views on Trump's ethical standards are notably low compared to previous administrations [1]. Partisan divides are significant, with 76% of Republicans viewing the ethical standards of Trump administration officials positively, while 90% of Democrats view them negatively [10].

Public opinion on whether Trump's policies have improved economic conditions is divided, with 40% believing they have improved, 28% saying they worsened, and 29% seeing no significant effect [4]. Currently, a notable partisan gap exists in perceptions of job availability, with Republicans more likely than Democrats to perceive jobs as widely available [2, 7]. Specifically, $71\%$ of Republicans believe there are plenty of jobs, compared to $53\%$ of Democrats [2, 6].

This difference in perception has been observed over time. In October 2017, $58\%$ of Republicans and $47\%$ of Democrats felt that jobs were widely available locally [2].
