The public's view of local job availability is at its most positive in decades [9], and positive views on job availability have generally tracked with more positive views of the economy [10]. Six-in-ten adults now say that there are plenty of jobs available in their local community, which is the highest share recorded since the question was first asked in 2001 [3]. Despite the overall positive sentiment, differences persist in how "good jobs" are perceived compared to job availability in general [4, 8]. Perceptions of job availability have risen in both parties [1, 5].

![Republicans are more likely to rate the availability of jobs in their community positively than Democrats.](image1)

In summary, perceptions of job availability differ significantly between Republicans and Democrats, with Republicans generally holding more positive views, and this partisan gap has been a consistent trend over time, even as overall perceptions of job availability have become more positive.

Perceptions of job availability are strongly divided along partisan lines [2, 10]. Currently, 71% of Republicans say there are plenty of jobs available, compared to 53% of Democrats [10]. These views on local job opportunities are among the most positive in the last two decades for both parties [3].

Views on job availability have become more positive since October 2017, aligning with more positive views of the economy [4]. ![The image displays a survey chart showing perceptions of job availability in communities, broken down by political affiliation, distinguishing between "jobs" and "good jobs."](image2)

The graph illustrates these trends from 2001 to 2019, showing the shifts in political leanings concerning job availability over the years.  ![The image is a line graph showing trends in job market perceptions from 2001 to 2019, indicating that "jobs are difficult to find" and another indicating that there are "plenty of jobs available."](image3) Positive views of economic conditions are more common among Republicans [9].  The divergence in perceptions between Republicans and Democrats is also reflected in their views of Trump's economic policies [8].

Perceptions of job availability differ significantly between Republicans and Democrats, with Republicans generally holding more positive views, and these perceptions have evolved over time, influenced by political events and economic conditions.

Public opinion on Wall Street's impact is significantly divided along partisan lines [1]. Republicans are more inclined to believe that Wall Street helps the U.S. economy, with $55\%$ holding this view, compared to only $31\%$ who think it hurts the economy [1, 8].  ![Republicans are more likely to think Wall Street helps the economy than hurts it, while Democrats are more divided](image3). In contrast, Democrats are more divided, with $46\%$ believing Wall Street hurts the economy and $41\%$ thinking it helps [7]. Overall, nearly half of Americans ($46\%$) believe Wall Street helps the U.S. economy more than it hurts [6].

Public satisfaction with the state of the nation reflects similar partisan divisions. Overall, seven-in-ten Americans are dissatisfied with the country's direction [3].  ![The "Dissatisfied" line is consistently higher than the "Satisfied" line, indicating widespread discontent](image1).  Dissatisfaction is higher than at any point in the past year, increasing by 9 percentage points since September [5]. Among Democrats, a large majority ($90\%$) express dissatisfaction [2].  While Republican satisfaction has decreased, it remains divided, with $47\%$ satisfied and $47\%$ dissatisfied [9].  ![Political affiliation trends indicate fluctuations in support for Republicans and Democrats over time](image2).  This division highlights how political affiliation significantly shapes perceptions of both Wall Street's impact and the overall state of the nation.

In summary, Republicans generally view Wall Street as beneficial and express divided satisfaction with national conditions, while Democrats are more critical of Wall Street and largely dissatisfied with the state of the nation.

From 1990 to 2019, there's been a noticeable shift in public satisfaction in the United States. The percentage of Americans dissatisfied with the state of the country has risen from 54% to 70%, while those satisfied have declined from 41% to 26% ![The graph illustrates a decrease in satisfaction and an increase in dissatisfaction among Americans from 1990 to 2019.](image2). This increasing dissatisfaction is evident across party lines [2].

Notably, views on Wall Street's impact are divided along partisan lines [7]. In early 2019, 55% of Republicans believed Wall Street helped the economy, while only 31% thought it hurt; conversely, Democrats were more split, with 46% seeing Wall Street as detrimental and 41% as helpful ![The chart highlights differing opinions between Republicans and Democrats regarding Wall Street's impact on the economy.](image4). These divisions have persisted, as highlighted by a recent survey, with nearly half of Americans overall believing Wall Street helps the economy [8].

Political affiliations have also seen fluctuations, with periods of stronger Republican or Democratic leaning depending on the president in office ![The line graph depicts fluctuating support for Republican and Democratic parties from 1990 to 2019.](image5). These partisan divisions contribute to the differing perspectives on key economic factors like the role of Wall Street.

Overall, public satisfaction has decreased, and political affiliations have fluctuated, contributing to partisan divisions on economic issues such as Wall Street's impact.

Confidence in Trump's abilities varied significantly depending on political affiliation, with Republicans generally expressing much higher confidence than Democrats [1].  Republicans were broadly confident in Trump on most issues, but rated him lower on working with Congress [7].

![Republicans and Democrats have different confidence levels on Trump's political ability.](image3)

As illustrated, there is a notable disparity between Republicans and Democrats regarding their confidence in Trump's ability to make good appointments to the federal courts [3]. Specifically, 64% of Republicans/Lean Republicans expressed "Very" confidence, and 24% felt "Somewhat" confident, while only 2% of Democrats/Lean Democrats felt "Very" confident, and 10% felt "Somewhat" confident ![Republicans and Democrats have different confidence levels on Trump's political ability.](image3). In comparison, when it comes to negotiating favorable trade agreements, 67% of Republicans/Lean Republicans were "Very" confident, and 22% were "Somewhat" confident, versus the Democratic side at 3% and 16% respectively; for managing the executive branch effectively, the Republican side was at 52% and 31%, while the Democratic side was at 2% and 6% ![Republicans and Democrats have different confidence levels on Trump's political ability.](image3).

Public confidence in Trump's ability to make good appointments to the federal courts is significantly higher among Republicans compared to Democrats, mirroring a broader trend of partisan division in confidence levels across various governmental tasks.

Confidence levels in Trump's ability to separate his business interests from his presidential decisions vary significantly across political affiliations. Overall, only a minority of Americans express strong confidence in Trump in this regard, as only 28% are very confident, and another 13% are somewhat confident [4].  A majority holds doubts, with 16% not too confident and 41% not at all confident [4]. Republicans generally show more confidence, with 55% being very confident and 23% somewhat confident [10]. However, this confidence is more pronounced among conservative Republicans (66% very confident) compared to moderate/liberal Republicans (39% very confident) [10].

Democrats, on the other hand, are deeply skeptical. A large majority (69%) are not at all confident that Trump keeps his business interests separate from his presidential decisions, with an additional 20% not too confident [2]. Liberal Democrats are particularly doubtful, with 83% expressing no confidence at all [2]. This disparity highlights a significant partisan divide in perceptions of Trump's ethical conduct and potential conflicts of interest. ![The bar chart shows U.S. adults feeling about Trump keeping his own business interests separate from the decisions he makes as president, categorized by political affiliation and ideology](image3).

Regarding Trump's responsibility to release his tax returns, a similar partisan split exists. Most Republicans (64%) do not believe he has this responsibility [3]. In contrast, a large majority of Democrats (91% in January 2019) believe he should release his tax returns ![The bar chart shows the percentage of people believing Trump has the responsibility to release his tax returns, broken down by political affiliation over time.](image4). Overall, a majority of Americans (64% in January 2019) feel Trump has a responsibility to release his tax returns [8].

In summary, confidence in Trump's ability to separate business interests from presidential decisions and the perception of his responsibility to release tax returns differ sharply along party lines, with Republicans generally more trusting and Democrats highly skeptical.

Partisan divides significantly influence perceptions of the COVID-19 response and trust in institutions. Democrats and Republicans hold starkly different views on the effectiveness of the U.S. response compared to other wealthy nations [1]. A large majority of Democrats (87%) believe the U.S. response has been less effective, while only a small fraction of Republicans (22%) share this view, with more Republicans saying it was about as effective (42%) or less effective (34%) ![Republicans are more likely to view the U.S. response as equally effective compared to Democrats](image1).

These partisan divisions extend to the assessment of public health officials and government leaders. There is a wider partisan difference in views of how public health officials, such as those with the CDC, are responding to the outbreak [10]. Positive ratings for CDC officials have dropped significantly among Republicans, while remaining relatively stable among Democrats [4]. The confidence level in public health officials differs, with 72% of Democrats and 53% of Republicans expressing confidence in them ![Democrats have more confidence in public health officials such as those at the CDC than Republicans](image2).

Even when considering the impact of COVID-19 in different geographic areas, partisan differences remain dominant [6]. Democrats are more likely than Republicans to attribute the rise in confirmed cases to rising infections, regardless of the COVID-19 impact in their area [3]. Republicans are less likely to attribute the increase in cases to more infections rather than just more testing [8].

These partisan divides also affect perceptions of the best approach to economic recovery, with Democrats more likely to agree that significantly reducing infections is crucial for a comfortable reopening compared to Republicans ![Democrats agree more with the statement that significantly reducing coronavirus infections to a comfortable level for reopening the economy is more effective for recovery](image3). Over time, approval ratings for key figures like Donald Trump have also shown sharp partisan divergence, highlighting the depth of these divides in the context of the pandemic response ![Approval ratings are different between 2017 and 2020](image4). The changes in approval ratings over time for public health officials and political figures reflect these partisan shifts in trust and confidence ![Approval ratings for public health officials, local, state officials and Donald Trump have changed from March to August](image5).

Partisan divides lead to differing perceptions of COVID-19 response effectiveness and varying levels of trust in institutions and leaders.

There are significant partisan differences in how people view the responses to the coronavirus outbreak from public health officials and Donald Trump [5]. Notably, positive views of public health officials have declined more sharply among Republicans than Democrats, as illustrated by the drop in positive ratings among Republicans from 84% to 53% [2, 3, 10]. Democrats' views have remained relatively stable, with 74% in March and 72% viewing public health officials positively [2, 5, 10]. This divergence is also reflected in confidence levels in institutions like the CDC, where Democrats show more confidence than Republicans ![Democrats have more confidence in the CDC than Republicans](image5).

Assessments of Donald Trump's handling of the outbreak also reveal a partisan divide [5]. While his approval ratings have decreased among both Republicans and Democrats, the decline is more pronounced among Democrats [7, 9]. The share of Democrats rating Trump's response as "poor" has risen significantly since March [9]. Approval ratings for Trump have dropped among Republicans/Lean Republicans from 83 to 73, and overall from 48 to 37 ![Approval ratings for Trump have dropped from 48 to 37](image3).

The public also holds consistent views of hospitals’ response to COVID-19 across party lines [4, 6].

These surveys highlight how political affiliation influences the perception of different entities' responses to the COVID-19 outbreak, particularly concerning public health officials and the former president [1].

Partisan differences significantly impact the perception of the COVID-19 response by public health officials and Donald Trump, with Republicans showing decreased confidence and approval compared to Democrats.

Since March, positive views of public health officials have declined [1]. There's been a decrease in positive assessments of state and local government officials as well [3].

Specifically, the positive ratings for public health officials have fallen, especially among Republicans [4].  The share of Republicans rating public health officials positively dropped from 84% to 53%, while Democrats' views remained relatively stable (74% in March, 72% currently) [9]. This is also shown in ![The chart shows public health officials' approval ratings dropping among both Democrats and Republicans, with a more significant decline among Republicans.](image4).

Trump's positive ratings for handling the coronavirus have also decreased since March [6]. Overall, 38% of Americans approve of Trump's performance as president, which is lower than in March (45%) [10].  

There are significant partisan differences in views of public health officials [7]. Currently, 72% of Democrats and those who lean to the party say public health officials are doing well, while approval among Republicans is much lower [7]. Only 5% of Democrats approve of Trump’s performance, compared to 77% of Republicans [2]. The share of Democrats who rate Trump’s response as “poor” has risen sharply since March [8]. This divide is clear in the views on Donald Trump ![The image shows approval ratings sharply divided along partisan lines, with the vast majority of Democrats disapproving of Trump's job performance and a large majority of Republicans approving.](image5).

Approval ratings for both public health officials and Donald Trump have declined since March, with a notable partisan divide in these changes, particularly a significant drop in Republican approval of public health officials.

Americans hold broadly negative assessments of the overall U.S. response to the coronavirus outbreak [3]. There are declining positive evaluations for state government officials, dropping from 70% to 56% since late March [10]. ![The bar chart shows public opinion ratings for various groups and individuals regarding their performance.](image1)
Trump's handling of the outbreak receives even more criticism; nearly half of Americans (48%) currently rate his response as “poor,” which is up 16 points since March [4]. While state government officials still receive generally positive ratings from a majority, Trump's approval is significantly lower [1, 4].
A sizable majority of U.S. adults (69%) express greater concern that state governments have been lifting restrictions on public activity too quickly [2]. ![The bar chart showing that 69% of respondents believe the COVID-19 restrictions are being lifted too quickly, while 30% think they are being lifted too slowly.](image5) This concern is reflected in the critical evaluations of state officials, with positive views declining since March [10]. The public is more critical of Trump’s response, with nearly half rating it as poor [6].

Americans are more critical of Trump's COVID-19 response compared to their state government's response.

Americans hold varied views on the effectiveness of different entities in handling the COVID-19 outbreak. There's a decline in positive views of public health officials, with only $63\%$ saying they are doing an excellent or good job, a decrease from $79\%$ in March [2]. This shift is more pronounced among Republicans [3]. Similarly, evaluations of state and local government officials have declined since March [5]. Opinions on Donald Trump's handling of the crisis are largely negative, with nearly half of Americans rating his performance as "poor" [6].

However, local hospitals and medical centers receive overwhelmingly positive ratings [5]. Comparing the effectiveness of the U.S. response to other wealthy countries, $62\%$ of Americans find it less effective [4]. This view is especially prevalent among Democrats [7]. Despite differing opinions, a significant portion of Republicans also acknowledges the U.S. response as less effective [7]. ![The image shows public opinion ratings for the performance of various groups and individuals; hospitals receive the highest ratings while Donald Trump receives the lowest.](image4)

Several factors contribute to the continued outbreak. A significant majority believes too few people are adhering to social distancing and mask-wearing guidelines [8]. While a majority also acknowledges that lifting restrictions too quickly is a major reason, there are partisan divides on these issues, with Democrats more likely to view the federal government's response as inadequate and to see the premature lifting of restrictions as problematic [9]. ![The image shows that a majority of respondents believe the primary reason for the continued spread of the coronavirus is that not enough people are social distancing and wearing masks.](image1)

In summary, Americans view the effectiveness of different officials and institutions in handling COVID-19 differently, with public health officials and elected officials receiving mixed to negative reviews, while hospitals are viewed positively; furthermore, the lack of adherence to guidelines and premature lifting of restrictions are seen as major factors contributing to the outbreak's continuation.

Partisan lines significantly shape views on governmental roles and the reasons behind the prolonged COVID-19 outbreak [4]. There is a public divide over which level of government is primarily responsible for policies to limit the spread of COVID-19 [6]. The public overall is almost evenly divided: 51% say this responsibility rests mostly with states, while 48% say the federal government should be primarily responsible [9].

![Democrats are more inclined to place responsibility on the federal government, while Republicans favor state control.](image4)

Republicans are more likely to assign responsibility to state and local governments (68%), whereas Democrats tend to believe the federal government should take the lead (64%) [9]. This divergence extends to perceptions of the outbreak's causes. A significant majority of Americans (75%) point to insufficient social distancing and mask-wearing as a primary factor for the continuation of the coronavirus outbreak ![Most Americans think insufficient social distancing and mask-wearing are a major reason for the continuation of the coronavirus outbreak.](image1). This sentiment is echoed across party lines, albeit with varying degrees of emphasis [3].  Democrats (89%) are more inclined than Republicans (57%) to view insufficient adherence to social distancing and mask-wearing guidelines as a major reason for the continued coronavirus outbreak [3].

![Democrats are far more likely than Republicans to consider factors such as federal response and lifting restrictions as major reasons for the continued outbreak.](image5)

Democrats are also more likely to criticize the federal government's response and the premature lifting of COVID-19 restrictions, with 82% considering both as major reasons for the continued outbreak, compared to 21% and 31% of Republicans, respectively [5]. These partisan differences highlight fundamentally different attitudes toward government intervention and public health measures during the pandemic [4].

Political affiliations significantly impact perceptions of government responsibility and the reasons cited for the continuation of the COVID-19 outbreak.

Americans largely agree that insufficient social distancing has prolonged the COVID-19 outbreak, but opinions diverge significantly along political lines regarding the role of government response [7, 3].  ![The chart indicates that 75% of people think not enough social distancing and mask-wearing is a major reason for the continued spread of COVID-19.](image4)
Democrats are far more likely than Republicans to view the federal government's response as inadequate [5, 9]. For example, a large majority of Democrats (82%) consider an inadequate federal response a major reason for the continued outbreak, compared to only 21% of Republicans [5]. This divide extends to perceptions about lifting restrictions too quickly, with 82% of Democrats believing it's a major reason, versus just 31% of Republicans [5, 10].

Furthermore, there is a notable partisan gap concerning adherence to social distancing and mask-wearing guidelines [7].  ![The chart shows that 89% of Democrats and 57% of Republicans believe that not enough people following social distancing and mask-wearing guidelines is a major reason for the continued coronavirus outbreak.](image5) While a majority of both Democrats (89%) and Republicans (57%) recognize insufficient adherence to these guidelines as a major factor, the higher percentage among Democrats underscores the differing emphasis placed on personal responsibility and public health measures [7].  This difference highlights how political affiliation shapes beliefs about the primary drivers of the pandemic's continuation.

Political affiliations significantly influence perceptions of the main reasons for the continuation of the COVID-19 outbreak, particularly concerning government response and social distancing.

Democrats are much more likely than Republicans to view the federal government's response to COVID-19 as inadequate [3]. Specifically, $82\%$ of Democrats consider the inadequate federal response a major reason for the continuation of the outbreak, while only $21\%$ of Republicans agree [3]. This is one of the widest partisan divides regarding the reasons for the ongoing outbreak [3].
![Democrats are much more likely than Republicans to blame the federal government for an inadequate response.](image1)
  Overall, about half of Americans $(53\%)$ say an inadequate federal government response is a major reason for the continuation of the outbreak [5].  Furthermore, a significant portion of Democrats $(67\%)$ believe that "not enough timely testing" is a major reason for the continued outbreak, compared to fewer Republicans $(30\%)$ who share this view [2].
![Democrats are much more likely than Republicans to say not enough timely testing is a major reason for the coronavirus outbreak continuing in the U.S.](image3)
  The most cited reason among the general public is insufficient social distancing and mask-wearing [7]. A majority of both Democrats $(89\%)$ and Republicans $(57\%)$ consider this a major factor [7].  Also, $58\%$ of people consider restrictions being lifted too quickly in some places as a major reason for the continuation of the outbreak [3].

The perception of the federal government's response to COVID-19 differs significantly between Democrats and Republicans, with the general public citing insufficient social distancing, mask-wearing, and restrictions lifted too quickly as major reasons for the outbreak's continuation.

Democrats and Republicans diverge significantly on the reasons for the continuation of the COVID-19 outbreak. A key difference lies in the perceived impact of easing restrictions too quickly, with 82% of Democrats considering this a major reason compared to only 31% of Republicans [5]. ![This image displays the percentage of Republicans and Democrats that believe that restrictions have been lifted too quickly](image3)

Another significant partisan divide concerns the federal government's response, where 82% of Democrats view it as inadequate compared to just 21% of Republicans [7]. This is further visualized, highlighting the partisan divide on the reasons for the continuation of the outbreak, where 82% of Democrats consider the federal government's response inadequate, versus only 21% of Republicans [10].

Regarding the rise in confirmed coronavirus cases, a majority of Republicans (62%) believe it's primarily due to increased testing, while only 36% think it's due to more new infections [6]. Conversely, most Americans (60%) attribute the rise in cases to rising infections rather than increased testing, revealing a wide partisan divide [8]. ![This image shows that 62% of Republicans believe the rise in confirmed coronavirus cases is due to more people being tested while 80% of Democrats believe it is due to new infections](image4). Furthermore, two-thirds of Democrats consider "not enough timely testing" a major reason for the outbreak's continuation, while fewer than half as many Republicans (30%) share this view [9].

Partisan beliefs significantly differ on the reasons for the continuation of the COVID-19 outbreak, particularly regarding the speed of restriction easing, the adequacy of the federal response, and the impact of testing versus new infections.

Americans are divided on the primary reasons behind the rise in confirmed coronavirus cases, with notable differences across political affiliations [4]. A significant portion of Republicans,  $62\%$, believe the increase is mainly due to more people being tested, while only $36\%$ attribute it to new infections [6].  This contrasts sharply with Democrats, where approximately $80\%$ attribute the rise in cases to more infections rather than just increased testing [7].

![Republicans are more likely to attribute the rise in cases to more testing, while Democrats believe it is due to more infections.](image1)

This partisan divide extends to the perception of state restrictions being lifted too quickly, with most Americans, $69\%$, expressing concern that states have eased restrictions prematurely [3]. Overwhelming shares of Democrats, both liberal ($93\%$) and conservative/moderate ($88\%$), share this concern [1].  In contrast, Republicans are more divided, with slightly more concerned that restrictions have not been lifted quickly enough ($53\%$) rather than lifted too quickly ($45\%$) [8].

![Most surveyed, except Republicans, believe the restrictions have been lifted too quickly.](image2)

The partisan gap is particularly evident on the issue of easing restrictions, where $82\%$ of Democrats see it as a major reason for the continuation of the outbreak, compared to just $31\%$ of Republicans [9].

![Democrats are far more likely than Republicans to consider lifted restrictions a major reason for continued outbreak.](image5)

In summary, Democrats are more inclined to attribute rising COVID-19 cases to increased infections and view the lifting of restrictions as a significant factor in the outbreak's continuation, whereas Republicans are more likely to attribute rising cases to increased testing and express less concern about the pace of restriction lifting.

Democrats and Republicans have significantly different views on both the causes of increased COVID-19 cases and whether restrictions were lifted too quickly. The data indicates a strong link between these two viewpoints across different political affiliations.

Democrats are far more inclined to attribute the rise in coronavirus cases to increased infections rather than simply increased testing [9]. Most Democrats, around 80%, believe that the increase in confirmed coronavirus cases is primarily due to more new infections [7, 9]. This perspective aligns with their concern that restrictions have been lifted too quickly; a large majority of Democrats (82%) consider the premature easing of restrictions as a major factor in the continuation of the outbreak [3, 6].  ![Democrats overwhelmingly believe increased infections are the main reason for rising COVID-19 cases](image5)

In contrast, Republicans are more likely to believe that the increase in confirmed cases is mainly a result of increased testing [5].  A $62\%$ majority of Republicans attribute the rise in confirmed cases primarily to increased testing [5]. Consequently, Republicans are relatively divided on whether restrictions have been lifted too quickly, with a slight majority being more concerned that restrictions haven't been lifted quickly enough [1].  ![Republicans are more likely to attribute rising COVID-19 cases to increased testing](image5)

These differing viewpoints extend to various subgroups within each party. For example, conservative Republicans are more likely to attribute the increase in cases to increased testing compared to moderate and liberal Republicans [5]. Similarly, liberal Democrats are more likely than conservative and moderate Democrats to attribute the increase to more infections [7].  ![Democrats overwhelmingly view lifting restrictions too quickly as a major factor in the outbreak](image3)

Overall, there is a clear partisan divide where Democrats are more concerned about premature lifting of restrictions due to their belief in increased infections, while Republicans are less concerned, attributing rising cases more to increased testing [3, 6]. Therefore, political affiliation strongly influences the perception of the causes of increased COVID-19 cases and, consequently, the opinions on lifting restrictions.

Generally, there's considerable support for requiring government-issued photo identification to vote [9]. However, views on voting policies differ by race and ethnicity within both parties [1]. While a narrow majority of White Democrats (54%) favor requiring government-issued photo ID, larger shares of Black (65%), Hispanic (72%), and Asian Democrats (71%) share this view [2].

![The image is a data visualization comparing values associated with different racial groups: White, Black, Hispanic, and Asian.](image2)

Republicans overwhelmingly support requiring photo ID (93%) [3]. However, Black adults show among the lowest levels of support for restrictive policies such as requiring photo ID [8].  Interestingly, White Democrats are more supportive of allowing early or absentee voting compared to Democrats of other races, while the opposite is true for White Republicans versus Hispanic Republicans [10].

![The image is a bar chart depicting public opinion regarding early and absentee voting options in elections.](image1)

In summary, support for requiring government-issued photo identification to vote is generally high, but it varies across racial groups and political affiliations, with notable differences between White Democrats and other racial groups within the Democratic party.

Racial and ethnic differences significantly influence support for various voting policies. For instance, Black adults show lower support for restrictive policies like removing people from registration lists if they haven’t recently voted or requiring government-issued photo identification [4].

![Support for requiring photo ID varies among racial groups within the Democratic party.](image1)

Black adults are more likely to favor "no excuse" early, absentee voting [1]. While a narrow majority of White Democrats (54%) favor requiring voters to show government-issued photo identification, larger shares of Black (65%), Hispanic (72%), and Asian Democrats (71%) share this view [2]. This indicates that even within the same political party, opinions on voter ID laws differ [3].

![Racial and ethnic groups have varying levels of support for policies aimed at easing voting, particularly within the Republican party.](image2)

White Democrats are more supportive of allowing all voters to vote early or absentee than are Democrats of other races and ethnicities [10]. Among Republicans, White adults are less supportive than Hispanic adults of policies aimed at easing voting, such as automatically registering all eligible citizens to vote [7]. Overall, White adults are less likely to favor making Election Day a national holiday and automatically registering all eligible citizens to vote than are Black, Hispanic, and Asian adults [5].

Racial and ethnic differences significantly influence support for voting policies, with Black adults often favoring more expansive policies, while opinions among White, Hispanic, and Asian adults vary depending on the specific policy and their political affiliation.

Racial and political affiliations significantly shape perspectives on voter identification and voting accessibility policies. While a large majority of adults favor requiring government-issued photo identification to vote [10], this support varies across racial and ethnic groups [6].

Notably, White Democrats show lower support for this requirement compared to Black, Hispanic, and Asian Democrats [6].

Conversely, when it comes to policies aimed at easing voting, White Democrats are more supportive of allowing early or absentee voting compared to Democrats of other races and ethnicities [1]. Among Republicans, White adults show less support than Hispanic adults for policies like automatic voter registration [3].

These differences highlight the complex interplay between race, ethnicity, and political affiliation in shaping opinions on voting policies [8]. Black adults, in particular, exhibit distinct preferences for more expansive voting policies, such as allowing convicted felons to vote after serving their sentences [7].

In contrast, Republicans are considerably more likely than Democrats to strongly favor photo identification requirements for voting [9].

Overall, racial and political identities create contrasting views on voter ID requirements and accessibility policies, with White Democrats less likely to favor strict ID laws compared to minority Democrats, and White Republicans less supportive of easing voting access relative to Hispanic Republicans.

Partisanship significantly influences attitudes towards early or absentee voting, with only 38% of Republicans favoring it [3]. Experiencing early or absentee voting increases support, especially among Republicans [4]. GOP voters who voted early or absentee are more inclined to support no-excuse options [5].

![The image is a bar chart showing approval, disapproval, and uncertainty ratings among different groups.](image2)

Regarding redistricting, nearly half of U.S. adults approve a House Democrats' proposal for redistricting commissions [8]. However, opinions vary among political affiliations, as 38% of Republican/Lean Republican approve the proposal, while 59% of Democrat/Lean Democrat approve it [8].

![The image is a bar chart depicting public opinion regarding early and absentee voting options in elections.](image1)

White Democrats are more supportive of early/absentee voting than Democrats of other races, while the opposite is true for White Republicans [2]. Among Republicans, ideological divides are present: conservatives prefer documented reasons for absentee/early voting, unlike moderates and liberals [9]. Overall, Democrats strongly support automatic voter registration and no-excuse early voting [7].

Different political and demographic groups hold varying views on independent redistricting and early absentee voting, shaped by partisanship, personal experience, and ideology.

Republicans and Democrats diverge on voting methods and redistricting. When it comes to congressional redistricting, nearly half of U.S. adults approve of a proposal for redistricting commissions [3]. However, Republicans are more likely to disapprove of non-legislative commissions than Democrats (19% vs. 8%) [8]. They are also more likely to be unsure (42% vs. 32%) [8].

![The image is a bar chart showing approval, disapproval, and uncertainty ratings among different groups.](image5)

Regarding early and absentee voting, Republicans who voted absentee in 2020 show more support for "no excuse" absentee or early voting [10]. A significant disparity existed between how Republicans and Democrats voted in the presidential election [4]. Roughly a third (34%) of Republican voters voted absentee or by mail, compared to 58% of Democratic voters [4]. Those with recent experience voting early or absentee are more likely to favor no-excuse early and absentee voting [6]. This is particularly true among Republicans [6].

![The image is a chart depicting voting patterns among different voter groups in the 2020 election.](image3)

Specifically, 52% of Republicans who voted absentee or by mail favor no-excuse absentee or early voting, while only about a third of early, in-person GOP voters (35%) and just 22% of those who voted in person on Election Day agree [7]. Among Democrats, these differences are less pronounced [7]. Conservative Republicans are more likely to say voters should provide documented reasons for voting absentee or early (70%) compared to moderate and liberal Republicans (49%) [9]. Ideological divides are less pronounced among Democrats on this issue [9]. Overall, 62% of Republican/Lean Republican voters believe that a voter should only be allowed to vote early or absentee if they have a documented reason for not voting in person on Election Day [Image4].

In summary, Democrats generally favor more accessible voting options and redistricting commissions, while Republicans show internal divisions based on voting behavior and ideology, with conservatives favoring stricter voting requirements.

Since 2018, there has been a notable shift in Republican views regarding 'no excuse' early or absentee voting, while Democratic views have remained relatively stable [5]. Republicans have become significantly less supportive of allowing any voter to cast an early or absentee ballot without a documented reason. The percentage of Republicans favoring this option has declined from 57% in October 2018 to 38% in April 2021 [5]. Conversely, Democrats have consistently supported automatically registering all eligible citizens to vote, with 82% in favor [1, 5].

![Republicans show sharp decline in share favoring ‘no excuse’ early or absentee voting, while Democrats remained stable](image2)

The data indicates that the percentage of Republicans who believe a voter should only be allowed to vote early or absentee with a documented reason increased from 42% to 62% between October 2018 and April 2021 [2]. In contrast, Democrats and Democratic leaners have remained highly supportive of automatically registering all eligible citizens to vote (82%) and no-excuse early voting (84%), with their views virtually unchanged in recent years [5]. Republicans are also less supportive of automatically registering all eligible citizens to vote, with support declining from 49% in 2018 to 38% in 2021 [7].

![Democrats remained stable in supporting automatically registering all eligible citizens to vote](image3)

In summary, between 2018 and 2021, Republican support for "no excuse" early or absentee voting and automatically registering all eligible citizens declined, while Democratic support for these policies remained stable.

In 2021, Democrats were more likely to favor making Election Day a national holiday compared to 2018 [1]. ![Democrats' support for making Election Day a national holiday increased from 2018 to 2021, while Republicans' support remained constant.](image2)Specifically, the percentage of Democrats/Lean Democrats supporting this proposal increased from 71% to 78% [2].

There has been little change in views regarding requiring voters to show government-issued photo ID to vote since 2018 [6]. ![The percentage of Republicans who support requiring photo ID to vote increased slightly from 2018 to 2021, while the percentage of Democrats decreased slightly.](image2) Republicans continue to overwhelmingly support this policy, with 93% in favor [6]. While majorities in both partisan groups favor this policy, Republicans are considerably more likely than Democrats to strongly favor photo identification requirements for voting [4].

Overall, Democrats' support for making Election Day a national holiday increased, while views on requiring photo ID remained largely unchanged between 2018 and 2021.

Latino registered voters predominantly identify with or lean towards the Democratic Party, with  $64\%$ versus $33\%$  for the Republican Party in 2022 [2]. This preference has remained relatively stable over the past few years [2]. However, future party affiliation remains uncertain [3].

![Line graph shows the percentages of Democratic and Republican parties from 2019 to 2022.](image2)

The Democratic Party's support among Latino voters has seen slight fluctuations between 2019 and 2022.

![Bar chart illustrates the preferences of different voter demographic groups towards Democratic or Republican candidates.](image4)

When it comes to key issues, the economy is a very important issue for  $80\%$ of Latino registered voters in 2022 [10]. Other top issues include healthcare ($71\%$), violent crime and education ($70\%$ each), and gun policy ($66\%$) [10]. Abortion has significantly risen in importance, with $57\%$ of Hispanic voters considering it very important, up from $42\%$ in March [8].

![Chart compares the importance of various issues to people in March and August.](image3)

The importance of abortion as a voting issue among Hispanics has increased significantly between March and August 2022.

![Chart displaying survey results about the perceived differences among Hispanics based on political affiliation.](image5)

There are perceived differences among Hispanics based on political affiliation.

In summary, Latino voters lean Democratic, with the economy, healthcare, crime, education, gun policy and abortion as key issues, and preferences vary based on demographic factors.

Hispanic Democrats and Republicans diverge significantly on the role of Donald Trump in national politics and the perception of racial discrimination. A large majority of Hispanic Democrats and leaners (94%) do not want Trump to remain a national political figure [7]. Conversely, a majority (63%) of Hispanic Republicans and leaners would like him to stay involved, with 41% suggesting he should run for president in 2024 [7].

![The chart shows the percentage of each group that thinks Trump should not remain in politics and those that think he should](image4)

Regarding perceptions of racial discrimination, the divide is also substantial.  73% of Latino Democrats and leaners believe that a significant problem is people not seeing racial discrimination where it exists [1]. In contrast, 62% of Republicans and leaners think the bigger problem is people perceiving racial discrimination where it does not exist [1].

![The graph compares perceptions of racial discrimination among different groups of Latinos](image5)

This divergence highlights a stark partisan divide within the Hispanic community on both political figures and social issues.

Hispanic registered voters' views on Donald Trump's political future are intertwined with their concerns about racial discrimination and gun rights, often along political party lines [3]. A significant majority of Hispanic registered voters, $73\%$, do not want to see Trump remain a national political figure [6, 8].

![The chart displays survey data on opinions about Trump remaining a national political figure, broken down by various demographics, showing the percentage who think he should run for president versus supporting another candidate](image4)

This sentiment is particularly strong among Latino Democrats, where $94\%$ share this view [6, 8]. However, this contrasts sharply with Hispanic Republicans, $63\%$ of whom would like to see Trump remain a national figure, with $41\%$ suggesting he should run for president in 2024 [6].

![The bar graph compares perceptions of racial discrimination among different groups of Latinos, highlighting differences in views based on political affiliation and the importance of their Hispanic identity](image5)

When it comes to racial discrimination, more Democrats than Republicans among Latinos believe that not seeing racial discrimination is a significant problem [9].  Views on gun policy also reveal divisions: about $73\%$ of Hispanics prioritize controlling gun ownership, with Hispanic Democrats being twice as likely as Hispanic Republicans to favor stricter gun control [7].

![The image shows a bar chart comparing opinions on gun control versus the right to own guns among different groups, revealing the contrast between Hispanics, U.S. adults, and their respective Democratic and Republican leanings](image3)

These viewpoints highlight a community that, while largely leaning towards controlling gun ownership and expressing concerns about racial discrimination, is significantly divided based on political affiliation regarding Trump's role in the future and approaches to gun policy.

In conclusion, Hispanic registered voters' opinions on Trump's political future are related to their concerns about racial discrimination and gun rights, primarily divided along party lines.

Hispanic Democrats and Republicans diverge significantly on the role of racial discrimination and the future of Donald Trump. Regarding racial discrimination, a large majority of Latino Democrats and leaners $(73\%)$ believe that people not seeing racial discrimination where it exists is a significant issue [10]. Conversely, about $62\%$ of Republicans and Republican leaners think that people seeing racial discrimination where it doesn't exist is a bigger problem [10].

![Perceptions of racial discrimination vary among different groups of Latinos.](image2)

This divide is mirrored in views about Donald Trump's political future.  A substantial $94\%$ of Latino Democrats and leaners do not want Trump to remain a national political figure [6]. Conversely, $63\%$ of Hispanic Republicans and GOP leaners wish to see Trump remain a national political figure, with $41\%$ suggesting he should run for president in 2024 [6]. This contrasts sharply with the broader sentiment among Latino registered voters, where $73\%$ oppose Trump remaining a national political figure [6].

![Most Hispanic registered voters do not want Trump to remain a national political figure.](image5)

These statistics highlight a stark polarization within the Hispanic community along party lines on the issues of racial discrimination and Trump's political future.

Hispanic perceptions of socialism and capitalism vary significantly across different political affiliations and age groups. Overall, Hispanics have a more positive view of capitalism than socialism [2]. The image shows a comparison between the views of all Hispanics, Democrats/Lean Democrats, and Republicans/Lean Republicans. It indicates the percentage of each group that views a certain subject as "Very/Somewhat bad," "Neither good nor bad," and "Very/Somewhat good" ![The bar chart depicts the opinions of All Hispanics, Democrats/Lean Democrats and Republicans/Lean Republicans regarding a certain topic, categorized as "Very/Somewhat bad", "Neither good nor bad" and "Very/Somewhat good".](image1).

There is a notable divide among Hispanic Democrats and Republicans regarding their views on capitalism, with a larger percentage of Republicans having a positive view [1].  Hispanics who identify as Republicans or lean Republican are more likely to have a positive view of capitalism compared to their Democratic counterparts [1]. The net attitudes toward capitalism for all Hispanics, Democrats, Republicans and U.S. adults are shown in the bar chart ![The bar chart shows the net attitudes of different groups toward capitalism including "All Hispanics," "Dem/Lean Dem," "Rep/Lean Rep," and "U.S. adults".](image3).

Younger Latinos (ages 18-29) are more evenly divided in their views of socialism, while older Latinos (ages 50-64 and 65+) tend to view socialism negatively [5, 6]. The image shows the perceptions of Hispanics toward a certain topic. It shows data from all Hispanics, Democrats/Lean Democrats, Republicans/Lean Republicans, different age groups, and based on how important being Hispanic is to them ![The image is a stacked bar chart showing the perceptions of certain groups towards being Hispanic or Hispanic identity.](image5).

In summary, Hispanic views on socialism and capitalism are shaped by both political affiliation and age, with Republicans generally favoring capitalism and younger Hispanics showing more openness to socialism.

Hispanics' views on socialism and capitalism vary significantly based on their political affiliations [3]. Overall, Hispanics have a more negative impression of socialism (53% vs. 41%) and a more positive view of capitalism (54% vs. 41%) [5].  ![Hispanics generally have a net positive view of capitalism and a net negative view of socialism, but views diverge among political affiliations.](image3)

Among Hispanic Democrats and those who lean Democratic, views on socialism are split, with 48% holding a negative view and 50% a positive one [4].  By contrast, a substantial majority (68%) of Hispanic Republicans and those who lean Republican have a positive view of capitalism [6]. However, only about half of Hispanic Democrats and leaners share this positive view of capitalism [6].  ![Views on an unnamed topic, possibly socialism or capitalism, vary significantly among Hispanics, Democrats, and Republicans, with Democrats being more positive and Republicans more negative.](image4) The data indicates a clear divide in attitudes toward both economic systems along party lines.

Hispanics overall have a more positive view of capitalism than socialism, with attitudes varying significantly by political affiliation [5].

Latinos have varied perceptions regarding which political party works to earn their votes, and these perceptions often correlate with different demographic factors.
![This bar chart compares the percentage of Latinos who identify as Democrats versus Republicans, separated by different demographic categories.](image1)
Hispanics who identify with either the Democratic (54%) or Republican (57%) party are more likely to perceive significant differences between the parties [1]. However, fewer independent Hispanics who lean Democrat (35%) or Republican (39%) see a great deal of difference between the parties [1].
![This image shows data on people's perceptions of differences, categorized by political affiliation and registration status.](image2)
Substantial shares of Latinos who are immigrants, Spanish speakers, Catholics, and evangelicals believe that Democrats work hard to earn Latinos’ votes [2].
![This bar chart shows survey data about the perceived differences among Hispanics in Various demographic groups.](image3)
In contrast, relatively few Latinos (19%) think Republicans work hard to earn their vote [3]. Even among Latino Republicans, only 40% agree with this statement, compared to just 13% of Latino Democrats [3].
![This chart details how different groups of Latinos assess something.](image5)
Smaller percentages of Latinos, including immigrants (23%), Spanish-dominant Latinos (24%), evangelicals (27%), those aged 50-64 (25%), and those 65 or older (23%), believe Republicans are actively trying to earn their votes [6].

These varying perceptions suggest a nuanced political landscape where demographic factors significantly influence how Latinos view the efforts of political parties to earn their votes.

There is a notable difference in how Latino Democrats and Republicans perceive each party's engagement with the Latino community.  A larger percentage of Hispanic Republicans and Republican leaners (56%) believe that the Democratic Party works hard to earn Latino votes, while only about a third of Hispanic Democrats and Democratic leaners (35%) think the same of the Republican Party [1]. This divide in perception extends to how much each party cares about Latinos; 36% of Latino Republicans and GOP leaners feel the Democratic Party cares about Latinos, whereas only 21% of Latino Democrats and leaners think the Republican Party cares [8].

![The survey results indicate different views on how well the Democratic and Republican parties engage with Latino voters.](image5)

These perceptions do not drastically alter party affiliations, as Latino voters still favor the Democratic Party by a significant margin [2].  The Democratic Party maintains a lead over the Republican Party in terms of party affiliation among Latino voters, with figures showing 64% identifying with or leaning towards the Democratic Party, compared to 33% for the Republican Party in 2022; these percentages have remained relatively stable over the past few years, as shown in the graph ![This graph shows the percentage leaning towards the Democratic Party and Republican Party from 2019-2022.](image2). Despite this, a substantial number of Hispanics (about half) see little difference between the two parties [5].

In summary, while Latino Democrats and Republicans have differing views on each party's efforts to engage with their community, these perceptions have not caused significant shifts in overall party affiliation trends, with the Democratic Party maintaining a solid lead.

Hispanics' views on the Democratic and Republican parties reveal nuanced perspectives shaped by political affiliation and evolving opinions. Latino registered voters tend to favor the Democratic Party over the Republican Party by a significant margin [8]. This preference has remained relatively stable in recent years, as shown in the graph ![The graph illustrates a stable preference for the Democratic Party among Latino registered voters from 2019 to 2022](image2).

However, a substantial portion of Hispanics do not perceive significant differences between the two major parties [6]. Specifically, in a survey, 36% indicated a fair amount of difference, while 16% saw hardly any difference at all [6]. Conversely, 45% believed there was a great deal of difference [6]. Notably, these perceptions are consistent among both Hispanic Democrats (47%) and Republicans (48%), who say there is a great deal of difference between the parties [6]. This is visually summarized, showing similar distributions across all Hispanics and those leaning towards either party ![The chart shows similar perceptions of party differences among all Hispanics, Democrats, and Republicans](image5).

  Majorities of Latino adults generally hold positive views of the Democratic Party [9]. A significant percentage feel the Democratic Party works hard for Latinos' votes, cares about Latinos, and represents their interests [9]. In comparison, fewer Latinos express the same sentiments about the Republican Party, although a notable percentage believe the GOP works to earn their votes [9]. The survey results break down how each party is perceived ![The bar graphs illustrate varying perceptions of the Democratic and Republican parties regarding their engagement with Latino voters](image4). Democrats and those who lean democratic are more likely to believe the Democratic Party cares about Latinos, whereas Republicans and those who lean republican are more likely to believe the Republican Party cares about Latinos ![The survey results show differing perceptions based on party affiliation regarding how well each party cares about Latino voters](image1).

In conclusion, while Latino voters predominantly lean towards the Democratic Party, a considerable portion sees little difference between the parties, and perceptions of each party's efforts and concern vary significantly along party lines.

Many Latino voters do not see major differences between the Democratic and Republican parties [1]. A significant percentage perceive only a fair amount or hardly any difference at all between the parties, highlighting a potential area of uncertainty in their political affiliations [1].

![A pie chart illustrating that 45% of all Hispanics see a great deal of difference between the Democratic and Republican parties.](image1)

Data indicates that Latino party identification has remained relatively stable in recent years, with a nearly two-to-one preference for the Democratic Party over the Republican Party [6]. This suggests a consistent, yet not overwhelmingly strong, alignment with the Democratic Party among Latino registered voters [6]. Despite this, a notable portion of Latino voters fall into groups with weaker attachments to either political party, indicating potential fluidity in their future affiliations [10].

![A line graph showing that Latino's affiliation to the Democratic party and Republican party has changed little from 2019 to 2022.](image2)

The perceived lack of significant difference between the parties, coupled with softer partisan ties for some Latino voters, could lead to shifts in party affiliation based on specific issues and candidates [10]. The economy, healthcare, violent crime, and education are key issues for Latino voters [3]. The salience of these issues could sway their support toward the party that they believe best addresses their concerns [3, 4, 5].

In recent years, Latino voters' views regarding the differences between the Democratic and Republican parties have shown a degree of stability in party affiliation, yet underlying uncertainties and issue-driven priorities suggest potential for future shifts.

Most Americans believe STEM jobs offer better compensation than other industries [3, 8]. The public generally views STEM jobs positively, especially regarding pay and attracting top talent [3].
![The public has positive perceptions of STEM jobs, including higher pay and attracting bright individuals](image4)
However, when considering job characteristics, differences emerge between men and women in STEM [9]. While both value flexibility [9], a higher percentage of men prioritize high pay and promotion opportunities, whereas women are more inclined to value jobs that focus on helping others [9].
![Men and women in STEM value flexibility, but women prioritize jobs that help others more than men](image1)
These differences in job characteristic preferences highlight that although STEM jobs are generally seen as high-paying [1], perceptions and priorities vary between genders [6].

In summary, while higher pay is a commonly held perception of STEM jobs, men and women differ in the job characteristics they value, with men prioritizing pay and promotion and women focusing on helping others [9].

Men and women in STEM both value job flexibility, but their priorities diverge in other areas [7, 9]. Women are more inclined to seek jobs focused on helping others; $59\%$ of women value jobs that help others, compared to only $31\%$ of men [1, 7].

![Women are more likely to value job characteristics such as helping others and making a meaningful societal contribution compared to men](image4)

While men prioritize higher pay ($59\%$) and opportunities for promotion (57%), women place greater emphasis on making a meaningful contribution to society and having a job that others respect and value [7]. This difference in values may contribute to the perception that STEM jobs are not as focused on helping others, as shown in the public image of STEM jobs, where only 28% believe STEM jobs focus on helping others ![STEM jobs are less likely to be seen as focused on helping others](image1).

Many Americans attribute the underrepresentation of women in STEM to a lack of early encouragement [5].  Furthermore, women in STEM are more likely than men to perceive gender discrimination in recruitment, hiring, and promotions as a major obstacle, with about half of women in STEM jobs (48%) holding this view compared to 29% of men [3, 10].  Some women feel their gender has made it harder to succeed due to pay gaps and unequal treatment stemming from gender stereotypes [3].

![Discrimination and lack of encouragement are major reasons for the underrepresentation of women in STEM](image3)

These perceptions of discrimination, coupled with the challenges of balancing work and family, as well as the perceived lack of focus on helping others in STEM, contribute to the difficulties women face in entering and thriving in the STEM workforce.

Women in STEM value jobs that help others and emphasize societal contributions more than men, and they are more likely to perceive gender discrimination as a barrier to their success in STEM fields.

The underrepresentation of women in STEM is attributed to factors like facing discrimination in recruitment, hiring, and promotion, with 39% of U.S. adults citing this as a major reason [1]. Another significant factor is the lack of encouragement for girls to pursue STEM from an early age, also noted by 39% of adults [6].   ![The image is a bar chart that illustrates the major reasons why more women, blacks, and Hispanics are not in STEM (Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics) jobs.](image1)
In contrast, the underrepresentation of blacks and Hispanics is primarily linked to limited access to quality education, cited by 42% of Americans [9]. Lack of encouragement from an early age is also a significant factor, with 41% considering it a major reason [6].  Notably, perceptions of discrimination vary significantly across racial and ethnic groups; 72% of blacks in STEM believe discrimination in recruitment, hiring, and promotions is a major reason for underrepresentation, compared to 27% of whites and 28% of Asians [5, 8].

Women in STEM are more likely to perceive gender discrimination as a major barrier [2, 3]. Specifically, about half of women in STEM (48%) believe gender discrimination in recruitment, hiring, and promotions is a major reason for the lack of women in STEM, compared to 29% of men in STEM [3]. Furthermore, a substantial percentage of Americans (42%) recognize that limited access to quality education is a major factor in the underrepresentation of blacks and Hispanics in the STEM workforce [9].

The main reasons for the underrepresentation of women in STEM include discrimination and lack of encouragement, while for blacks and Hispanics, the primary reason is limited access to quality education.

STEM workers generally have higher education levels than non-STEM workers [7]. Specifically, 65% of STEM workers have at least a bachelor's degree, compared to 32% of non-STEM workers [7]. This is further illustrated in the stacked bar chart, which shows that STEM-employed individuals have a higher percentage of bachelor's and postgraduate degrees compared to their non-STEM counterparts, who more commonly have a high school diploma or less ![The stacked bar chart compares education levels of STEM and non-STEM employed individuals, showing STEM has more bachelor's and postgraduate degrees](image2).

Most STEM workers are employed in the private, for-profit sector, mirroring the overall employment landscape [8]. However, the distribution varies among specific STEM fields. For example, engineers and computer workers are more likely to work for private employers, while healthcare practitioners and technicians are more frequently employed by not-for-profit organizations [8]. This is further visualized in the bar chart, which breaks down employment types across various job categories, highlighting the differences between STEM and non-STEM jobs, as well as among specific STEM fields such as engineering, computer science, and health-related occupations ![This bar chart illustrates the distribution of employment types across various STEM and non-STEM job categories, showing the prevalence of private, for-profit employment](image4).

In summary, STEM workers tend to be more educated than non-STEM workers and are primarily employed in the private sector, although the specific employment sector distribution varies depending on the particular STEM field.

STEM workers generally have higher levels of education compared to their non-STEM counterparts [6]. Specifically, a significant percentage of STEM workers hold at least a bachelor's degree (65%) compared to non-STEM workers (32%) [6]. Furthermore, a large portion of STEM workers have advanced degrees, such as a master's, doctorate, or professional degree (29%), which significantly exceeds the percentage of non-STEM workers with similar qualifications (12%) [6]. This difference is highlighted in ![The education levels of STEM and Non-STEM employed individuals are compared](image2), which visually compares the education levels of STEM and non-STEM employed individuals.

Most STEM workers are employed in the private, for-profit sector, mirroring the overall employment landscape [4]. Notably, engineers and architects (82%) and computer workers (77%) are particularly likely to work for private employers [4]. While the majority of STEM jobs are in the private sector, certain fields like health-related occupations show a different distribution, with a notable percentage working for not-for-profit employers (23%) [4]. The distribution of employment sectors across various STEM fields is illustrated in ![The distribution of employment types across various job categories](image3), showing percentages in private, not-for-profit, government, and self-employment sectors.

Over time, there have been shifts in the representation of women in STEM fields such as life and physical sciences ![Both Life Science and Physical Science shows an upward trend over the years](image4) and health-related and math occupations ![Health-related and Math occupations shows an upward trend](image5). However, women remain underrepresented in computer and engineering roles [10], as shown in the proportion of women in the "Computer" field has decreased from 1990 to 2016, while "Engineering" has only slightly increased. ![The proportion of "Computer" field decreased, while "Engineering" field increased](image1).

In summary, STEM workers tend to have higher educational attainment compared to non-STEM workers, and most are employed in the private sector, with variations across specific STEM fields; furthermore, there are noticeable shifts in gender representation across different STEM occupations over time.

Black STEM employees report the highest rates of workplace discrimination, with 62% reporting such experiences [3, 5]. A significant portion of Asians (44%) and Hispanics (42%) in STEM also report discrimination, while only 13% of whites in STEM report similar experiences [5, 7].

Experiences of discrimination also vary by gender. Half (50%) of women in STEM jobs report experiencing some form of gender discrimination [6]. This rate is higher than that of women in non-STEM jobs (41%) and significantly higher than that of men in STEM occupations (19%) [6]. Women in computer jobs experience gender-related discrimination at a rate of 74%, a stark contrast to the 16% of men in similar roles who report such experiences ![Gender-related discrimination is significantly higher for women in computer jobs compared to men.](image3).

Racial and ethnic minorities, particularly blacks, are more likely to feel that there is too little attention to diversity in their workplaces [10]. This is further compounded when considering the representation of these groups in STEM, as blacks and Hispanics are underrepresented relative to their share in the U.S. workforce [4].  Women in STEM jobs, especially those in male-dominated environments, also face more gender-related challenges compared to their male counterparts, including higher rates of gender discrimination and the feeling that their gender makes it harder to succeed ![Women in male-dominated STEM workplaces experience more gender-related discrimination.](image1).

In summary, experiences of discrimination in STEM jobs differ significantly among racial groups, with Black employees reporting the highest rates, and are also notably prevalent among women, particularly in computer and male-dominated fields.

Women in STEM jobs, particularly those in male-dominated workplaces, face significant challenges related to discrimination and gender inequities [2, 7]. A substantial 78% of women in majority-male STEM workplaces report experiencing gender discrimination, a stark contrast to the 43% of women in majority-female workplaces who report the same [6, 8]. ![Women in STEM in male-dominated environments are more likely to face gender discrimination](image4). These disparities extend to the perception of gender hindering success, with 48% of women in male-dominated settings feeling that their gender has made it harder to succeed, compared to only 12% of their counterparts in majority-female environments [8].

Moreover, women in majority-male STEM workplaces are more likely to feel the need to prove themselves to gain respect from coworkers [3]. This heightened pressure contributes to a sense of isolation and inequity, as reflected in the different forms of discrimination experienced, such as earning less than male counterparts, being treated as incompetent, and receiving less support from senior leaders [5, 9]. ![A higher percentage of women in STEM compared to women in non-STEM reported gender discrimination at work](image2). Even though women in STEM are as likely as men to feel valued, those in male-dominated environments often need to work harder to earn that appreciation [10].  ![Women with postgraduate degrees, in computer jobs, or in mostly male workplaces face higher rates of gender discrimination and obstacles to success](image1).

Women in STEM jobs in male-dominated environments experience significantly higher rates of workplace discrimination and gender inequities compared to those in more gender-balanced settings.

Self-identification as Hispanic in the U.S. is influenced by several factors that vary across generations [2]. The concept of racial and ethnic identity relies on self-reports [5]. As generations progress, the connection to Hispanic identity tends to diminish [1]. By the third generation, only 77% self-identify as Hispanic, and this drops to about half by the fourth generation [1].

Experiences and cultural connections also play a significant role [2]. For adults with Hispanic ancestry who do not identify as Hispanic, a major reason is a mixed background or distant Hispanic ancestry ![Many individuals do not identify as Hispanic due to mixed backgrounds or distant ancestry.](image2). Other reasons include upbringing, limited contact with Hispanic relatives, not speaking Spanish, lacking a link to Hispanic culture, identifying as another race, or simply considering themselves American due to being born in the U.S. [10]. ![Many self-identified Hispanics do not speak Spanish, with the percentage increasing across generations.](image5) Even among self-identified Hispanics, the necessity of speaking Spanish to be considered Latino is not universally agreed upon; a majority of Latinos, including 84% of second-generation and 92% of third or higher generation Latinos, do not believe speaking Spanish is required [6].

The degree to which individuals see themselves as typical Americans also increases across generations [7]. Only 36% of immigrant Hispanics consider themselves a typical American, but this rises to 63% among second-generation and 73% among third or higher generation Hispanics [7]. ![Preferences for self-identification terms vary, with "country of origin/heritage" being the most popular.](image3)

These factors collectively highlight the complex and evolving nature of Hispanic identity in the U.S., influenced by generational status, cultural connections, language, and self-perception.

Cultural experiences and parental pride discussions vary significantly across generations of self-identified Hispanics and non-Hispanics, influencing their connection to their Hispanic identity [10]. Among self-identified Hispanics, first-generation immigrants are more likely to have been taken to Hispanic cultural celebrations during their childhood [9]. Specifically, $59\%$ of immigrant self-identified Hispanics report their parents often took them to such celebrations [9]. This reflects the strong cultural ties they maintain, often growing up outside the U.S. [9].

Second-generation Hispanics also report a high frequency of cultural celebration attendance, with $49\%$ saying their parents often took them to these events [6]. However, this percentage decreases in the third or higher generations, where only $35\%$ report the same [6]. This decline indicates a fading connection to cultural traditions over time, as immigrant connections weaken [10]. The bar chart clearly visualizes the differences in cultural celebration attendance among these groups, highlighting the generational shift ![The bar chart visualizes differences in attending cultural celebrations among Hispanic generations](image3).

Parental discussions about pride in their country of origin also follow a similar trend. Immigrant and second-generation self-identified Hispanics are more likely to report frequent conversations about their heritage ($57\%$ and $50\%$ respectively) [7]. By the third generation, only $33\%$ say their parents often discussed their pride in their roots [7].  This shows a significant decrease in the emphasis on Hispanic heritage as generations progress [7].

In stark contrast, self-identified non-Hispanics with Hispanic ancestry report significantly lower engagement in Hispanic cultural activities. Only $9\%$ say their parents often took them to Latino cultural celebrations, while $60\%$ report this never happened [1]. Similarly, only $9\%$ of self-identified non-Hispanics say their parents often encouraged them to speak Spanish [3]. These statistics underscore the considerable distance this group has from its immigrant roots [3].  This distance is further highlighted by the reasons why individuals may not identify as Hispanic, such as mixed backgrounds, lack of contact with Hispanic relatives, and not speaking Spanish ![The bar chart shows the reasons individuals may not identify as Hispanic](image1).

In summary, cultural engagement and parental pride discussions diminish across generations for self-identified Hispanics, while self-identified non-Hispanics report considerably less exposure to Hispanic cultural activities and heritage discussions.

The frequency of attending Hispanic cultural celebrations and the prevalence of parental pride discussions vary significantly across generations of self-identified Hispanics and non-Hispanics, reflecting the evolving connection to their Hispanic roots [3, 7]. Among immigrant self-identified Hispanics, a notable 59% report that their parents often took them to Hispanic cultural celebrations, highlighting the strong cultural immersion experienced by those who grew up outside the U.S. [9]. This contrasts sharply with self-identified non-Hispanics, where only 9% report frequent exposure to Latino cultural celebrations during their upbringing, with 60% stating it never occurred [5].

![Foreign-born Hispanics are more likely to be taken to cultural celebrations often.](image5)

As generations progress, the frequency of these cultural experiences declines among self-identified Hispanics [7].  Specifically, 49% of second-generation self-identified Hispanics recall frequent attendance at Hispanic cultural celebrations during childhood, a figure that drops to 35% for third or higher generations [4].  This generational shift underscores the fading influence of immigrant experiences on cultural engagement [3].  

![There's a higher percentage of foreign-born Hispanics that self-identified as Hispanic.](image2)

Furthermore, discussions about pride in their country of origin also diminish across generations [10]. While 57% of immigrant and 50% of second-generation self-identified Hispanics recall their parents frequently expressing pride in their roots, only 33% of third-generation Hispanics report the same [10]. This decline is mirrored in language use, with English dominance increasing in later generations, as shown in ![English-speaking dominance increases among later generations of Hispanics.](image4).

In summary, the frequency of attending Latino cultural celebrations and parental pride discussions decreases across generations from immigrant to third-or-higher generation self-identified Hispanics, while it remains consistently low among self-identified non-Hispanics with Hispanic ancestry.

Language dominance shifts across generations of self-identified Hispanics, with English becoming more prevalent [5]. Among foreign-born Hispanics, the majority are Spanish dominant, but this decreases to only a small fraction in later generations [9]. ![The image shows language dominance among self-identified Hispanics and non-Hispanics, categorized into English dominant, Bilingual, and Spanish dominant.](image5)

Parental encouragement to speak Spanish also declines across generations [2]. A high percentage of foreign-born Hispanics report their parents often encouraged them to speak Spanish, but this figure drops significantly in subsequent generations [6]. ![The image is a bar chart illustrating the percentage of self-identified Hispanics whose parents encouraged them to speak Spanish, showing a decline across generations.](image1) In contrast, very few self-identified non-Hispanics with Hispanic ancestry report such encouragement [4].

Participation in Hispanic cultural celebrations is another differentiating factor, with foreign-born Hispanics more likely to have frequently attended these celebrations during childhood, compared to later generations [1, 3]. ![The image shows how frequently different groups self-identify as Hispanic, with the results segmented by generation and identification status.](image2) This suggests a gradual disconnect from cultural practices with each successive generation [3].

In summary, language dominance shifts towards English, parental encouragement of Spanish decreases, and participation in cultural celebrations declines across generations of self-identified Hispanics.

As immigrant roots become more distant, connections with ancestral national origins decline among self-identified Hispanics [7]. Eight-in-ten immigrants who identify as Hispanics feel connected with their country of origin, while only $44\%$ of the third generation feel that connection [7]. ![Foreign-born Hispanics feel the most connected to their heritage, while that feeling diminishes in later generations.](image1)

Language proficiency also shifts across generations.  Among self-identified Hispanics, 61% of immigrants are Spanish dominant, whereas essentially none of the third generation is Spanish dominant [2].
