Contemporary evaluation practices of RAG models emphasize three primary quality scores and four essential abilities, which collectively inform the evaluation of the two principal targets of the RAG model: retrieval and generation [3]. Several benchmarks and tools facilitate the evaluation of RAG, furnishing quantitative metrics to gauge model performance and enhance comprehension of the model’s capabilities across various evaluation aspects [6].

RGB, RECALL, RAGAS, ARES and TruLens are the evaluation framework for RAG [6]. The evaluation target includes retrieval quality and generation quality, with the evaluation aspect in terms of answer relevance, noise robustness, context relevance, negation rejection, answer faithfulness, information integration, counterfactual robustness.
![The image shows the components of the RAG ecosystem, including downstream tasks, technology stacks, challenges, and evaluation metrics.](image4)

The metrics for each evaluation aspect are derived from related work but do not yet represent a mature or standardized approach for quantifying RAG evaluation aspects [5].  Specifically, RGB, RAGAS, ARES, TruLens and CRUD all target both retrieval and generation quality as shown in the table, assessing aspects like context relevance, faithfulness, and answer relevance using metrics like Accuracy and Cosine Similarity. ![This table outlines different evaluation frameworks (RGB, RECALL, RAGAS, ARES, TruLens, CRUD), their targets (Retrieval Quality, Generation Quality), aspects (e.g., Context Relevance, Faithfulness), and quantitative metrics used in evaluation (e.g., Accuracy, Cosine Similarity).](image2)

Evaluation frameworks like RGB, RAGAS, ARES, TruLens and CRUD focus on both retrieval and generation quality, using a variety of metrics such as Accuracy, EM (Exact Match), Cosine Similarity, BLEU, and ROUGE-L to assess aspects like context relevance, faithfulness, and answer relevance.

RAG evaluation focuses on retrieval and generation quality, using specific metrics to assess different aspects [10]. Current metrics are derived from related work and do not yet represent a mature or standardized approach for quantifying RAG evaluation aspects [4].

Key evaluation aspects include answer relevance, noise robustness, context relevance, negation rejection, answer faithfulness, information integration, and counterfactual robustness, as summarized in the RAG ecosystem ![The image is a summary of the RAG (Retrieval-Augmented Generation) ecosystem.](image1). Context relevance is assessed using metrics like Accuracy, EM, Recall, Precision, Cosine Similarity, Hit Rate, MRR, and ROUGE/ROUGE-L, while faithfulness is evaluated by Accuracy, EM, BLEU, and ROUGE/ROUGE-L ![The image categorizes different evaluation metrics based on which aspects they assess.](image3).

Various evaluation frameworks like RGB, RECALL, RAGAS, ARES, TruLens and CRUD employ different metrics to evaluate these aspects ![The table provides an overview of different evaluation frameworks, their targets, aspects, and quantitative metrics used in evaluation.](image5). For instance, RGB targets noise robustness, negative rejection, information integration, and counterfactual robustness using accuracy and EM metrics, whereas RECALL focuses on counterfactual robustness using R-Rate.

RAG models are evaluated through benchmarks and automated tools ![The image is a summary of the RAG (Retrieval-Augmented Generation) ecosystem.](image1). Benchmarks like RGB, RECALL and CRUD appraise the essential abilities of RAG models [10]. Concurrently, state-of-the-art automated tools like RAGAS, ARES, and TruLens employ LLMs to adjudicate the quality scores [10].

In summary, RAG evaluation involves assessing retrieval and generation quality using a range of metrics across different aspects, with frameworks varying in their specific focus and metrics.

The RGB and CRUD frameworks are used to evaluate Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG) models, focusing on distinct aspects of performance [9]. RGB focuses on retrieval and generation quality, specifically assessing noise robustness, negative rejection, information integration, and counterfactual robustness ![RGB evaluates noise robustness, negative rejection, information integration, and counterfactual robustness.](image4). In contrast, CRUD also targets retrieval and generation quality, but it evaluates creative generation, knowledge-intensive question answering, error correction, and summarization [9].

These frameworks use different quantitative metrics to gauge the quality of RAG models.  RGB uses accuracy and exact match (EM) to measure its defined aspects ![RGB uses accuracy and exact match (EM) as metrics.](image4). CRUD, on the other hand, employs BLEU, ROUGE-L, BertScore, and RAGQuestEval to evaluate its specific targets [9].

The key difference lies in the aspects each framework emphasizes: RGB is concerned with the robustness and reliability of the model, while CRUD assesses the model's ability to generate creative content, handle complex knowledge, correct errors, and summarize information [9].

In summary, RGB focuses on evaluating the robustness of RAG models, while CRUD emphasizes the creative and practical application aspects.

RAG model evaluations focus on how well they perform in downstream tasks, using metrics suited to those tasks [9]. For example, question answering uses EM and F1 scores, while fact-checking uses Accuracy [9]. The evaluation targets include assessing both retrieval and generation quality [8].

![The image illustrates the components of the RAG ecosystem, challenges, techniques, and evaluation targets.](image2)

Different evaluation frameworks like RGB, RAGAS, and CRUD focus on various aspects of RAG systems and use different quantitative metrics [9]. RGB targets retrieval and generation quality, assessing aspects like noise robustness, negative rejection, information integration, and counterfactual robustness, using metrics like Accuracy and EM [image4]. RAGAS also targets retrieval and generation quality but assesses context relevance, faithfulness, and answer relevance, employing metrics such as cosine similarity [image4]. CRUD focuses on creative generation, knowledge-intensive QA, error correction, and summarization, utilizing metrics like BLEU, ROUGE-L, and BertScore [image4].

![The table provides an overview of evaluation frameworks, their targets, aspects, and quantitative metrics.](image4)

RGB, RAGAS, and CRUD differ in their evaluation targets, aspects assessed, and the quantitative metrics they employ to evaluate RAG systems.

Advanced RAG enhances retrieval quality by employing pre-retrieval and post-retrieval strategies, refining indexing techniques, and incorporating optimization methods to streamline the retrieval process [1]. It improves upon Naive RAG by addressing its limitations through these specific enhancements [3].

![Advanced RAG builds on naive RAG, adding optimization strategies in pre-retrieval and post-retrieval stages](image3)

Modular RAG further advances beyond both Naive and Advanced RAG paradigms by offering enhanced adaptability and versatility [8]. It incorporates diverse strategies such as adding a search module for similarity searches and refining the retriever through fine-tuning [8]. Modular RAG introduces specialized components to enhance retrieval and processing capabilities, adapting to specific scenarios and improving the quality and relevance of retrieved information [6]. The evolution from Naive RAG to Advanced RAG and then to Modular RAG represents a progression and refinement within the RAG family [8].

![Modular RAG combines multiple modules organically.](image5)

Advanced RAG improves retrieval quality through refined indexing and optimization, while Modular RAG enhances adaptability and versatility with specialized modules.

Naive RAG follows a traditional process of indexing, retrieval, and generation [3].  Advanced RAG enhances retrieval quality through pre-retrieval and post-retrieval strategies and refines indexing techniques [1]. ![The image compares the three paradigms of RAG: Naive, Advanced, and Modular, highlighting their different processes and components.](image1) Modular RAG provides adaptability by allowing module substitution or reconfiguration to address specific challenges, going beyond the fixed structures of Naive and Advanced RAG [5]. It introduces specialized components to enhance retrieval and processing capabilities [7].

Modular RAG incorporates diverse strategies for improving its components, such as adding a search module for similarity searches and refining the retriever through fine-tuning [10].  Adjustments in module arrangement and interaction showcase the dynamic use of module outputs to bolster another module’s functionality, illustrating a sophisticated understanding of enhancing module synergy [6]. ![The diagram illustrates iterative, recursive, and adaptive retrieval augmentation processes for a RAG system, each enhancing retrieval and generation differently to improve system performance and flexibility.](image4) Unlike the fixed retrieval process of Naive and Advanced RAG, Modular RAG evaluates the necessity of retrieval based on different scenarios [6].

In summary, Naive RAG uses a straightforward retrieve-and-read approach, Advanced RAG optimizes retrieval using pre- and post-retrieval strategies, and Modular RAG offers a flexible architecture with interchangeable modules for diverse tasks.

RAPTOR employs two querying mechanisms: tree traversal and collapsed tree, each offering unique ways to navigate the multi-layered RAPTOR tree for information retrieval [9].  The collapsed tree method has demonstrated superior performance compared to tree traversal due to its flexibility in retrieving information at the appropriate level of granularity for a given question [10].  ![The image illustrates two mechanisms for retrieving information using tree structures: Tree Traversal Retrieval and Collapsed Tree Retrieval.](image2)

The collapsed tree approach searches through all the nodes simultaneously, enabling it to retrieve information that matches the specific detail level required by a question [10]. In contrast, tree traversal maintains a constant ratio of higher-order thematic information to granular details, regardless of the question, which can be less effective [10]. Controlled comparisons on the QASPER dataset using different language models like GPT-3, GPT-4, and UnifiedQA, show that RAPTOR consistently outperforms BM25 and DPR [2, 6].  Specifically, RAPTOR's F-1 scores are significantly higher than both DPR and BM25 [2, 6].  ![The image is a graph comparing different querying methods based on the F1 score.](image3) As illustrated in Figure 3, the collapsed tree approach, particularly with a context length of 2000 tokens, yields the best F1 score on the QASPER dataset [10].

RAPTOR, when paired with UnifiedQA, also demonstrates strong performance on the Narrative QA dataset [4].  Furthermore, RAPTOR's tree-based retrieval allows it to select nodes from different tree layers, which often results in more relevant and comprehensive information compared to DPR [7].  ![The image is an illustration of the querying process by RAPTOR, a system for retrieving information.](image1) On the QuALITY dataset, RAPTOR outperforms baselines like BM25 and DPR by at least 2.0% in accuracy [4]. The integration of RAPTOR with models like SBERT, BM25, and DPR consistently improves their performance across various metrics such as ROUGE, BLEU-1, BLEU-4, and METEOR, as shown in Table 5 [5].

In summary, the collapsed tree retrieval method, as part of the RAPTOR system, generally outperforms tree traversal and enhances the performance of models like DPR on the QASPER dataset and other evaluation metrics.

RAPTOR employs two querying mechanisms, tree traversal and collapsed tree, to navigate its multi-layered structure for retrieving information [6]. The collapsed tree approach has demonstrated superior performance due to its flexibility in searching through all nodes simultaneously, allowing it to retrieve information at the correct level of granularity for a given question [5].

![Collapsed tree retrieval is better due to offering greater flexibility than tree traversal.](image1)

In contrast, tree traversal maintains a constant ratio of thematic information to granular details, regardless of the question [5]. Consequently, the collapsed tree approach is preferred for querying within RAPTOR [7].

When compared to a recursively summarizing model, RAPTOR demonstrates strong performance, achieving a new state-of-the-art METEOR score [3]. Unlike models that rely solely on the top root node summary, RAPTOR benefits from its intermediate layers and clustering approaches, capturing a range of information from general themes to specific details, contributing to its overall strong performance [3].

Therefore, collapsed tree retrieval, offering greater flexibility, outperforms tree traversal, and RAPTOR achieves state-of-the-art METEOR scores, highlighting its effectiveness in capturing both general and specific details.

RAPTOR, a tree-based retrieval system, has shown superior performance compared to other methods across various datasets and evaluation metrics [9]. In the Narrative QA dataset, RAPTOR paired with UnifiedQA sets a new state-of-the-art METEOR score, surpassing retrieval methods like BM25 and DPR [1, 4].
![RAPTOR's architecture enhances information synthesis across retrieval corpora.](image1)
RAPTOR benefits from its intermediate layers and clustering approaches, enabling it to capture a range of information, from general themes to specific details, contributing to its overall strong performance [3]. The effectiveness of RAPTOR's clustering mechanism was confirmed by ablation studies [2]. On the QASPER dataset, RAPTOR consistently outperforms BM25 and DPR across different Language Models, with F-1 Match scores surpassing DPR by margins of 1.8 to 4.5 points and BM25 by 5.5 to 10.2 points [5, 8].

The collapsed tree approach, particularly with 2000 maximum tokens, is preferred due to its flexibility and superior performance on the QASPER dataset [6]. For experiments with the UnifiedQA model, 400 tokens of context are provided, maintaining consistency across RAPTOR and the baselines, to ensure that the context does not exceed model context constraints [6]. The tree-based retrieval of RAPTOR allows it to select nodes from different tree layers, matching the question’s detail level and providing relevant and comprehensive information [10].
![The illustration depicts RAPTOR's tree-based retrieval selecting nodes from varying layers to match question detail levels.](image2)
RAPTOR demonstrates enhanced performance and flexibility by leveraging a tree structure for retrieval, where context length is managed to optimize performance within model constraints.

RAPTOR, a novel tree-based retrieval system, generally demonstrates superior performance compared to traditional methods like BM25 and DPR across various metrics and datasets [5]. In the Narrative QA dataset, RAPTOR outperforms BM25 and DPR in ROUGE-L, BLEU-1, BLEU-4, and METEOR metrics [2].

![RAPTOR compared to BM25 and DPR with accuracy percentages for each model on two different tasks](image2)

RAPTOR consistently outperforms BM25 and DPR across different Language Models on the QASPER dataset, achieving higher F-1 Match scores [3]. The superior performance is attributed to RAPTOR's ability to synthesize information within NLP papers, leveraging higher-level summary nodes, unlike methods that extract only the top-k most similar raw chunks [3].

![The table shows F-1 Match scores for different retrievers when combined with different models](image5)

Qualitative analysis reveals that RAPTOR's tree-based retrieval allows it to select nodes from different tree layers, aligning with the question's detail level, which yields more relevant and comprehensive information than DPR [7].

![Illustration of the querying process by RAPTOR](image4)

The data indicates that a substantial portion of the nodes contributing to the final retrieval comes from non-leaf layers, highlighting the importance of RAPTOR’s hierarchical summarization in the retrieval process [9].  RAPTOR consistently outperforms the respective retriever across all datasets [4]. When paired with UnifiedQA 3B, RAPTOR sets a new state-of-the-art in the METEOR metric [1].

In summary, RAPTOR generally outperforms other retrieval methods due to its hierarchical structure and ability to synthesize information across different levels of abstraction.

RAPTOR consistently demonstrates superior performance compared to other retrieval methods across various evaluation metrics and datasets [6]. For instance, on the Narrative QA dataset, RAPTOR excels, surpassing BM25 and DPR in ROUGE-L by 7.3 and 2.7 points, respectively [1]. Moreover, it outperforms BM25 and DPR in metrics like BLEU-1, BLEU-4, and METEOR, with margins ranging from 1.7 to 5.8 and 0.7 to 2.1 points, respectively [1].

RAPTOR's effectiveness is also evident on the QASPER dataset, where it outperforms BM25 and DPR across different Language Models [4]. Specifically, RAPTOR's F-1 Match scores are $53.1\%$, $55.7\%$, and $36.6\%$ when using GPT-3, GPT-4, and UnifiedQA, respectively, surpassing DPR by 1.8, 2.7, and 4.5 points, and outdoing BM25 by 6.5, 5.5, and 10.2 points across the respective LLMs [4]. The querying structure plays a crucial role, as RAPTOR's hierarchical tree structure, created through recursive clustering and summarization, synthesizes information across various sections of the retrieval corpora [9].

This hierarchical approach allows RAPTOR to capture a range of information, from general themes to specific details, contributing to its overall strong performance [10]. The upper nodes are crucial in handling thematic or multi-hop queries, which require a broader understanding of the text [3].

RAPTOR's tree-based retrieval system augments the parametric knowledge of large language models with contextual information at various levels of abstraction, leading to more effective retrieval [9].
RAPTOR outperforms other retrieval methods due to its hierarchical tree structure and ability to synthesize information across various levels of abstraction.

RAPTOR consistently demonstrates superior performance compared to other models across various datasets and language models [2, 8]. In the QASPER dataset, RAPTOR outperforms BM25 and DPR across GPT-3, GPT-4, and UnifiedQA, achieving F-1 Match scores of $53.1\%$, $55.7\%$, and $36.6\%$ respectively, surpassing DPR by 1.8, 2.7, and 4.5 points, and BM25 by 6.5, 5.5, and 10.2 points [2].

![RAPTOR outperforms BM25 and DPR in F-1 scores on the QASPER dataset across different language models.](image1)

RAPTOR paired with GPT-4 sets a new benchmark on QASPER, with a $55.7\%$ F-1 score, surpassing CoLT5 XL's score of $53.9\%$ [10]. Additionally, in the QuALITY dataset, RAPTOR achieves an accuracy of $62.4\%$, improving over DPR and BM25 by $2\%$ and $5.1\%$ respectively [7]. When paired with GPT-4 in the QuALITY dataset, RAPTOR sets a new state-of-the-art with an accuracy of $82.6\%$, outperforming CoLISA by $21.5\%$ on QuALITY-HARD [3]. Therefore, RAPTOR generally has higher F-1 Match scores and accuracy compared to other models.

RAPTOR's performance demonstrates significant improvements over existing methods across multiple datasets and evaluation metrics. On the QASPER dataset, RAPTOR consistently outperforms BM25 and DPR across different language models like GPT-3, GPT-4, and UnifiedQA [4]. For instance, RAPTOR achieves F-1 scores of $53.1\%$, $55.7\%$, and $36.6\%$ with GPT-3, GPT-4, and UnifiedQA, respectively, surpassing DPR by 1.8 to 4.5 points and BM25 by 6.5 to 10.2 points [4]. Furthermore, RAPTOR with GPT-4 sets a new benchmark on QASPER, achieving a $55.7\%$ F-1 score, which exceeds CoLT5 XL's score of $53.9\%$ [3].

In the Narrative QA dataset, RAPTOR, when combined with UnifiedQA 3B, surpasses retrieval methods like BM25 and DPR and establishes a new state-of-the-art in the METEOR metric [2]. (2021), RAPTOR shows superior performance across all metrics, leveraging its intermediate layers and clustering approaches to capture a wide range of information [6]. Similarly, on the QuALITY dataset, RAPTOR achieves an accuracy of $62.4\%$, outperforming DPR and BM25 by $2\%$ and $5.1\%$, respectively [7]. When paired with GPT-4 on the QuALITY dataset, RAPTOR sets a new state-of-the-art with an accuracy of $82.6\%$, surpassing the previous best result by $21.5\%$ on QuALITY-HARD [8]. RAPTOR’s hierarchical summarization proves crucial, as a substantial portion of retrieved nodes comes from non-leaf layers, particularly the first and second layers [10]. RAPTOR consistently demonstrates superior performance by effectively utilizing its tree-based structure to synthesize information at various abstraction levels [9].

RAPTOR consistently outperforms traditional retrieval methods and sets new benchmarks across various question-answering tasks and datasets.

When evaluating the performance of models like Chameleon, Gemini, and GPT-4, human annotators play a crucial role in assessing the quality and relevance of the responses. The agreement level among these annotators provides insights into the consistency and reliability of the evaluations [10]. In absolute evaluations, annotators generally show high agreement on objective aspects such as whether the content is objectionable or not [1].

![The bar chart showing inter-annotator agreement on various factors including task fulfillment and relevance, with "All" agreement being the most frequent.](image4)

Specifically, when considering task fulfillment, Chameleon demonstrates a higher percentage of fully fulfilled tasks compared to Gemini+ and GPT-4V+ [2]. Furthermore, the relevance and quality of the generated images also contribute to the overall appeal of Chameleon's mixed-modal responses [3].  The agreement levels among annotators vary, with a significant portion showing unanimous judgments and a smaller fraction showing disagreements [9].

In relative evaluations, where Chameleon is directly compared against other models, annotator agreement also plays a key role.  As shown in the agreement statistics, there are instances where all three annotators agree, two agree, or there is no agreement, reflecting the complexities in assessing model performance [9].  Despite these variations, Chameleon generally achieves competitive win rates against baseline models like Gemini and GPT-4V [8].

The inter-annotator agreement for task fulfillment and relevance is generally high, with the majority of cases showing either unanimous agreement or agreement between two out of three annotators, indicating a reasonable level of consistency in evaluating Chameleon's performance.

In relative evaluations, agreement levels among annotators vary, with unanimous judgments occurring in approximately 28% to 35% of cases, while about 55% to 60% of pairs show agreement between two annotators [1]. Instances of no agreement occur in slightly above 10% of cases [1]. The table details annotator agreement levels for comparisons between Chameleon and other models, showing the number and percentage of instances with different levels of agreement ![The table provides statistics about agreement levels among annotators for different comparisons involving Chameleon, Gemini, and GPT-4 models](image2).

Absolute evaluations involve assessing each model's output separately, focusing on relevance and quality [4]. Figure 10 shows the levels of agreement on each question in the absolute evaluation [3]. The inter-annotator agreement on questions in the absolute evaluation generally shows high counts for "All" agreement across categories such as image quality, relevance, and task fulfillment ![The image is a horizontal bar chart, which indicates the inter-annotator agreement on the questions in the absolute evaluation](image4). For simple, objective properties, annotators rarely disagree; for example, there are unanimous judgments on whether responses contain objectionable content [2].

Chameleon and its comparison models show varying levels of inter-annotator agreement, with higher agreement on objective properties and more variability in relative evaluations.

Chameleon's safety was evaluated using crowdsourced prompts and red teaming to provoke unsafe content generation, with annotators labeling responses as safe, unsafe, or unsure [9].  The safety evaluations vary between models with different parameters and datasets. ![The table presents data about the safety evaluation of different models with varying parameters using two types of datasets: "Crowdsourced" and "Red Team."](image3) For crowdsourced data, the 7B parameter model showed 99.2% safe responses, while the 34B parameter model showed 99.7% safe responses [9].  The Red Team dataset evaluation for the 34B parameter model resulted in 93.9% safe, 1.6% unsafe, and 4.5% unsure responses, highlighting the impact of different datasets on safety assessments [9].

The level of agreement among annotators in model comparisons involving Chameleon varies, as indicated by the instances of agreement. ![The table provides statistics about agreement levels among annotators for different comparisons involving Chameleon, Gemini, and GPT-4 models (both standard and enhanced versions denoted by a "+").](image1) For instance, when comparing Chameleon to Gemini+, all three annotators agreed in 31.5% of cases, while there was no agreement in 10.3% of cases [2].  Similarly, when comparing Chameleon to GPT-4V+, all three annotators agreed in 35.4% of cases, with no agreement in 9.3% of cases [2].  Overall, there is unanimous judgment in about 28% to 35% of pairs, and one annotator differs from the other two in about 55% to 60% of pairs, which suggests that Chameleon performs similarly to other baselines in many cases, making the relative evaluation challenging [2].

In summary, safety evaluations differ based on model parameters and datasets, and annotator agreement in Chameleon comparisons varies, with a notable percentage of cases showing either unanimous agreement or disagreement among annotators.

Chameleon models show high safety ratings, particularly the 34B parameter model, which achieves 99.7% safe on crowdsourced datasets and 93.9% on red team datasets ![The table highlights how the safety assessment varied across different datasets and model sizes](image4).

In terms of benchmarks, Chameleon models demonstrate strong performance in commonsense reasoning and reading comprehension tasks, even outperforming Llama-2 70B on several tasks [3]. Furthermore, they exhibit robust math capabilities, with Chameleon-34B outperforming Llama2-70B on GSM8k and approaching the performance of Mixtral 8x7B on MATH ![Each entry in the table provides performance results, indicating how well these models perform on the respective tasks. The table helps compare the relative efficacy of different AI models across a variety of AI/ML challenges](image5) [6].

Chameleon models maintain competitive performance on text-only benchmarks while achieving state-of-the-art results in visual question answering and image captioning tasks [10]. They also demonstrate impressive mixed-modal reasoning and generation capabilities [2].

The Chameleon models exhibit high safety ratings and strong performance in both benchmark evaluations for reasoning and math tasks.

RAR enhances few-shot recognition abilities for datasets with extensive vocabularies [8]. The "RAR (LLaVA1.5)" model demonstrates improved performance over "CLIP+KNN" in both common and fine-grained datasets, as illustrated in the table ![RAR (LLaVA1.5) generally outperforms CLIP+KNN across different datasets.](image1). In scenarios with many fine-grained categories, RAR also achieved improvements [10]. The results in the table show that RAR models, including RAR (LLaVA1.5), generally improve Average Precision metrics compared to baseline models like CLIP, suggesting enhanced performance in object recognition tasks ![RAR (LLaVA1.5) and other RAR variants show improvements in Average Precision metrics compared to the CLIP baseline.](image5).

RAR demonstrates a significant improvement, especially in handling rare categories, by leveraging external memory and reranking mechanisms [3]. The results from 1-shot to 16-shot experiments indicate that RAR's results improve over the CLIP+KNN method, showcasing its excellence in image classification tasks, including fine-grained image classification [9]. The table highlights that "RAR (LLaVA1.5)" shows generally better performance compared to "CLIP+KNN," with improvements highlighted in green ![RAR (LLaVA1.5) shows generally better performance compared to CLIP+KNN, especially in fine-grained datasets.](image4). When applying RAR, notable improvements are observed in all metrics, especially when combined with the InternLM-XC2 model [7]. The RAR models enhance performance across various metrics compared to the baseline CLIP models, with RAR (InternLM-XC2) showing the highest improvements, especially in the AP_r metric ![RAR models generally improve performance metrics compared to the CLIP baseline.](image3). The RAR (LLaVA1.5) model exhibits competitive scores, showing improvements in several categories [2]. Overall, RAR (LLaVA1.5) demonstrates enhanced capabilities in both fine-grained visual recognition and zero-shot object recognition by leveraging retrieval and ranking mechanisms [8, 10].

RAR (LLaVA1.5) enhances performance in both fine-grained visual recognition and zero-shot object recognition through its retrieval and ranking mechanisms.

The RAR approach significantly enhances zero-shot object recognition performance compared to baseline models by leveraging MLLMs for ranking and refining initial predictions [8]. For example, on the V3Det dataset, RAR surpasses the CLIP baseline by 1.5 percentage points in overall average precision, demonstrating robust performance in handling a challenging array of 13,204 distinct classes [9].

The experimental results also demonstrate that the integration of RAR to MLLMs plays a pivotal role, showing a substantial advantage in identifying rare categories [7]. The RAR method achieves peak performance on   $A P_{r}$, surpassing the CLIP model by as much as 19.6 percentage points [7]. This is attributed to the retrieving and reranking mechanism effectively pooling relevant information from external memory, providing MLLMs with a richer context for rare class identification [7].

![The table presents performance metrics for various models in object detection or recognition, possibly using the CLIP model with bounding boxes](image1)

As shown in the table, RAR models (LLaVA1.5, Qwen-VL, and InternLM-XC2) achieve higher Average Precision (AP) scores compared to the baseline CLIP model with bounding boxes [image1]. Specifically, InternLM-XC2 achieves improvements of +2.9, +0.2, +1.7, and +1.5 across various AP metrics [image1].

![The table compares performance metrics (AP_r, AP_c, AP_f, AP_all) for different models and configurations](image2)

Moreover, the RAR models demonstrate improvements over the RegionCLIP baseline, with InternLM-XC2 showing the highest improvements across most metrics [image2]. This indicates that RAR effectively enhances the ability of MLLMs to discern and accurately classify objects, addressing a significant challenge in long-tailed distribution datasets [7]. The visualization results demonstrate that RAR meets the need for fine-grained and large vocabulary recognition [1].

In zero-shot object recognition, RAR models consistently outperform baseline models by refining the object labels and improving classification accuracy, especially in datasets with extensive and fine-grained vocabularies [5, 8].

The multimodal retriever system employs a specific methodology for processing and ranking objects in detection datasets, which involves initial pre-processing steps and subsequent embedding and retrieval processes [8]. To enhance the MLLMs’ focus on relevant objects, a blurring technique is applied to non-target areas [8].

First, the images undergo pre-processing, where objects within the image are identified using bounding boxes, cropped, and resized to create individual embeddings using an Image Encoder ![The diagram illustrates how pre-processing techniques like cropping and resizing assist in zero-shot recognition for object detection tasks using multimodal retrieval methods.](image4).  Since CLIP’s ability to extract features from low-resolution images is limited, image-to-text retrieval is conducted using CLIP's inherent image-text interaction capabilities to obtain the top-k category information [6].

These image embeddings are then utilized in a k-nearest neighbors (k-NN) search, and an index is created for these embeddings, linked to a memory storage [8]. The blurring strategy is designed to direct the MLLMs’ focus toward the relevant objects, thereby facilitating their identification in object detection tasks [8]. The MLLMs rank the retrieved candidate results as the final prediction results [9]. To bolster the MLLMs’ ranking performance, fine-tuning with ranking format data or in-context learning examples without training are explored [9]. By integrating retrieval-augmented design, the approach bridges the gap between the broad generalization capabilities of MLLMs and the need for precise, fine-grained categorization [9].

In detection datasets, the system crops image regions based on proposal bounding box coordinates, resizes the cropped region to a fixed proportion, and applies a blurring technique to non-target areas to direct the MLLMs’ focus [8].

Step-Back + RAG demonstrates varying degrees of effectiveness in mitigating errors across different datasets. On TimeQA, Step-Back + RAG is able to correct a substantial portion of wrong baseline predictions.  Specifically, it fixes 39.9% of the predictions where the baseline is wrong, while introducing errors in only 5.6% of cases [4]. Furthermore, it rectifies 21.6% of errors originating from RAG, with Step-Back introducing a relatively low 6.3% of errors to RAG [4]. ![Step-Back + RAG corrects a substantial portion of wrong baseline predictions on TimeQA.](image2)

In contrast, the error analysis for StrategyQA reveals a different pattern. Step-Back + RAG corrects 15.4% of wrong baseline predictions and introduces errors in 6.1% of cases [3, 10]. It fixes 12.7% of errors from RAG, while Step-Back introduces just 4.4% of errors to RAG [3, 10]. These results suggest that Step-Back + RAG is more effective at improving performance on TimeQA compared to StrategyQA, as it fixes a larger percentage of baseline errors and RAG errors while introducing a similar or lower percentage of new errors.

These differences are significant considering the nature of the datasets. TimeQA involves temporal reasoning, and StrategyQA requires more complex, multi-hop reasoning [7].  The initial abstraction provided by Step-Back makes the information retrieval easier, but a large portion of errors, about 45%, are due to failure in retrieving the correct information [6]. This highlights the difficulty of the TimeQA task [6]. The ability of Step-Back + RAG to more effectively fix errors on TimeQA suggests it's particularly useful for tasks where initial reasoning and abstraction can significantly aid in retrieving and processing relevant information.

In summary, Step-Back + RAG shows a greater error correction rate on TimeQA compared to StrategyQA, indicating its increased effectiveness for tasks that benefit from enhanced information retrieval following initial reasoning.

The Step-Back prompting method demonstrates significant improvements and specific error profiles compared to other prompting and augmentation techniques. In Knowledge QA tasks, Step-Back + RAG achieves a remarkable 68.7% accuracy on TimeQA [4]. The table of performance shows that PaLM-2L + Step-Back + RAG achieves the highest accuracy on TimeQA and TQA Easy benchmarks compared to other methods ![The table shows the performance of different methods on four benchmarks: TimeQA, TQA Easy, TQA Hard, and SituatedQA.](image1).

Error analysis reveals that Step-Back prompting fixes a substantial portion of errors made by baseline models. Specifically, it corrects 39.9% of incorrect predictions by PaLM-2L while introducing only 5.6% new errors [5]. Furthermore, it rectifies 21.6% of errors originating from RAG, with a relatively low error introduction rate of 6.3% [5]. Despite its effectiveness, Step-Back prompting is not without limitations. The primary error source is reasoning errors, as shown in the error analysis on high-school physics questions using the MMLU dataset ![The image contains two main parts related to error analysis in high-school physics using Step-Back Prompting on the MMLU dataset.](image2). In MMLU Physics and Chemistry tasks, PaLM-2L with Step-Back prompting outperforms other PaLM-2L variants and even surpasses GPT-4, achieving 73.2% and 81.8% accuracy, respectively ![The table presents performance metrics for different methods on two datasets: MMLU Physics and MMLU Chemistry.](image5). Ablation studies indicate that the performance of Step-Back prompting remains robust regardless of the number of exemplars used [9].

Step-Back prompting enhances model performance by addressing key limitations in baseline models and RAG, with reasoning errors being the most significant remaining challenge.

`STEP-BACK PROMPTING` significantly improves performance across various Knowledge QA tasks [3]. In TimeQA, baseline models like GPT-4 and PaLM-2L achieve accuracies of $45.6\%$ and $41.5\%$ respectively [9]. Augmenting the baseline model with regular retrieval augmentation (RAG) improves accuracy to $57.4\%$, but combining Step-Back with RAG leads to a remarkable $68.7\%$ accuracy [9]. ![PaLM-2L with Step-Back and RAG demonstrates the highest performance on TimeQA.](image2) shows that `PaLM-2L + Step-Back + RAG` achieves the highest performance on TimeQA (68.7\%) and TQA Easy (75.2\%). On Multi-Hop Reasoning tasks, baseline performances of PaLM-2L and GPT-4 are low in MuSiQue ($35.5\%$ and $38.5\%$ respectively), while StrategyQA has stronger baselines ($82.8\%$ and $78.3\%$ respectively) [1]. `STEP-BACK PROMPTING` produces the best performance, reaching $42.8\%$ in MuSiQue and $86.4\%$ in StrategyQA, significantly outperforming GPT-4 [1]. ![Step-Back with RAG achieves the highest performance on both MuSiQue and StrategyQA datasets.](image5) shows that `PaLM-2L + Step-Back + RAG` achieves the highest performance on both MuSiQue (42.8%) and StrategyQA (86.4%) datasets.

Error analysis reveals that reasoning errors are the most frequent when using `STEP-BACK PROMPTING` [4]. More than half of the errors are due to reasoning errors, and $45\%$ are due to failing to retrieve the right information, despite the abstraction provided by step-back [10]. ![Reasoning Error is the dominating error source when using Step-Back.](image3) shows that Reasoning Error is a significant error source.  ![The majority of errors in Step-Back Prompting are attributed to reasoning.](image4) indicates that reasoning errors are the most frequent when using `STEP-BACK PROMPTING`, with math errors also being significant. The step-back question generated is not always helpful, and RAG sometimes fails to retrieve relevant information even when the step-back question is on target [2]. However, `STEP-BACK PROMPTING` is robust against the number of exemplars used in demonstration, highlighting the sample efficiency of learning abstraction skills [5].

In summary, `STEP-BACK PROMPTING`, especially when combined with RAG, generally enhances performance across various QA tasks compared to GPT-4, with reasoning errors being the most common challenge.

Step-Back Prompting, particularly when combined with Retrieval-Augmented Generation (RAG), shows significant performance improvements across various Knowledge QA tasks [5]. On TimeQA, the baseline models of GPT-4 and PaLM-2L achieved $45.6\%$ and $41.5\%$ respectively, but Step-Back + RAG significantly improved the accuracy to $68.7\%$ [4]. The table illustrates that PaLM-2L + Step-Back + RAG achieves the highest performance on TimeQA, specifically $68.7\%$ ![PaLM-2L + Step-Back + RAG achieves the highest performance on TimeQA, specifically 68.7%.](image2).

On the MuSiQue dataset, baseline performances of PaLM-2L and GPT4 are low ($35.5\%$ and $38.5\%$ respectively) [7]. However, Step-Back Prompting with RAG produces the best performance of all methods, achieving $42.8\%$ [7]. As shown in the table, PaLM-2L + Step-Back + RAG achieves the highest performance on MuSiQue, specifically 42.8% ![PaLM-2L + Step-Back + RAG achieves the highest performance on MuSiQue, specifically 42.8%.](image5).

Similarly, for StrategyQA, Step-Back Prompting with RAG significantly outperforms GPT-4, achieving $86.4\%$ [7].

Step-Back Prompting enhances performance by abstracting high-level concepts, facilitating more reliable retrieval augmentation [4]. This approach breaks down complex tasks into abstraction and reasoning steps, leveraging LLMs' reasoning capabilities and reducing reasoning failures [6].

In summary, PaLM-2L with Step-Back and RAG consistently demonstrates superior performance across TimeQA, MuSiQue, and StrategyQA by leveraging abstraction and enhanced retrieval augmentation.

The dataset is designed to represent a wide array of real-world entities across 22 primary categories [8, 9]. Entity popularity, measured by average Wikipedia pageviews, reveals that entities in the celebrity category have the highest average popularity [5].

The statistics for the number of entities in each category are represented in the donut chart, where 'Landmark' constitutes 9.9% and 'Celebrity' constitutes 9.7% of the entities. ![The number of entities in the landmark and celebrity categories are 9.9% and 9.7% respectively.](image5)

In contrast, pageview statistics show a different distribution.  The donut chart indicates that the celebrity category accounts for 49.3% of the total pageviews, while landmarks account for only 9.1%. ![Celebrities account for 49.3% of the total pageviews, while landmarks account for only 9.1%.](image1)

The celebrity category has a substantially higher percentage of pageviews compared to its entity percentage, indicating a greater public interest or awareness compared to landmarks.

The SnapNTell model's architecture uses retrieval augmentation to find relevant information about the entity in the image, and this information is combined with the question before being fed into the word embedding layer ![The SnapNTell model architecture uses retrieval augmentation to source relevant information about the entity in the image and combines it with the question before feeding it into the word embedding layer.](image1). The inclusion of entity detection (ED) significantly contributes to the model's overall effectiveness [2].

Retrieval augmentation (RA) significantly enhances performance across various entity types, particularly improving performance for torso-to-tail entities, which effectively addresses hallucinations in long-tailed entities [1]. The retrieval-augmented multimodal LLM surpasses the performance of all existing baseline models, emphasizing the efficiency of retrieval augmentation in producing responses enriched with entity-centric information [4]. The model uses a novel task for entity-centric VQA, designed to assess the proficiency of models in accurately identifying and generating responses that exhibit a deep comprehension of these identified entities [5].

The inclusion of both entity detection and retrieval augmentation enhances the SnapNTell model's accuracy and reduces hallucination rates, especially for long-tail entities.

The SnapNTell model demonstrates superior performance compared to existing baseline models, particularly excelling in producing responses enriched with entity-centric information [5]. This highlights the substantial impact of retrieval augmentation on the task [5]. The model's architecture begins with retrieval augmentation to source relevant information about the entity in the image, and this information, along with the question, feeds into the word embedding layer. Text embeddings merge with image-projected embeddings before entering the LLM, culminating in a knowledgeable answer as the output [2].

![The SnapNTell model architecture takes an image-question pair as input, uses retrieval augmentation, and merges text and image embeddings before feeding into the LLM.](image2)

The model's effectiveness is also significantly enhanced by its entity detection (ED) component [10]. When compared to a variant lacking this feature, the approach incorporating entity detection markedly surpasses it, underscoring the necessity of the entity detection step [10]. Evaluations of the model include assessments of recognition accuracy, response accuracy, and pairwise comparisons [1]. The SnapNTell dataset is particularly effective in evaluating a model's capabilities to recognize entities and produce responses centered around these entities [8]. The model outperforms baselines by displaying a significantly smaller difference when measured against manually annotated ground-truth samples, highlighting its robustness [7].

Therefore, the SnapNTell model outperforms existing baselines in accuracy due to retrieval augmentation and entity detection.

The inclusion of entity detection (ED) significantly enhances the performance of the SnapNTell model [4]. The approach incorporating entity detection markedly surpasses the variant lacking this feature [4]. This highlights the significant contribution and necessity of the entity detection step in the model’s overall effectiveness [4].

In summary, incorporating entity detection is crucial for the effectiveness of the SnapNTell model.

SnapNTell is evaluated using both established NLP metrics and human evaluations [9]. NLP metrics such as BLEU, METEOR, ROUGE, and BLEURT are used to assess answer quality [9].

![Table 3 shows that the proposed retrieval-augmented multimodal LLM surpasses the performance of all existing baseline models, emphasizing the efficiency of retrieval augmentation in producing responses enriched with entity-centric information.](image1)

The retrieval-augmented multimodal LLM proposed for SnapNTell surpasses the performance of existing baseline models across all metrics [7]. Human evaluation results suggest there is still potential for improvement [2]. Although the approach often neared human-level performance, it did not consistently outperform human annotations [2].

In summary, SnapNTell outperforms existing baseline models according to NLP metrics, but human evaluations indicate room for further improvement to consistently match or exceed human-level performance.

SPECTER generally outperforms other models in document classification and citation prediction [5]. Specifically, in document classification, SPECTER achieves an F1 score of 86.4 on the MeSH dataset, a notable increase over the best baseline [5]. In predicting user activity, SPECTER attains a MAP score of 83.8 on the co-view task and 84.5 on the co-read task, also surpassing the best baseline [5]. For recommendation tasks, SPECTER also outperforms other models, achieving an nDCG of 53.9 [8].

<![SPECTER excels in classification, user activity prediction, citation prediction, and recommendation tasks, often outperforming other baseline models.](image3)>

The superiority of SPECTER embeddings in encoding topical information is also visually evident, as demonstrated by more compact clusters in the embedding space [6].  The homogeneity and completeness values for SPECTER are 0.41 and 0.72, respectively, compared to SciBERT's 0.19 and 0.63, indicating a clear improvement in topic separation [6].

<![SPECTER's clustering shows clearer separation between topics compared to SciBERT.](image2)>

SPECTER demonstrates enhanced performance in document classification and citation prediction compared to other models, and it exhibits improved topic separation in visual clustering compared to SciBERT [5, 6].

The SPECTER model demonstrates substantial improvements across various tasks, achieving an average performance of 80.0 across all metrics, which is a 3.1 point absolute improvement over the next-best baseline [1]. ![SPECTER compared to SciBERT shows better topic separation.](image1) When comparing SPECTER embeddings with SciBERT, SPECTER embeddings are better at encoding topical information, with more compact clusters [8]. The homogeneity and completeness values for SPECTER are 0.41 and 0.72 respectively, compared to SciBERT’s 0.19 and 0.63, indicating a clear improvement in separating topics using the projected embeddings [8].

SPECTER outperforms other models in document classification, user activity prediction, citation prediction, and recommendation tasks [7]. ![SPECTER outperforms other models in various tasks, achieving the highest average score.](image3) For document classification, SPECTER achieves an F1 score of 86.4 on the MeSH dataset and 82.0 on the MAG dataset, which is a  $\Delta{=}+2.3$ and (+1.5) point absolute increase over the best baseline on each dataset respectively [6]. In user activity prediction, SPECTER achieves a MAP score of 83.8 on the co-view task and 84.5 on the co-read task, improving over the best baseline by 2.7 and 4.0 points, respectively [6]. SPECTER also outperforms all other models on the recommendation task, with an nDCG of 53.9 [7].

Removing the abstract from the textual input results in a substantial decrease in performance, while adding authors as an input hurts performance [3]. ![The table shows the ablation study of SPECTER, indicating performance changes when metadata is added or removed.](image5) One possible explanation is that author names are sparse in the corpus, making it difficult for the model to infer document-level relatedness from them [3]. Adding venues slightly decreases performance, except on document classification [3].

SPECTER's design includes hard negative distractors in the citation-based fine-tuning objective, which is important, as using only easy negatives reduces performance on all tasks [5]. ![SPECTER model architecture emphasizing the use of triplet loss for training with related and unrelated papers.](image2) Using a strong general-domain language model (BERT-Large) instead of SciBERT in SPECTER reduces performance considerably, highlighting the importance of pretraining on scientific text [5].

In summary, the SPECTER model generally outperforms other models across a range of tasks, and while venue data can improve document classification, author data tends to hurt performance.

SPECTER demonstrates superior performance compared to SciBERT in various tasks, as it leverages a Transformer language model pretrained on citations [4]. S PECTER does not require fine-tuning, which reduces the cost of using its paper embeddings [5].

Notably, using a strong general-domain language model like BERT-Large instead of SciBERT in SPECTER reduces performance, because SciBERT is pre-trained on scientific text [1]. SPECTER also uses hard negative distractors in its citation-based fine-tuning objective, which is important for maintaining performance across all tasks [1]. ![SPECTER uses a transformer model initialized with SciBERT to generate paper embeddings using triplet loss.](image4)

Visualizations of SPECTER embeddings compared with SciBERT embeddings reveal that SPECTER excels at encoding topical information, resulting in more compact clusters [2]. The homogeneity and completeness values for SPECTER are 0.41 and 0.72, respectively, compared to SciBERT's 0.19 and 0.63, marking a significant improvement in topic separation using the projected embeddings [2]. ![SPECTER's clustering of academic topics is more compact and separated than SciBERT's, as shown in t-SNE projections.](image2)

SPECTER outperforms SciBERT even without additional final task-specific fine-tuning, further demonstrating its effectiveness and versatility [3]. As shown in the table, S PECTER consistently achieves higher scores across various metrics compared to SciBERT fine-tuned on different tasks [5]. ![SPECTER consistently achieves higher scores across various metrics compared to SciBERT fine-tuned on different tasks.](image5)

SPECTER demonstrates superior performance and better topical encoding compared to SciBERT, making it a more effective model for scientific document representation.

SPECTER demonstrates superior performance compared to SciBERT when fine-tuned on task-specific signals for document classification.  Notably, without additional fine-tuning, SPECTER outperforms a SciBERT model that is fine-tuned on end tasks and their multitask combination [3].
![SPECTER consistently outperforms SciBERT across various document-related tasks](image3)
SPECTER achieves the highest scores across most metrics, including CLS, USR, CITE, REC and ALL, when compared to different variations of SciBERT fine-tuned on different tasks [3]. The t-SNE projections also indicate that SPECTER's embeddings are better at encoding topical information compared to SciBERT, leading to more compact clusters [1, 9].
![SPECTER exhibits better clustering of academic topics compared to SciBERT](image2)
This is further supported by the homogeneity and completeness values, where SPECTER achieves 0.41 and 0.72, respectively, compared to SciBERT's 0.19 and 0.63 [9].

The enhancements to BERT-MRC models, such as the addition of Focal Loss (FL), Dice Loss (DL), and DSC loss, show varying degrees of improvement across different datasets. On the CoNLL 2003 dataset, BERT-MRC+DSC achieves an F1 score of 93.33, which is a +0.29 improvement over the baseline BERT-MRC ![BERT-MRC+DSC achieves an F1 score of 93.33 on the CoNLL 2003 dataset, a +0.29 improvement.](image1). Similarly, on the OntoNotes 5.0 dataset, BERT-MRC+DSC reaches an F1 score of 92.07, representing a +0.96 increase [3] compared to the base BERT-MRC model ![BERT-MRC+DSC achieves an F1 score of 92.07 on the OntoNotes 5.0 dataset, a +0.96 increase.](image4).

Looking at Chinese datasets, BERT-MRC+DSC also demonstrates strong performance.  On MSRA and OntoNotes 4.0, BERT-MRC+DSC achieves the highest F1-scores [3, 4], consistently outperforming other variations ![BERT-MRC+DSC model shows the highest F1-scores in both the Chinese MSRA and Chinese OntoNotes 4.0 datasets.](image2).  For the MRC task, DSC loss boosts performance on both EM and F1 scores with either BERT or XLNet [5]. The performance improvements from FL and DL are less consistent, while DSC consistently performs the best across all datasets [6].

In summary, BERT-MRC models enhanced with DSC consistently show the highest F1-score improvements across various datasets, indicating its robustness and effectiveness.

The DSC loss enhancement significantly improves the performance of BERT-MRC on NER datasets [9]. The results indicate that DSC outperforms BERT-MRC by +0.29 on CoNLL2003 and +0.96 on OntoNotes5.0 [9].

Therefore, the DSC enhancement improves BERT-MRC performance on both the English CoNLL 2003 and English OntoNotes 5.0 datasets.

The DSC loss enhancements significantly improve the performance of models on various datasets [5]. Specifically, DSC outperforms BERT-MRC on CoNLL2003 and MSRA datasets, achieving improvements of $+0.29$ and $+0.97$, respectively [1].

The DSC loss, when applied to either BERT or XLNet, yields a significant performance boost on both EM and F1 scores [5]. For SQuADv1.1, DSC outperforms XLNet by $+1.25$ in F1 score and $+0.84$ in EM [5]. The image shows the models achieve state-of-the-art performance across four NER datasets.

Therefore, the DSC loss enhancement significantly improves the performance of both BERT-MRC and XLNet models on the English CoNLL2003 and Chinese MSRA datasets.

The enhancements FL, DL, and DSC generally improve the performance of both BERT and XLNet across various datasets and tasks. For machine reading comprehension (MRC) tasks, the DSC loss obtains significant performance boosts on both EM and F1 [4].  For SQuADv1.1, the proposed method outperforms XLNet by +1.25 in terms of F1 score and +0.84 in terms of EM [4]. For SQuAD v2.0, the proposed method achieves 87.65 on EM and 89.51 on F1, while on QuoRef, the proposed method surpasses XLNet by +1.46 on EM and +1.41 on F1 [4].

![The table compares the performance of different models on various datasets for question answering tasks.](image1)

Specifically, BERT and its variants show improvements with FL, DL, and DSC enhancements, providing small incremental gains in EM and F1, with BERT+DSC often achieving the highest scores among BERT variants. XLNet itself performs better than BERT, and its enhancements (FL, DL, DSC) further improve performance slightly, with XLNet+DSC achieving the highest scores overall as shown in table 6 [4]. For the paraphrase identification task, the table shows F1 scores for different models on the MRPC and QQP datasets, with +DSC achieving the highest scores in both datasets for both models, showing the most significant improvements.  The values in parentheses represent the increase in F1 scores compared to the baseline models [image4].

![This table presents the performance metrics of several variations of the BERT model under different conditions.](image2)

However, the proposed dice loss is not accuracy-oriented and should not be used for accuracy-oriented tasks [9]. COMET-Rank and BLEU are both metrics used to evaluate the quality of machine translations, but they differ significantly in their approach and performance [1]. BLEU relies on n-gram matching, counting the number of simultaneous n-grams in a candidate translation and human references [1]. COMET, on the other hand, uses a neural framework to train MT evaluation models, allowing it to capture more nuanced aspects of translation quality [3].

The table `![The table presents the results of a translation performance metric called COMET-RANK for various language pairs.](image1)` shows the performance of COMET-RANK with and without reference translations across several language pairs. The "Δτ" values indicate the improvement in COMET-RANK scores when references are included, suggesting that references enhance the metric's accuracy.  In contrast, BLEU's performance is often surpassed by COMET metrics, as illustrated in the evaluation across different language pairs [9, 10].

Looking at the language pairs where English is the target, COMET models often outperform or are competitive with other metrics, including BLEU [2]. For instance, in the language pairs evaluated in the  graphs `![The image contains five line graphs, each representing the performance of different machine translation (MT) evaluation metrics over various top MT systems translated into English from different languages.](image2)`, COMET-RANK generally maintains a higher Kendall Tau score compared to BLEU across different numbers of top-performing MT systems.

The performance comparison across various metrics and language pairs as displayed in `![The table presents evaluation metrics for machine translation systems across various language pairs.](image3)` and `![The table presents the performance of various metrics for evaluating machine translation quality across three language pairs.](image4)` further supports this observation. COMET-RANK often achieves the highest scores compared to BLEU. The trends from English to another language (bottom graph) and from another language to English (top graph) in `![The image consists of two line graphs that display the performance of various metrics across different sets of machine translation (MT) systems.](image5)` clearly show that COMET metrics generally outperform BLEU, indicating a higher correlation with human judgments.

In summary, COMET-RANK generally outperforms BLEU in evaluating translation quality across different language pairs due to its ability to capture semantic similarity beyond lexical matching.

CodeBERT shows enhanced performance compared to other models in NL-PL probing tasks [7]. The results indicate that CodeBERT generally outperforms baselines like RoBERTa across almost all languages in both NL and PL probing tasks. ![CodeBERT (MLM) demonstrates superior overall scores in programming language probing compared to Roberta and Pre-Train w/ Code Only](image2) As shown in the table, CodeBERT (MLM) achieves an overall score of 85.66 in PL probing, which is significantly higher than RoBERTa's 62.45 and the model pre-trained with code only at 74.11 [image2].

Even when considering only the preceding context, CodeBERT (MLM) maintains a competitive edge, with an overall score of 59.12 compared to RoBERTa's 52.24 and the pre-trained with code only model's 56.71 [image2]. This suggests that CodeBERT is more effective in understanding and utilizing contextual information in both natural and programming languages. The architecture of CodeBERT, trained with both MLM and RTD objectives, allows it to generalize better to unseen programming languages [4]. Furthermore, language can improve code-to-NL generation [1].

CodeBERT consistently outperforms RoBERTa, a purely natural language-based pre-trained model [7]. As illustrated in another table, CodeBERT (RTD+MLM) generally achieves the highest scores across all programming languages, underscoring its superior performance compared to other models [image5].

CodeBERT demonstrates better performance in probing tasks compared to other models across different programming and natural languages.

The DS-DST and DS-Picklist models are designed to improve dialog state tracking (DST) by leveraging different strategies for handling categorical and non-categorical slots [9]. DS-DST uses a dual-strategy approach, while DS-Picklist assumes a full ontology is available and treats all domain-slot pairs as categorical slots [1, 9].

The joint accuracy of DS-DST and DS-Picklist can be compared with other models, including BERT-based approaches. DS-DST achieves a joint accuracy of 51.21% on MultiWOZ 2.1, while DS-Picklist achieves 53.30% [1, 5]. Both DS-DST and DS-Picklist outperform BERT-DST, which has a joint accuracy of 43.40% ![The table presents a comparison of different models based on their joint accuracy.](image1).

When comparing DS-Span and DS-DST, it is evident that jointly using non-categorical and categorical approaches is helpful in multi-domain DST [6]. DS-Picklist further improves performance when the model has access to the full ontology [6]. DS-Picklist's higher performance compared to DS-DST suggests the advantage of using a full ontology, though it may not always be available in real scenarios [6].

Looking at slot-level accuracy, DS-DST and DS-Picklist show significant improvements over DS-Span for slots like `hotel-type`, `attraction-type`, `attraction-name`, `hotel-internet`, and `hotel-parking` [3]. This improvement occurs because the values for these slots often have varied expressions that are difficult to extract directly from the dialog context, whereas DS-DST and DS-Picklist can predict these values directly from candidate-value lists [3].
![The table displays accuracy percentages for various slots across three different models: DS-Span, DS-DST, and DS-Picklist.](image5)

In summary, DS-Picklist generally achieves higher joint and slot accuracy compared to DS-DST, especially for categorical slots with values that are not easily extracted from the dialog context, making it a more effective approach when a full ontology is available.

The DS-DST and DS-Picklist models demonstrate varying performance across different slots in the MultiWOZ 2.1 dataset [2]. DS-Picklist generally shows higher accuracy, but accessing the full ontology in real scenarios can be challenging [5].

![DS-Picklist generally shows higher accuracy](image1)

The table shows slot-level accuracy on the MultiWOZ 2.1 test set [7]. DS-DST improves significantly over DS-Span for slots like 'hotel-type', 'attraction-type', 'attraction-name', 'hotel-internet', and 'hotel-parking' [2].  These slots benefit from direct prediction from candidate-value lists rather than extraction from dialog context [2]. DS-Picklist can further reduce error rates, especially when the predicted values are found in candidate-value lists [3].

![DS-Picklist can further reduce error rates](image5)

While DS-Picklist generally outperforms DS-DST, slots like 'taxi-leave at' and 'train-arrive by' remain challenging for both, as these are span-based slots without span matching in the dialogue context [3]. The results show the effectiveness of jointly using non-categorical and categorical approaches in multi-domain DST [5].

In conclusion, while both models improve upon the DS-Span model, DS-Picklist generally performs better overall, with specific advantages in slots where values can be predicted from candidate lists.

The DS-Picklist model generally outperforms both DS-DST and DS-Span, particularly when a full ontology is accessible [1]. The architecture of the DS-DST model, which is crucial for understanding the basis of these comparisons, involves a dual strategy with strong interactions between the dialog context and domain-slot pairs, leveraging both categorical and non-categorical approaches for slot value prediction ![The image is a schematic representation of the DS-DST model architecture.](image1).

DS-Picklist achieves a joint accuracy of 53.30%, which is higher than DS-DST's 51.21% and significantly better than the BERT-DST model's 43.40% [9].  DS-Span, which employs the strength of BERT, also underperforms compared to DS-DST [5].  In terms of slot-level accuracy, DS-Picklist shows improvements over DS-Span, especially in slots like `hotel-type`, `attraction-name`, `hotel-internet`, and `hotel-parking` [4].  These slots benefit from the candidate-value lists used in DS-Picklist, as their values often have varied expressions not easily extracted from dialog context alone [4].  The detailed slot-level accuracy comparison highlights the strengths of DS-Picklist in categorical slots ![The table presents data about various "Slot Names" and their corresponding statistics under three categories: DS-Span, DS-DST, and DS-Picklist.](image3), while DS-DST also shows considerable improvement over DS-Span in these areas [6].  

Although DS-DST is higher than DS-Span, in real scenarios, it may be nontrivial to have access to the full ontology [1]. When the ontology is accessible, DS-Picklist can further reduce the error rates, since the predicted values can be found in the candidate-values lists [6]. Table 6 shows three examples of dialogue turns in the validation set; in the third example, all the predictions are semantically correct; however, in terms of the string match, only DS-Picklist can correctly predict the value ![The table in the image consists of interactions between a "User" and a "System" in a dialogue format.](image2). Table 4 shows the slot-level accuracy on the test set of MultiWOZ 2.1 ![The table presents a comparison of different models based on their joint accuracy.](image4). The average slot accuracy for DS-Picklist is 97.40%, slightly higher than DS-DST's 97.35% and DS-Span's 96.38% [10]. DS-DST drops by 1.90% on MultiWOZ 2.1, which shows the benefits of jointly training [8].

In summary, DS-Picklist generally demonstrates superior performance in both joint and slot-level accuracy compared to DS-DST and DS-Span, particularly for categorical slots and when a complete ontology is available.

The DeClarE model demonstrates varied performance across different datasets (Snopes, PolitiFact, NewsTrust, and SemEval) depending on its configuration, highlighting the impact of its components on credibility assessment.

On the Snopes and PolitiFact datasets, DeClarE generally outperforms LSTM-text and CNN-text models, indicating the value of external evidence [6].  The table shows the performance of different model configurations on the Snopes and PolitiFact datasets, with DeClarE variants achieving high accuracy, Macro F1-score, and AUC values compared to LSTM-text and CNN-text ![The table presents the performance of different configurations of models on two datasets, Snopes and PolitiFact. It includes measurements of accuracy for true and false claims, macro F1-score, and AUC (Area Under the Curve)](image3). Specifically, on the PolitiFact dataset, DeClarE outperforms baseline models by a large margin, with improvements in AUC and Macro F1, and the addition of the attention mechanism and source embeddings improve performance over the plain configuration [7].

In the NewsTrust dataset for credibility regression, DeClarE (Full) outperforms all baselines with a significant decrease in MSE compared to other models, while DeClarE (Plain) performs worse, illustrating the value of attention and source embeddings [9]. The table shows the comparison of various approaches for credibility regression on the NewsTrust dataset, with DeClarE (Full) achieving the lowest MSE value [4].
