P&G has a long history of dividend payments, increasing its dividend for 66 consecutive years since 1956 [4, 8, 10]. In 2022, dividends per common share increased by 9% to $3.5227 per share [10]. A review of the dividends per share from 1956 to 2022, adjusted for stock splits, shows a substantial increase over the decades.

The dividend per share was $0.01 in 1956, gradually rising to $0.26 by 1992, and then making a more significant jump to $0.76 by 2002. By 2012, it had reached $2.14, and by 2022, it stood at $3.52 ![The dividend per share increased from $0.01 in 1956 to $3.52 in 2022, showing a significant rise over the years.](image2).

![The graph illustrates the growth of dividends per share from 1956 to 2022, reaching $3.52 in 2022.](image3) This consistent increase in dividends reflects P&G's commitment to returning value to shareholders [8].  The company's ability to sustain and grow its dividend payments is tied to its profitability and cash flow [4].

The dividend per share has increased significantly over time, reaching $3.52 in 2022.

In 2020, ExxonMobil experienced a decrease in capital expenditures (Capex) compared to 2019 [3]. Specifically, Capex for 2020 was $21.4 billion, and the corporation prioritized opportunities to hold 2021 capital spending in a range of $16 billion to $19 billion [3]. The evolution of capital investments in the Downstream sector shows a slight decrease from $4.4 billion in 2019 to $4.2 billion in 2020 ![Capital investments in the Downstream sector slightly decreased in 2020.](image1). Chemical capital expenditures also saw a reduction of $0.5 billion [6].

 Taxes on the corporation's income statement also saw a significant decrease from $38.5 billion in 2019 to $22.8 billion in 2020 [10]. Income tax transitioned from an expense of $5.3 billion in 2019 to a benefit of $5.6 billion in 2020, primarily driven by asset impairments recorded in 2020 [10]. This shift is also reflected in the effective tax rate, which dropped from 34% to 17% due to changes in the mix of results across different tax jurisdictions ![The effective tax rate decreased from 34% to 17% due to changes in the mix of results across different tax jurisdictions.](image4). Total other taxes and duties also decreased by $4.8 billion [10]. Worldwide environmental expenditures amounted to $4.5 billion in 2020, with expectations to increase to approximately $4.9 billion in 2021 and 2022 [5].

Industry conditions led to lower realized prices for ExxonMobil's products, resulting in substantially lower earnings and operating cash flow in 2020 compared to 2019 [4]. The company issued $23 billion of long-term debt to strengthen liquidity and implemented significant capital and operating cost reductions [4]. As a result, gross debt ended the year at $68 billion, with intentions to reduce it over time [4]. The average realizations for crude oil and NGL decreased from $56.32 per barrel in 2019 to $35.41 per barrel in 2020 ![Average realizations for crude oil and NGL decreased significantly from 2019 to 2020.](image2).

ExxonMobil's capital expenditures and taxes both decreased significantly from 2019 to 2020, leading to financial adjustments including increased debt and cost reductions due to lower earnings and cash flow.

Berkshire Hathaway's financial activities include strategic stock repurchases and diverse segment earnings, which reflect its overall financial health. The company's stock repurchase program is designed to buy back shares when the price is below intrinsic value, as determined by Warren Buffett and Charlie Munger [3, 4]. In 2021 alone, Berkshire paid $27.1 billion to repurchase its Class A and Class B common stock [4]. The program does not specify a maximum number of shares and will not reduce consolidated cash below $30 billion [4, 6]. The table reveals that Berkshire repurchased Class A and Class B shares in October, November and December with the average price paid per Class A share ranging from $430,172.46 to $439,625.92, and the average price paid per Class B share ranging from $282.86 to $287.62 ![Berkshire repurchased Class A and Class B shares in October, November and December of 2021](image2).

Berkshire Hathaway's net earnings are distributed across several key segments. The table presents net earnings attributable to Berkshire Hathaway shareholders for the past three years.  Net earnings attributable to Berkshire Hathaway shareholders were $89,795 million in 2021, $42,521 million in 2020 and $81,417 million in 2019 [1, 5].
![The table presents net earnings attributable to Berkshire Hathaway shareholders for the past three years](image5).
Examining specific segments, insurance underwriting generated $728 million in 2021, $657 million in 2020, and $325 million in 2019 [2]. The railroad business saw after-tax earnings rise by 16.1% in 2021 compared to 2020, while utilities and energy increased by 13.1% over the same period [7]. Furthermore, the manufacturing, service, and retailing businesses experienced a 34.0% increase in earnings in 2021 compared to 2020 [10]. Investment and derivative gains/losses, another significant component, amounted to $62,340 million in 2021, $31,591 million in 2020 and $57,445 million in 2019 [5].

In summary, Berkshire Hathaway strategically used its stock repurchase program while achieving substantial and varied net earnings across its diverse business segments between 2019 and 2021.

The calculation of grant-date fair value for stock options relies on several key assumptions [1]. These include risk-free interest rates, expected volatility, expected dividend yields, and estimated option exercises and forfeitures [4]. Risk-free interest rates are determined using U.S. Treasury yields at the time of grant, while expected volatilities are based on the company's historical stock volatility and implied volatility from exchange-traded options [4]. The expected life of options granted is derived from historical exercise patterns [4].  ![The table shows financial data for the years ended December 31 for 2020, 2019, and 2018, detailing the risk-free interest rate, expected volatility, expected dividend yield, forfeiture rate, and expected life in years used for calculating stock option values.](image4)

On the other hand, the future minimum lease payments as of December 31, 2020, outline the company's obligations under non-cancelable operating leases [8].  These payments are structured across several years, detailing the amounts due in 2021 through 2025, and thereafter, totaling \$5,046 million before imputed interest [8].  ![The table presents future minimum lease payments in millions for different years.](image2) This total reduces to $4,447 million after subtracting imputed interest of $599 million [8]. The weighted-average remaining lease term is 8.7 years, with a weighted-average discount rate of 3.0% [10].

In essence, the assumptions for stock options relate to variables affecting the valuation of equity-based compensation, while the lease payments represent the company's fixed obligations under lease agreements. Therefore, these two sets of financial metrics serve distinct purposes within the company's financial reporting.

The composition of assets in TI's benefit plans is designed to align with the interest rate sensitivity of the plan's liabilities [8]. A greater proportion of fixed income securities is held in most plans worldwide due to their return characteristics, which closely mirror changes in liabilities caused by discount rate volatility [8].

![The graph illustrates the projected benefit obligations for U.S. and non-U.S. defined benefit plans from 2018 to 2020.](image1)

The company utilizes asset-liability modeling studies to strike a balance between the impact of discount rate changes and the need for asset growth to cover future service costs when determining the appropriate mix of equity and bond investments [8]. The assumptions used for non-U.S. defined benefit plans also take into account the different economic environments within various countries [2]. Most of our plans around the world have a greater proportion of fixed income securities with return characteristics that are more closely aligned with changes in the liabilities caused by discount rate volatility [8].

From 2018 to 2020, the company's provision for income taxes has fluctuated, with a notable increase in 2020. The total provision for income taxes was $3,562 million in 2018, $3,742 million in 2019, and $4,973 million in 2020 [5].

![The table displays financial data related to income taxes over three years (2020, 2019, and 2018), expressed in millions and percentages.](image1)

The deferred income tax provision or benefit generally reflects the net change in deferred income tax assets and liabilities during the year [1]. In 2020, there was a deferred benefit of $(8) million, while in 2019 and 2018, there were deferred provisions of $230 million and $42 million, respectively [5]. This indicates that the net change in deferred tax assets and liabilities had a reducing impact on the total provision for income taxes in 2020 compared to the prior two years.

![The table displays deferred income tax assets and liabilities for the years 2020 and 2019, measured in millions.](image3)

Deferred income tax assets and liabilities are recognized for the differences between the financial and income tax reporting bases of assets and liabilities based on enacted tax rates and laws [6]. As of December 31, 2020, the total deferred income tax assets were $3,391 million, and the total deferred income tax liabilities were $(6,758) million, resulting in net deferred income tax liabilities of $(3,367) million [3]. These deferred tax components play a crucial role in shaping the overall income tax provision trends, as they reflect the future tax consequences of temporary differences between financial reporting and tax reporting.

In summary, the company's income tax provisions increased from 2018 to 2020, with deferred tax assets and liabilities playing a significant role in these fluctuations.

The firm's effective tax rate increased in 2020 compared to the prior year, primarily due to higher earnings and lower net discrete tax benefits [8]. Net discrete tax benefits in 2020 were \$122 million and were primarily related to the conversion of employee share-based awards [8].

In 2019, the provision for income taxes included net discrete tax benefits of \$475 million, mainly from the remeasurement of reserves and interest related to multi-jurisdiction tax examinations and benefits from the conversion of employee share-based awards [3, 5].
![Net discrete tax benefits primarily stem from the remeasurement of reserves and interest due to tax examinations, as well as the conversion of share-based awards.](image1)

Compensation and benefits expenses in 2020 increased by 11\% from the prior year, totaling \$20,854 million [9]. This rise was mainly due to increases in discretionary incentive compensation, formulaic payouts to Wealth Management representatives driven by higher revenues, higher expenses related to certain deferred compensation plans linked to investment performance, and incremental compensation from the E*TRADE acquisition [9]. These increases were partially offset by lower compensation associated with carried interest [9]. The changes in the effective tax rate and net discrete tax benefits do not appear to have a direct relationship with the overall compensation expenses, as the increase in compensation expenses was primarily driven by incentive compensation, payouts, and the E*TRADE acquisition rather than changes in tax benefits [9].

In summary, the effective tax rate increased in 2020 due to higher earnings and lower net discrete tax benefits, while compensation expenses rose due to increased incentive compensation and the E*TRADE acquisition.

From 2020 to 2021, there were notable shifts in card member loans and receivables. Card Member loans increased 21 percent, while this growth was tempered by higher paydown rates due to customer liquidity [4]. This is also reflected in the increase in Card Member loans from $73.4 billion in 2020 to $88.6 billion in 2021, and Card Member receivables also rose from $43.7 billion to $53.6 billion during the same period ![Card member loans and receivables increased from 2020 to 2021.](image5).

Simultaneously, network volumes and card member spending saw significant growth. The increase in discount revenue, driven by growth in Card Member spending, reflects this [9]. The percentage increase in billed business was 25% from 2020 to 2021, and network volumes also increased by 24% ![Network volumes and billed business increased in 2021.](image4). This increase is further substantiated by an increase in total revenues net of interest expense by 17 percent, year-over-year [9]. This growth in spending is a key driver for the increases seen in loan and receivable balances.

From 2019 to 2020, net income and comprehensive income experienced notable changes. Net income decreased from $6,025.4 million in 2019 to $4,730.5 million in 2020 ![The table presents financial data for a company over the years ended December 31, 2020, 2019, and 2018.](image4). This decrease is also reflected in diluted earnings per share, which dropped by approximately 20% [4].

Several factors contributed to these shifts.  A decrease in operating income, impacted by strategic charges and gains, played a role [6]. Specifically, 2020 included $268 million in net strategic gains, primarily from the sale of McDonald's Japan stock, while 2019 included $74 million in net strategic charges [6]. Excluding these items, operating income still decreased by a significant margin [6]. Additionally, cash provided by operations decreased in 2020 compared to 2019 primarily due to a reduction in operating earnings due to COVID-19 [9].

Comprehensive income also decreased from $6,152.2 million in 2019 to $4,626.4 million in 2020 ![The table presents financial data for a company over the years ended December 31, 2020, 2019, and 2018.](image4).  Changes in other comprehensive income components, such as foreign currency translation adjustments and cash flow hedges, further influenced this decrease. Foreign currency translation adjustments decreased from a gain of $174.3 million in 2019 to a gain of $63.1 million in 2020, and cash flow hedges shifted from a loss of $20.4 million in 2019 to a loss of $123.3 million in 2020 ![The table presents financial data for a company over the years ended December 31, 2020, 2019, and 2018.](image4). These fluctuations in comprehensive income components further contributed to the overall reduction.

In summary, net income and comprehensive income both decreased from 2019 to 2020 due to factors including decreased operating income, the impact of strategic gains and charges, and changes in components of other comprehensive income like foreign currency translation and cash flow hedges.

Siemens Healthineers experienced significant changes in cash flows from both financing and investing activities between fiscal years 2020 and 2021. Cash inflows from financing activities saw a substantial increase of €12,087 million, reaching €11,839 million in 2021 [5]. This surge was primarily driven by the financing of the Varian acquisition [5].

![Cash flows from financing activities increased substantially due to the Varian acquisition](image4)

Specifically, Siemens Group provided borrowings of €10 billion and an additional €850 million in fiscal year 2021 to support the Varian acquisition [8]. This was partially offset by repayments of matured loans totaling €730 million and €300 million [8]. Further cash outflows included dividends paid to shareholders, which amounted to €856 million in 2021, compared to €798 million in 2020 [9].

![Equity rose mainly because of issuing new shares for the Varian acquisition](image3)

Conversely, cash outflows from investing activities increased by €12,228 million to €14,140 million in 2021 [6]. The primary driver of this increase was the payout for the acquisition of Varian [6]. Additionally, investments in capacity expansions contributed to increased cash outflows, with additions to intangible assets and property, plant, and equipment rising by €117 million [6].  These investments aimed to enhance competitiveness and innovation capabilities [2].

![Cash outflows from investing activities increased significantly due to the Varian acquisition](image4)

In summary, the considerable increase in cash inflows from financing activities was mainly due to financing the Varian acquisition, while the large increase in cash outflows from investing activities was primarily due to the Varian acquisition payout and increased investments in intangible assets and property.

To determine the total long-term capital and finance lease obligations, several components and calculations are involved. For capital leases, the gross capital lease obligations was $14,811 million, which is then reduced by imputed interest of $(534) million to arrive at the present value of net minimum lease payments of $14,277 million. Subtracting the current portion of capital lease obligations, $(5,839) million, results in total long-term capital lease obligations of $8,438 million ![The table shows financial data related to capital lease obligations as of December 31, 2017](image3). Similarly, for finance leases, the gross finance lease obligations were $6,265 million, which is reduced by imputed interest of $(1,238) million to get a present value of net minimum lease payments of $5,027 million. After subtracting the current portion of finance lease obligations, $(282) million, the total long-term finance lease obligations amount to $4,745 million ![The table shows financial data as of December 31, 2017, related to finance lease obligations](image4).
The summation of long-term capital lease obligations and long-term finance lease obligations contributes to the total other long-term liabilities [7].  As of December 31, 2017, long-term capital lease obligations stood at $8,438 million, and long-term finance lease obligations were $4,745 million ![The table shows a list of long-term liabilities for the years ending December 31, 2016, and 2017](image1). These lease obligations, along with other components like construction liabilities and tax contingencies, form the total other long-term liabilities.

The total long-term capital and finance lease obligations for December 31, 2017, are determined by subtracting imputed interest and the current portion of the obligations from the gross obligations.

The financial institution's risk-based capital ratios are calculated using both the Standardized Approach and the Advanced Approach [4]. These ratios pertain to Common Equity Tier 1 capital, Tier 1 capital, and Total capital, with necessary adjustments and deductions [1].

In 2020, Market risk RWA experienced an increase under both approaches, primarily due to a rise in Regulatory VaR influenced by heightened market volatility [6]. Credit risk RWA also increased in 2020 under both the Standardized and Advanced Approaches [9]. This was largely due to increased Derivatives exposures driven by market volatility, and an increase in Investment securities mainly as a result of the $\mathrm{E}^{*}$TRADE acquisition [9]. The Advanced Approach increase was also impacted by increased exposure in Derivatives and higher credit spread volatility [9].

The decrease in operational risk RWA under the Advanced Approach in 2020 is attributed to a reduction in the frequency and severity of litigation-related losses [2]. The increase in Common Equity Tier 1 capital compared to the end of 2019 was mainly due to a net increase in Retained earnings and the impact of the $\mathrm{E}^{*}$TRADE acquisition [5].

Chevron Corporation divides its investments into two primary business segments: Upstream and Downstream [1]. The Upstream segment focuses on crude oil and natural gas exploration, development, production, and transportation, while the Downstream segment refines crude oil into petroleum products and handles marketing, manufacturing, and transportation [1]. Earnings for the downstream segment depend on margins from refining, manufacturing, and marketing products such as gasoline, diesel, and lubricants. These margins are affected by supply-demand balance, crude oil prices, and geopolitical events [4].

To evaluate segment performance, Chevron uses an after-tax basis, excluding debt financing interest expense and investment interest income [8].

![This image presents Chevron's segment earnings for 2021, 2020, and 2019, showing significant fluctuations in Upstream earnings and more stable Downstream earnings.](image1)

Based on the information, the company classified $768 of net properties, plant, and equipment as "Assets held for sale" related to upstream operations expected to be sold within 12 months [2]. In the company’s downstream business, crude oil is the largest cost component of refined products [7].

In summary, the Upstream segment's earnings are more volatile and heavily influenced by crude oil prices, while the Downstream segment's earnings are more stable but dependent on refining margins and market conditions.

In 2020, IBM experienced a decline in total revenue, with a decrease of 4.6 percent as reported [3]. This broad decline is reflected in the performance of various segments and geographic regions.  ![Total revenue decreased from $77,147 million in 2019 to $73,620 million in 2020, a year-to-year decrease of 4.6%.](image4)

Specifically, Systems revenue saw a decrease of 8.2 percent [7]. Within Systems, Systems Hardware revenue decreased by 7.4 percent, driven primarily by declines in Power Systems and Storage Systems, although there was some offset from growth in IBM Z [7].  Notably, IBM Z revenue increased by 1.9 percent, demonstrating its continued importance [2]. The total Systems external revenue decreased from $7,604 million in 2019 to $6,978 million in 2020, marking an 8.2% decrease, whereas the Power Systems experienced a more significant decline of 22.4%  ![Total Systems external revenue decreased 8.2% year-to-year.](image1).

The Global Financing segment also experienced a downturn, with pre-tax income decreasing by 27.8 percent [8].  The external revenue for Global Financing decreased by 19.8%, and pre-tax income decreased by 27.8% [5].  This decrease was primarily driven by lower revenue [8].
![External revenue decreased 19.8% year-to-year, and pre-tax income decreased 27.8%.](image5)

The Global Technology Services segment saw external total gross profit decrease by 5.7% and pre-tax income decreased by 92.9% [3].  ![External total gross profit decreased 5.7% year-to-year, and pre-tax income decreased 92.9%.](image3)

In summary, IBM experienced year-to-year decreases in both external revenue and pre-tax income across its systems and various regions in 2020, although there were some exceptions like the growth in IBM Z revenue.

Derivative financial instruments are measured at fair value based on quoted market prices if traded in active markets [4]. Gains and losses from fair value changes in financial assets, including derivatives, are recognized in the income statement as financial income or expenses [7].
Cash flow changes convert income statement items from accrual to cash basis by reversing non-cash items [10]. For presenting the cash flow statement, non-cash items with effect on the income statement must be reversed to identify the actual cash flow effect from the income statement [6].

When hedging instruments expire or are sold, or when a hedge no longer meets hedge accounting criteria, cumulative gains or losses remain in equity until the forecast transaction impacts the income statement [2].
![Fair value measurement hierarchy](image1)
These financial elements affect the income statement, balance sheet, and cash flow statement by determining financial income or expenses and impacting cash from operating, investing, and financing activities.

Siemens Healthineers utilizes actuarial valuations that rely on key assumptions, such as discount rates, expected compensation increases, pension progression, and mortality rates to measure entitlements from defined benefit plans [7]. Due to changing market, economic and social conditions, the underlying actuarial assumptions may differ from actual developments [7].

Changes in these assumptions can significantly impact the defined benefit obligation. For instance, a $10\,\%$ reduction in mortality rates for all beneficiaries would increase the defined benefit obligation by €110 million as of September 30, 2021, compared to €109 million in the previous year [2].

Siemens Healthineers manages risks associated with the funded status of pension plans by monitoring asset development and making necessary adjustments to the investment strategy [5]. They also use derivatives to reduce risks as part of their risk management [5].

In Switzerland, Siemens Healthineers sponsors cash balance plans, and in case of an underfunded plan, they, along with employees, may be required to pay supplementary contributions [9].

![](/image1)

The company also employs a liability-driven investment approach and monitors risks using a defined risk measure (Value at Risk, VaR), which considers both plan assets and the defined benefit obligation [5]. The effect of the defined benefit obligation can be influenced by changes in actuarial assumptions, primarily the discount rate, and movements in financial markets [3].

Fluctuations in actuarial assumptions, such as discount rates and mortality rates, between fiscal years 2020 and 2021 led to changes in the defined benefit obligation, impacting actuarial gains and losses.

Specifically, foreign currency translation moved from a loss of $(305,225) in 2018 to a gain of $197,696 in 2020 [image1].

These changes in comprehensive income directly affect the accumulated other comprehensive loss component of shareholders' equity [image2, image3]. Additionally, activities such as share repurchases, issuances, and dividend payments influence the overall shareholders' equity [1, 5]. For instance, in fiscal year 2020, purchases of Class A shares decreased equity by $2,894,253, while dividends reduced it by $2,112,457 [image5].

Comprehensive income generally increased from 2018 to 2020, with fluctuations in its components impacting shareholders' equity through retained earnings and accumulated other comprehensive income.

They are reinforcing their profit structure by reducing costs and applying the Toyota Production System (TPS) to secure funds for investment in advanced technologies [6]. This includes investments in environmental technologies aimed at realizing a carbon-neutral society [10]. As the percentage of electrified vehicles is expected to increase in a society that is based on scenarios with climate change measures, Toyota is responding accordingly [5].

Toyota's commitment to shareholder returns is evident in its policy of ensuring stable and continuous dividend payments, aiming to maintain a consolidated payout ratio of 30% [10]. The financial data shows dividend per share (yen) increasing from 210 in 2017/3 to 240 in 2021/3, with substantial total shareholder returns through dividends and share repurchases. ![Toyota's financial data from 2017 to 2021 shows shareholder returns through dividends and share repurchases.](image5) This shareholder benefit is deemed an important element of its management policy [10].

Toyota’s financial strategy supports investments in electrification and other climate-related measures while maintaining attractive shareholder returns.

In 2020, Novo Nordisk recognized an impairment loss of DKK 350 million, which is notably lower than the DKK 982 million recorded in 2019; the majority of these losses pertained to patents and licenses [3]. A significant portion, DKK 350 million (compared to DKK 282 million in 2019), was specifically related to the Diabetes and Obesity care segment, while none was related to Biopharm (compared to DKK 700 million in 2019) [3].

![This image shows a close-up of the document that contains information about depreciation and impairment losses, focusing on intangible assets and property, plant, and equipment.](image1)

These impairment losses were fully recognized within research and development costs [3]. Intangible assets that are not yet subject to amortization have increased to DKK 9,607 million in 2020 from DKK 3,380 million in 2019, mainly involving patents and licenses related to R&D projects [4]. Assets subject to amortization are reviewed for impairment when circumstances suggest the carrying amount is not recoverable [2]. The company determines depreciation based on the straight-line method over the assets' estimated useful lives, which vary by asset type [8].

![This image showcases a page focusing on intangible assets not yet available for use and their impairment testing based on management's projections.](image2)

The depreciation starts once the asset is ready for its intended use, with the residual values and useful lives reviewed periodically [10]. Research and development costs include depreciation and impairment losses related to software and property, plant, and equipment used in these activities [5].

In summary, impairment losses decreased from 2019 to 2020, impacting the carrying amounts of intangible assets and property, plant, and equipment, with specific effects varying across different segments and asset types.

From 2019 to 2021, there's a contrasting trend between premiums earned and net investment income. Premiums earned saw an increase, while net investment income experienced a decline.

In the P&C businesses, premiums earned decreased by $1.3\%$ in 2020 compared to 2019 but increased by $7.4\%$ in 2021 compared to 2020 [10, 4]. This growth in 2021 was despite the impact of the GEICO Giveback program, which reduced earned premiums by approximately $2.5$ billion in 2020, with the remainder of the impact felt in 2021 [4].

![The graph shows that short-term interest rates declined significantly from the second half of 2019 through 2021.](image1)

Conversely, net investment income showed a consistent decline over the same period. It decreased by $49.0\%$ in 2020 compared to 2019 and further declined by $44.4\%$ in 2021 compared to 2020 [6]. This downturn was mainly attributed to lower income from short-term investments and fixed maturity securities, influenced by declining short-term interest rates from the second half of 2019 through 2021 [6].

In summary, premiums earned generally increased from 2019 to 2021, while net investment income consistently decreased during the same period.

The provided information describes the methods for determining the expected return on plan assets and provides the fair value of plan assets, as well as the accumulated benefit obligations.

In 2020, IBM experienced significant shifts in its cash flow activities compared to 2019. Cash provided by operating activities increased by $3.4 billion to reach $18.2 billion, primarily driven by an increase in cash provided by receivables [6]. This was further supported by a $4,795 million increase in cash from receivables, largely due to sales of receivables, including $3,076 million from financing receivables, and approximately $600 million from payroll tax and value-added tax payment deferrals and exemptions related to COVID-19 relief [10].

However, these gains were partially offset by performance-related declines within net income and an increase in workforce rebalancing payments of $293 million [10]. Additionally, there was a $162 million net increase in cash payments for income taxes, mainly driven by withholding tax on intercompany dividends [10].

Furthermore, net cash used in investing activities decreased by $23.9 billion [5]. This decrease was influenced by a $32,294 million reduction in net cash used for acquisitions, primarily because of the Red Hat acquisition in the prior year, though this was partially offset by a $6,245 million decrease in cash provided by net non-operating finance receivables, mainly due to the wind down of OEM IT commercial financing operations [1, 9]. There was also an $896 million increase in cash used for net purchases of marketable securities and other investments [1].

![The graph illustrates IBM's cash flow activities in 2020, highlighting significant inflows from operating activities and outflows from investing and financing activities.](image1)

Financing activities resulted in a net use of cash of $9,721 million in 2020, a significant shift from a net source of cash of $9,042 million in 2019 [8]. The $18,763 million year-to-year change was influenced by various factors [8]. Total equity decreased by $258 million, primarily due to dividends paid of $5,797 million and a decline in accumulated other comprehensive income of $740 million, though partially offset by increases from net income of $5,590 million and common stock of $661 million [2].

Overall, IBM experienced a complex interplay of factors affecting its cash flow, with increased cash from operating activities and decreased cash used in investing activities, but a shift to net cash used in financing activities.

In 2020, total Company-operated sales and franchised revenues experienced a decrease of 10%, primarily due to sales declines in the International Operated Markets segment caused by COVID-19 [9]. However, positive sales performance in the U.S. partially offset this decline, though this was countered by marketing support and incentives for franchisees, including the Thank You Meals program [9].

![The image shows a collage of various McDonald's marketing campaigns and promotional materials, highlighting their food items and special offers, set against a backdrop of their iconic golden arches.](image1)

Additionally, total restaurant margins decreased by 13% in 2020, reflecting sales declines in the International Operated Markets segment due to COVID-19, despite positive sales performance in the U.S. [8]. The revenue declines were notably driven by the U.K., France, Germany, Italy, and Spain, where temporary restaurant closures and limited operations significantly impacted sales [1]. Furthermore, franchised margins in the U.S. were affected by higher depreciation costs related to investments in Experience of the Future (EOTF) and marketing support to accelerate recovery, including the Thank You Meals initiative [2].

Overall, the decline in total revenues and restaurant margins from 2019 to 2020 was primarily driven by the impact of COVID-19, particularly in international markets, and increased expenses related to marketing and technology investments.

These factors suggest that while stock-based compensation represents a cost, the company's overall financial performance, as reflected in net earnings per share, has generally improved, demonstrating effective management of equity and profitability.

BHP's governance framework actively incorporates climate change considerations at multiple levels, including the Board's agenda and key management decisions [3]. The Sustainability Committee assists the Board in overseeing the Group’s climate change performance and governance responsibilities [3]. The Risk and Audit Committee also supports the Board in overseeing climate-related risk management [3]. The Committee also specifically considered how the Group’s greenhouse gas emissions reduction commitments and climate change scenarios are reflected in the Group’s key judgements and estimates used in the preparation of the Group’s FY2021 finance statements [7].

Climate change sessions were part of briefings and development sessions, aiming to provide directors with a deeper understanding of key issues and considerations related to climate change ![Directors receive briefings to enhance their understanding of BHP's activities, environment, and key issues, including climate change considerations.](image5).

The RAC confirmed its view to the Board that BHP’s 2021 Annual Report taken as a whole is fair, balanced and understandable [8]. The Board actively seeks input from management and independent advisors to consider potential implications of climate change on BHP [10]. The Nomination and Governance Committee supports the Board by reviewing requests from Directors for authorization of situations of actual or potential conflict and making recommendations to the Board [2].

![The table highlights that directors receive training and development, emphasizing the processes for board evaluation and director development, including a specific program in 2021.](image4)

Thus, BHP's governance framework addresses climate change risks through board oversight, committee involvement, and risk management processes, and ensures directors are well-informed through briefings and development sessions.

From January 1, 2015, to December 31, 2017, Amazon's Stockholders’ Equity experienced significant changes, influenced by net income, comprehensive income or loss, and stock-based compensation activities. The balance on January 1, 2015, was $10,741 [image3].

For the year ended December 31, 2015, net income added $596, but other comprehensive loss reduced the equity by $212 [image3]. Stock option exercises and other stock-based compensation adjustments further increased equity, leading to a total Stockholders’ Equity of $13,384 by the end of 2015 [image3].  ![The table shows a summary of changes in stockholders’ equity from 2015 to 2017, detailing common stock, treasury stock, additional paid-in capital, accumulated other comprehensive income (loss), retained earnings, and total stockholders’ equity.](image3)

In 2016, net income contributed $2,371, while other comprehensive loss subtracted $262 [image3]. Additional shares issued through stock options and other stock-based compensation adjustments continued to boost equity, resulting in a total Stockholders’ Equity of $19,285 by the end of 2016 [image3]. In 2017, adjustments were made due to accounting principles related to stock-based compensation [image3]. Net income added $3,033, and comprehensive income gains amounted to $501 [image3]. Further increases from stock-based compensation issuances, totaling $4,202, led to an ending Stockholders’ Equity [image3].

The total Stockholders’ Equity increased from $10,741 in 2015 to $13,384 in 2015, then to $19,285 in 2016, driven by net income, comprehensive income or loss, and stock-based compensation activities.

Shell Midstream Partners, L.P. experienced fluctuations in both operating income and cash flow from investing activities between 2019 and 2020. The consolidated statements of cash flows show that net cash provided by investing activities was $64 million in 2020, compared to net cash used in investing activities of ($87) million in 2019 ![Net cash from investing activities changed from -$87 million in 2019 to $64 million in 2020](image5).

Referring to the consolidated statements of income, operating income decreased from 608 million in 2019 to 587 million in 2020 ![Operating income decreased from $608 million to $587 million between 2019 and 2020](image3). Total revenue decreased by $22 million in 2020 compared to 2019. This was composed of decreases of $53 million in transportation services revenue, $12 million in allowance oil revenue, and $21 million attributable to product revenue, partially offset by increases of $63 million attributable to terminaling services revenue and $1 million in lease revenue [9]. The decrease in transportation services revenue was attributed to the COVID-19 pandemic, lower rates on Zydeco committed contracts, and the impact from planned turnaround activities, storms, and related shut-ins [10].

Capital expenditures also played a role; they were \$22 million in 2020 compared to \$35 million in 2019 [3]. The decrease in capital expenditures from 2019 to 2020 is primarily due to the completion of the Houma tank expansion and directional drill projects for Zydeco [3]. Further, there were no contributions to investment in 2020 [3].

In summary, Shell Midstream Partners, L.P.'s operating income decreased from 2019 to 2020 due to reduced transportation services revenue, while the cash flow from investing activities increased primarily due to decreased capital expenditures and no contributions to investment.

Wells Fargo sold Wells Fargo Asset Management (WFAM) on November 1, 2021 [2, 7]. Prior to the sale, WFAM generated fees from assets under management (AUM), which included equity, alternative, balanced, fixed income, money market, and stable value assets [2, 9]. Management considered AUM a useful metric for assessing the impact of asset changes on asset-based fees [9].

![WFAM AUM is useful to assess the impact of asset changes on asset-based fees.](image1)

The amortized cost, net of the allowance for credit losses, of available-for-sale (AFS) and held-to-maturity (HTM) debt securities increased from December 31, 2020 [3]. Moreover,  \$56.0 billion of AFS debt securities were transferred to HTM debt securities in 2021 to reposition the overall portfolio for capital management [3]. The total net unrealized gains on AFS and HTM debt securities decreased from December 31, 2020, due to higher interest rates [8].

In summary, WFAM was sold, and while the amortized cost of AFS securities increased, unrealized gains decreased due to higher interest rates.

Wells Fargo's financial strategy in 2021 was influenced by shifts in total assets and the sale of Wells Fargo Asset Management (WFAM). Total assets are a key indicator of a financial institution's size and scope, while WFAM's assets under management (AUM) directly relate to fee generation and strategic focus [4].

The sale of WFAM on November 1, 2021, significantly altered Wells Fargo's asset management operations [6, 10]. The WFAM assets under management saw considerable changes due to market impacts and the sale itself ![WFAM assets experienced significant changes due to market factors and the sale](image5). WFAM's AUM is considered a useful metric to assess how changes in asset amounts may impact the generation of asset-based fees [4]. The balance sheet data also reflects these changes, providing a clear view of the company's financial position across three years ![The table provides a summary of the financial positions for 2019, 2020 and 2021](image3).

Changes in the investment portfolio also reflect strategic realignments. For example, there were shifts in available-for-sale (AFS) and held-to-maturity (HTM) debt securities, influenced by liquidity and interest rate risk management objectives [8]. The net unrealized gains on these securities decreased from December 31, 2020, due to higher interest rates [2]. The company rebalanced its AFS debt securities portfolio to manage interest rate risk, indicating proactive measures to adapt to changing economic conditions [8]. Furthermore, the amortized cost of AFS and HTM debt securities increased as the company continued to purchase these securities [9].

The loan portfolio also saw changes, with commercial loans increasing and consumer loans decreasing [1]. These shifts reflect changes in loan demand and strategic decisions regarding loan sales and securitizations ![This image shows that commercial loans increased while consumer loans decreased from 2020 to 2021](image4). The maturity and interest rate structures of these loans further illustrate the complexity of managing these assets [1].

These strategic actions, including the sale of WFAM and adjustments to the debt securities and loan portfolios, demonstrate Wells Fargo's efforts to optimize its balance sheet, manage risks, and adapt to evolving market conditions.

Wells Fargo strategically rebalanced its assets through the sale of WFAM and adjustments to its securities and loan portfolios in response to market conditions.

Siemens Healthineers calculates defined benefit plan entitlements using the projected unit credit method, which relies on key actuarial assumptions, including discount rates [6]. These rates are determined by considering yields on high-quality corporate bonds and government bond yields [6]. Due to changing market, economic, and social conditions, the underlying actuarial assumptions may differ from actual developments [6].

Regarding actuarial assumptions, Germany utilizes Siemens-specific tables (Siemens Bio) based on data from the German Siemens population and the Federal Statistical Office, while the United States uses the Pri-2012 generational projection from the U.S. Social Security Administration's Long Range Demographic Assumptions ![Actuarial assumptions used in Germany, United States, United Kingdom and Switzerland for 2021 and 2020.](image5).

![Percentage rates for different financial indicators as of September 30 for the years 2021 and 2020.](image4) The discount rates as of September 30 show differences between the two countries: For the U.S. dollar, the discount rate was 2.7% in 2021 and 2.4% in 2020, while for the Euro, the discount rate was 1.0% in 2021 and 0.9% in 2020 [4].

In fiscal year 2021, Siemens Healthineers managed defined benefit obligations, fair value of plan assets, and asset ceiling effects, including those from the acquisition of Varian [5]. In the United States, defined benefit plans sponsored by Siemens Healthineers have been frozen to new entrants and future benefit accruals [8]. These plans are subject to funding requirements under ERISA, mandating a minimum funding level of 80% to avoid benefit restrictions [8].

The actuarial assumptions and financial indicators for defined benefit plans in Germany and the United States differ in terms of demographic projections, discount rates, and specific plan management strategies.

To determine the sales to working capital ratio, we need to calculate the working capital first. Working capital is the difference between current assets and current liabilities.  Based on the consolidated balance sheets [5], current assets in 2015 were $5,431,840 and current liabilities were $3,529,624.

Thus, Working Capital = Current Assets - Current Liabilities = $5,431,840 - $3,529,624 = $1,902,216

Next, we need to find the sales (revenue) for 2015. According to the income statement [2], revenue in 2015 was $6,779,511.  ![The table is an income statement of a company for the years ended December 31, 2015, 2014, and 2013.](image2)

Now, we can calculate the sales to working capital ratio:

Sales to Working Capital Ratio = Revenue / Working Capital = $6,779,511 / $1,902,216 ≈ 3.56

Therefore, the sales to working capital ratio for Netflix in FY 2015 is approximately 3.56.

From December 31, 2020, to December 31, 2021, total loans saw an increase, driven predominantly by commercial loans [1, 5]. The ACL for loans also decreased, reflecting improvements in portfolio credit quality and economic conditions [9]. Considering these changes, the financial entity appears to be strategically shifting its focus towards commercial lending while managing its assets to comply with regulatory requirements and optimize its portfolio in response to the prevailing economic environment.

In summary, between December 31, 2020 and December 31, 2021, the financial entity increased its commercial lending, decreased its consumer lending, and strategically managed its deposit composition and asset quality.

The changes in PMI shipment volumes and net revenues varied significantly across different regions from 2019 to 2020. In South and Southeast Asia, commentaries were made regarding the total market, PMI shipment volume, and market share [1]. Similarly, the Middle East and Africa also had commentaries focusing on the total market, PMI shipment volume, and market share [3].

PMI Duty Free experienced a significant decrease of $70.8\%$, or $58.8\%$ excluding distributor inventory movements, primarily due to a lower total market [4].  Turkey also saw a decrease of $8.5\%$, mainly due to the lower total market and reduced market share because of adult smokers down-trading after the 2019 price increases [4]. Pakistan experienced a decrease of $10.3\%$, mainly attributed to excise tax-driven price increases in June 2019 and price increases on PMI value brands in February 2020 [8].

Net revenues, excluding unfavorable currency impacts, decreased by $21.7\%$. This was mainly due to lower cigarette volume, heated tobacco unit volume, and IQOS device volume in PMI Duty Free, as well as reduced cigarette volume in South Africa and Turkey [5]. These declines were partially offset by favorable pricing variances, particularly in the GCC (especially Saudi Arabia), North Africa, and PMI Duty Free, though this was partly offset by Turkey [5].

Operating income, excluding unfavorable currency effects, decreased by $35.2\%$, primarily due to unfavorable volume/mix, largely due to lower cigarette and heated tobacco unit volume in PMI Duty Free.  Lower fees for certain distribution rights also contributed to this decline [2].

![The pie chart showing the net revenue for each region.](image1)

Excluding certain 2020 and 2019 items and unfavorable currency impacts of $110 million, operating income decreased by $22.5\%$. This was mainly due to unfavorable volume/mix, driven by the same factors affecting net revenues, and the unfavorable impact of the RBH deconsolidation [7]. East Asia and Australia also had commentaries on total market, PMI shipment volume, and market share [9]. It is important to note that net revenues include revenues from shipments of Platform 1 devices, heated tobacco units, and accessories to Altria Group, Inc., starting in the third quarter of 2019, for sale under license in the United States [10].

In summary, PMI shipment volumes and net revenues generally decreased across various regions from 2019 to 2020, with notable declines in PMI Duty Free, Turkey, and Pakistan, influenced by factors such as lower market demand, price increases, and unfavorable volume/mix.

Next, we identify the Total Assets as of January 28, 2023. From the consolidated balance sheets, the Total Assets as of January 28, 2023, were  $21,173$ million [image2].

Now, calculate the Gross Profit to Total Assets ratio:
Ratio = Gross Profit / Total Assets = $10,819 / $21,173 = 0.511075...$
Rounding to three decimal places, the ratio is 0.511.

```
Gross Profit to Total Assets Ratio = $10,819 / $21,173 = 0.511
```

```

```

Toyota strives to nurture a corporate culture where all employees, including women, can demonstrate their full potential [3]. The company recognizes gender diversity as an area needing improvement, especially within Toyota Motor Corporation in Japan [3].

In 2012, the focus shifted to creating a work environment that motivates women and supports their participation, particularly in developing female managers [4]. Toyota is committed to increasing the percentage of positions held by women across all levels, from initial hiring to executive positions [10].

Toyota supports female employee participation and diversity by implementing initiatives that balance work and childcare and create a supportive work environment, with the goal of increasing female representation at all levels within the company.

As of December 31, 2020, the calculation of capital ratios incorporates a five-year transition period related to the adoption of CECL [1, 8]. The standardized approach was used to calculate TLAC and long-term debt ratios for both December 31, 2020 and 2019 [4].

Looking at the specific figures, we can see the changes in risk-weighted assets. ![The table compares financial data for two approaches, "Standardized Approach" and "Advanced Approaches," over two years, 2020 and 2019, as of December 31.](image1) Under the standardized approach, risk-weighted assets decreased from $1,493 billion in 2019 to $1,480 billion in 2020 [2].  The decrease was primarily due to lower commercial and consumer lending exposures, partially offset by investments of excess deposits in securities [2]. Under the advanced approaches, risk-weighted assets decreased from $1,447 in 2019 to $1,371 in 2020.

The TLAC ratios also experienced changes. ![The table presents financial data related to TLAC (Total Loss-Absorbing Capacity) and Long-term Debt for the years ending December 31, 2020, and December 31, 2019.](image5) The TLAC amount increased from $367,449 in 2019 to $405,153 in 2020. As a percentage, TLAC increased from 24.6% in 2019 to 27.4% in 2020, against a regulatory minimum of 22.0% for both years [5].

In summary, risk-weighted assets decreased under both standardized and advanced approaches from 2019 to 2020, while TLAC ratios increased and remained above the regulatory minimums.

From 2019 to 2020, there were notable shifts in the number of individuals served by UnitedHealthcare across its various segments.  Specifically, the number of individuals served in "Commercial" plans experienced a decrease, with risk-based plans dropping by 665,000 (-8%) and fee-based plans decreasing by 875,000 (-5%) [3].  This decline in the commercial sector is also reflected in the Employer & Individual segment, which saw a decrease in revenue ![The table shows UnitedHealthcare Employer & Individual revenue decreased by $1,073 million (2%) from 2019 to 2020.](image4).

Conversely, the "Public and Senior" segments saw increases, with Medicare Advantage growing by 440,000 (8%) and Medicaid increasing by 720,000 (12%) [3].  The growth in Medicare & Retirement is consistent with the revenue increase in this segment ![The table shows UnitedHealthcare Medicare & Retirement revenue increased by $7,512 million (9%) from 2019 to 2020.](image4). The increase in Medicaid may be related to states easing redetermination requirements due to COVID-19 [10]. Overall, the total number of individuals served by UnitedHealthcare domestically decreased slightly by 420,000 (-1%) [3]. The number of people served by UnitedHealthcare Global also decreased [5, 10], reflected in a revenue decrease in the Global segment ![The table shows UnitedHealthcare Global revenue decreased by $2,103 million (21%) from 2019 to 2020.](image4).

These shifts in enrollment and revenue across segments reflect a combination of factors, including economic changes, policy adjustments, and the ongoing impact of the COVID-19 pandemic. Increased unemployment led to attrition in commercial fee-based and risk-based plans [10], while the easing of redetermination requirements for Medicaid during the pandemic and growth in Dual Special Needs Plans contributed to increases in the Medicaid segment [10].

In summary, UnitedHealthcare experienced a decrease in individuals served in its commercial and global segments, while its Medicare and Medicaid segments saw increases, driven by economic factors, policy changes, and the effects of the COVID-19 pandemic.

The actuarial gain for pension plans and other retiree benefits (OPRB) in 2022 was primarily related to increases in discount rates [4]. The discount rate impacts plan obligations and expenses because pension and OPRB liabilities are measured on a discounted basis [10].

![The table shows the weighted average assumptions used to determine benefit obligations recorded on the Consolidated Balance Sheets as of June 30, 2022 and 2021.](image1)

In 2022, the average discount rate on defined benefit pension plans was 3.7%, while the average discount rate on the OPRB plan was 5.0% [10]. The actuarial gain for other retiree benefits in 2022 was primarily related to increases in discount rates, partially offset by unfavorable medical claim experience [4]. In 2021, the actuarial gain for pension plans was primarily related to increases in discount rates, partially offset by unfavorable actuarial assumptions, including inflation assumptions [4]. The actuarial gain for other retiree benefits in 2021 was primarily related to favorable medical cost trends [4]. The average return on assets assumptions for pension plan assets and OPRB assets was 5.5% and 8.4%, respectively [1]. A change in the rate of return of 100 basis points for both pension and OPRB assets would impact annual after-tax benefit/expense by approximately $125 million [1].

In summary, both pension and OPRB plans experienced increases in discount rates from 2021 to 2022, which led to actuarial gains; the expected return on plan assets were 5.5% and 8.4% for pension and OPRB assets respectively [1, 4].

BHP's Nomination and Governance Committee plays a crucial role in ensuring effective board succession planning and director development [5]. The Committee actively oversees and monitors renewal and succession planning, along with the evaluation of Board and Director performance [5]. This includes advising on and recommending the Group’s governance practices [5]. The board regularly assesses its current skills and expected future requirements to establish clear succession plans [8].

BHP employs a structured and rigorous method to manage Board succession planning, ensuring a diverse pipeline, considering unforeseen departures, and focusing on diversity, skills, and experience needed for governance and risk management ![BHP uses a structured and rigorous method to manage Board succession planning](image2). Succession planning is an ongoing process, especially for Non-executive Directors, with a nine-year tenure as a guide [2]. The Board balances experience with new perspectives to adapt to changing external factors [2].

![The Nomination and Governance Committee is responsible for succession planning processes, evaluation and training and corporate governance practices](image3).

For new appointments, the Nomination and Governance Committee outlines a role description, incorporating criteria and attributes specified in the Board Governance Document [3]. This role description is provided to an external search firm to carry out a global search [3]. Shortlisted candidates are initially considered by the Chair and the Nomination and Governance Committee, followed by meetings with each Board member before a decision is made about their appointment [3]. The Nomination and Governance Committee recommends the preferred candidate for Board appointment, and background checks are performed [3]. The process concludes with a letter of appointment detailing the terms for Non-executive Directors and defining their role and independence [3].

To ensure ongoing development, Non-executive Directors participate in continuous improvement activities overseen by the Nomination and Governance Committee [7]. These activities cover business, environmental, social, and governance matters, providing updates on BHP’s assets, commodities, geographies, and markets [7]. Programs are designed and reviewed to maximize effectiveness, incorporating the results of Director performance evaluations [7].

![Directors gain a deeper understanding of assets and key issues through briefings, development sessions, and site visits.](image1)

In summary, BHP's Nomination and Governance Committee ensures effective board succession planning and director development through structured planning, rigorous selection processes, and ongoing training and development programs.

Long-term debt, excluding finance lease liabilities, also decreased from $30,805 in 2020 to $22,164 in 2021 [6]. This decrease in debt and finance lease liabilities was primarily due to the repayment of long-term notes, early retirement of long-term notes, and the elimination of borrowings [9].

From 2020 to 2021, there were notable shifts in total loans and deposits across various lines of business, influenced by several economic factors. Total loans decreased, driven by lower loan demand and higher paydowns [3]. Specifically, average total loans decreased from $211,436 million in 2020 to $181,237 million in 2021, a reduction of $30,199 million or 14% ![Total loans decreased by 14% from 2020 to 2021.](image4). This decline was seen across multiple sectors, including commercial and industrial loans, which dropped by $22,867 million (16%), and commercial real estate loans, which decreased by $5,202 million (10%) ![Commercial and Industrial loans dropped by 16% from 2020 to 2021.](image4). The decrease in total loans was partially attributed to lower line utilization and continued high levels of client liquidity [3].

Conversely, total deposits increased due to higher levels of liquidity and lower investment spending, reflecting government stimulus programs and economic uncertainty related to the COVID-19 pandemic [4, 6]. This increase in deposits was also observed among consumer customers, who experienced higher savings due to stimulus and payment deferral programs [6]. The fluctuations in loan balances were further affected by specific actions, such as temporarily curtailing certain non-conforming residential mortgage originations [8].

Changes in net interest income also played a role, with lower net interest income reflecting lower loan balances driven by weak demand and the lower interest rate environment [1]. However, this was partially offset by higher income from deposit balances and increased deposit-related fees due to higher treasury management fees and transaction volumes [1]. The financial data from different lines of business shows these changes from 2021, 2020 and 2019 ![Financial data table for different lines of business.](image1).

Total loans decreased, while total deposits increased due to various economic factors like decreased loan demand, government stimulus, and the COVID-19 pandemic.

Chevron's financial results from 2019 to 2021 show considerable fluctuations in both upstream and downstream operations, significantly affecting the company's net income. ![The table shows Chevron's net income and earnings per share amounts for 2019, 2020, and 2021, along with sales and other operating revenues, and return on capital employed and stockholders' equity.](image2)

The upstream segment, which is most affected by crude oil prices [3], experienced losses in 2019 and 2020 before a substantial recovery in 2021. Specifically, U.S. upstream reported losses of \$5.1 billion in 2019 and \$1.6 billion in 2020, before earnings of \$7.3 billion in 2021 [5]. International upstream also followed a similar trend, with earnings of \$7.7 billion in 2019, a loss of \$825 million in 2020, and earnings of \$8.5 billion in 2021 [6]. These changes were largely due to fluctuations in crude oil prices and impairments [5, 6]. ![The table shows Chevron's Upstream and Downstream earnings for 2019, 2020, and 2021, with total net income attributable to Chevron Corporation.](image1)

The downstream segment showed more stability but still reflected market conditions. U.S. downstream earnings were \$1.6 billion in 2019, a loss of \$571 million in 2020, and earnings of \$2.4 billion in 2021 [9]. International downstream earnings were \$922 million in 2019, \$618 million in 2020, and \$525 million in 2021 [2]. The decrease in international downstream earnings in 2021 was primarily due to lower margins on refined product sales [2]. These operational results culminated in a net loss attributable to Chevron Corporation of \$5.5 billion in 2020 but rebounded to a net income of \$15.6 billion in 2021 [image1].

Overall, Chevron's financial performance from 2019 to 2021 was characterized by initial losses and a strong recovery, primarily driven by fluctuations in crude oil prices and the performance of its upstream operations.

To determine the R&D to asset ratio for Activision Blizzard in FY 2019, we need to calculate the ratio of product development costs to total assets. The product development cost for 2019 was $998 million, representing 15% of consolidated net revenues ![The table shows product development costs for 2019 and 2018, with a decrease of $103 million from 2018 to 2019.](image4). The total assets for 2019 were $19,845 million ![The balance sheet compares Activision Blizzard's financial position as of December 31, 2019, and December 31, 2018, detailing assets, liabilities, and shareholders' equity.](image5).

The R&D to asset ratio is calculated as follows:

```
R&D to Asset Ratio = (Product Development Costs) / (Total Assets)
R&D to Asset Ratio = ($998 million) / ($19,845 million)
R&D to Asset Ratio = 0.0503
```

Therefore, the R&D to asset ratio for Activision Blizzard in FY 2019 is approximately 0.0503 or 5.03%.

PMI's total shipment volume experienced a decrease of 11.6% [10]. Specifically, in Latin America and Canada, the total shipment volume decreased from 72,592 million units in 2019 to 64,200 million units in 2020 ![The image provides data on the PMI shipment volume in million units for the full years of 2020 and 2019, covering Cigarettes and Heated Tobacco Units in Latin America and Canada, showing a decrease of 11.6% in total shipment volume.](image3). This decline is further reflected in the cigarette shipment volumes, which decreased by 11.8% from 2019 to 2020 [10].
Several factors contributed to these changes. In Argentina, a decrease of 12.2% was primarily due to a lower market share caused by adult smokers switching to ultra-low-price brands and retail out-of-stock issues [2]. Similarly, Mexico experienced an 18.0% decrease due to a lower total market and adult smokers down-trading after price increases, compounded by the pandemic's impact [2]. However, Brazil saw a 13.4% increase, mainly due to a lower prevalence of illicit trade resulting from reduced price gaps with legal products and border restrictions due to the pandemic [9].
Despite the decrease in overall shipment volumes, net revenues in Latin America & Canada decreased by 22.9% overall, but only 15.5% excluding currency impacts. ![The table presents a financial summary for the years ended December 31 for 2020 and 2019, in millions of dollars, showing decreases in net revenues but significant increases in operating income.](image4). The net revenues were $1,701 million in 2020 compared to $2,206 million in 2019 [10].
The changes in shipment volumes and financial activities led to decreased net revenues but increased operating income in Latin America and Canada between 2019 and 2020.

Siemens Healthineers experienced notable shifts in both equity and liabilities between 2020 and 2021.

Equity saw an increase of €3,828 million, reaching €16,339 million [10].

![Equity increased significantly due to issuing new shares.](image1)

This growth was largely driven by the issuance of new shares in March 2021 to finance the acquisition of Varian, which led to increases in issued capital by €53 million and capital reserves by €2,275 million [10]. The company's comparable revenue growth was $19\,\%$ [2]. Further contributing to the equity increase was a rise in unappropriated net income of €497 million, although this was partially offset by dividend payouts to shareholders amounting to €856 million [3].

However, the equity ratio declined from $76\,\%$ to $55\,\%$ [3].

![The equity ratio declined despite an overall increase in equity.](image2)

This decline was primarily due to a significant increase in loan liabilities, even though the capital increase partially mitigated this effect [3]. The company also increased its treasury shares by €203 million to €240 million to fulfill share-based payment programs [5]. Additionally, Siemens Healthineers continued to utilize credit facilities from the Siemens Group, with €311 million drawn as of September 30, 2021 [6]. The company also had contractual obligations to purchase property, plant, and equipment totaling €84 million [4]. The cash flows from other transactions with Siemens Group resulted in a positive figure of €10,961 million, including borrowings of €10 billion and additional financing of €850 million for the Varian acquisition [7].

In summary, Siemens Healthineers' equity increased substantially due to new share issuances and net income, while its liabilities also grew significantly, leading to a decreased equity ratio.

Total sales and revenues for the fourth quarter of 2021 increased by $2.563 billion, or 23 percent, compared to the same period in 2020 [10]. This increase was primarily due to higher sales volume, driven by greater end-user demand for equipment and services, and the impact of changes in dealer inventories, alongside favorable price realization [10].  ![The image is a bar graph comparing consolidated sales and revenues for the fourth quarter of 2021 versus the fourth quarter of 2020.](image1) This is visually represented in the bar graph, where sales volume contributed significantly to the increased revenue.

Specifically, Construction Industries saw a substantial increase, with sales rising by $1.228 billion, or 27 percent, due to higher sales volume influenced by changes in dealer inventories, increased end-user demand, and favorable price realization [5]. Dealers decreased inventories more during the fourth quarter of 2020 than in 2021 [5].  North America sales also increased significantly, by 29 percent, influenced by changes in dealer inventories, higher end-user demand for services, and favorable price realization [4].  ![The table presents financial data for different segments and regions over the fourth quarters of 2021 and 2020, focusing on sales and revenues for a company's Machinery, Energy & Transportation and Financial Products segments.](image3) In Asia/Pacific, sales increased by 9 percent, driven by changes in dealer inventories, higher end-user demand, and favorable price realization [8].

Operating profit for the fourth quarter of 2021 was $1.611 billion, a $231 million, or 17 percent, increase from $1.380 billion in the fourth quarter of 2020 [7]. While higher manufacturing costs and increased SG&A and R&D expenses partially offset this gain, it was primarily driven by higher sales volume, favorable price realization, and net restructuring income from the sale of a facility [7]. ![The image is a chart comparing consolidated operating profit between the fourth quarter of 2020 and the fourth quarter of 2021 for Caterpillar.](image4) The chart illustrates how sales volume and price realization positively impacted the operating profit, while manufacturing costs had a negative impact. The segment profit for Financial Products also increased by $53 million, or 27 percent, mainly due to a favorable impact from returned or repossessed equipment and lower provision for credit losses [3].  The consolidated operating profit for 2021 was $1,611 million, up from $1,380 million in 2020, reflecting a $231 million or 17% increase [Image2].

In summary, the increase in sales volume and operating profit for the fourth quarter of 2021, compared to 2020, was mainly due to higher end-user demand, changes in dealer inventories, favorable price realization, and gains from restructuring activities.

In conclusion, net income and EPS are influenced by adjustments like restructuring, asset divestments, and legal provisions, with tax implications further shaping the core results.

In 2021, Chevron's equity structure and cash flow were significantly influenced by cash dividends and treasury stock transactions, as detailed in the consolidated financial statements [1]. The consolidated statement of equity elucidates these impacts, presenting changes in equity components and common stock share activity over several years ![The table presents information about a company's equity changes over several years, detailing changes in equity components, common stock share activity, net income, cash dividends, purchases and issuances of treasury shares, and acquisitions.](image3).

The payment of cash dividends directly reduces retained earnings, a key component of stockholders' equity, as illustrated in the equity statement ![The table shows financial data with a significant net income in 2021, currency translation adjustments, unrealized holding gain/loss on securities, derivatives, defined benefit plans, and other comprehensive income, resulting in positive comprehensive income.](image2). Simultaneously, the financing activities section of the consolidated statement of cash flows would reflect the outflow of cash due to dividend payments ![The table presents consolidated cash flow data, divided into operating, investing, and financing activities, for a company over three years.](image4). Treasury stock transactions, involving the purchase and reissuance of the company’s own shares, affect equity by reducing treasury stock (at cost) when shares are repurchased and potentially increasing capital in excess of par value if reissued above cost. These transactions are also reflected in the financing activities section of the cash flow statement, showing cash outflows for purchases and inflows for issuances. The balance sheet also reflects these changes, detailing components such as common stock, retained earnings, and treasury stock [6].

Therefore, cash dividends reduced retained earnings and cash, while treasury stock transactions altered both equity components and cash flow, reflecting strategic capital management.

The adoption of AASB 16 Leases from 1 July 2019 brought about significant changes in accounting for leases [2]. This standard introduces a single, on-balance sheet accounting model for lessees, leading the Group to recognize right-of-use assets and lease liabilities [10].

![AASB 16 requires lessees to recognize right-of-use assets and lease liabilities on the balance sheet.](image1)

Upon transitioning to AASB 16, lease liabilities were measured at the present value of the remaining lease payments, discounted at the Group’s incremental borrowing rate as of 1 July 2019 [8].  Right-of-use assets were measured at an amount equal to the lease liability, adjusted by any prepaid or accrued lease payments [8].  Site restoration is now capitalized as part of the lease right-of-use asset and depreciated over the lease term [4].

Regarding employee benefits, liabilities for wages, salaries, and annual leave expected to be settled within 12 months are calculated at undiscounted amounts based on remuneration wage and salary rates expected at the reporting date, including related on-costs [1].

In summary, the transition to AASB 16 resulted in the recognition of right-of-use assets and lease liabilities on the balance sheet, while employee benefit liabilities were calculated based on undiscounted amounts of expected remuneration.

The acquisition of ClickSoftware involved a more detailed allocation of fair value to various assets and liabilities compared to the Salesforce.org acquisition. For ClickSoftware, the net assets acquired totaled $1,386 million, including significant amounts for goodwill ($1,132 million) and intangible assets ($276 million) ![The table lists various financial items and their associated fair values](image5). Key intangible assets included developed technology ($215 million) and customer relationships ($61 million) ![The image is a table showing intangible assets subject to amortization](image1). Additionally, ClickSoftware's assets included cash and cash equivalents ($38 million), accounts receivable ($28 million), and other assets ($33 million), while liabilities included accounts payable, accrued expenses, and other liabilities ($-55 million), unearned revenue ($-40 million), and deferred tax liability ($-26 million) [5]. The goodwill was primarily attributed to the assembled workforce and expanded market opportunities [4, 5]. The fair value of consideration transferred for ClickSoftware was approximately $1.4 billion [8].

In contrast, the business combination with Salesforce.org involved a different allocation of net assets. The net assets acquired totaled $134 million and included cash and cash equivalents ($54 million), a deferred tax asset ($59 million), and other current and noncurrent assets ($46 million), along with goodwill ($164 million) ![The table lists various assets and liabilities along with their fair values](image2). Liabilities included accounts payable, accrued expenses, and other liabilities ($-39 million), unearned revenue ($-138 million), and deferred income taxes and income taxes payable ($-12 million). A notable aspect of the Salesforce.org transaction was a non-cash charge of approximately $166 million recorded within operating expenses due to favorable reseller agreement terms [10]. The combination with Salesforce.org contributed approximately $228 million in total revenues in fiscal year 2020 [2].

Both acquisitions resulted in goodwill being recorded, primarily attributed to the assembled workforce and expanded market opportunities [3, 4, 5]. However, ClickSoftware's acquisition involved a much larger scale and a more detailed breakdown of identifiable intangible assets, such as developed technology and customer relationships, which was not specified in the Salesforce.org acquisition details.

In summary, the ClickSoftware acquisition involved a detailed allocation of fair value across various asset and liability categories, whereas the Salesforce.org acquisition had a more simplified allocation with a notable charge related to the reseller agreement.

Toyota's executive remuneration system is designed to align with corporate performance and shareholder value [8]. The Annual Total Remuneration for each executive position is determined using a formula based on benchmark results of executive compensation [1]. This remuneration is linked to consolidated operating income and the volatility of Toyota's share price [1, 3, 10], reflecting the company's financial performance and shareholder value. Individual performance evaluation is also a factor, assessed in accordance with the "Toyoda" concept [1].

The Board of Directors decides the policy for determining remuneration, linking it to corporate performance while considering individual responsibilities [2]. Performance-based remuneration is determined by consolidated operating income, share price volatility, and individual performance, considering job responsibilities and the remuneration standard of the executive's home country [10]. Toyota also considers the benefit of its shareholders as an important element of its management policy, working to improve corporate structure and enhance corporate value for sustainable growth [7]. This involves striving to ensure stable and continuous dividend payments [7].

Toyota sets appropriate executive compensation levels based on position and duties, referencing a benchmark group of companies in Japan [4]. The Executive Compensation Meeting determines the amount of remuneration for each member of the Board of Directors, taking into account factors such as corporate performance, individual job responsibilities, and performance [5].
![The image displays a flowchart that illustrates Toyota's executive compensation decision-making process.](image1)

Toyota’s executive remuneration evaluation reflects their business performance and shareholder value indicators through consolidated operating income, share price volatility, and individual performance evaluations.
