European Venture Funds have evolved since the 1990s [1], and the distribution of investment stages has shifted considerably over time. Examining the data from 1998 to 2007, significant changes are evident in how funds were allocated across different stages.

In 1998, seed investments comprised a substantial portion of the fund, accounting for 78% with 21 investments, while early-stage investments made up 18% with 5 investments, and mid-stage investments were only 4% with 1 investment ![The image illustrates the distribution of funds across Seed, Early Stage, and Mid-Stage for the years 1998, 2000, and 2007, highlighting a shift in focus towards Early Stage investments by 2007.](image1). By 2007, this distribution had changed dramatically; seed investments decreased to just 10% with 2 investments, early-stage investments rose to 74% with 14 investments, and mid-stage investments increased to 16% with 3 investments ![The image illustrates the distribution of funds across Seed, Early Stage, and Mid-Stage for the years 1998, 2000, and 2007, highlighting a shift in focus towards Early Stage investments by 2007.](image1). This reflects a clear shift towards early-stage ventures, potentially due to an entrepreneurial boom and a maturing venture ecosystem [7].

Notably, while venture capital fund commitments remained down for the last 6 years, the fundamentals for a venture decade in Europe improved, creating a demand-supply imbalance of available capital [7]. Furthermore, despite lower entry valuations in Europe compared to the US ![The image shows that early-stage entry valuations are higher in the USA compared to Europe.](image4), European venture capital has demonstrated capital efficiency, approximately 70 percent higher than in the US [4].

The distribution of investment stages shifted from a seed-heavy focus in 1998 to an early-stage emphasis in 2007.

Since 1990, STEM employment has grown significantly [8, 10]. The analysis of the U.S. Census Bureau’s American Community Survey indicates that employment in STEM occupations has increased by $79\%$ since 1990 [3]. Overall employment grew only $34\%$ [8].

Driven by the proliferation of information technology industries and the growth of the health care sector, computer workers have more than quadrupled since 1990 [8]. ![Computer jobs experienced the largest growth in STEM fields since 1990.](image5) The largest growth occurred in computer occupations ($338\%$ growth since 1990) [3]. In comparison, healthcare practitioners and technicians have nearly doubled (a $92\%$ increase) [8].

Computer occupations have experienced the most significant growth since 1990.

Therefore, 20% of people regularly access mobile phones outside their homes, which is more than other technologies like television, computers, and the internet, although less than those who don't use any such technologies.

Latino registered voters tend to identify with or lean towards the Democratic Party over the Republican Party by nearly a two-to-one margin [4]. This preference has shown little shift in recent years [4, 8].

The Democratic Party has generally maintained a lead over the Republican Party among Latino voters, as the Democratic affiliation has remained relatively stable, with 64% in 2022, while the Republican affiliation has seen slight fluctuations but remains significantly lower ![The graph illustrates the affiliations of Democratic and Republican parties from 2019 to 2022.](image3).

Despite this general preference, future party affiliation remains uncertain due to soft ties to political parties [2]. Registered Latino voters are not entirely monolithic in their views; substantial portions feel there are significant differences among Hispanics based on their political affiliations ![The chart shows the perceived differences among Hispanics based on their political affiliation.](image2). A considerable percentage of all Hispanics (45%) believe there is a great deal of difference among them, and this sentiment is similarly echoed among both Democratic and Republican leaners [image2].

Even with a general alignment towards the Democratic party, many Latino voters are dissatisfied with the current state of affairs in the country [3]. While the economy remains a critical issue, other concerns such as healthcare, violent crime, education, and gun policy also hold substantial importance [9]. The issue of abortion has also risen significantly in importance among Hispanic voters [10]. This indicates a dynamic interplay of factors influencing their voting decisions.

In summary, while Latino registered voters largely lean towards the Democratic Party, this alignment has remained fairly stable in recent years, and there are recognized differences within the Latino community based on political affiliation and a variety of important issues influencing their choices.

Europe's venture capital (VC) market demonstrates distinct characteristics when compared to the US, particularly regarding capital efficiency and exit values [1, 2].  The scarcity of VC funding in Europe leads to increased capital efficiency, approximately 70 percent higher than in the US [1].  This efficiency, combined with lower entry valuations [5], allows European VC to match the US in successful exit values, averaging around $350 million [2].

While average exit values in Europe are about 25% smaller, lower entry valuations and higher capital efficiency compensate for this difference [4]. Furthermore, real performance data indicates that European VC drives the best exit multiples globally [9], achieving similar exit magnitudes with only half the VC investment compared to the US [10]. ![Europe has a higher median multiple of cash invested and a greater percentage of investments reaching a multiple of 5 or more than the USA.](image4)
As shown, the median multiple of cash invested in Europe is 7.2 compared to 4.5 in the USA [image4]. The median exit valuation is $173 million for Europe and $236 million for the USA [image4].

The median exit valuation in the USA was $63 million more than in Europe at the time of the presentation.

In Indonesia, the mobile landscape includes several GSM/WCDMA & CDMA operators [6]. Telkomsel, XL Axiata, and Indosat are the major GSM players [6]. By early 2014, Indonesia had 240 million mobile subscribers, demonstrating continuous growth [3].

Comparing subscriber and data user numbers between 2013-2014 and late 2014 for Telkomsel, XL, and Indosat provides insights into their performance.
![A bar chart showing the number of subscribers, smartphone users, BlackBerry users, Android users, and data users for Telkomsel, XL, and Indosat.](image4)
In late 2014, Telkomsel had 139.3 million subscribers and 63.5 million data users, XL had 58.3 million subscribers and 32 million data users, and Indosat had 54.2 million subscribers and 29 million data users [Telecom Operators-late 2014(4)].
![A bar chart comparing various metrics for different telecommunications providers.](image2)

Notably, the rise of data-based services like IM and VoIP has reduced SMS and voice call usage [10], leading to decreased ARPU [5]. The prepaid ARPU for major telecom companies like Indosat, Telkomsel and XL decreased from 2008 to 2012 [image5].
![A bar chart comparing the prepaid ARPU for four telecom companies in 2008 and 2012.](image5)
This shift highlights the increasing importance of data services in driving revenue and subscriber engagement for these operators [10].

The data indicates a growing reliance on data services and a shift away from traditional voice and SMS, suggesting that operators like Telkomsel, XL, and Indosat are focusing on expanding their data user base to offset declining ARPU from voice and SMS services.

Among adults who majored in STEM, women are more likely than men to work in a STEM occupation [6]. This is especially driven by women with health professions degrees, where 69% of women work in a health-related occupation compared to 61% of men [6].

Looking at employment sectors across different STEM degrees, employment distribution varies by gender. ![The image is a stacked bar chart comparing the employment sectors of men and women with different STEM degrees.](image3)

For those with computer degrees, 53% of men are employed in a computer occupation, while women with engineering degrees are less likely than men to be in engineering jobs (24% vs. 30%) [8].

Considering all college-educated STEM workers, 81% of those who majored in health professions are women, but only 16% of those who majored in engineering are women [9]. This also corresponds to the share of women in these occupational clusters [9].

Therefore, there is a difference of 7% in the percentage of women and men who have received a STEM degree and are employed in their field, with women being more likely to be employed in a STEM field than men.

Liberal Democrats are notably more pessimistic about America's future global influence, with a significant percentage believing it will diminish [4]. In contrast, conservative Republicans are far less likely to share this concern [4]. These differences highlight deep divisions in how different political groups perceive the pandemic's impact on U.S. influence.

Partisan divisions are evident, as Democrats are more inclined than Republicans to anticipate a weakening of American influence [7]. Specifically, 56% of liberal Democrats foresee a decline in U.S. influence, a stark contrast to the views of moderate and conservative Democrats, as well as Republicans [4].

Across different demographics, opinions vary. ![The chart illustrates opinions across different political groups.](image3) The survey data reveals that those with a postgraduate education are split, with nearly equal percentages believing U.S. influence will either improve or remain the same [image5]. ![The bar chart shows survey results on three categories: "More," "About the same," and "Less."](image4) However, when considering political affiliations, a clearer picture emerges [4, 7].

Women in STEM jobs are more likely than men to face gender discrimination [3]. Half of women in STEM report experiencing some form of gender-related discrimination at work, a figure much higher than the 19% of men in STEM positions who report the same [3, 5].

This disparity is further highlighted when examining specific issues such as gender-related discrimination, sexual harassment, and the perception of gender as a hindrance to success, the percentages for women are notably higher than those for men ![The image presents a survey comparing the experiences of men and women in computer jobs regarding gender-related issues at work](image1). For example, 74% of women in computer jobs report gender-related discrimination compared to only 16% of men [image1].

Experiences of women in STEM vary depending on the gender composition of their workplace; those in majority-male environments are far more likely to report discrimination [7]. 78% of women in majority-male STEM workplaces report gender discrimination, compared to 43% in majority-female workplaces [7].  A significant 48% of women in majority-male workplaces feel that their gender has hindered their career success, while only 12% of women in majority-female workplaces feel the same [7].
![The chart illustrates that women in STEM, particularly in male-dominated environments, often face more gender-related challenges compared to their male counterparts](image5)

Common forms of gender discrimination include earning less than male counterparts (29%), being treated as incompetent (29%), encountering repeated slights (20%), and receiving less support from senior leaders (18%) [3, 6].

While women in STEM are more likely to experience discrimination than men, they report similar rates of sexual harassment as women in non-STEM jobs [4, 9].

In summary, gender discrimination is more prevalent among women in STEM jobs compared to their male counterparts, particularly in male-dominated environments.

While requiring government-issued photo ID to vote is favored by majorities in both partisan groups, Republicans are considerably more likely than Democrats to strongly favor this policy [5]. ![Republicans are more likely to strongly favor photo identification requirements for voting than Democrats.](image5)

Looking at the opinions on voting reforms over time, total support requiring all voters to show government-issued photo identification to vote remained constant at 76% from October 2018 to April 2021, while support among  Republicans/Lean Republican increased from 91% to 93%, and decreased among Democrat/Lean Democrat from 63% to 61% ![Support for requiring photo ID to vote remained constant.](image1). Democrats and Republicans diverge significantly in their strength of support for requiring photo ID to vote, with Republicans showing much stronger support.

European VC has shown strong fundamentals, especially after shaking off the impact of the capital deluge from 1999-2001 [4, 6]. Confidence in Donald Trump varies across different domains [8]. The public shows mixed confidence in Trump on key issues [2]. Notably, a narrow majority (54%) expresses confidence in his ability to negotiate favorable trade agreements [2].

However, regarding specific issues, 55% of the public has little or no confidence in Trump’s immigration policy, while 54% lack confidence in his handling of international crises and his ability to work effectively with Congress [5]. These figures reflect significant public reservations in these domains. In general, 54% say they don’t like the way he conducts himself as president [9].

Here are the domains where adults express the highest confidence and lack of confidence in Donald Trump's government, based on the survey data:

1.  **Negotiate favorable trade agreements with other countries**: A narrow majority (54%) are either very or somewhat confident [2].
2.  **Not confident in immigration policy**: 55% of the public say they have little or no confidence [5].

Therefore, the answer is: ["Negotiate favorable trade agreements with other countries", "Not confident in immigration policy"].

Among self-identified Hispanics, the composition of friendship networks varies across immigrant generations [1]. A significant 77% of foreign-born Latinos report that all or most of their friends are also Latino. This percentage decreases to 55% among second-generation Latinos. By the third or higher generation, only 37% of self-identified Latinos say the same [1]. This can be visualized in ![The chart shows the percentage of Latinos who say all or most of their friends are Latino, broken down by generation.](image2).

To find the average, we sum the percentages of each group (77% + 55% + 37%) and divide by 3: (77 + 55 + 37) / 3 = 56.33%.

On average, approximately 56.33% of Latinos (foreign-born, second generation, and third or higher generation) say that all or most of their friends are Latinos.

ISRO operates several key facilities in Bengaluru, supporting various aspects of its space program. One of these is the ISRO Telemetry, Tracking and Command Network (ISTRAC), which plays a crucial role in tracking ISRO's satellite and launch vehicle missions and also provides space operations support for Deep Space Missions [2].
![ISTRAC provides tracking support for all satellite and launch vehicle missions of ISRO](image3)

Additionally, Bengaluru hosts the ISRO Satellite Centre (ISAC), which is the lead center for the design, development, fabrication, and testing of all Indian-made satellites [8].
![ISAC is the lead centre of ISRO for design, development and testing of all Indian made satellites](image2)

These facilities, along with the DOS Secretariat and ISRO Headquarters, which coordinate various programs, demonstrate Bengaluru's importance to the Indian Space Programme [7]. Bengaluru is a hub for ISRO's satellite development, tracking, and program coordination.

Americans hold varied and significant concerns regarding China, spanning human rights, economic issues, and political threats [6, 8, 9]. When prompted about their initial thoughts on China, a substantial number of Americans mention human rights concerns [4].

![Human rights and the economy are top-of-mind for Americans when they think of China](image5)

Specifically, half of Americans view China's human rights policies as a very serious problem for the U.S., a figure that has risen in recent years [6]. This includes concerns about the lack of personal freedoms and the treatment of Uyghurs in Xinjiang [4, 6].

![The percentage change from 2020 to 2021 on various issues related to China](image4)

Furthermore, economic issues weigh heavily on the minds of Americans, with many citing China's powerful economy and its role as a manufacturing center [9]. Concerns about cyber attacks and the loss of U.S. jobs to China are also prominent, with significant percentages of Americans viewing these as very serious problems [8]. Older Americans tend to express even greater concern across these issues [7]. While some believe the U.S. should prioritize promoting human rights in China even at the expense of economic relations, overall economic ties are seen as strained [9, image3].

The top concerns Americans have about China include human rights issues, economic challenges, and political and security threats.

Hispanics' expectations for their financial future are closely linked to their present financial circumstances [4]. According to the Pew Research Center National Survey of Latinos, a considerable proportion of Hispanics, specifically 59%, describe their financial condition as "only fair" (47%) or "poor" (12%) [2].

Those who rate their current financial situation as excellent or good are more optimistic about future improvements [3].  ![The bar chart shows that Hispanics with excellent financial conditions are most likely to expect their finances to improve a lot.](image1) As shown in the segmented bar chart, when evaluating different financial situations, 15% of those who consider their financial situation as poor expect their financial situation to get a lot worse.

Following the crash, social media platforms became increasingly important [1, 10]. Within 90 minutes of the crash, both Airbus and Lufthansa acknowledged the incident via Twitter [5]. Germanwings, Lufthansa and Airbus quickly adapted their websites and social media platforms [1].

Germanwings focused its digital activity on Twitter, posting in both English and German [4]. Both Germanwings and Lufthansa experienced significant spikes in followers on Twitter because of the crash [4].

![Germanwings, Airbus, and Lufthansa each have a line graph showing number of Twitter followers from March 20 to March 25.](image5)

The number of tweets referencing #Germanwings reached nearly 500,000 globally within six hours [9]. Germanwings had become the top trending topic on Twitter within the first 60 minutes [8].

The number of followers on Twitter significantly increased for Germanwings, Airbus, and Lufthansa following the crash.

Women in STEM jobs are more likely than their male counterparts to view sexual harassment as a problem in their workplace [1, 8]. Specifically, 36% of women in STEM consider sexual harassment to be at least a small problem in their workplace, compared to 28% of men [1, 3].

These findings highlight a significant difference in how men and women in STEM experience and perceive sexual harassment in their professional environments [4, 5].

Women in STEM jobs are more likely than men to perceive sexual harassment as a problem in their workplace [8].

Hispanic voters' views on Biden are closely related to their sense of Hispanic identity [7]. A greater percentage of Hispanic voters who consider their Hispanic identity important approve of Biden's performance compared to those who do not [7]. Specifically, 52% of Hispanics who say being Hispanic is important to how they think of themselves approve of Biden, while only 37% of those who say it is less important share this view [2, 7].

This is further highlighted by the fact that most Hispanics who consider their Hispanic identity extremely or very important would vote for the Democratic candidate in their local congressional district [5]. Furthermore, the vast majority of these voters do not want Trump to remain a national political figure ![The majority of Hispanic voters who consider their Hispanic identity important do not want Trump to remain a national political figure.](image1).

Looking at the approval and disapproval ratings, the image shows that among those for whom being Hispanic is extremely/very important, 52% approve of Biden's performance ![Approval ratings of Biden vary among Hispanic registered voters based on factors such as political affiliation, religious affiliation, and the importance of being Hispanic.](image2). In contrast, the disapproval rate is 47% within this group.

In summary, Hispanic registered voters who consider their Hispanic identity important are more likely to approve of Biden's job performance compared to those who do not.

The Republican party has had a steep increase in limiting China's power and influence since 2018 [4]. Overall, these statistics indicate a strong association between conservative Republican affiliation and the perception of China as an enemy [9].

There are significant differences in opinions on the pace of lifting COVID-19 restrictions based on political affiliations and racial groups [10]. Democrats overwhelmingly express concern that state restrictions on public activity have been lifted too quickly [1]. This concern is echoed by a large majority of Black adults (84%) and Hispanic adults (72%), along with nearly two-thirds of white adults (65%) [9].

Republicans, however, are more divided, with a slight majority believing restrictions have not been lifted quickly enough [2].  Notably, conservative Republicans are more inclined to think restrictions are not being lifted fast enough, while moderate and liberal Republicans share concerns that restrictions have been lifted too quickly [2].

![The image is a bar chart showing survey results on opinions about lifting restrictions too quickly versus not quickly enough. It is divided by demographics including race (White, Black, Hispanic), age groups (18-29, 30-49, 50-64, 65+), education level (Postgrad, College grad, Some college, HS or less), and political affiliation (Rep/Lean Rep, Dem/Lean Dem) with further breakdowns into Conservative, Mod/Lib, and Liberal. Each category has two percentages: "Not lifted quickly enough" and "Lifted too quickly." The majority in most groups believe restrictions were "Lifted too quickly."](image2)

Partisan divisions are evident when considering the reasons for continued outbreaks, with a significant gap between Democrats and Republicans on whether lifting COVID-19 restrictions too quickly is a major reason (82% of Democrats vs. 31% of Republicans) [4].  These partisan differences overshadow geographic variations, with a majority of Democrats attributing the rise in confirmed cases to rising infections, regardless of the COVID-19 impact in their area [8].

![The image is a graph from Pew Research Center showing survey results about some opinions of U.S. adults conducted from July 27 to August 2, 2020. The categories are "Less," "About as," and "More." - **Total**: 62% for "Less," 25% for "About as," and 13% for "More." - **Rep/Lean Rep**: 34% for "Less," 42% for "About as," and 22% for "More." - **Dem/Lean Dem**: 87% for "Less," 8% for "About as," and 4% for "More." Note: "No response not shown."](image3)

In summary, Democrats and racial minority groups are more concerned that COVID-19 restrictions have been lifted too quickly, while Republicans are more divided, with many feeling the pace is too slow.

The perception of neighborhood Hispanic identity varies among self-identified Hispanics across generations, particularly regarding the prevalence of Hispanic neighbors. There is a notable difference in the proportion of Hispanics who report that "all" or "most" of their neighbors are also Hispanic, depending on whether they are self-identified Hispanics or self-identified non-Hispanics [5].

Among self-identified Hispanics, the foreign-born and second-generation individuals are more likely to report that "all" or "most" of their neighbors share their heritage ![Foreign-born and second-generation Hispanics are more likely to report that most of their neighbors share their heritage.](image1). Specifically, about 41% of both the foreign-born and second-generation Hispanics report this, in comparison to 30% of third or higher generation self-identified Latinos [10]. This trend indicates that as generations progress, the likelihood of living in predominantly Hispanic neighborhoods decreases [10].

In contrast, self-identified non-Hispanics with Hispanic ancestry are more dispersed across the country, with only 17% reporting that "all" or "most" of their neighbors are Hispanic [5]. This suggests that later generations of Hispanic Americans are less likely to reside in heavily Hispanic neighborhoods compared to first and second-generation immigrants and their children [2].
   
These differences highlight how the closeness to immigrant experiences shapes the views and experiences with Hispanic culture and identity [2, 1]. As generations progress, the connection to heavily Hispanic neighborhoods diminishes, potentially influencing identity and cultural ties [9].

Overall, perceptions of neighborhood Hispanic identity vary, with foreign-born and second-generation Hispanics more likely to live in predominantly Hispanic neighborhoods compared to later generations.

After 2004, the European venture capital landscape experienced significant shifts, particularly in fundraising and market dynamics [6]. The market saw a saturation of pre-bubble VC funds around 2004-2005 ![Market saturation with pre-bubble VC funds](image1). Simultaneously, an exit boom began to drive up demand around 2005 [1].

Despite improving fundamentals for a venture decade in Europe, venture capital fund commitments remained low for the six years leading up to the period discussed, creating a demand-supply imbalance [6]. The graph indicates a substantial "current supply gap" around 2009-2010, pointing to a scarcity of available capital relative to demand ![Significant supply gap in venture capital](image1). This scarcity led to increased capital efficiency and yield due to investors being more selective [3].

The number of VC funds in Europe experienced a significant decrease, dropping from 1,600 in 1999 to 711 in 2011, marking a 63% decline ![Decline in the number of VC funds in Europe](image5). Additionally, post-bubble vintages, effectively starting around 2004/2005, showed significantly better performance, reaching an inflection point as evidenced by recent exits across top-tier funds [5]. The venture deal flow experienced an immediate 50% drop in 2000, and many entrepreneurs retreated after the bubble burst around 2001-2002 ![Drop in venture deal flow and entrepreneur retreat](image1). Furthermore, a large percentage of VC funds, approximately 65%, faded into obsolescence [1].

Early-stage VC fundraising in Europe after 2004 was characterized by a supply gap, increased capital efficiency, and improved performance of post-bubble vintages despite a decrease in the number of active funds.

Americans and Germans hold different opinions on countries and international organizations [5]. Germans tend to view these nations and organizations more positively than Americans, with the divide being starkest when it comes to views of the EU [5].
![The image is a comparative bar chart showing approval ratings of five international entities (EU, Russia, China, UN, and NATO) from the perspectives of three groups: U.S., a 32-country median, and Germany.](image1)
While roughly seven-in-ten Germans favor the EU, only about half of Americans agree [5]. There is greater consensus on the UN and NATO, though notably, Germans tend to think more highly of these organizations than Americans [5]. About one-in-five Americans express no opinion of either the EU or NATO [5]. The approval ratings for the EU are 51% from the U.S. and 69% from Germany, highlighting an +18% difference [image1]. For NATO, the ratings are 52% from the U.S. and 57% from Germany, showing a smaller +5% difference [image1].

In general, Germans tend to view international organizations more favorably than Americans [5].

Many people express concerns regarding automated systems because they believe these systems are unfair [1]. Although some think algorithms would be effective, a large portion of Americans are skeptical about their fairness [4, 2].

![U.S. adults have mixed opinions on the acceptability of using automated criminal risk scores in the criminal justice system.](image3)

Those who find automated criminal risk scores unacceptable often feel that every individual and circumstance is different [10]. Some worry about the lack of human involvement in the process and that the system might result in unfair bias or profiling [1, 10]. The ability of people to change over time is another significant concern [8]. Alternatively, some individuals believe the current system relying on human decisions is more flawed [7, 9]. They argue that decisions are often made subjectively, and using objective criteria could lead to fairer outcomes for all individuals [9].

In conclusion, the acceptability of automated criminal risk scores is divided due to concerns about fairness, the lack of individual consideration, and the potential for bias, versus the perceived objectivity and potential for reducing human biases.

Educational attainment appears to correlate with differing congressional vote preferences. In contrast, voters without a college degree are more divided in their preferences [4]. Specifically, only 20% of those with a high school degree or less think neither party has high ethical standards [3]. This divide may contribute to the differing levels of support for congressional candidates. Educational levels significantly influence congressional vote preferences, with higher education correlating with increased support for Democratic candidates.

From 1994 to 2018, there have been shifts in the proportions of Americans identifying with different political affiliations [5]. While the percentage of both Democrats and Republicans has remained relatively stable or slightly decreased, there's been a notable increase in the proportion of individuals identifying as independents [5].

These independents, however, are not necessarily politically unaligned. An overwhelming majority of independents (81\%) "lean" toward either the Republican or Democratic party [4]. The share of Democratic-leaning independents with a very unfavorable opinion of the Republican Party has more than quadrupled between 1994 and 2018 [9]. There has been a similar trend in how Republican leaners view the Democratic Party [9].

![The stacked area chart shows the percentage of people who identify as Democrats, Republicans, or Independents in the United States over the years 1994 to 2018.](image5)

Although the proportion of independents has increased, most still lean towards the major parties, and the small fraction of truly independent individuals often show limited interest in politics [7]. The chart shows that from 1994 to 2018, the percentage of independents grew, but most of them lean towards either the Democratic or Republican party [5].

The proportion of political independents in the U.S. increased from 1994 to 2018, but most of these individuals lean towards one of the two major parties.

Latino perceptions of their economic well-being have generally increased across most demographic subgroups [3, 4, 9]. Hamilton County has seen its share of trails and routes since its initial settlement [1]. The Nebraska City-Fort Kearny cut-off was one of the earliest routes, which became a popular trail that also went by the names Old Fort Kearney Road and the Pike’s Peak Trail [10]. Later, the development of railroads provided key connections to larger cities [6].

![The map highlights Hamilton County in Nebraska and its communities, also indicating routes such as NE-66, NE-14, US-34, and I-80.](image5)

Today, several major automobile routes serve Hamilton County [8]. These include State Highway 14, connecting Central City to Aurora and continuing south, and US Highway 34, running east to west from York to Grand Island across the county [8]. Additionally, Interstate 80 bisects the county east to west a few miles south of Aurora [8]. Key communities marked on the map include Aurora, Marquette, Phillips, Murphy, Hampton, Giltner, Kronborg, Hordville, and Stockham.

Major routes such as State Highway 14, US Highway 34, and Interstate 80 pass through Hamilton County, Nebraska, and key communities marked on the map include Aurora, Marquette, Phillips, Murphy, Hampton, Giltner, Kronborg, Hordville, and Stockham.

Several voting policies have broad support, but requiring electronic voting machines to print a paper backup of the ballot is particularly favored [8]. The overall support for this policy stands at 82% ![The image is a chart showing survey results about opinions on voting-related policies, segmented by different racial groups (Hispanic, Black, Asian, White) and their total percentage support.](image4).

Other policies with strong support include making early in-person voting available for at least two weeks before Election Day (78%) and requiring all voters to show government-issued photo identification (76%) [8]. Although a majority of adults support automatically registering all eligible citizens to vote (61%), this policy receives slightly less support compared to others [6].

There are significant racial and ethnic differences in support for various voting policies [1, 4]. For instance, Black adults show lower support for more restrictive policies like removing people from registration lists if they haven’t recently voted [3]. Black adults are also more likely to support allowing people with felony convictions to vote after serving their sentences (85%), compared to White, Hispanic, and Asian Americans (around 70%) [4]. However, among Democrats, White adults are sometimes more supportive of policies aimed at easing voting than Black, Hispanic, and Asian adults [5].

The voting policy with the highest overall support is requiring electronic voting machines to print a paper backup of the ballot, though levels of support vary across racial groups.

As generations pass, connections to ancestral national origins diminish among self-identified Hispanics [4]. The sense of connection to their family's country of origin decreases from 82% among immigrants to 44% by the third generation [4].

This trend is mirrored in cultural practices. While 49% of second-generation Hispanics report their immigrant parents often took them to Hispanic cultural celebrations, only 35% of third or higher generation Hispanics say the same about their childhoods [5]. ![The bar graph illustrates that 65% of self-identified Hispanics are third generation or higher, while 96% of self-identified non-Hispanics are also third generation or higher.](image4)

Intermarriage patterns also highlight this shift, with only 35% of married third-generation Hispanics having a Hispanic spouse, compared to 93% of married immigrant Hispanics [6]. Furthermore, the composition of friendship networks changes, with only 37% of third or higher generation Hispanics reporting that most of their friends are Latinos, down from 77% among immigrant Latinos [9]. ![This chart shows that as the generation increases, the percentage of people who speak Spanish and have a Spanish last name decreases among self-identified Hispanics.](image5)

The generational breakdown reveals a fading Hispanic identity as immigrant connections weaken, leading to a more diluted sense of heritage identification over time.

Over the past two decades, negative perceptions of opposing parties have risen among Republicans and Democrats [1]. A significant portion of both Democrats (88%) and Republicans (87%) hold unfavorable views of the other party, with these figures near all-time highs [2].  Independents who lean towards either party have also followed this trend [8]. The percentage of Democratic-leaning independents with a very unfavorable view of the Republican Party has increased significantly from 1994 to 2018 [3].  Similarly, Republican leaners' very unfavorable opinions of the Democratic Party have also increased [3].

![The graph illustrates increasing polarization over the years, with growing unfavorable views of the opposite party among partisan groups](image4)

However, it is worth noting that independents without a party preference are more likely to view both parties unfavorably [4, 5].  Still, the proportion of independents with a negative view of both parties has decreased in recent years [10]. In 2015, over a third (36%) of independents viewed both parties unfavorably [10]. Today, a majority of GOP leaners view the Republican Party favorably (55%), while just 24% view both parties unfavorably [9].  The shifts in ideology within party affiliations over nearly two decades can be visually represented, highlighting trends such as growing conservatism among Republicans and increasing liberalism among Democrats ![Democrats have increased their share in the Liberal section, starting at about 28% in 2000 and reaching 47% by 2018](image5).

In summary, unfavorable views of both Republican and Democratic parties have generally increased over time among party members and leaners, though the percentage of independents viewing both parties negatively has seen some decline in recent years.

"Uptown Funk!" demonstrated exceptionally strong performance across various platforms. Public confidence in Trump varies across different tasks, with some areas showing more concern than others [2, 3]. However, a deeper dive into specific performance evaluations reveals where the public feels Trump is least effective.

The tasks are rated across different levels of effectiveness: "Not at all," "Not too," "Somewhat," and "Very" effectively. ![The bar chart shows percentage of respondents who feel Trump is doing various aspects of performance not at all, not too, somewhat and very effectively.](image4)

For instance, while views on economic policy and trade agreements show some confidence [7, 9, 10], other areas highlight significant concern.   ![The line graph illustrates public opinion over time about Trump's performance in handling an international crisis, making good decisions about economic policy, decisions about immigration policy and working effectively with congress.](image5)

From 2004 to 2015, public opinion shifted from concerns about civil liberties to prioritizing national protection [7, 8]. Initially, more people worried about government policies restricting civil liberties, but by 2015, twice as many were concerned that policies didn't go far enough to protect the country [8].

This shift is visually represented in the change of the public opinion between 2004 and 2015. ![The graph illustrates a shift in public opinion over time.](image3)

Notably, this change occurred after Edward Snowden's leaks regarding NSA surveillance programs in 2013 [7]. The concern that policies have not gone far enough is now roughly the same as the high seen shortly after the failed Christmas Day terrorist attack on an airliner in 2010 [1]. The concern about government restrictions on civil liberties has dramatically decreased since July 2013 [7].

The graph indicates attitudes of Republicans, Democrats, and Independents regarding the government's anti-terrorism policies, highlighting the different levels of concern among the parties. ![The graph suggests how each group's metrics have changed over the specified years.](image4)

In conclusion, from 2004 to 2015, public opinion shifted from concerns about civil liberties to greater worry that anti-terrorism policies did not go far enough to protect the country.

Between 2014 and 2015, about half of all Hispanic adults said they were falling behind financially, as was true for the U.S. public as a whole [7]. While Hispanic views of family income in relation to the cost of living were unchanged, whites reported some improvement in their family income relative to the cost of living across the one-year time period [10].

![The image is a bar chart comparing the perceptions of family income relative to the cost of living among Hispanic, White, and Black adults in 2014 and 2015.](image4)

In 2014, 59% of White adults felt their income was falling behind, but this decreased to 49% in 2015 [image4]. The share of all Americans with a favorable view of their family’s future finances rose by 3 percentage points from 2011 to 2015 [6]. Overall in 2015, the three racial and ethnic groups looked fairly similar on this measure [10].

The White group experienced the most significant decrease in the percentage of households claiming their income was falling behind the cost of living, with a 10% drop from 59% in 2014 to 49% in 2015.

Hispanic Republicans are more inclined to believe the Republican Party cares about Hispanics compared to Hispanic Democrats [3]. A substantial share of Republicans (41%) feel the Republican Party cares about Hispanics, while only 7% of Democrats agree [3].

However, even among Hispanic Republicans, views are somewhat lukewarm, with 31% expressing this sentiment [3]. In contrast, most Hispanic Democrats (75% of conservatives and moderates, and 84% of liberals) disagree with the statement that the Republican Party cares about Hispanics [2].

![The image is a bar chart depicting survey responses from various demographic and political groups regarding how well they are doing. Furthermore, only a minority of Hispanic Republicans and Republican leaners find that the statement "the Republican Party really cares about Hispanics" describes their views well, with 41% of conservatives and 25% of moderates and liberals agreeing [2]. This contrasts sharply with the views of Hispanic Democrats, where a majority believes the Republican Party does not care about Hispanics [2]. This divergence highlights the deep partisan divide within the Hispanic community regarding the Republican Party.

In summary, Hispanic Republicans are more likely than Hispanic Democrats to believe that the Republican Party cares about Hispanics, though this view is not overwhelmingly positive even within the Republican demographic.

Hamilton County's population experienced significant changes between 1870 and 2000, influenced by factors such as railroad construction, immigration, and agricultural practices. The population exploded in the late 1800s [5]. The table shows the population of Hamilton County from 1870 to 2000, illustrating a surge in the late 19th century and subsequent fluctuations. ![The table shows the population of Hamilton County from 1870 to 2000, illustrating a surge in the late 19th century and subsequent fluctuations.](image3)

Initially, the county's population stood at 130 in 1870, which dramatically increased to 8,267 in 1880 and peaked at 14,096 in 1890 [5]. This rapid growth was spurred by the Transcontinental Railroad Act and the Homestead Act of 1862 [9]. The railroad facilitated the transformation of Nebraska into a booming agricultural state [9]. The Homestead Act attracted settlers by offering 160 acres of land to those who constructed a permanent structure and resided there for five years [9].

However, after its peak in 1890, Hamilton County's population slowly declined [5].  Consolidation in the agriculture sector also played a role as the number of farms decreased while the average farm size increased [4]. Despite these general trends, some towns like Aurora have shown recent population gains, contrasting the notion that small towns are disappearing [2]. Moreover, the presence of ethnic clusters such as the Danish in Kronborg and the Swedish in Hordville, contributed to the cultural and religious landscape, with churches like St. John's Lutheran Church serving as focal points for these communities [7, 10]. St. John’s Lutheran Church in Kronborg stands as a testament to the area's Danish heritage. ![St. John’s Lutheran Church in Kronborg stands as a testament to the area's Danish heritage.](image1)

Hamilton County's population initially surged due to railroad construction and homesteading, followed by a decline and fluctuations influenced by agricultural changes and ethnic settlements.

While 89% of Republicans are confident in Trump's ability to negotiate favorable trade agreements, only 19% of Democrats share the same level of confidence [5].   This divergence highlights a significant partisan divide in perceptions of Trump's capabilities [10].  Moreover, when it comes to working effectively with Congress, confidence levels are notably lower across the board, especially when compared to trade and economic policy, as depicted in ![The bar chart shows the levels of confidence for various governmental tasks, with "Work effectively with Congress" having the lowest confidence levels.](image1).

Confidence in Trump's abilities varies significantly between Republicans and Democrats, with his ability to negotiate trade agreements garnering higher confidence compared to his ability to work effectively with Congress.

European VC funds exhibit a notably different distribution compared to their US counterparts when benchmarked against US performance standards. In the US, VC funds are uniformly distributed across quartiles, with each quartile containing 25% of the 373 funds analyzed, indicating an even spread of performance [image1].

However, EU VC funds present a skewed distribution. A significant 35% of EU funds are in the top quartile, outperforming the US benchmark [image1]. The second quartile contains 25% of the funds, mirroring the US distribution, while the third and bottom quartiles hold 17% and 23% respectively [image1]. This indicates a stronger concentration of EU VC funds in the top quartile compared to the US, suggesting that a higher proportion of European funds achieve top-tier performance when evaluated against US benchmarks [3].

Moreover, while European VC-backed IPO performance matches or exceeds US performance, visibility on European VC Funds for investors is highly limited [1, 6]. The scarcity of VC money in Europe has led to higher capital efficiency and yield because the scarcity of money allows the very few investors to simply be more selective [5]. Active GPs managing funds of vintage greater than or equal to 2006 have investment-grade funds [2].

![The distribution of EU VC funds has a higher share in the top quartile compared to the US.](image1)

In summary, when benchmarked against the US, EU VC funds are more heavily concentrated in the top quartile compared to the uniform distribution seen in US VC funds.

Partisan views differ significantly, with most Republicans believing Obama was "not tough enough" on foreign policy, while most Democrats felt his approach was "about right" [2, 8].

Americans overwhelmingly favor limiting robots and computers to jobs that are dangerous or unhealthy for humans [5, 7]. Specifically, $85\%$ of Americans support this policy, with nearly half ($47\%$) strongly in favor ![Public strongly favors limiting machines to dangerous jobs](image5).

In comparison, other policies receive less support. While a majority still favor them, the percentages are lower.  For example, $62\%$ of Americans support the option to pay extra to interact with a human worker instead of a machine [1]. Likewise, support for a universal basic income and a national service program is at $60\%$ and $58\%$ respectively [1].

Political affiliation also influences these views, with Democrats generally showing more support for universal basic income ($77\%$) and national service programs ($66\%$) compared to Republicans ($38\%$ and $46\%$ respectively) [3, 6]. However, there are no major partisan differences in support for limiting machines to dangerous and dirty jobs [3]. This is further illustrated in the bar chart, where support for limiting machines to dangerous jobs is nearly equal among Democrats and Republicans ![Support for limiting machines to dangerous jobs is similar across political parties](image2).

Therefore, Americans express the strongest support for limiting machines to dangerous or unhealthy jobs compared to other automation policies like universal basic income or national service programs.

In 2016, there was a notable partisan divide regarding whether Democratic leaders should collaborate with President Trump, with only 35% of Clinton voters favoring cooperation, while 83% of Trump voters held this view [1]. This contrasts with the sentiment in 2008, where a larger proportion of voters, including those who supported the losing candidate, favored their party's leaders working with President Obama [2, 5, 8].

![In 2016, 59% of all voters believed Democratic leaders should work with Trump, while in 2008, 74% believed Republican leaders should work with Obama.](image2)

Specifically, in November 2008, 59% of Republicans and Republican-leaning voters felt that GOP leaders should work with Obama, whereas 36% preferred them to "stand up" to the new president [9]. This is in contrast to November 2016, where a higher percentage of Democratic voters preferred their leaders to stand up to Trump [9]. In fact, Democratic support for cooperation with the president-elect in 2016 was substantially less than GOP support for working with Obama eight years prior [7]. A significant 65% of Democratic voters in 2016 wanted Democratic leaders to stand up to Trump, even if it meant less progress in Washington [6].  Furthermore, in 2008, 52% of Obama voters supported him appointing Republicans to his cabinet, which is double the proportion of Trump voters who favored Democrats in his cabinet in 2016 [3].

![In 2008, 52% of Obama voters thought he should appoint Republicans to his cabinet.](image4)

Voter opinions regarding political leaders working with newly elected presidents showed a greater partisan divide in 2016 compared to 2008, with less willingness among the losing candidate's supporters to cooperate with the winning president.

Americans hold broadly negative views regarding the U.S. response to the coronavirus outbreak [5]. Only 13% of Americans think the U.S. response has been more effective than other wealthy countries [1, 9], as illustrated in ![showing the U.S. response to the coronavirus outbreak](image4).

In contrast, a significant majority, 62%, believe the U.S. response has been less effective compared to other wealthy nations [3]. A quarter of Americans feel the U.S. response has been about as effective as other countries [3, 9]. Republicans and Democrats diverge significantly in their opinions, with only 22% of Republicans believing the U.S. response was more effective, while 87% of Democrats consider it less effective [2, 7].

Most U.S. adults (69%) are more concerned that states are lifting restrictions too quickly [6], as shown in ![showing the percentage of people saying states lift the restrictions too quickly or too slow](image2). This concern aligns with the view that reducing infections is the most effective way to help the economy recover, favored by 73% of Americans [8], evidenced in ![indicating the percentages for the more effective way to help the economy recover](image1).

Overall, most Americans view the U.S. response to the coronavirus outbreak as less effective compared to other wealthy countries.

The ridership growth in specific locations impacts the broader ridership trends of Caltrain [1, 2]. The image depicts a crowded train, reflecting the growing ridership and the challenges of accommodating more passengers [image5].

Palo Alto University experienced a ridership growth of 38%, while Mountain View's ridership grew by 16% between 2012 and 2014.

The public's focus shifted significantly from economic issues to terrorism between December 2014 and December 2015 [1, 2, 8, 9, 10]. Mentions of economic issues such as the economy or unemployment as the most important problem decreased, while concerns about terrorism, national security, and ISIS surged [1, 2, 8].

![The table presents changes in public concerns from December 2014 to December 2015, showing a significant increase in concerns about terrorism and a decrease in economic issues.](image4)

Specifically, the share of the public mentioning economic issues dropped from 34% in December 2014 to 23% [1]. In contrast, those citing terrorism, national security, or ISIS rose dramatically from 4% to 29%, the highest level since February 2003 [2, 8]. As a result, terrorism has reshaped the public’s agenda both at home and abroad [2].

Public concern shifted from economic issues to terrorism between December 2014 and December 2015.

Following the 2016 election, voters held differing views on whether Trump would prioritize the needs of all Americans or favor those who supported him [4, 6]. Overall, 51% believed Trump would give equal priority to all Americans, while 46% thought he would prioritize his supporters [6].

However, these views were sharply divided along support lines. An overwhelming majority (84%) of Trump voters believed he would give equal priority to the needs of all Americans. ![Trump voters overwhelmingly think Trump will give equal priority to all Americans](image4). In stark contrast, 75% of Clinton voters anticipated that he would prioritize the needs of his supporters [2]. This divergence highlights the deep partisan divide in expectations and perceptions following the election [2].

Among self-identified Hispanics, racial identification varies across generations, as illustrated by data on racial identification ![The image shows the racial identification of self-identified Hispanics and non-Hispanics](image5). For instance, 78% of foreign-born Hispanics identify as Hispanic or Latino, while this percentage decreases to 66% among second-generation Hispanics and further to 46% among third or higher generation Hispanics [5].

Interestingly, as Hispanic identity decreases across generations, identification with other races increases. Among self-identified non-Hispanics, 59% say passersby on the street would describe them as white, and not Hispanic or Latino [4]. Conversely, the likelihood of being perceived as Hispanic decreases with each subsequent generation [9]. 

These shifts in identity are further underscored by the fact that the closer individuals are to their immigrant roots, the more likely they are to identify as Hispanic [7]. As observed in previous Pew Research Center Latino surveys, later generations may see their identity as more tied to the U.S. than to their ancestral origins [6]. The differences in identification appear in the perception of shared views as well ![The image shows perceptions of Hispanics in different groups regarding how many people in America share similar views](image1).

Racial identification differs across generations of self-identified Hispanics, with foreign-born Hispanics most likely to identify as Hispanic/Latino and subsequent generations showing a decrease in this identification.

Blacks in STEM jobs are more likely to report workplace discrimination due to race compared to other groups [1, 2, 7].  Specifically, a higher percentage of blacks in STEM report experiencing racial/ethnic discrimination (62%) compared to Asians (44%), Hispanics (42%), and whites (13%) [2, 7].

Discrimination in recruitment, hiring, and promotions is seen as a major reason for underrepresentation by 72% of blacks in STEM, while only 27% of whites and 28% of Asians share this view [4, 10]. ![Black STEM workers are more likely to report discrimination at work compared to other groups.](image3)

Blacks in STEM are also less convinced that black employees are treated fairly in hiring and promotions, with only 43% believing they are treated fairly during recruitment and 37% during promotion [5].  In contrast, most white STEM workers believe blacks are usually treated fairly in these processes [5].

Overall, there are significant differences in how racial and ethnic groups in STEM perceive workplace discrimination and fairness [10].

Voters' evaluations of the 2016 presidential campaign were notably negative compared to previous elections [5]. ![The graph shows the percentage of the vote received by winning and losing presidential candidates in U.S. elections from 1988 to 2016.](image2)Despite winning, Donald Trump received particularly low grades for his conduct during the campaign [8]. Only 30% of voters gave Trump an A or B, marking the lowest grade for a winning candidate in 28 years [8]. This contrasts sharply with past elections, where winning candidates typically received more favorable grades [10]. Even Trump's own supporters were not as positive as Obama's supporters had been in previous elections [4]. Furthermore, nearly two-thirds of Clinton voters (65%) gave Trump a failing grade [1].

Trump received the lowest voter grades compared to other winning candidates since 1988 [8].

Democrats overwhelmingly disapprove of Trump's conduct, with 85% expressing dislike [1, 6]. This sentiment remains consistent, showing little change since August [1].  ![Democrats overwhelmingly dislike Trump's conduct as president](image5). Republicans are more divided in their opinions; while 38% like his conduct, a significant 45% have mixed feelings [6, 7]. Opinions regarding the government's role in supporting workers displaced by automation are significantly divided along political lines [1, 3]. ![The bar chart shows that Democrats are more in favor of government responsibility while Republicans favor individual responsibility.](image5)Notably, 65% of Democrats and those leaning towards the Democratic party believe the government should support displaced workers, even if it necessitates higher taxes [1, 5]. In stark contrast, a nearly identical percentage (68%) of Republicans and Republican-leaning individuals feel that individuals should bear the responsibility for their financial well-being, even if widespread automation leads to job losses [1, 5]. This divide underscores a fundamental difference in perspectives on the role of government versus individual responsibility in addressing the challenges posed by automation [8].

The stark difference in opinions based on political affiliation is further highlighted when considering specific policies like universal basic income and national service programs [5]. A substantial 77% of Democrats favor a universal basic income, compared to only 38% of Republicans. Similarly, 66% of Democrats support a national service program, while only 46% of Republicans share this view [5]. ![Democrats show more support of guaranteed basic income and national service programs compared to Republicans.](image3)This partisan divide emphasizes differing views on how to best support workers in an era of increasing automation [10].

In summary, Democrats are more inclined to believe the government should support workers displaced by automation, while Republicans are more likely to believe individuals should be responsible for their own financial well-being [1].

Seniors have been historically slower in adopting technology [4]. Overall, 77% of seniors own cell phones, which is less than the 91% of all Americans who own one [3].

Smartphones in particular have a lower adoption rate among older adults, with only 18% of seniors being smartphone adopters, significantly below the national adoption rate of 55% ![The image is a bar chart showing the percentage of ownership of smartphones and tablets or e-readers among two groups: all adults and people aged 65 and over.](image1). While the majority of older adults have a cell phone (77%), these are generally more basic devices [6].

When it comes to internet usage, 59% of seniors report going online, while 86% of all adults use the internet ![The image is a bar chart comparing the percentage of technology adoption between "All adults" and those aged "65+.".](image3). Furthermore, 47% of seniors have a high-speed broadband connection at home [9], compared to 70% of all adults with broadband access [3]. A substantial percentage of seniors, 41%, do not use the internet at all [10].

Technology adoption rates are generally lower among adults aged 65+ compared to all adults.

Caltrain's capacity and efficiency are key concerns as indicated by the question, "How can Caltrain keep up?" [8] and napkin math considerations for peak hour capacity [3]. Currently, the peak service involves 5-car trains running 5 times per hour, totaling 25 train cars during peak hours [10].

![Current peak service uses 25 train cars](image5)

Different service improvement scenarios affect the peak hour train car requirements. Using Metrolink's used cars increases the peak service to 6x5, requiring 30 train cars [5, image5]. Electrification allows for a peak service of 6x6, needing 36 train cars. Longer platforms can accommodate a 6x8 service, which requires 48 train cars. The highest capacity scenario, increasing frequency potentially with High-Speed Rail (HSR), results in a peak service of 8x8 and requires 64 train cars during peak hours [2, image5]. If Caltrain were shut down, it would take 4-5 extra lanes on Highway 101 to carry the equivalent traffic [6].

![Vehicles wait at a railway crossing](image2)

The peak hour train car requirement increases from 25 to 64 with different Caltrain service improvement scenarios.

From August 2014 to December 2015, there was a general trend of increasing approval and decreasing disapproval for the U.S. military campaign against ISIS [10]. Views on ethical standards vary significantly across different educational and political groups. A quarter of the general public believes that "high ethical standards" describe neither the Republican nor the Democratic Party [6]. However, this sentiment is more pronounced among those with higher education; nearly a third of college graduates share this view [4]. In contrast, fewer individuals with some college experience (26%) or a high school degree or less (20%) think neither party possesses high ethical standards [10].

![This image shows the percentages of people from different education and political affiliation groups who think neither party has ethical standards.](image2)

Independents are notably more inclined than partisans to perceive that neither party upholds "high ethical standards," with about 34% of independents holding this belief [5]. This includes equal shares of Republican and Democratic leaners (33% each) [5]. By comparison, only around 19% of Republicans and 18% of Democrats feel the same way [5]. Even among those affiliated with a party, there's some skepticism; while majorities of Republicans (66%) and Democrats (64%) describe their own party as having high ethical standards, this indicates a degree of internal critique [3]. The public has nearly identical views of both parties when it comes to ethical standards, with 41% viewing the GOP as having high ethical standards and 42% saying the same about the Democratic Party ![This image illustrates the public opinion on whether the Republican and Democratic parties possess good policy ideas, high ethical standards, and are too extreme.](image3).

In summary, perceptions of ethical standards differ notably across educational levels and political affiliations, with higher education and independent status correlating with greater skepticism towards both parties' ethical standards.

Among older adults, tablets and e-book readers are as popular as smartphones [5]. While smartphones are more common among the general public, tablets, e-book readers, and smartphones are each owned by 18% of older adults [5].

Hispanic Democrats and Republicans diverge significantly in their perceptions of how much the Democratic Party cares about Hispanics. While a considerable percentage of Republicans (41%) believe that the Republican Party cares about Hispanics, only a small fraction of Democrats (7%) share this view [6]. This divide highlights the partisan polarization in how Hispanics view the GOP, mirroring similar divisions regarding the Democratic Party.

![The chart shows that among all Hispanics, 60% affiliate with the Democratic Party, while 34% affiliate with the Republican Party.](image4)

However, when it comes to the Democratic Party, opinions among Hispanics are mixed [2]. A significant 41% of Hispanic Democrats find that the statement "the Democratic Party really cares about Hispanics" describes their views very or extremely well, with an additional 46% saying it describes their views somewhat well [3]. This suggests that while Hispanic Democrats generally hold positive views of the Democratic Party, their enthusiasm is not overwhelming [3]. The lukewarm sentiment is echoed in the finding that a substantial percentage of all Hispanics feel the Democratic Party does not care about Hispanics [1].

![This chart summarizes survey responses about how well different groups think the statement "The Democratic Party really cares about Hispanics" describes their views.](image2)

Specifically, when looking at Democrats and those who lean Democratic, about a third of both conservatives/moderates (34%) and liberals (33%) express strong agreement that the Democratic Party cares about Hispanics [5]. This contrasts sharply with the views of Republicans and Republican leaners, where a majority of conservatives (70%) feel the statement does not accurately reflect their views [5].  Even among moderate and liberal Republicans, a substantial portion (56%) still disagree that the Democratic Party cares about Hispanics [5]. The divide underscores the deep partisan rifts within the Hispanic community regarding the perceived caring attitude of the Democratic Party.

In summary, Hispanic Democrats generally hold more positive views, though with lukewarm enthusiasm, while Hispanic Republicans are largely skeptical about whether the Democratic Party genuinely cares about Hispanics.

Arab youth are facing rising costs of living and unemployment as major concerns [4]. Health issues are also a significant worry [1].

Moreover, Arab youth are increasingly concerned about obesity and lifestyle diseases [9]. This is reflected in the data, which shows a significant rise in concern about obesity.

From 2013 to 2014, concern about obesity among the surveyed population more than doubled.

Internet and broadband usage among seniors is influenced significantly by age [7]. Those in their mid-to-late 60s are more likely to be online, with approximately 74% of seniors aged 65-69 using the internet [10]. But as age increases, internet and broadband adoption decreases, particularly after age 75 [1, 5].

![Internet usage and broadband adoption decrease with age](image4)

For example, among those aged 80 or older, only about 37% use the internet, and just 21% have broadband at home [8]. This pattern is further illustrated in the graph, showing a decline in both internet usage and broadband adoption as age increases [6].

![Internet usage among seniors increases from 2000 to 2013, but remains lower than all adults](image3)

While internet usage among seniors has increased over time, it still lags behind the general adult population [3, 4]. The trends indicate that younger, higher-income, and more educated seniors are more likely to adopt the internet and broadband [1]. The trends in the graph confirm the increase in internet usage among seniors from 2000 to 2013, but the rate is still lower than that of all adults [3].

Internet and broadband usage among seniors decreases with advancing age, especially after age 75.

Asians are overrepresented in STEM, especially among college-educated workers [3, 4, 5].  In fact, Asians account for 19% of workers in both computer and life science fields, much higher than their overall workforce share [7]. This overrepresentation can be seen across all STEM occupational clusters [3, 7]. While whites comprise the majority of STEM workers, Asians have a disproportionately large presence [8].

The percentage of employed individuals in STEM jobs compared to all employed individuals shows that Asians are overrepresented. ![The bar chart shows that Asians are overrepresented in STEM jobs compared to their representation in all employed occupations.](image1)

Asians are the most overrepresented racial/ethnic group in STEM jobs compared to their representation in all employment categories.

For Wave I, there were 52 fieldwork personnel, and for Wave II, there were 50 fieldwork personnel involved in administering the survey ![Wave I had 52 fieldwork personnel while Wave II had 50](image1).

The personnel were trained on various aspects of the survey process [9, 10]. The margin of error for Wave I and II was $+j_{-}\mid.8$  percent at a 95 percent confidence level at the national level [2].

In total, there were 102 fieldwork personnel for Wave I and Wave II.

Independents show divided opinions regarding government regulation of business [1, 8]. Overall,  $49\%$  say regulation is necessary, while  $43\%$  say it does more harm ![Overall, almost half of the respondents think government regulation is necessary to protect the public interest, while a similar percentage believes it does more harm.](image4). However, when broken down by political leaning, distinct differences emerge. 

Democrats are more inclined to believe that government regulation is necessary to protect the public interest, with  $65\%$  supporting this view, while only  $29\%$  think it does more harm ![Democrats are more likely to believe that government regulation is necessary.](image4). This is further emphasized by those who lean towards the Democratic party, where  $69\%$  believe in the necessity of government regulation versus the  $27\%$  who think it is harmful ![Lean Democrats are also more likely to see the necessity of government regulation.](image4). Conversely, Republicans are more likely to believe that government regulation of business does more harm than good, with  $61\%$  holding this view compared to the  $33\%$  who see it as necessary ![Republicans are more likely to believe that government regulation does more harm than good.](image4). Similarly, those who lean towards the Republican party also share this sentiment, with  $58\%$  believing regulation does more harm compared to the  $33\%$  who see it as necessary ![Lean Republicans also share the view that government regulation does more harm.](image4).

Political affiliations differ in their views on the necessity of government regulation to protect public interest, with Democrats generally supporting it and Republicans opposing it.

As the bar chart indicates, 60% of Blacks follow the news either very or fairly closely.

Blacks follow the 2018 midterm elections most closely.

Latino Republicans and Democrats hold divergent perspectives on whether Republicans are actively trying to win over the Latino vote. While a considerable percentage of Latino Republicans and Republican-leaning conservatives believe that Republicans are indeed working diligently to earn their votes, this sentiment is not shared by the majority of Latino Democrats and Democratic leaners [1].

![The image is a bar chart showing survey results about how well different groups perform on a certain issue, divided into three categories: "NET Not too/Not at all well," "Somewhat well," and "NET Extremely/Very well."](image2)

Specifically, the data indicates that only a small fraction of Latino Democrats feel that Republicans are trying to earn their vote [7]. This contrasts sharply with the views of Latino Republicans, among whom a much larger percentage feel that Republicans are actively working to earn Latino votes [7].

![The image is a bar chart showing survey data about the legality of a certain issue across various demographic and political groups.](image1)

In summary, Latino Republicans are more inclined to believe that Republicans are actively seeking the Latino vote, while Latino Democrats generally do not share this view.
