Voters experienced a range of emotions following Donald Trump's election, with "uneasy" being a prevalent feeling [10]. The election's unexpected nature is reflected in voters' reactions [3].
![The bar chart illustrates that "uneasy" was a prominent emotion among voters regarding Trump's election.](image5)
While many Trump supporters expressed happiness, others conveyed surprise or shock [3]. On the other hand, Clinton supporters predominantly felt unease, with a significant percentage also feeling sad and scared [4, 6]. The graphic illustrates that 53% felt uneasy while 51% felt hopeful [5, 8]. Comparing this to Obama's election, reactions were somewhat more positive, with a larger percentage of voters feeling hopeful [7].

Overall, voters primarily felt uneasy and hopeful about Trump's election, as shown in the bar chart.

Vietnamese smartphone users engage in a variety of online activities on a weekly basis [4, 9, 10]. The most popular of these activities is using social networks, with 59% of users participating [5]. Following closely, 56% of users utilize search engines for various purposes ![search engines are used by 56% of smartphone users in Vietnam](image5). Watching online videos is also highly prevalent, with 54% of users engaging in this activity [3, 5]. There are millions of online video views on smartphones every day in Vietnam [3].

The top three online activities performed by Vietnamese smartphone users weekly are using social networks, using search engines, and watching online videos.

In March, positive ratings for public health officials stood at 84% among Republicans, but this figure declined to 53% by August [1, 2]. Democrats' views remained relatively stable, with 74% approval in March and 72% in August [1, 2]. Overall positive views of public health officials decreased from 79% in March to 63% [9].

This image shows the changes in approval ratings for public health officials, local officials, state officials, and Donald Trump from March to August among different political groups. ![The approval rating for public health officials decreased significantly among Republicans and slightly among Democrats, while Trump's rating also decreased across both groups.](image3)

There were much wider partisan differences in views of how public health officials are responding to the outbreak [6]. Currently, 72% of Democrats say public health officials are doing well [6]. This shift is primarily among Republicans [2, 4, 8]. The image shows confidence levels in public health officials are at 72% for Democrats and 53% for Republicans [2, 4, 8].

This image displays confidence levels in various institutions and leaders, highlighting the partisan divide in trust towards public health officials and Donald Trump. ![Democrats show more confidence in public health officials, while Republicans express greater confidence in Donald Trump.](image4)

The approval ratings for public health officials saw a significant decrease among Republicans from March to August, while remaining relatively stable among Democrats.

Hispanics have shown increasing optimism about their financial future compared to the general public, especially after the Great Recession [2, 8, 9]. A survey showed that  $81\%$ of Hispanic adults expected their family's financial situation to improve in the next year, a notable increase from $67\%$ in 2008 [1].  By contrast, the U.S. public's optimism also increased, but not as dramatically, going from $56\%$ to $61\%$ over the same period [1].

This difference in financial expectations between Hispanics and the general public has widened since 2004 [10]. ![The image is a bar chart comparing two groups: "General population" and "All Hispanics," showing data from 2008 and 2015.](image1) The share of Latinos expecting their family finances to improve has risen by 14 percentage points between 2008 and 2015, while for all Americans, this increase was only 6 percentage points [2].  Notably, all of the increase in positive perceptions among Hispanics regarding their family's finances has occurred since 2011 [6].

Even when considering views of family income in relation to the cost of living, about half of Hispanic adults felt they were falling behind financially, a sentiment shared by the U.S. public as a whole between 2014 and 2015 [3].  However, when looking back to before the recession, Latino views of their financial situation are more positive now than in 2004 [5]. ![The line graph illustrates that the percentage of favorable opinions about finances for Hispanics and the general public changed from 2004 to 2015, with Hispanics showing a more significant increase.](image2)

Hispanics have become more optimistic about their financial expectations compared to the general public from 2004 to 2015.

Older internet users generally recognize the importance of online access, with a large majority agreeing that those without internet are at a disadvantage [1, 6].
![A large majority of internet users agree that those without internet are at a disadvantage](image3)
This is further supported by data showing that 79% of older adult internet users feel that people without access are missing out [1, 6].
However, non-users are more split in their opinions [7, 10]. While nearly half of non-users recognize the disadvantage, a substantial percentage, around 35%, disagree with the idea that they are missing out on important information [4, 10].
![Almost half of older non-users agree that those without internet are at a disadvantage](image3)
This difference highlights varying perceptions about the necessity and benefits of internet access among older adults, based on their usage.

In conclusion, internet users overwhelmingly view the lack of internet access as a disadvantage, while non-users are more divided on the issue.

Many Americans believe that the current crisis will have a long-term impact on China’s global stature [3]. Specifically, half of Americans think China will have less influence in world affairs after the pandemic ![50% of respondents believe that China will have less influence](image4). In contrast, nearly one-in-five Americans think China's influence will grow, and about a third believe its global standing will remain about the same [4].

There is a notable partisan divide on this issue, with roughly six-in-ten Republicans believing China’s international clout will diminish, compared to just 40% of Democrats [1]. Overall negative attitudes toward China have been on the rise, with 66% of Americans expressing an unfavorable opinion, marking the most negative rating since 2005 [3].

Based on the survey, half of Americans believe China will have less influence in world affairs after the coronavirus outbreak.

Public sentiment regarding the state of the nation has shifted notably between 1990 and 2019, with dissatisfaction on the rise [4, 5]. ![The graph illustrates the decline in satisfaction and rise in dissatisfaction with the country's direction from 1990 to 2019.](image4)
In fact, public dissatisfaction with the state of the nation is higher than at any point in the past year [4]. Currently, about 70% of Americans express dissatisfaction, while only about 26% are satisfied [5]. This represents a significant increase in dissatisfaction [4]. The percentage of Americans satisfied with the way things are going in the country stands at just 26%, down from 33% in September [2]. Public satisfaction with the state of the nation has dipped, reaching the lowest GOP satisfaction level in a year [10].

Public satisfaction with the state of the nation has decreased from 1990 to 2019.

The assembly of Net Asset Value (NAV) of European venture funds by vintage year shows distinct trends between pre- and post-bubble vintages. From 1997 to 2004, there's a mix of realized and unrealized NAV, with the unrealized portion becoming more substantial, especially from 2001 to 2004.  ![The chart shows the NAV assembly of European venture funds, indicating a shift to unrealized investments post-2005.](image4) Starting from 2005 to 2009, the NAV is shown as 100% unrealized, highlighting "Post-bubble vintages" [4]. This suggests that funds from these years had not yet been realized, marking a clear shift in the European venture capital landscape after the financial bubble [4].

The visibility on European VC Funds for investors is highly limited and prejudiced by the poor quality of published industry fund statistics in Europe [9, 6]. In the US, market publication requirements of endowments oblige most GPs to publish financial performance, while there are no such requirements in Europe [2]. Consequently, many top-performing European funds do not publish their financial data [2]. Furthermore, a significant percentage of EVCA-listed funds have disappeared since the burst of the bubble, with only a small fraction of the remaining funds considered active [2].

The assembly of NAV for European venture funds by vintage year indicates a shift towards unrealized investments in the post-bubble period.

Trump voters were considerably more optimistic that race relations would improve, while the vast majority of Clinton voters anticipated they would worsen following Trump's election [8, 9]. Specifically, half of Trump voters expected race relations to improve, and a substantial percentage believed his election would not make a difference ![Among Trump voters, 50% felt things got better, 38% saw no difference, and 9% felt things got worse.](image2). In stark contrast, the overwhelming majority of Clinton voters (84%) thought race relations would worsen under Trump [8, 9].

Voter perceptions on whether the election of Trump in 2016 or Obama in 2008 would lead to better race relations show a clear divide, with a significantly higher percentage believing Obama's election would improve race relations compared to Trump's ![The data presents that 52% felt things got better after Obama election, while only 25% felt that way after Trump election.](image2). This divergence highlights the different expectations and concerns among voters regarding the impact of each president on race relations in the United States [8, 10].

Trump and Clinton voters sharply diverge in their expectations: most Trump voters anticipated improved race relations, while most Clinton voters feared they would worsen.

Most U.S. adults do not believe that social media accurately reflects society's views on important issues [7]. Specifically, 74% of the public thinks content on social media is not reflective of how society feels about important issues [8].

![A pie chart illustrating that 74% of people think social media does not accurately reflect society.](image2)

Conversely, only a quarter of adults, or 25%, believe that social media paints an accurate picture of society [8]. There are differences among demographic groups, with blacks (37%) and Hispanics (35%) more likely than whites (20%) to agree that social media provides an accurate picture [3].

Therefore, a majority of U.S. adults, specifically 74%, do not think that social media provides an accurate picture of how society feels about important issues.

European venture capital demonstrates strong potential, particularly in its ability to generate high returns [3]. Despite misleading industry data [1, 8], real performance metrics reveal compelling insights. Proportionally, Europe excels in producing higher exit multiples, effectively compensating for smaller average exit values through lower entry valuations and greater capital efficiency [9].

![Europe has a median multiple of 7.2 and the USA has a median multiple of 4.5](image3)

The "Median Multiple of Cash Invested" for Europe is 7.2, while for the USA, it is 4.5. Furthermore, 57.26% of European investments achieve a multiple of cash greater than or equal to 5, compared to 47.27% in the USA [image3]. Even considering total capital invested, the number of exits exceeding US$100 million, and the total number of exits, Europe demonstrates competitive performance [image5]. The post-IPO performance of European VC-backed companies often matches or exceeds that of their US counterparts [7, image4]. The median multiple of cash invested is higher in Europe compared to the USA.

Older Americans are more critical of China's performance [4]. Overall, half of Americans think China's influence will decline [7].

Americans aged 65 and older are also more likely to say China will have less global influence [8].

The 65 and older age group is the least likely to believe that China's global influence will increase after the coronavirus outbreak.

Conservative Republicans have become significantly more critical of the government's efforts over time [2]. In January, $59\%$ of Republicans thought the government was doing well, but that number plummeted to only $18\%$ [2].

This shift is also evident when considering anti-terrorism policies: seven-in-ten Republicans ($71\%$) feel the policies don't go far enough, marking a 33-point increase since July 2013 ($38\%$) [3]. ![The graph illustrates the trend of opinions from 2004-2015 regarding whether the country has gone too far restricting civil liberties or not far enough to protect the country.](image2)

Assessments of government efforts have become more negative across the political spectrum, but particularly among Republicans [4]. Republicans' views on government efforts to reduce the terrorist threat have become significantly more negative over time.

Since 2018, negative feelings toward China have increased among both Republicans and Democrats, although the partisan gap has widened [1].  In 2021,  $67\%$ of Americans felt "cold" toward China, a notable increase from $46\%$ in 2018 [6]. This shift is evident in data collected via online surveys, mirroring trends observed in phone surveys [6].

![The line graph illustrates the change in negative views toward China from 2005 to 2021, using data from phone surveys and the ATP feeling thermometer.](image1)

Notably, the percentage of Americans with "very cold" feelings toward China nearly doubled from $23\%$ in 2018 to $47\%$ in 2021 [5].

![This bar chart shows the percentages of people with "very cold" and "somewhat cold" attitudes toward China across different demographics.](image4)

Republicans showed a more significant increase in negative sentiment;  $62\%$  felt "very cold" toward China, a 31-point increase since 2018, while  $38\%$  of Democrats felt similarly, a 21-point increase [1]. The shift towards more negative views is clear across the political spectrum, but more pronounced among Republicans [10].

![These bar charts compare the warmth or coldness felt by different political affiliations towards China in 2018 and 2021.](image5)

In summary, between 2018 and 2021, negative perceptions of China increased across all political affiliations in the U.S., with a more substantial shift observed among Republicans.

The use of automated systems in decision-making processes elicits mixed reactions from the public. Many feel these systems could offer objectivity, with 42% of Americans finding the use of automated criminal risk scores acceptable because they could be effective or fairer than the current system [8]. Some believe such programs should be just one part of the decision-making process [8].

However, a significant portion of the population expresses reservations. Concerns revolve around the potential for these systems to overlook individual circumstances and the capacity for people to change [1]. As the pie chart illustrates, a substantial 56% of U.S. adults do not find the use of automated criminal risk scores acceptable, with only 25% thinking it does work  ![The pie chart indicates that 74% of respondents believe the system does not work, 25% believe it does, and 1% provided no answer.](image1). This viewpoint is reinforced by the belief that every individual and circumstance is different [image5].

Therefore, 42% of US adults think it's acceptable for the criminal justice system to use automated criminal risk scores [image5].

Arab youth increasingly favor the private sector for employment [1]. ![A bar chart compares responses to a survey question across multiple countries and regions, categorized by "Yes," "No," and "Don't know."](image4) This aligns with a growing entrepreneurial spirit, as many young Arabs are more inclined to start businesses compared to previous generations [1, 6]. The ethical standards of the Trump administration were rated as "not good" or "poor" by a majority of respondents [1, 3]. Specifically, 58% rated the administration's ethical standards as "not good" or "poor" [3]. Republicans and Democrats held starkly contrasting views, with 75% of Republicans giving the administration high marks, while 86% of Democrats rated them negatively [6]. About four-in-ten Americans rate the ethical standards of Trump administration officials as excellent (9%) or good (30%), while 58% say they are not good (21%) or poor (36%) [7]. The ethical standards of top Trump administration officials were seen as "not good" or "poor" by most adults [1, 3].

![The bar chart illustrates the percentage of adults who rate Trump administration officials' ethics as poor, not good, good, or excellent, broken down by total, Republican/Lean Republican, and Democrat/Lean Democrat.](image5)

Among all adults surveyed between April 25 and May 1, 2018, 36% rated the Trump administration's ethical standards as poor [7].

Latino support for the Democratic Party varies depending on education levels, with those having less education showing slightly higher support [6]. Across different Hispanic groups, majorities generally express positive views of the Democratic Party [8, 10].

Specifically, among Latinos, 62% with a high school education or less support the Democratic Party, while 58% with some college and 56% with a bachelor's degree or higher also support the Democratic Party ![The chart breaks down Latino support for the Democratic and Republican parties across various demographic and sociocultural categories, including education level.](image4). Despite these variations, the Democratic Party is generally viewed favorably by Hispanics [10].

Even when considering different origins, significant shares of Mexicans (62%) and Puerto Ricans (58%) feel the Democratic Party represents their interests well ![The bar chart compares political party preferences among various Hispanic groups in the United States.](image2). Views on party representation also differ by religion, with 67% of Latino Catholics feeling represented by the Democratic Party compared to 53% of Latino evangelicals [4].  

In summary, support for the Democratic Party among Latinos is generally strong, with some variation based on education level, though those with less education tend to show slightly higher support.

Radio listening habits vary between rural and urban areas, with different devices being preferred for tuning in. Both Vietnam mobile news and APPOTA news cover updates and insights related to the mobile market [4, 7]. Instagram opening its doors to advertisers in Vietnam is one such update, signaling its emergence as a powerful advertising platform [1].

The increasing competition among Over-The-Top (OTT) apps, especially with platforms like Messenger offering voice call features, is another significant development in the Vietnamese mobile market [2]. ![{Messenger's logo represents communication services in the mobile market}](image3)

Appota releases quarterly mobile market reports providing valuable data for mobile developers and publishers in Vietnam [10]. These reports, based on data from the Appota platform and other public sources, offer references and insights into the market [10]. The rise of mobile advertising platforms, and the competition among app developers, are all key news items covered in the context of the Vietnam mobile market [1, 6].

News related to the mobile market, mobile advertising platforms, and competition among app developers appear in both Vietnam mobile news and APPOTA news.

Women in STEM, especially those in computer jobs, face significant gender disparities at work [2, 4]. The experiences of women and men in STEM jobs differ notably, with women more likely to face gender-related discrimination, sexual harassment, and impediments to career success due to their gender, as highlighted in Pew Research Center surveys [10].

In computer jobs, a staggering 74% of women report experiencing gender discrimination at work, compared to only 16% of men [8]. ![The image is a bar chart depicting the percentage of individuals who have not experienced sexual harassment at work, broken down by gender and type of job.](image4) This disparity is further emphasized by the fact that women in computer jobs are more likely to report pay inequities (46% vs. 29% of all women in STEM) and are often treated as if they are not competent due to their gender (40% vs. 29% of all women in STEM jobs) [6]. These inequities are particularly pronounced in workplaces where men outnumber women [4, 9]. ![This image presents a bar chart comparing the experiences of women and men in STEM jobs regarding gender-related issues.](image1)

Furthermore, women in computer jobs are more likely than men to view gender discrimination as a major problem in the tech industry (43% to 31%) [7]. ![The image is a bar chart comparing perceptions of fairness in the recruitment and hiring process, as well as in opportunities for promotion and advancement.](image2) The differences in perceptions and experiences are evident in various aspects of workplace dynamics, including experiences of gender-related discrimination, sexual harassment, and the impact of gender on career success [9]. ![The image is a chart showing the experiences of women with STEM jobs in workplaces with different gender compositions, comparing their experiences to those of men in STEM jobs.](image3)  ![The image is a horizontal bar graph comparing the perceptions and experiences of men and women in computer jobs regarding gender-related issues in the workplace.](image5)

Women in computer science careers face the largest gender gap in STEM, where they consistently encounter discrimination and inequities in the workplace [8, 6].

Views on Trump’s performance are notably divided across different demographics, with White non-Hispanic adults showing a near split in their opinions [8]. ![The chart shows disapproval and approval percentages of Donald Trump's performance as president among different demographics.](image2)While 47% of White non-Hispanic adults approve, 50% disapprove of Trump’s handling of his job as president [8]. This divide is further highlighted when considering educational attainment among White individuals; those with a college degree are more likely to disapprove (65%) compared to those without a college degree (42%) [image2].

Men are more inclined than women to perceive bullying and deception on social media [2, 8]. For instance, 29% of men report frequently seeing mean or bullying content, compared to only 19% of women [8]. In contrast, women are slightly more inclined to report seeing supportive behavior [8]. However, the majority of both men (52%) and women (56%) perceive an equal mix of supportive and bullying conduct on social media platforms [8]. Similarly, men are almost twice as likely as women to perceive deceptive behavior (24% vs. 13%) [5]. Despite these differences, most men (58%) and women (67%) perceive an equal blend of deceptiveness and attempts to correct misinformation [5].

![The image presents two sets of bar graphs comparing perceptions of online behavior between men and women.](image2)

In terms of content types, users frequently encounter overly dramatic or exaggerated posts (58%) and people making accusations or starting arguments without verifying facts (59%) [10]. In the 2016 election, a majority of voters felt that news organizations exerted too much influence [9]. Specifically, in 2016, 57% of voters believed the press had too much influence [7, 9]. While a substantial percentage of Trump voters (62%) felt this way, a notable portion of Clinton voters (50%) shared this sentiment [3, 10]. It's worth noting that after George W. Bush's reelection in 2004, only 45% of Bush voters thought news organizations had too much influence [2]. The percentage of voters who felt the press had the right amount of influence was the lowest since 1992 [9].

Overall, the perception that news organizations have too much influence on presidential elections has increased since 1992, reaching its highest point in 2016.

There are notable differences in how Republicans, Democrats, and Independents perceive the impact of U.S. involvement in addressing global issues. Republicans are more inclined to believe that the absence of U.S. efforts would worsen global problems, with $62\%$ agreeing with this sentiment, while Democrats are at $56\%$ and Independents at $50\%$ [5].

![Differing perceptions among political affiliations regarding U.S. involvement in global issues](image5)

Conversely, Independents are more likely to think that U.S. intervention tends to exacerbate global issues, with $43\%$ holding this view, compared to $37\%$ of Democrats and $31\%$ of Republicans [5]. Overall, a majority of Americans ($55\%$) believe that global problems would be worse without U.S. involvement [10]. However, opinions diverge within the Democratic party, with liberal Democrats showing nearly equal concern that U.S. efforts might worsen situations ($45\%$) versus the belief that things would be worse without U.S. involvement ($50\%$) [2]. The divide is also evident when considering specific threats, with Republicans more likely to view issues like terrorism and immigration as major threats, while Democrats prioritize concerns like climate change [3, 9].

In summary, perceptions of U.S. involvement in solving global problems differ significantly among political affiliations, with Republicans generally more supportive and Independents more skeptical of its positive impact.

Generational differences significantly impact the likelihood of self-identified Hispanics having Hispanic friends, with each subsequent generation being less likely to have predominantly Hispanic friendship networks.

Between 2003 and 2007, New York City experienced a significant wave of rezoning initiatives [5, 7]. These rezonings aimed to address various objectives, including economic development, population growth, and the diverse needs of the city's neighborhoods [5]. However, despite the attention given to individual rezoning proposals, a comprehensive analysis of their cumulative impact on the city's overall development capacity was lacking [2].

During this period, approximately 188,000 lots were subject to City-initiated rezoning actions, representing a substantial portion of the city's total lot area [7, 10].  Of these, a notable percentage underwent contextual-only rezonings, while others were either downzoned or upzoned [10]. Even though upzoned lots made up only 14% of all the rezoned lots, the new residential capacity added to upzoned lots outweighed the capacity lost from lots that were downzoned or contextual-only rezoned [1]. As a result, the net effect of these rezonings was to increase the City’s total residential development capacity “on paper” by about 1.7% [1].

The impact of these rezonings varied across boroughs. According to Table A, the percentage of land area rezoned in the Bronx was 18.4% between 2003 and 2007 ![The table displays residential capacity, percentage of land area rezoned, change in residential capacity, and percentage of capacity change for each borough in New York City between 2003 and 2007.](image3).

Between 2003 and 2007, 18.4% of the land area in the Bronx was rezoned.

Electric vehicles (EVs) exhibit a superior energy efficiency compared to internal combustion engine vehicles (ICEVs) when the entire energy conversion process is considered [4]. For EVs, the energy conversion efficiency from generation to transmission is 31%, and the plug-to-wheels efficiency is 76%, resulting in an overall energy efficiency of 23% from source to wheel ![EVs have greater energy efficiency compared to ICEVs, especially considering the energy conversion chain](image4). In contrast, ICEVs have a refining efficiency of 82% and a transmission efficiency of 98%, resulting in approximately 80% efficiency from well-to-tank, but with a pump-to-wheels efficiency of only 16%, the overall energy efficiency from source to wheel is only 13% ![EVs have greater energy efficiency compared to ICEVs, especially considering the energy conversion chain](image4). The progression of vehicle technology, including hybrid and EV technology, are helping to improve efficiency ![Vehicle technology has been evolving from conventional to hydrogen to improve efficiency](image5).

Overall, electric vehicles are more energy-efficient than internal combustion engine vehicles from source to wheel.

Many seniors face hurdles in adopting new digital devices due to physical or health-related issues [8]. As many as 23% of older adults report having conditions that make reading difficult, while 29% have disabilities or chronic diseases that limit their participation in daily activities [8].   ![The chart compares the percentage of all adults and those 65+ who have conditions impacting reading or daily activities, showing higher percentages among seniors.](image1)
These challenges contribute to a noticeable gap in technology adoption between seniors with and without such conditions [9]. For example, a significant portion of older adults have physical or health conditions that make tech use challenging [6].  Specifically, 39% of older adults face these challenges, making them less likely to go online (49% vs. 66%), have broadband at home (38% vs. 53%), own a cell phone (69% vs. 82%), or have a smartphone (13% vs. 22%) [3]. Despite these obstacles, many older adults who do use the internet make it a regular part of their lives, with 71% going online almost every day [1].

Physical health conditions present significant barriers to technology adoption among older adults compared to all adults.

Many Americans believe that a significant factor in the continuation of the coronavirus outbreak is the lack of adherence to guidelines, with 75% citing insufficient social distancing and mask-wearing [3]. A considerable number also attribute the continued spread to the premature lifting of restrictions in some areas [3]. This is further evidenced by the statistic that 58% feel restrictions were lifted too quickly, contributing to the ongoing outbreak ![The chart categorizes reasons such as not enough social distancing and restrictions lifted too quickly as major, minor, or not a reason for the spread.](image2). However, there are also other reasons that are marked as major reason. For example, approximately half of Americans (53%) point to an inadequate federal government response [5], and nearly as many (49%) cite a lack of timely testing as major reasons for the continuation of the outbreak [5].

![This image shows the disparity in agreement between Republicans and Democrats regarding issues related to COVID-19.](image4)

Specifically, nearly half of Americans, 49%, identify the lack of timely testing as a major reason for the continued COVID-19 outbreak [8].

According to a Pew Research Center survey, the most commonly cited major reason for the continuation of the coronavirus outbreak in the United States is the insufficient adherence to social distancing and mask-wearing guidelines [2, 7, 8]. A significant 75% of Americans identify this as a major factor contributing to the ongoing spread of the virus ![The image is a bar chart showing reasons for the spread of an issue, with different levels of perceived importance:](image1). This concern transcends partisan lines, with majorities in both Democratic and Republican coalitions agreeing on its significance [5, 7]. While 89% of Democrats consider this a major reason, a narrower majority of Republicans (57%) also share this view ![This image is a chart that compares opinions on several issues related to COVID-19, segmented by political affiliation: Republicans/Lean Republican (in red) and Democrats/Lean Democrat (in blue).](image4).

Other notable reasons include the perception that restrictions on businesses and individuals have been lifted prematurely [2, 3].  Roughly 58% of Americans believe that lifting restrictions too quickly is a major factor in the continued spread [2]. However, there is a significant partisan divide on this issue, with 82% of Democrats viewing it as a major reason compared to only 31% of Republicans [4, 6].  About half of Americans also point to an inadequate federal government response (53%) and a lack of timely testing (49%) as major reasons for the outbreak's continuation [1, 9].  In contrast, only 28% of Americans believe that it is not possible to do much to control the spread [1, 9].

A majority of Americans (60%) believe that the increase in confirmed coronavirus cases is primarily due to more new infections rather than just increased testing [10] ![The image is a bar chart comparing two perspectives on whether more people are getting tested versus there being more new infections. It is segmented by political affiliation:](image2).  These findings underscore the complex interplay of factors influencing the course of the pandemic and highlight the varying perspectives across different segments of the population.

The most cited major reason for the continuation of the COVID-19 outbreak is that not enough people are following social distancing and mask-wearing guidelines.

Cyber attacks from China and China's policies on human rights both showed the greatest increase in concern among Americans from 2020 to 2021.

As generations progress, the likelihood of self-identifying as Hispanic decreases [4]. This is evident with 97% of foreign-born individuals identifying as Hispanic, while only 50% of fourth or higher generation individuals do so ![In the "Fourth or higher generation," there is an equal split, with 50% Hispanic and 50% Non-Hispanic.](image5). The smallest bar corresponds to the percentage of foreign-born individuals who identify as Non-Hispanic.

The smallest bar in the graph indicates that 3% of foreign-born individuals identify as Non-Hispanic.

Experiences with Hispanic cultural celebrations during childhood differ significantly across immigrant generations [5, 6]. Among self-identified Hispanics, a considerable $59\%$ of first-generation individuals report frequent exposure to such celebrations, reflecting their upbringing largely outside the U.S. [2].

Second-generation Hispanics also report relatively high rates of exposure, with approximately half ($49\%$) recalling frequent participation in Hispanic cultural celebrations during their childhood [7].

However, this trend declines in later generations, as only $35\%$ of third or higher generation self-identified Hispanics report the same level of involvement [7]. This decline is mirrored by a fading of Hispanic self-identity across generations [9]. In contrast, only $9\%$ of Americans with Latino ancestry who do not self-identify as Latino report frequent childhood experiences with Latino cultural celebrations, while $60\%$ state that such experiences never occurred [8].

The frequency of attending Hispanic cultural celebrations in childhood decreases across immigrant generations, with first-generation Hispanics reporting the highest rates and subsequent generations showing a decline.

Women's representation in STEM is significantly influenced by their educational background [2, 7]. ![Women in STEM jobs increased from 1990 to 2016 across all education levels.](image5)Specifically, the percentage of women earning a STEM degree often mirrors their representation in STEM occupational clusters [7]. For instance, a large proportion of college-educated workers with health professions degrees are women, whereas engineering degrees are overwhelmingly held by men [7]. As shown in the image, the percentage of employed individuals with varying levels of education differs between STEM jobs and all jobs; for example, 41% of all employed individuals have a high school education or less, while the number is 55% for STEM jobs. ![Education levels of individuals in STEM jobs compared to the overall employed population.](image3)

Moreover, women with advanced degrees in STEM are more likely to report experiences of gender discrimination and perceive gender-related obstacles to success in their workplaces [3]. ![The distribution of employment types across various job categories, including STEM and non-STEM, showing percentages in private, not-for-profit, government, and self-employed sectors.](image2) Despite comprising half of the STEM workforce overall, women remain underrepresented in specific fields such as computer jobs and engineering [5]. Also, the representation of women in STEM jobs is lower among those with advanced degrees [9].

In summary, women's representation in STEM jobs varies by education level, with those holding advanced degrees experiencing both higher rates of discrimination and different employment distributions across STEM fields.

Female representation in STEM fields varies significantly across different job clusters [2, 4, 9]. Women constitute a majority in healthcare roles but are underrepresented in computer and engineering positions [1, 4].

![Health-related jobs have the highest share of women in STEM](image3)

Specifically, engineering occupations have the lowest share of women at 14%, followed by computer occupations at 25% [8]. In contrast, women's representation among life scientists (47%) and math workers (46%) is roughly equal to their overall share in the workforce (47%) [8]. The share of women varies across STEM jobs, ranging from 7% for sales engineers and 8% for mechanical engineers to 96% for speech-language pathologists and 95% for dental hygienists [9]. The representation of women in STEM is also influenced by their educational background, with a higher percentage of women in health professions (81%) compared to engineering (16%) among college-educated workers [10].

![The gender distribution varies significantly among STEM job clusters.](image3)

Female representation varies significantly across different STEM job clusters, with health-related fields having the highest representation and engineering having the lowest.

Latinos, in general, exhibited a substantial increase in economic optimism regarding their family's future financial prospects [2].  ![The general population and all hispanics’ economic optimism in 2008 and 2015](image1). This increase was more pronounced among Latinos compared to the general public [2, 3]. The share of Latinos expecting their family finances to improve rose by 14 percentage points, reaching 81% in 2015 [2].  In contrast, the general public saw an increase of only 6 percentage points, reaching 61% during the same period [2].

Notably, this optimistic view was particularly strong among Latinos who had completed some college, with a 20 percentage point increase in economic optimism since 2008 [6].  ![Various demographic groups and their economic well-being from 2008 to 2015](image2). This surpassed the gains made by those with a high school diploma (+9 percentage points) or less education (+11 percentage points) [6]. This data indicates that educational attainment played a significant role in the surge of economic optimism within the Latino community.

Since 2004, Latinos have consistently been more optimistic about their finances compared to the general public [3]. The gap in financial expectations between Latinos and the general public reached its largest point since the series began, with 81% of Latinos expressing optimism compared to 61% of the general public [3].  ![The economic well-being of different Hispanic groups](image3). This demonstrates a notable divergence in economic sentiment between these two groups.  Nearly all major demographic groups recorded some increase in economic optimism [1].

Economic optimism regarding future family financial prospects increased more rapidly among Latinos compared to the general population [2]. ![Line graph illustrating survey results of favorable opinions between Hispanic and general public groups from 2004 to 2015](image4). Those Latinos who had completed some college experienced the greatest surge in economic optimism from 2008 to 2015 [6].

Americans' unfavorable views of China have increased significantly across all age groups from 2005 to 2020 [4]. ![The graph illustrates the shift in unfavorable views of China among different age groups from 2005 to 2020.](image2)

The increase is most pronounced among those aged 50 and older, with unfavorable views reaching 81% in 2020 [1]. This represents a substantial increase compared to younger age groups, such as those aged 30-49 (71%) and those under 30 (56%) [1]. While around a quarter of those aged 18-29 view China as a partner, only 6% of those 50 and older share this perspective [2]. Older Americans are also approximately three times more likely to view China as an enemy compared to their younger counterparts [2]. The overall trend indicates a growing negative sentiment toward China across all age demographics [10].

In conclusion, unfavorable views of China have increased across all age groups between 2005 and 2020, with older Americans expressing the most significant rise in negative sentiment.

Hamilton County experienced a significant population surge in the late 1800s [1]. The population in 1870 was 130, which dramatically increased to 8,267 in 1880, and peaked at 14,096 in 1890 [1]. Since that peak, the population has generally declined, as shown in the table ![The table shows Hamilton County population from 1870 to 2000, peaking in 1890.](image3).

While many small towns in the Midwest and Great Plains peaked in population between 1900 and 1940, some have shown recent gains [3]. Aurora, for instance, reached its peak population in 2000 with 4,225 citizens [4]. Despite these fluctuations, farm consolidation trends suggest that towns outside of Aurora may struggle to maintain their populations [4, 5]. The trend of farm consolidation has led to a decrease in the number of farms and an increase in the average farm size [6].

Overall, Hamilton County's population experienced rapid growth in the late 19th century followed by a gradual decline and recent stabilization or slight increase in some areas.

Democrats and Republicans hold significantly different views on the automatic registration of all eligible citizens to vote.  A sizable majority of Democrats favor automatically registering all eligible citizens to vote [2]. ![Democrats overwhelmingly support automatically registering all eligible citizens.](image5) As of a recent survey, 82% of Democrats/lean Democrats support this measure [2, 9].  This level of support has seen a slight increase from 78% in 2018 [6, 9].

By contrast, Republicans show much lower support for automatic voter registration.  Only 38% of Republicans/lean Republicans currently favor this policy [3]. ![Only a minority of Republicans supports automatic voter registration.](image5) This represents a decline from 49% in 2018 [3, 6, 8]. Therefore, Democrats are more than twice as likely as Republicans to support automatically registering all eligible citizens to vote.

Blacks in STEM jobs are more likely to report experiences of workplace discrimination and perceive unfair treatment compared to their white counterparts [1, 4]. ![62% of blacks in STEM say they have experienced discrimination at work, compared with just 13% of whites.](image4) Specifically, a substantial $62\%$ of blacks in STEM report experiencing discrimination due to their race or ethnicity, contrasting sharply with only $13\%$ of whites [4]. This disparity extends to perceptions of fairness in hiring and promotion processes, as only $43\%$ of blacks in STEM believe that blacks are usually treated fairly during recruitment, and $37\%$ feel this is the case for promotion opportunities [3].

In stark contrast, the majority of white STEM workers hold the belief that blacks are generally treated fairly in these processes, with $78\%$ agreeing about hiring and $75\%$ about advancement [3]. These differing perceptions highlight a significant gap in how racial and ethnic groups experience and view fairness within STEM workplaces [7, 8].

Concerns about the underrepresentation of blacks and other racial minorities in STEM have been persistent for decades [4]. This is further compounded by the fact that blacks in STEM jobs are more likely to report experiences of workplace discrimination due to race than blacks in non-STEM jobs ($62\%$ vs. $50\%$) [10].  ![The chart compares experiences of sexual harassment among different groups.](image2)

Blacks in STEM jobs report higher rates of discrimination and perceive less fairness in hiring and promotion processes compared to white STEM workers [1, 9].

The benchmarks for measuring Expert AGI should start from college-level exams [4]. These exams evaluate skilled adults specialized in different disciplines, and this strategy has been adopted in benchmarks such as MMLU and AGIEval [4]. However, these benchmarks only consider text-based questions [4].

Large multimodal models (LMMs) can understand both text and images [4]. These LMMs have excelled in existing multimodal benchmarks, but most of these benchmarks focus on commonsense and daily knowledge rather than expert-level domain knowledge [4]. ![The image shows a table comparing performance scores of large multimodal models and large language models across different categories and disciplines.](image1)

The MMMU benchmark excels in both depth and breadth compared to other benchmarks and has a broad range of image types sourced from textbooks and the internet, with both open and multiple-choice answers available. ![The image compares the MMMU benchmark with other benchmarks, highlighting MMMU's depth and breadth in reasoning and knowledge.](image5) It contains 11,550 questions across six broad disciplines, 30 subjects, and 183 subfields [3]. ![The chart shows the distribution of multimodal questions across six broad disciplines, 30 subjects, and 183 subfields.](image2)

The SWEM model is considerably more computationally efficient due to the absence of compositional parameters, resulting in fewer parameters compared to LSTM or CNN [8]. SWEM achieves better results on Yahoo! Answer than CNN/LSTM, with only 61K parameters, which is one-tenth the number of LSTM parameters [8].

![SWEM has 61,000 parameters and a speed of 63 seconds, while LSTM has 1,800,000 parameters and a speed of 598 seconds.](image5)

As illustrated in Table 4, SWEM takes a fraction of the training time relative to CNN or LSTM [8]. Specifically, CNN takes 171 seconds, LSTM takes 598 seconds, and SWEM takes only 63 seconds [image5]. Therefore, SWEM is significantly faster than LSTM in terms of training speed.

Pre-training enhances BLEU scores, particularly for low-resource languages, but the extent of the improvement varies depending on the language pair and baseline system performance [1, 6].  For example, pre-training can substantially improve translation accuracy for less frequent words and phrases, as seen in the  ${\mathrm{GL}}\to{\mathrm{EN}}$  translation, which benefits from capturing rarer vocabulary and generating more grammatically correct sentences [2].

The gains from pre-training are more significant when the baseline system's BLEU score is low but not too low, typically in the range of 3-4 [4]. This suggests that pre-training is most effective when the system has enough data to capture the basic characteristics of the language  ![The graphs show that pre-training increases BLEU scores, especially with smaller training datasets.](image2).

When pre-trained embeddings are applied to multilingual translation systems, the gains in each translation pair are roughly in order of their similarity [5].  For instance,  ${\mathrm{GL}}$/${\mathrm{PT}}$ shows the largest gains, while ${\mathrm{BE}}$/${\mathrm{RU}}$ shows a small decrease, and aligning word embeddings further increases BLEU scores across tasks [10]. Pre-training improves translation accuracy across the entire vocabulary, especially for low-frequency words [8].  The impact of pre-training is also evident when comparing different language families; languages with larger headroom for improvement, such as ${\mathrm{RU}}$ and ${\mathrm{HE}}$, tend to show larger increases in accuracy [9].

Pre-training generally increases BLEU scores, especially for low-resource languages and when the baseline system has moderate initial performance.

The Twitter16 dataset consists of 412 source tweets, split almost evenly between true (205) and fake (207) tweets, involving 115,036 users and averaging 308.70 retweets per story ![Twitter16 dataset contains 412 source tweets.](image2). The average number of words per source tweet is 12.81 ![Twitter16 dataset has an average of 12.81 words per source tweet.](image2). The GCAN model uses this data to predict whether a source tweet is fake or not [1]. The GCAN model significantly outperforms competing methods in accuracy [1].

The Twitter16 dataset contains 412 source tweets.

The Grammarly’s Yahoo Answers Formality Corpus (GYAFC) contains a total of 110K informal / formal sentence pairs [7]. To ensure a uniform distribution of data, sentences that are questions, contain URLs, and are shorter than 5 words or longer than 25 are removed [8]. After preprocessing, about 40 million sentences remain [8]. The domains of Entertainment & Music and Family & Relationships contain the most informal sentences and are used to create the GYAFC dataset [8].

![This table presents data related to Yahoo Answers, particularly focusing on different domains and their respective format.](image1)

The number of sentences in the train, tune, and test sets are shown in Table 3 [5]. For the "Informal to Formal" direction, the E&M category has 52,595 instances for training, 2,877 for tuning, and 1,416 for testing [2]. For the same direction, the F&R category has 51,967 instances for training, 2,788 for tuning, and 1,332 for testing [2].

![The table contains data related to datasets used in two different writing style transformation tasks: Informal to Formal and Formal to Informal.](image2)

Therefore, there are 52,595 + 51,967 = 104,562 sentences in the training set for the "Informal to Formal" direction.

In relative evaluations, annotator agreement levels vary when comparing Chameleon to other models, with a bit higher than 10% of cases showing no agreement among the three annotators [9].  The different levels of agreement among annotators when comparing Chameleon to Gemini+, GPT-4V+, Gemini, and GPT-4V are detailed in the table. ![The table provides statistics about agreement levels among annotators for different comparisons involving Chameleon, Gemini, and GPT-4 models.](image2)

Specifically, the percentage of unanimous judgments (all three annotators agree) ranges from 28.6% to 35.4%, while the percentage of cases where two out of three annotators agree is between 55.2% and 59.3% [9]. This suggests that Chameleon performs similarly to the baselines in many cases, making relative evaluation challenging [9].  The varying degrees of agreement suggest that differentiating Chameleon's performance from other models can be subjective [9].

Chameleon's win rates against other models, such as Gemini and GPT-4V, further illustrate its competitive performance [2].  When comparing Chameleon with Gemini$^{+}$, annotators found Chameleon's responses better in 41.5% of cases, with 34.5% resulting in a tie [2]. Against GPT-4V+, Chameleon achieved a 35.8% win rate, a 31.6% tie rate, and a 32.6% loss rate [2]. These results highlight that annotator preferences are not always consistent, indicating the nuances in evaluating the model's performance [9].

Annotator agreement levels indicate that Chameleon's performance is often perceived similarly to other models, making definitive judgments challenging due to the subjective nature of relative evaluations.

To determine the difference between the highest and lowest AUPRC values for the BoolQ dataset, we need to refer to the metrics provided in the table. The table compares models using GloVe + LSTM and BERT + LSTM with different explanation methods such as Attention, Gradient, Lime and Random [5].

According to the table, for BoolQ dataset, the highest AUPRC value is 39.1 achieved by the model using BERT + LSTM with the Attention explanation method and the lowest AUPRC value is 0.5 achieved by the model using Glove + LSTM with the Random explanation method [5].

```
Highest AUPRC (BERT + LSTM with Attention): 39.1
Lowest AUPRC (GloVe + LSTM with Random): 0.5
Difference: 39.1 - 0.5 = 38.6
```

Therefore, the difference between the highest and lowest AUPRC values for the BoolQ dataset is 38.6, with the highest value corresponding to BERT + LSTM with Attention and the lowest to GloVe + LSTM with Random.

The number of demonstrations and the inclusion of logical constraints both significantly affect the Micro-F1 performance on the MAVEN-ERE and CTB datasets [10]. As the number of demonstrations increases from 1 to 5, there is a noticeable improvement in Micro-F1 score; however, the gains diminish with further increases in the number of demonstrations beyond 5 [10].

Adding logical constraints to LLM instructions leads to consistent improvements, especially when more demonstrations are used [10]. ![The graph shows the performance (Micro-F1 score) of different models/datasets with and without logical constraints as the number of demonstration samples increases.](image4) Specifically, using logical constraints with fewer demonstrations can outperform prompts that rely solely on a larger number of demonstrations [10]. For example, the performance on MAVEN-ERE with 5 demonstrations and logical constraints (25.7%) exceeds that of 10 demonstrations without logical constraints (24.5%) [10]. This highlights the importance of balancing demonstrations ("What") and logical constraints ("How") for solving reasoning tasks [10].

Incorporating relevant logic into LLM instruction is very helpful in solving reasoning tasks [7]. When relevant logic is added, the model performance improves significantly on both MAVEN-ERE and Proof Writer; however, irrelevant logic can lead to fluctuations in results [7].

In conclusion, increasing the number of demonstration samples generally improves Micro-F1 performance, and adding logical constraints enhances this effect, often allowing better performance with fewer demonstrations.

Step-Back prompting, when applied to TimeQA, exhibits several error types, with Reasoning and RAG being the most prominent [7]. The errors are categorized into four classes [7, 8].

 Reasoning errors constitute a significant portion of the mistakes made by Step-Back prompting [9].
![The bar chart shows that Reasoning Error and RAG are the dominant error sources in Step-Back Prompting on TimeQA.](image3)
RAG failures, where relevant information isn't retrieved even when the step-back question is accurate, also contribute substantially to the errors [2, 6].

Other errors include cases where the step-back question is unhelpful [2]. Additionally, scoring errors, where the evaluation by the judge model is incorrect, also occur [2].

In summary, the main error types in Step-Back Prompting on TimeQA are Reasoning errors and RAG failures, with StepBack question failures and Scoring errors also contributing, but to a lesser extent.

The Entity-GCN model's performance can be compared to other models using the unmasked test set [1]. The Entity-GCN model without coreference achieves a score of 67.6, outperforming previous works by over 2% [4].

Even when coreference is included, the Entity-GCN model remains competitive.  The Entity-GCN model with coreference achieves a score of 66.4 on the unmasked test set, as shown in the table ![The table compares model performance, with the Entity-GCN model achieving 66.4 with coreference and 67.6 without coreference on the unmasked test.](image3). The ensemble model achieves the best performance [1]. The full ensemble model has the highest performance in unmasked and masked conditions ![The table shows the performance of different models; the full ensemble model has the highest performance in unmasked and masked conditions.](image2).

However, it is important to note that the Entity-GCN model seems to gain little advantage from the coreference system; surprisingly, with coreference, there is a performance degradation on the test set [3]. Despite this, the model makes better use of document-based connections than MATCH or COREF connections ![The image visualizes supporting documents as nodes, with different types of connections based on co-occurrence, exact match, and coreference.](image4).  Questions regarding places are considered harder for Entity-GCN ![The table shows model performance metrics for different relations, highlighting that questions about places of birth and death have lower accuracy.](image1).

The Entity-GCN model with coreference demonstrates competitive performance on the unmasked test set compared to other models, although it experiences a slight degradation compared to the version without coreference.

The anchor re-weighting method enhances ICL performance by adjusting the contributions of demonstrations [3]. As shown in the results, anchor re-weighting significantly improves ICL performance, especially on the SST-2 and EmoC datasets [8]. In contrast to vanilla ICL, which may introduce noise and instability with additional demonstrations, anchor re-weighting uses a trained re-weighting vector to modulate label anchor contributions, shortening the input context and maintaining inference speed [8].

![The table presents performance data for various methods, highlighting the superior performance of Anchor Re-weighting.](image3)

The "Anchor Re-weighting" method achieves an average score of 68.64 across the datasets, which is notably higher than the 51.90 of "Vanilla In-Context Learning (1-shot per class)" and the 46.87 of "Vanilla In-Context Learning (5-shot per class)" [image3]. The anchor re-weighting method, employing a learnable vector to adjust the significance of different label words in demonstrations, leads to a 16.7% average accuracy boost compared to standard ICL baselines [6].

The anchor re-weighting method improves the performance of vanilla ICL by an average of 16.7% [6].

The survey categorizes correction methodologies into training-time, generation-time, and post-hoc approaches [3, 10]. Training-time correction involves rectifying model behavior during the training phase, using strategies like direct optimization with human feedback, reward modeling, and self-training, as illustrated in ![Training-time correction strategies include direct human feedback, reward modeling, and self-training.](image4). Generation-time correction utilizes automated feedback to guide the LLM during the generation process [6]. Two main strategies in this category are Generate-then-Rank and Feedback-Guided Decoding, both of which aim to correct LLMs during the generation time [2], which are shown in ![Generate-then-Rank selects the best output from multiple options, while Feedback-Guided Decoding refines outputs iteratively with feedback.](image3). Post-hoc correction refines the model output after it has been generated, without updating the model parameters [8]. Key post-hoc correction strategies include self-correction, correction with external feedback, and multi-agent debate, as depicted in ![Post-hoc correction strategies include self-correction, correction with external feedback, and multi-agent debate.](image2).

Based on the information provided in the text quotes, it is not possible to determine which of the three correction strategies (training-time, generation-time, or post-hoc) has the most representative papers in the survey.

The Tversky index (TI) offers flexibility in controlling the tradeoff between false negatives and false positives, and the effect of hyperparameters (specifically, \(\alpha\) and \(\beta\)) in TI can be observed through experiments on the Chinese OntoNotes4.0 NER dataset and the English QuoRef MRC dataset [8]. The table presents F1 score values across the "Chinese Onto4.0" and "English QuoRef" datasets for different values of \(\alpha\) ![The table presents values across two datasets, "Chinese Onto4.0" and "English QuoRef," for various values of a parameter denoted as \(\alpha\).](image1).

The highest F1 score on the Chinese OntoNotes4.0 dataset is 84.67 when \(\alpha\) is set to 0.6, while for the QuoRef dataset, the highest F1 score is 68.44 when \(\alpha\) is set to 0.4 [8]. The performance varies significantly as \(\alpha\) changes in distinct datasets, indicating that the hyperparameters \(\alpha\) and \(\beta\) play an important role in TI [8].

The optimal \( \alpha \) value for Chinese OntoNotes4.0 is 0.6, yielding an F1 score of 84.67, and for English QuoRef, it is 0.4, resulting in an F1 score of 68.44.

The Graph-aware Co-Attention Networks (GCAN) model was evaluated on its ability to accurately detect fake news and provide reasonable explanations for its predictions [1, 9]. The study compared GCAN's performance against state-of-the-art methods and analyzed the contribution of each component to the overall performance [2, 4]. The results, as shown in the table, demonstrate that GCAN significantly outperforms competing methods across various metrics on both the Twitter15 and Twitter16 datasets [7]. ![The table compares performance metrics of different methods on two Twitter datasets, Twitter15 and Twitter16.](image4)

Specifically, GCAN achieved an average improvement of approximately 17% and 15% on Twitter15 and Twitter16, respectively [7]. The model's explainability is attributed to its co-attention weights, which highlight evidential words and users involved in spreading fake news [5, 6]. Even with only a small number of retweeters, GCAN maintains high accuracy, making it suitable for early detection of fake news [8].  The model's ability to generate accurate early detection of spreading fake news is evident in its performance with as few as ten retweeters [8].  The accuracy of different models based on the number of retweet users, with GCAN consistently showing the highest accuracy is depicted below. ![This model shows high accuracy, remaining consistently above 0.9 across all user counts.](image2)

To calculate the average Recall improvement, we consider the Recall values for GCAN and DTC (as a baseline) on both datasets from the table.  On Twitter15, the Recall for GCAN is 0.8295 and for DTC is 0.4806. On Twitter16, the Recall for GCAN is 0.7632 and for DTC is 0.5369. The improvements are as follows:
- Twitter15: 0.8295 - 0.4806 = 0.3489
- Twitter16: 0.7632 - 0.5369 = 0.2263
The average Recall improvement is (0.3489 + 0.2263) / 2 = 0.28765, or 28.77%.

The average Recall improvement of GCAN across both Twitter15 and Twitter16 datasets is approximately 28.77%.

The single-task model, illustrated in Figure 1a, features a single decoder attending to the states of an encoder to produce an output sequence ![Single-task model uses a single decoder to attend to the encoder states for output.](image4). Conversely, the multitask model, depicted in Figure 1b, employs two decoders that both attend to the states of the same encoder [2] ![Multitask model uses two decoders attending to the same encoder states.](image4). Each decoder in the multitask model has its own attention mechanism, leading to separate context vectors and predictions [4]. Therefore, unlike the single-task model with just one decoder attending to the encoder, the multitask model uses two decoders for the same purpose.

The RAR pipeline leverages both a multimodal retriever and a ranking system to enhance the performance of Multimodal Large Language Models (MLLMs) in tasks like fine-grained recognition [9, 10]. The core idea is to combine the strengths of CLIP-based retrieval with the knowledge of MLLMs [9].

The first main component is the Multimodal Retriever. It addresses the challenge of efficiently encoding and storing a large volume of images and text embeddings for quick and accurate retrieval [8]. This retriever creates and stores multimodal embeddings [1], optimizing retrieval speed through index construction techniques [8]. As illustrated in the pipeline, the image encoder extracts image feature embeddings, which are then stored and indexed in the feature index, utilizing a memory ($\mathcal{M}$) for external storage, and employing k-NN for image-image and image-text retrieval ![The RAR pipeline includes a multimodal retriever for feature extraction, indexing, and storage.](image3). To enhance retrieval speed, techniques like the HNSW algorithm are used to reduce dimensionality and create a more condensed index [7].

Following retrieval, the ranking component refines the results. During the inference stage, an input image is encoded into embeddings, and the top-k categories are retrieved from memory based on similarity [3, 4]. MLLMs then rank these categories to make the final prediction [1]. This ranking process combines the internal knowledge of the MLLM with the retrieved information to provide a more accurate and contextually aware classification [4]. The prompt guides MLLMs to rank the retrieved candidate object categories based on similarity [5]. For object detection datasets, pre-processing steps like cropping and blurring are applied to focus the MLLMs' attention on the relevant objects within the image [3].
![The RAR pipeline employs MLLMs to rank retrieved categories for final prediction.](image3)

In summary, the RAR pipeline consists of a multimodal retriever for efficient information retrieval and a ranking system using MLLMs to refine and finalize predictions, enhancing the accuracy and contextual awareness of image classification.

The authors structured their prompt design based on a multi-step reasoning process of causal inference [1]. The process begins with four preparation steps: identifying the causal graph structure, determining the causal query type, formulating the query symbolically precisely, and extracting relevant data from the prompt [1].

Then, the formal solution involves correctly deducing the estimand using causal inference techniques and evaluating the estimand to answer the question [1]. The Causal Chain-of-Thought (CausalCoT) model is divided into Preparation Phase and Solution Phase ![The CausalCoT model is divided into Preparation Phase and Solution Phase](image5).  The six subskills necessary for causal inference are causal graph extraction, correct query type interpretation, symbolic formalization of the query, semantic parsing to compile the available data, estimand derivation, and arithmetic calculation to solve the estimand, as illustrated in the colored boxes in Figure 1 ![The image outlines the steps to determine if getting vaccinated increases the likelihood of death, including parsing the causal graph, classifying the query type, formulating the query in symbolic form, collecting available data, deriving the estimand using causal inference, and solving for the estimand](image4).

The authors divided causal inference into six key steps.

LLM-based reranking enhances performance on hard samples but impedes performance on easy samples [9]. This is achieved by reranking only a small subset of samples, minimizing extra latency and budgets [7]. The adaptive filter-then-rerank paradigm leverages both SLMs for efficiency and LLMs for accuracy on more complex tasks, utilizing SLMs as filters and LLMs as rerankers for challenging samples [3, 7].

The filter-then-rerank method consistently improves performance across datasets [8]. LLMs exhibit greater proficiency in handling hard samples compared to SLMs but underperform relative to SLMs on easy samples [9]. The architecture of this paradigm involves processing easy samples directly through SLMs, while hard samples undergo reranking by LLMs, which convert top-N SLM predictions into multiple-choice questions [image3].

Reranking results in a substantial performance boost on hard samples, enhancing the overall performance [4]. The graph for FewNERD displays performance across different confidence scores, with blue lines indicating performance with LLM reranking and pink lines showing performance without it [image5]. LLM reranking enhances performance on hard samples (left areas) [9].

LLM reranking enhances performance on hard samples and impedes performance on easy samples for the FewNERD dataset [9, image5].

Supervised learning (SL) models can struggle with unseen dialogue states during user interactions [7]. The task success rate of different models can be visualized in learning curves, showing performance over interactive dialogue learning sessions ![The image shows a line graph depicting the task success rate over time across different interactive dialogue learning sessions.](image2). As shown in these curves, the SL model performs poorly, possibly due to compounding errors from mismatched dialogue state distributions between offline training and interactive learning [6].

Applying imitation learning on top of supervised training model efficiently improves the task success rate, and further RL optimization increases it even more [1]. Looking at the average dialogue turn size, the red curve with RL applied directly after supervised pre-training model gives the lowest average number of turns at the end of the interactive learning cycles, compared to models with imitation dialogue learning [10].

Compared to other models, the model with supervised learning, imitation learning (1000 episodes), and reinforcement learning (SL + IL 1000 + RL) achieves higher task success rates [1]. The learning curves in Figure 3 show this model quickly reaches and stabilizes at a high success rate [1].  End-to-end model updates during interactive learning achieve a higher dialogue task success rate compared to only updating the policy network ![The image is a line graph depicting the interactive learning curves for task success rate over time with different reinforcement learning (RL) training settings.](image1).

The SL + IL 1000 + RL model demonstrates the most significant improvement in task success rate over time, achieving and maintaining the highest success rate among the compared models.

SenseBERT enhances word-meaning awareness through semantic level pre-training, outperforming vanilla BERT in supersense disambiguation [1]. SenseBERT achieves competitive results, even without fine-tuning, and demonstrates a clear ability to learn word-level semantics [1].

![SenseBERT models generally show better performance on SemEval-SS task compared to BERT models, both in frozen and fine-tuned settings](image3)

SenseBERT's pre-training yields embeddings carrying lexical semantic information, which benefits downstream tasks [4]. SenseBERT's lexical semantic knowledge doesn't compromise its performance on other downstream tasks [5].

![The table compares BERT and SenseBERT performance on various NLP tasks, highlighting their scores and performance metrics for each task.](image4)

SenseBERT\(_{\text{BASE}}\) achieves an overall score of 77.9, compared to 77.5 achieved by BERT\(_{\text{BASE}}\) [5]. Weighted decoding uses a decoding feature (`resp rel`) to control response-relatedness [5]. As the weight increases, the generated responses vary significantly, and extreme weights can lead to nonsensical output [2].

For the input "Yes, I'm studying law at the moment," the baseline response is "That sounds like a lot of fun!" ![The baseline response to the input is "That sounds like a lot of fun!"](image5).  When the weight is -5.0, the response is "Oh......................................" with a low NIDF of 0.6%. At a weight of 0.0, the response remains the same as the baseline. As the weight increases to 3.0, the model generates "That sounds like a lot of fun. How long have you been studying?" When the weight is 7.0, the response becomes "I majored in practising my spiritual full-time philosophy test". An even higher weight of 10.0 results in the nonsensical response, "Oh wow! Merna jean isa paino yi hao hui bu acara sya gila [...]" [2].  This demonstrates that varying the weight in weighted decoding can drastically alter the generated response, potentially leading to nonsensical outputs when weights are too extreme [9].

In the weighted decoding response table, the weight significantly influences the generated response, with extreme weights potentially leading to nonsensical outputs.

The architecture described involves classifying each warrant independently with the argument to yield logits [6]. The general architecture for the models is shown in ![The image illustrates the general architecture of the models, processing claims, reasons and warrants to output logits and probability distributions.](image2). These logits are then concatenated and passed through a softmax function to determine a probability distribution over the two warrants [5]. The prediction is based on which warrant has the highest probability [5]. The BERT classifier also operates in this manner, as visualized in ![The diagram illustrates the architecture of a BERT model processing claims, reasons, and warrants to calculate logits.](image3).

The probability distribution over the two warrants is determined using the softmax function.

SenseBERT provides a supersense abstraction of the sentence "Dan cooked a bass on the grill" [1]. Instead of just processing the words, SenseBERT identifies the underlying semantic roles [1]. In this context, "Dan" is recognized as a "[Person]", "cooked" as "[created]", and "bass" as "[food]" [1].

This is highlighted in the example provided, which demonstrates how SenseBERT assigns the label "noun.food" to "bass" when it appears in the sentence "Dan cooked a bass on the grill," showcasing its capability to differentiate the meaning of "bass" based on context ![The image contains two sentences with parts of speech and word sense annotations for specific words](image1). SenseBERT is therefore able to extract more knowledge and generalize semantically similar notions even with different phrasings [1].

SenseBERT abstracts the role of "bass" in the sentence "Dan cooked a bass on the grill" as "[food]" [1].

The Twitter15 dataset includes 190,868 users, while the Twitter16 dataset contains 115,036 users ![The table presents the number of source tweets, true and fake tweets, users, average retweets per story, and average words per source for Twitter15 and Twitter16](image5). The model uses user characteristics extraction, new story encoding, user propagation representation, dual co-attention mechanisms, and prediction generation to identify fake news [1]. By examining which parts of the source story are retweeted by which users, the model can identify fake clues based on user interactions [3]. GCAN's performance is significantly better than competing methods, improving performance by around 17% and 15% on average in Twitter15 and Twitter16, respectively [4]. The dual co-attention mechanism in GCAN is particularly effective [4].

The words of a sentence are first converted into word embeddings before being processed by the LSTM layers, as illustrated in the neural network architecture [9]. These word embeddings serve as numerical representations of the words, allowing the model to capture semantic information. The word embeddings are then passed through bi-directional LSTM layers, enabling the model to consider both previous and subsequent context when processing each word ![Each word is converted into a word embedding before being processed by the LSTM layers.](image4). This process helps in effectively classifying each word in the text with its respective named entity label, as demonstrated in the example with the words "Best", "Buy", and others [9].

Each word is represented by its word embedding before being input to the LSTM layers [9].

Otter demonstrates superior performance over Open Flamingo in few-shot settings, indicating effective in-context learning [2, 4]. It also shows improvements in video understanding and vision-language alignment compared to other models ![Otter demonstrates superior performance in video understanding and vision-language alignment.](image5).
