The classification loss is crucial for training [2]. Models that incorporate both class and  ℓ₁ losses achieve an AP₅₀ of 57.3, as shown in the table ![The table shows the impact of different loss components on Average Precision (AP) and its variants for object detection.](image5). Spatial positional encodings are also important, with significant drops in AP when they are not used [3]. The table details the performance metrics for a model trained without GIoU loss ![The table presents results for different configurations of positional encoding in an encoder-decoder model.](image3). The model's ability to disentangle objects through global scene reasoning is also crucial, as evidenced by the attention maps of the last encoder layer [5]. Without encoder layers, there is an overall drop in AP [5]. The architecture of DETR uses a transformer with specific learning rates for the transformer and backbone, and the transformer weights are initialized using Xavier initialization [4]. The final layers benefit from self-attention, which inhibits duplicate predictions, although NMS can sometimes remove true positive predictions at these layers ![This image shows AP and AP50 performance vs decoder layers, with and without NMS.](image2). The visualization of decoder attention on animal objects demonstrates how the model effectively localizes and identifies these objects within a scene ![The image visualizes how DETR-DC5 identifies animals in a scene, highlighting decoder attention on elephants and zebras.](image4).

DETR with L1 loss and without GIoU loss has an AP50 value of 57.3 on the COCO validation set.

The Translation Ranking model uses a pre-trained cross-lingual encoder and pooling layer to obtain sentence embeddings for segments [2]. These segments include the source, reference, and hypotheses [10]. The embeddings are then optimized using the triplet margin loss.

![The diagram illustrates the use of the triplet margin loss function to optimize sentence embeddings in a model with an anchor, positive, and negative input.](image3)

The purpose of the triplet margin loss is to minimize the distance between the "better" hypothesis and the "anchors" (source and reference) in the resulting embedding space [10]. This process ensures that the sentence embeddings map closely related sentences near each other while pushing unrelated sentences farther apart [10].

In the Translation Ranking model, the triplet margin loss optimizes the embedding space to minimize the distance between the better hypothesis and the source and reference.

The Aggression Identification Shared Task at COLING 2018 had a structured timeline [1, 5]. Participants first registered using a Google Form to compete in either English, Hindi, or both [3]. They received annotated datasets and were allowed to use publicly available additional data [3].

The shared task was announced on February 1, 2018, and registration commenced ![The table provides key dates for the shared task, starting with the announcement and registration in February and ending with the submission deadline for system description papers in May.](image2). The train and development sets were released on March 13, 2018 [3]. The test set was released on April 25, 2018, giving participants five days to test and upload their systems [3].

Submissions were due by April 30, 2018, and the results were declared on May 2, 2018 ![The table provides key dates for the shared task, starting with the announcement and registration in February and ending with the submission deadline for system description papers in May.](image2). The deadline for submitting system description papers was May 28, 2018 [3].

In 2018, the Aggression Identification Shared Task began with the announcement and registration in February, followed by data releases in March and April, culminating in result declarations in May.

Post-hoc correction with external feedback enhances output refinement by incorporating external resources to improve the quality and accuracy of the generated content. This strategy involves a language model generating outputs, which are then reviewed by a critic model that provides feedback ![The image illustrates three post-hoc correction strategies:Self-Correction, Post-hoc Correction with External Feedback, and Multi-Agent Debate.](image1). The key enhancement comes from leveraging external models and tools such as knowledge bases, trained models, code interpreters, and search engines to assist in refining these outputs [1].

Specifically, external knowledge is employed to ensure the factual accuracy of the output [6]. Models like RARR, REFEED, and LLM-Augmenter prompt LLMs to question their outputs, and then an external retriever searches for relevant evidence, which is subsequently used to refine the outputs [6]. This approach is further extended by FACTOOL to a wider range of tasks, including code generation, mathematical reasoning, and scientific literature review [6]. The integration of external feedback sources allows for more informative and diverse input, leading to a more transparent and explainable self-correction process [5].

Post-hoc correction with external feedback refines outputs by using external resources like knowledge bases and search engines to enhance accuracy and quality.

The document does not contain the specific prompt template used for the label 'Contact.Meet' within the filter-then-rerank method. However, it does provide insights into the general methodology and related aspects.

The research introduces a filter-then-rerank paradigm that integrates both SLMs and LLMs to improve performance on few-shot IE tasks [5]. This paradigm uses SLMs to select the top N candidate labels, which are then reranked by LLMs to make the final decisions [5]. This approach reframes the task as a multi-choice question (MCQ) problem, where each candidate label is converted into a choice using pre-defined templates [5].

The prompts consist of instructions, demonstrations, and questions [6]. The prompt format converts the demo and sample to input context for LLMs [6].  The study also explores different prompt formats, including text prompts and code prompts [9]. Examples of prompts on IE tasks including Named Entity Recognition (NER), Relation Extraction, Event Detection, and Event Argument Extraction are shown in the document ![Examples of prompts for NER, Relation Extraction, Event Detection and Event Argument Extraction](image3).

The templates for converting candidate labels to question options are listed for the FewNERD, TACREV and ACE05 datasets [4]. Templates for TACREV dataset are defined using placeholders for subject and object entities [8]. Various event types and their corresponding trigger templates are described, although 'Contact.Meet' is not among them ![Event types and trigger templates](image4). Similarly, entity types and templates for classification are provided, but without specific mention of 'Contact.Meet' [5].

Therefore, while the document details the filter-then-rerank approach and provides examples of prompt templates for various datasets and entity types, the specific template for the 'Contact.Meet' label is not included.

RAPTOR utilizes two querying strategies: tree traversal and collapsed tree, to navigate its hierarchical tree structure for effective information retrieval [4, 8].

The tree traversal method navigates the tree layer by layer, pruning and selecting the most relevant nodes at each level, whereas the collapsed tree method assesses nodes from all layers simultaneously to identify the most relevant ones ![The image illustrates two mechanisms for retrieving information using tree structures: Tree Traversal Retrieval and Collapsed Tree Retrieval.](image2). In tree traversal, the process begins by selecting the top-k most relevant root nodes based on cosine similarity to the query embedding [7].  At each subsequent layer, children of the selected nodes are considered, and the top $k$ nodes are chosen based on their cosine similarity to the query vector, repeating this process until reaching the leaf nodes [7].  The text from all selected nodes is then concatenated to form the retrieved context [7]. By adjusting the depth $d$ and the number of nodes $k$ selected at each layer, tree traversal provides control over the specificity and breadth of the retrieved information, starting broadly and focusing on finer details [9].

In contrast, the collapsed tree approach simplifies the search by considering all nodes in the tree at once, flattening the multi-layered tree into a single layer for comparison [3].  This method offers greater flexibility by searching through all nodes simultaneously, retrieving information at the correct level of granularity for a given question [1]. Tests on the QASPER dataset indicate that the collapsed tree approach consistently performs better than tree traversal, likely because it can retrieve information at the most appropriate level of detail for a given question, as depicted in Figure 3 [1].  The collapsed tree method involves flattening the tree and retrieving nodes based on cosine similarity until a threshold number of tokens is reached ![The image is a graph comparing different querying methods based on the F1 score.](image5).

In summary, tree traversal navigates the tree layer by layer, whereas collapsed tree flattens the tree to consider all nodes simultaneously for retrieval.

The t-SNE plots provide a visual representation of the style and content spaces learned by both DAE and VAE models [9].  Sentences with different styles are noticeably separated in the style space, but are less distinguishable in the content space [9].  This suggests that the models successfully disentangle style from content.

![The image shows t-SNE plots that visualize the disentangled style and content spaces for Yelp data.](image3)

The latent space learned by VAE is smoother and more continuous compared to that of DAE [9]. Looking at the style space plots, DAE shows more distinct clusters for each class ('neg' and 'pos'), while VAE also clusters the points but with less distinct separation. The content space plots for both models display overlapping clusters, indicating less separation in this space.  This is further supported by experiments verifying that the style space contains style information, while the content space does not [1].

DAE exhibits more defined clusters in style space, whereas VAE produces a smoother, more continuous latent space.

The "hard-to-contrast" strategy generally outperforms others across different datasets [5]. This observation is supported by Figure 5, which shows a quantitative comparison of map-based querying strategies [5]. ![The image is a bar chart comparing map-based querying strategies across four datasets: PathMNIST, OrganAMNIST, BloodMNIST, and CIFAR-10-LT](image1). As demonstrated in image1, "hard-to-contrast" consistently yields the highest AUC scores in PathMNIST, OrganAMNIST, and BloodMNIST datasets [5]. The "hard-to-contrast" querying strategy significantly outperforms random selection [5]. Furthermore, this strategy does not require ground truths, making it practical for active learning [5].

The hard-to-contrast initial query strategy outperforms other initial query strategies in every cycle of active learning [6, 9]. Hard-to-contrast data consistently outperforms the others and steadily improves model performance [10].

Therefore, the hard-to-contrast map-based querying strategy consistently performs best across different datasets.

The amount of training data significantly impacts the accuracy of NLP models [8]. Training models on Common Crawl data reveals a positive correlation between the amount of data and performance, as illustrated in the graph ![The graph shows the average GLUE score increasing as the number of train data tokens increases, demonstrating a positive correlation.](image3).

Models were trained using the same hyper-parameter settings on Common Crawl data for 600K updates [8]. As the amount of Common Crawl data increases from 562 million tokens to 18 billion tokens, the average GLUE score also increases ![The table provides detailed performance metrics for various NLP tasks using different training data sizes from Common Crawl.](image4). Specifically, pretraining on Common Crawl benefits CoLA and RTE tasks the most from additional data [10].

Based on the experimental results, models trained on 18B Common Crawl tokens achieved the highest average accuracy across all GLUE tasks [1, 9].

Active learning aims to improve annotation efficiency by selecting the most critical data for annotation [6]. However, a significant challenge is the "cold start problem," where active learning initially performs worse than random selection due to biased initial queries [6]. Addressing this, a novel active querying strategy has been developed to ensure label diversity and identify hard-to-contrast data [3].

![The image is a bar chart comparing map-based querying strategies across four datasets, with the "hard-to-contrast" strategy tending to outperform others across different datasets.](image1)

The querying strategy emphasizes label diversity, which is often lacking in other active querying methods, leading to poorer performance compared to random selection [5]. Enforcing label diversity can significantly improve performance [4, 5]. As shown in the study, many existing active querying strategies benefit from incorporating label diversity, becoming more performant and robust [8]. For instance, on CIFAR-10-LT, hard-to-contrast selection significantly outperforms random selection [2]. Our querying strategy can select more data from minority classes such as horse, ship, and truck [1].

![This image illustrates different querying strategies based on Dataset Maps for the CIFAR-10-LT dataset, which helps identify easy-to-contrast and hard-to-contrast data, representing the most common patterns in the dataset.](image5)

Furthermore, selecting hard-to-contrast data, identified via pseudo-labels, contributes to optimal models and outperforms random selection [2]. Unlike easy- or hard-to-learn strategies that require ground truths, hard-to-contrast selection is a label-free approach [2]. The initial query strategy not only outperforms existing active querying strategies but also surpasses random selection by a large margin [3, 6, 9].

In the initial stages of active learning on CIFAR-10, random selection can be more effective than active querying strategies due to selection bias [image4]. However, hard-to-contrast data selection outperforms random selection [2].

Therefore, the hard-to-contrast selection strategy outperforms the random selection baseline on CIFAR-10-LT.

The combination layers in the model architecture serve to aggregate information from the processed states of each input token to generate embeddings [image2]. During fine-tuning, connections that are masked during training become unmasked in the combination layer, allowing the incorporation of more complete information [image2, 4].

The architecture combines outputs from green and blue sequences, processed by transformer decoder blocks, using multi-head self-attention in the combination mechanism [image1].

![Combination layers in Figure 2 gather information from processed states to generate embeddings.](image2)

The purpose of the combination layers is to gather information from the processed states of each input token, generating meaningful embeddings used for classification.

GPT-4V's errors have been meticulously analyzed using 150 randomly sampled instances [1]. The distribution of these errors is illustrated in a pie chart, which breaks down the error types and their proportions ![This chart shows the distribution of error types in GPT-4V's analysis, with perceptual errors being the most common.](image5). Perceptual errors constitute the largest portion of these inaccuracies, accounting for 35% of the total errors [2]. These errors are further divided into basic and domain-specific types; basic errors involve misinterpretations of elementary visual information, while domain-specific errors arise from a lack of specialized knowledge [2]. For example, GPT-4V may misidentify parts of a bone in a medical image, leading to incorrect reasoning [3].

GPT-4V's perceptual errors can also stem from prioritizing textual information over visual inputs, which can cause it to misinterpret visual narratives [2]. This is also exhibited in scenarios where the model relies solely on text descriptions, failing to integrate visual cues effectively [4]. The prevalence of perceptual errors highlights a key area for improvement in GPT-4V's ability to process and understand visual information. An example includes the model's struggles with the direction of arrows, revealing a deficiency in spatial awareness within images [8].

Therefore, the most common error type in GPT-4V's analysis is perceptual error.

The task success rate varies depending on the training setting used [2]. End-to-end RL training allows gradient propagation from the system action output layer back to the natural language user input layer [4]. The "SL + IL 1000 + end-to-end RL" setting, represented by a line with stars, starts the highest and reaches above 0.65, demonstrating the most significant improvement in task success rate among the settings.![The line graph shows different RL training settings, where "SL + IL 1000 + end-to-end RL" achieved the highest task success rate over time.](image5)

According to Figure 6, the "SL + IL 1000 + end-to-end RL" training setting achieved the highest task success rate over time.

CodeBERT has demonstrated state-of-the-art performance in code-to-documentation generation [4, 6]. Models pre-trained on programming languages generally outperform those trained solely on natural language, highlighting the benefit of incorporating programming language understanding [3].

![CodeBERT (MLM+RTD) achieves the highest BLEU score of 22.36, outperforming other models.](image3)

Specifically, CodeBERT pre-trained with Replaced Token Detection (RTD) and Masked Language Modeling (MLM) objectives shows a gain of 1.3 BLEU score over RoBERTa [1]. Furthermore, CodeBERT with both MLM and RTD pre-training objectives achieves a BLEU score of 22.36, improving by 2.55 points over RoBERTa [8]. The use of language can also improve code-to-NL generation [1]. The comparison of models reveals that CodeBERT generally outperforms baselines, as shown in evaluations for code documentation generation [10].

Therefore, CodeBERT (RTD+MLM) performs best in code-to-documentation generation overall.

The Llama 2 family includes models with varying sizes, each having a different carbon footprint due to the computational resources required for pre-training [4, 6]. TRADE can adapt to new domains without losing previously learned information [3]. When expanding domains, fine-tuning strategies are employed, and Gradient Episodic Memory (GEM) outperforms naive and Elastic Weight Consolidation (EWC) fine-tuning in overcoming catastrophic forgetting [2, 4]. For instance, GEM maintains higher performance on the original four domains compared to naive fine-tuning [9].

Expanding TRADE from four domains to a new domain achieves better performance than training from scratch on the new domain [7]. The evaluation on the 4 domains with different fine-tuning strategies, including Naive, EWC, and GEM are shown in ![The table presents the results of fine-tuning a model on new domains, comparing different strategies and their impact on joint and slot accuracy.](image4).

In the specific case of the hotel domain, different fine-tuning strategies impact the joint goal accuracy [9]. The performance on the four domains after fine-tuning with GEM only drops from 58.98% to 53.54% (-5.44%) on joint accuracy, whereas naive fine-tuning deteriorates the tracking ability, dropping joint goal accuracy to 36.08% (-22.9%) [9]. Additionally, when considering hotel as a new domain, fine-tuning with GEM outperforms the naive fine-tuning approach on the new domain [10].

GEM fine-tuning resulted in the highest joint goal accuracy for the "Hotel" domain after domain expansion.

The unsupervised cross-lingual NER task involves leveraging labeled data from a resource-rich source language to train a model for a low-resource target language, like Uyghur [1, 8, 9]. A key challenge is effectively mapping lexical items between languages, which can be improved using bilingual word embeddings.
![The image illustrates a method for translating Spanish-English words that aren't included in a dictionary using word embeddings.](image4)
One approach to address word order differences is using self-attention mechanisms [8]. The architecture of such a model, like the Self-attentive Bi-LSTM-CRF, involves character-level and word-level embeddings processed through Bi-LSTM layers, followed by masked self-attention and a CRF layer for sequence prediction ![The image depicts a detailed architecture of a Self-attentive Bi-LSTM-CRF model.](image1).

The performance of different models on Uyghur NER is detailed in Table 3 [4, 5]. Mayhew et al. (2017) achieved a score of 51.32 using Wikipedia and a 100K dictionary, while using only English data, the score was 27.20 ![The table presents the results of different models evaluated on an "Original Unsequestered Set," with the use of various extra resources.](image2). The BWET model scored 25.73 ± 0.89 with a 5K dictionary, and with self-attention, it scored 26.38 ± 0.34.  A combined approach that uses word embeddings to translate words not covered by Mayhew et al.'s dictionary achieved the best results [2].

Based on the data, the combined approach, particularly "Combined + self-att.," performs best in the Uyghur NER task, achieving a score of 32.09 ± 0.61 [2].

TRADE leverages knowledge transfer for predicting unseen (domain, slot, value) triplets [1]. When expanding TRADE to a new domain, fine-tuning generally outperforms training from scratch [5, 7]. The results on new domain for two cases: training from scratch and ﬁne-tuning from the base model show that ﬁne-tuning from the base model usually achieves better results on the new domain compared to training from scratch [3].

![The table highlights the comparison of performance metrics of Joint and Slot between training with only 1% of new domain data and fine-tuning BM on 1% of the new domain data using Naive, EWC, and GEM methods.](image5)

As seen in the evaluation within the "Train" domain, fine-tuning with GEM achieved a joint goal accuracy, shown as the joint metric, of 59.83, while training from scratch with the same amount of data yielded a joint accuracy of 44.24 [5]. Therefore, GEM fine-tuning outperforms training from scratch [7].

The joint goal accuracy in the "Train" domain improved by 15.59% when using the GEM fine-tuning strategy compared to training from scratch.

MIMIC-IT incorporates visual data from several datasets, each associated with its own image license [10]. These datasets include MS-COCO, Spot-the-diff, ScanNetV2, ActivityNet Captions, Visual Storytelling, TV Captions, and Ego4D [10]. The image licenses vary across these datasets; for example, MS-COCO uses a custom license, ScanNetV2 is non-commercial, and Ego4D uses a non-exclusive, non-transferable license ![The table lists different datasets in the context of visual data along with their associated image licenses and instruction-response licenses](image3).

In contrast, the instruction-response pairs for all these datasets share a uniform license: CC BY-NC-SA (Creative Commons Attribution-NonCommercial-ShareAlike) [10]. This license indicates that while the instruction-response data can be shared and adapted, it must be for non-commercial purposes, and any derivative works must be shared under the same terms. Thus, the image licenses are diverse and specific to each dataset, while the instruction-response licenses are standardized under a Creative Commons license.

The supervised fine-tuning (SFT) dataset for Chameleon is separated into categories such as Text, Code, Visual Chat, Image Generation, Interleaved Text/Image Generation, and Safety [7]. Balancing modalities within the SFT stage is crucial for high-quality alignment, preventing the model from developing an unconditional prior for generating a single modality [5].

The `Chameleon-SFT` dataset includes varying numbers of samples, tokens, and images across these categories, as shown in the table ![The table presents the number of samples, tokens, and images for different data categories within the Chameleon-SFT dataset](image5). For instance, the Text category contains 1.6 million samples with 940.0 million tokens, while the Image Generation category includes 64.3 thousand samples, 68.0 million tokens, and 64.3 thousand images [5]. The Interleaved Generation category has 16.9 thousand samples, 35.8 million tokens, and 30.7 thousand images. Safety data includes 95.3 thousand samples, 38.6 million tokens, and 1.6 thousand images [5].

Chameleon utilizes carefully curated high-quality datasets for both Visual Chat and Interleaved Text/Image Generation, following strategies recommended by Touvron et al. (2023) and Zhou et al. (2023) [2, 3]. The model's architecture and training approach are specifically tailored for the early-fusion, token-based, mixed-modal setting, enabling it to understand and generate images and text in any arbitrary sequence [4]. This mixed-modal approach allows Chameleon to handle prompts that expect interleaving, mixed-modal responses effectively [8]. Furthermore, the inclusion of safety data, particularly mixed-modal prompts, addresses potential multi-modal attack vectors, which are outside the distribution of text-only and text-to-image safety tuning datasets [9].

The statistics of the supervised fine-tuning dataset inform Chameleon's ability to generate mixed-modal content by balancing the representation of text and images.

Step-Back prompting, especially when combined with Retrieval Augmented Generation (RAG), significantly enhances performance on multi-hop reasoning tasks [2]. On the MuSiQue dataset, baseline performances for PaLM-2L and GPT-4 are notably low, but Step-Back prompting produces the best performance [2].

![The table shows the performance of different methods on MuSiQue and StrategyQA datasets, with PaLM-2L + Step-Back + RAG achieving the highest scores.](image2)

As shown in the table, PaLM-2L + Step-Back + RAG achieves **42.8%** on MuSiQue and **86.4%** on StrategyQA [2].  These results notably outperform GPT-4 on both tasks [2]. The ability of Step-Back prompting to derive high-level concepts and first principles from detailed instances guides the reasoning steps, leading to a more accurate solution [1].

Step-Back prompting combined with RAG achieves the highest performance on both MuSiQue and StrategyQA datasets, with percentages of 42.8% and 86.4%, respectively.

The SCITAB dataset exhibits a diverse range of reasons for refuted claims [2, 10]. Manual verification plays a crucial role in validating claims, especially those marked as "Not Enough Information(NEI)" [3]. LLMs tend to generate claims that are either not logical or irrelevant to the table content, necessitating human intervention [3]. 

The most common error types include incorrect calculation results and the use of incorrect approximation words [10]. Grounding errors and ambiguity errors also present unique challenges [8].  ![The table lists types of errors and their estimated proportions in percentages](image4). The types of errors include grounding, ambiguity, calculation and program errors. The majority of 'supported' claims that were incorrectly classified as 'refuted' involve numerical reasoning or comparison [7].

According to an analysis of refuted claims in the Sci-Fact dataset, a significant proportion are simply negated or paraphrased [1]. However, SCITAB exhibits greater diversity in refuted claims [10].  ![The table contains two sections titled "Refuted Reasons" and "NEI Reasons," each listing reasons along with their proportional percentages](image5). The calculation result being wrong is the most common reason for refuted claims.

The most common reason for a refuted claim in the SCITAB dataset is an incorrect calculation result.

The RAR pipeline combines retrieving and ranking with multi-modal large language models to enhance perception tasks [7]. In the inference stage, the image embedding is navigated through a memory index, and the top-k retrieved results serve as a preliminary filter [1]. The diagram illustrates a two-part pipeline involving a multimodal retriever and a retrieving & ranking process ![The pipeline aims to enhance recognition tasks by combining multi-modal data retrieval and ranking processes.](image5).

The object detection procedure in the dataset begins with cropping the image regions based on proposal bounding box coordinates, subsequently resizing the cropped region to a fixed proportion [4]. The image embeddings are used in a k-nearest neighbors (k-NN) search ![The diagram illustrates how pre-processing techniques like cropping and resizing assist in zero-shot recognition for object detection tasks using multimodal retrieval methods.](image2). The prompt guides MLLMs to rank the retrieved candidate object categories based on similarity [8]. An example of a ranking prompt for few-shot image classification, showcasing retrieved car images and their respective model names, demonstrates the process of using few-shot learning and ranking prompts to classify images ![This illustrates the process of using few-shot learning and ranking prompts to classify images.](image4).

In the example provided in the pipeline diagram, a butterfly is used as the input case, with the final prediction being a "Monarch butterfly" ![The pipeline aims to enhance recognition tasks by combining multi-modal data retrieval and ranking processes.](image5).

The distribution of the first words in questions reveals interesting patterns, with only 44% being WH- words [7]. A significant portion, 37%, falls into the "Other" category, indicating diverse question structures ![The pie chart displays the percentage distribution of the first word used in questions and example questions.](image2).

Specific examples include "What" (21%), "Where" (18%), and "The" (13%) [7]. Furthermore, questions sometimes begin with names or "if", adding variability [7]. For instance, "if" accounts for 7% of questions [7]. These questions are used to present a hypothetical scenario [7].

Therefore, the most common starting words in the questions include "What" and "Where," while "The" and "If" also appear frequently, with "Other" comprising a large portion of the distribution [7].

The DETR model uses a transformer decoder that decodes $N$ objects in parallel, differing from the original transformer which predicts the output sequence one element at a time [5]. Since the decoder is permutation-invariant, the $N$ input embeddings must be different to produce different results [5]. These input embeddings are learned positional encodings referred to as "object queries" [5].

![DETR architecture diagram, highlighting the use of CNN backbone, transformer encoder-decoder, and prediction heads for object detection](image3)

These object queries are transformed into an output embedding by the decoder and are then independently decoded into box coordinates and class labels by a feed-forward network, resulting in $N$ final predictions [5]. The model globally reasons about all objects together using pair-wise relations between them, while being able to use the whole image as context by using self- and encoder-decoder attention over these embeddings [5]. The transformer decoder uses multi-headed self- and encoder-decoder attention mechanisms to transform $N$ embeddings of size $d$ [5]. The detailed description of the transformer used in DETR, with positional encodings passed at every attention layer, is given in Fig. 10 [3].

![A DETR architecture diagram shows how the model predicts objects by using a CNN backbone, a transformer encoder-decoder, and bipartite matching for training](image2)

DETR leverages learned positional encodings, known as object queries, within its decoder to produce distinct object predictions, enabling the model to reason about object relationships and global context.

BERT with cross-entropy (CE) achieves an accuracy of 94.90 on the SST-2 dataset, while BERT with Dice Loss (DL) scores 94.37 [image1].

The use of Dice Loss is not accuracy-oriented and should not be used for accuracy-oriented tasks [5]. Experimental results for sentiment analysis tasks show that BERT with cross-entropy achieves 55.57 in terms of accuracy, while DL and DSC perform slightly worse [5].  ![The table presents accuracy (Acc) results for three different models on two sentiment analysis datasets, SST-2 and SST-5.](image1)

BERT+CE's accuracy on SST-2 exceeds that of BERT+DL by 0.53.

Fine-tuning and in-context learning represent two distinct strategies for enhancing the ranking capabilities of Multimodal Large Language Models (MLLMs) within the RAR framework [6, 7]. Fine-tuning involves training the MLLM on specific datasets like FGVC-Aircraft to bolster its ranking capabilities [6, 8]. In contrast, in-context learning leverages the model’s pre-existing knowledge by providing specific examples within the input prompt, guiding the model to rank without explicit re-training [7].

![The table presents performance metrics for different methods evaluated on several datasets.](image4)

The results indicate that fine-tuning generally leads to a consistent improvement in accuracy across almost all datasets for InternLM-XC2 [6]. As shown in the table, the 'Strategy' column differentiates between fine-tuning (F) and in-context learning (S), allowing for a direct comparison of performance metrics across various datasets [image4]. Green highlights indicate the highest performance for a specific dataset and strategy, emphasizing the effectiveness of fine-tuning in many scenarios [image4].

![The image is a table showcasing the process of reranking class names for zero-shot object recognition.](image1)

RAR with fine-tuning often demonstrates a more substantial enhancement in performance compared to in-context learning, suggesting that targeted training on relevant datasets significantly bolsters the model's ability to rerank and classify objects accurately, as visualized in the reranking process [1, image1].

Fine-tuning generally outperforms in-context learning for the RAR method on the InternLM-XC2 model across various datasets.

QAC HECK is designed to address the limitations of existing fact-checking systems by generating multi-step explanations through question-guided reasoning [4, 5]. The system includes a claim verifier, question generator, question-answering module, QA validator, and reasoner to ensure a transparent and explainable fact-checking process [4, 5].  ![The system visualizes a step-by-step reasoning process for answering the query, including reasoning depth, generated question, relevant retrieved evidence and predicted answer.](image2)

QAC HECK also allows users to customize each module with different models, providing flexibility in the question-answering component, such as using the retriever-reader model or the FLAN-T5 model [1, 8]. ![The image depicts three different implementations of a Question Answering (QA) module in a system referred to as QAC HECK.](image1) The performance of QAC HECK was evaluated using the HOVER dataset, which includes claims requiring multi-step reasoning [7].  QAC HECK achieved macro-F1 scores of 55.67, 54.67, and 52.35 on HOVER two-hop, three-hop, and four-hop claims, respectively [9].  

To calculate the average performance gap between ProgramFC and QAC HECK on the HOVER dataset, we average the difference in F1 scores for the 2-hop, 3-hop, and 4-hop tasks. The F1 scores for ProgramFC are 54.27, 54.18, and 52.88, while the corresponding scores for QAC HECK are 55.67, 54.67, and 52.35 [9].  The differences are (55.67 - 54.27) = 1.40, (54.67 - 54.18) = 0.49, and (52.35 - 52.88) = -0.53. The average of these differences is (1.40 + 0.49 - 0.53) / 3 = 0.4533.  ![The table presents the performance of different AI models on two datasets: HOVER and FEVEROUS.](image3)

The average performance gap between ProgramFC and QAC HECK on the HOVER dataset is 0.45.

The experiment leverages an Application Programming Interface (API) to automatically analyze the user’s personality from their review texts [6]. Specifically, the Recep ti viti API is used because it is a widely-validated and widely-used psychology-based language analysis platform [6]. The API outputs scores for the OCEAN personality model, which includes Openness, Conscientiousness, Extroversion, Agreeableness, and Neuroticism [6].

The user's personality is represented by a 5-dimensional OCEAN score, which includes Openness, Conscientiousness, Extraversion, Agreeableness, and Neuroticism. Three methods are used to incorporate these scores into the model: the Most Salient Personality method, the Soft-labeled Personality method, and Hard-coded Personality [4].

![The diagram presents three methods for incorporating OCEAN scores into the model.](image4)

To evaluate the accuracy of detected personality traits, the personality scores inferred by the API are analyzed [5]. The inferred personality matches the review text in 81% of the Amazon-beauty samples and 79% of the samples from Amazon-music, with an average Cohen’s Kappa of 0.70 [5].

Based on the diagram, the personality vector with hard-coded personality is the one with the blue color scheme. The raw OCEAN scores are scaled and fixed as a personality vector {0.3, 0.7, 0.5, 0.3, 0.2}, and it won't change during training [4].

Therefore, the personality scores of the data sample with extreme personality cases, where the personality vector color is blue in the overall model structure, are [0.2, 0.3, 0.3, 0.5, 0.7].

To address adversarial spelling mistakes, a word recognition model can be placed before the downstream classifier [3]. These models are trained to recognize words corrupted by random additions, deletions, swaps, and keyboard mistakes [3]. The architecture often builds upon the RNN semi-character architecture, introducing backoff strategies for handling rare and unseen words, as shown in the structure of the foreground and background models ![The image illustrates a diagram representing a hybrid model combining two components: a "Background Model" and a "Foreground Model".](image4).

Spelling correction is viewed as a sub-task of grammatical error correction [2]. Classic methods use a source language model and a noisy channel model to find the most likely correction for a given word [2]. Neural techniques have also been applied, modeling the context and orthography of the input [2]. The table showcases different models' performance under various attack types, including "Swap", "Drop", "Add", and "Key" errors ![This table presents the performance (likely accuracy or another metric) of different models under various types of text perturbations or attacks.](image2). The results indicate how models like BERT perform under single-character and two-character attacks, and how defenses like "Pass-through" and "Neutral" variants can restore accuracy ![The table presents a comparison of different models' performance under scenarios with and without attacks.](image1).

Specifically, the neutral backoff variant has the lowest sensitivity [6]. This is because it returns a fixed neutral word whenever the ScRNN predicts an unknown token, reducing the number of unique outputs it predicts [6]. A comparison of different spell-correction methods, including ATD and ScRNN variants, highlights the performance across various error types.  ![The table presents a comparison of the effectiveness of different spell-correction methods across various types of spelling errors.](image3). According to the text, the most accurate variant involves backing off to the background model, resulting in a low error rate of 6.9%, leading to the best performance on word recognition [5]. This is a 32% relative error reduction compared to the vanilla ScRNN model with a pass-through backoff strategy [5].

Based on the information provided in the image3, ScRNN with a dataset of 10K words using the Background backoff variant performs best across all types of spelling errors.

The contextual augmentation method provides a wider range of substitute words by using words predicted by a bi-directional language model (LM) according to the context [5]. This method stochastically replaces words with other words that are predicted by a bi-directional language model at the word positions [6].  For instance, in the sentence "the actors are fantastic," the word "actors" can be replaced with words like "performances," "films," "movies," and "stories" ![The image illustrates the process of contextual augmentation using a bi-directional RNN language model](image1). The label-conditional architecture ensures that the replacements are compatible with the original labels [6]. When the label is positive, words like "fantastic" are replaced with positive expressions such as "funny," "honest," and "good." Conversely, with a negative label, "fantastic" is replaced with negative words like "tired," "forgettable," and "bad" [3].  This is illustrated by the top-10 word predictions for a sentence from the SST dataset, where predictions vary significantly depending on the label fed into the conditional LM ![The image is a diagram illustrating the predicted words with the ten highest probabilities from a conditional bi-directional language model applied to the sentence "the actors are fantastic"](image2).

The results in Table 1 indicate that contextual augmentation improves model performances more significantly than synonym-based augmentation [1].  For the RNN architecture, the average accuracy with synonym augmentation is 77.40, while the average accuracy with context and label is 77.83 ![The table presents the performance metrics of two types of models, CNN and RNN, along with various modifications, across different tasks or datasets](image3). Therefore, the label-conditional architecture boosted the performances on average and achieved the best accuracies [1].

The average accuracy improved by 0.43 when using the model with context and label compared to the model with synonym for the RNN architecture.

The Sythus pipeline is an automated process designed for generating high-quality instruction-response pairs in multiple languages [6]. It builds upon the framework proposed by LLaVA and utilizes ChatGPT to generate instruction-response pairs based on visual content [6].

The process begins with setting a system message and including a visual annotation ![The image is a flowchart explaining the Sythus process for generating high-quality instruction-response pairs in eight languages.](image1). The pipeline incorporates system messages, visual annotations, and in-context examples as prompts for ChatGPT to ensure the quality of the generated pairs [6]. System messages define the desired tone and style, while visual annotations provide essential image information such as bounding boxes and image descriptions [6]. In-context examples assist ChatGPT in learning within the context [6].

A cold-start strategy is employed to enhance in-context examples before large-scale querying since the quality of the coreset impacts the subsequent data collection process [6]. During the cold-start stage, in-context examples are collected by prompting ChatGPT solely through system messages and visual annotations, using a heuristic approach; this stage concludes only when satisfactory in-context examples are identified [6].

ChatGPT is then utilized to generate instruction-response pairs [6]. After generating the instruction-response pairs, a filtering process is applied to ensure quality, again using ChatGPT ![The image is a flowchart explaining the Sythus process for generating high-quality instruction-response pairs in eight languages.](image1). Finally, the instruction-response pairs are translated into eight languages: Chinese, Japanese, Spanish, German, French, Korean, and Arabic [6].

The Sythus process involves setting system messages, using visual annotations, generating instruction-response pairs with ChatGPT, filtering for quality, and translating the pairs into multiple languages.

The LANI (Landmark Navigation) corpus and the CHAI (CHALET Instructions) corpus represent different approaches to instruction following and navigation tasks [3, 9]. Instructions in LANI typically include a single goal, whereas CHAI instructions often require multiple intermediate goals [9]. The data collection methods also differ; LANI is inspired by the HCRC Map Task, but uses a scalable data collection process, while CHAI instructions were collected using scenarios given to workers [5].

Looking at the distribution of linguistic categories in both datasets, we can identify the most frequent category in LANI ![This image displays counts and examples for linguistic categories in the LANI and CHAI datasets, highlighting spatial relations as the most frequent in LANI.](image5). As shown in the table, "Spatial relations between locations" has the highest count in LANI, with 123 occurrences [image5]. An example instruction from LANI illustrating this category is: "go past the bed to the desk" [image5].

Spatial relations between locations are the most frequent linguistic category in LANI, exemplified by instructions such as "go past the bed to the desk" [image5].

The Translation Ranking model uses a tuple  $\chi=(s,h^{+},h^{-},r)$ as input [7]. The model is designed to receive four segments: the source (s), a "better" hypothesis ($h^{+}$), a "worse" hypothesis ($h^{-}$), and a reference translation (r) [2].

The model then encodes these segments independently using a pre-trained cross-lingual encoder to obtain sentence embeddings [2, 7]. The architecture is optimized using the triplet margin loss to minimize the distance between the "better" hypothesis and the anchors (source and reference) in the resulting embedding space, as illustrated in the architecture diagram.
![The Translation Ranking model processes the source, reference, and two hypotheses to refine the embedding space using triplet margin loss.](image4)

The inputs to the Translation Ranking model are the source text, a better hypothesis, a worse hypothesis, and a reference translation.

The Hidden anchor compression method achieves significant speed-up ratios, influenced by the length of the demonstrations [6]. Datasets with longer demonstration lengths tend to exhibit higher acceleration ratios [2]. For instance, the AGNews dataset, having the longest demonstration length ($L_{\mathrm{demo}}$), shows the highest acceleration ratio among the datasets analyzed [2].

The table ![The table compares speed-up ratios for GPT2-XL and GPT-J across different datasets, including AGNews.](image1) shows that the speed-up ratio for GPT2-XL on the AGNews dataset is 2.5x [1]. The speed-up ratio ranges from $1.1\times$ to $2.9\times$ [6]. Also, the acceleration effect is more pronounced in the GPT-J model compared to GPT2-XL [5].

Using anchor-only context compression, GPT2-XL can speed up by 2.5x on AGNews.

The dynamic span graph framework refines span representations through iterative propagation of coreference and relation type confidences [1]. According to Figure 3a, the coreference layer obtains the best performance on the second iteration (N=2) [2]. Similarly, Figure 3b shows that the model achieves the best performance for relation propagation on the second iteration (M=2) [4]. ![The left graph shows the F1 score of entity extraction across four iteration counts for CorefProp, with the highest score at two iterations.](image1)

The study also investigates the impact of coreference propagation on entity categorization of pronouns, demonstrating a 6.6% improvement on pronoun performance with DYGIE [3]. The framework's effectiveness is further validated through tests on datasets like ACE2004, ACE2005, SciERC, and the Wet Lab Protocol Corpus [5]. The results indicate that coreference propagation is beneficial for entities, while relation propagation significantly benefits both entity and relation extraction [7]. In joint entity and relation extraction tasks, DYGIE achieves substantial improvements in both entity recognition and relation extraction across multiple datasets [8].

The inclusion of repetition control impacts the question-asking frequency in generated text [3]. "Question-controlled CT with repetition control" demonstrates a more gradual increase in question percentage, reaching a lower maximum percentage near 80% as the control level increases, compared to "Question-controlled CT" which approaches near 100% question-asking at higher control levels ![The graph illustrates how the question frequency in text can be modulated using different controls or techniques, potentially providing a tool for adjusting question-asking behavior in language generation models.](image4).

The primary problem is the weighted decoding feature extrep bigram, which discourages bigrams that have appeared in previous utterances preventing the model from producing bigrams that commonly occur in many questions, such as 'do you' and 'what is' [3]. To address this, a setting  $z\ =\ 10\ (b o o s t)$ was introduced to allow the model to produce necessary question-asking bigrams [3]. This adjustment yields a  $99.54\%$ question-asking rate, albeit with a slight increase in external bigram repetition [3].

The Long-Short Term User Representation (LSTUR) approach uses a news encoder to learn representations of news and a user encoder to learn representations of users [1]. Two methods, LSTUR-ini and LSTUR-con, combine long-term and short-term user representations [2].

In LSTUR-ini, the long-term user representation initializes the hidden state of the GRU network used for short-term user representation; the last hidden state of the GRU network then serves as the final user representation [4]. ![LSTUR-ini uses user embedding to initialize the model](image3)

Conversely, LSTUR-con concatenates the long-term user representation with the short-term user representation to create the final user representation [4]. ![LSTUR-con concatenates user embedding and a fixed user embedding](image3)

These methods balance the learning of long-term and short-term user representations, with a moderate balance (e.g., 0.5) being optimal for both LSTUR-ini and LSTUR-con [3]. Both methods achieve comparable performance and outperform baseline methods, with LSTUR-con being more stable [5].

In summary, LSTUR-ini initializes the GRU network with long-term user data, while LSTUR-con concatenates long-term and short-term user representations.

The training of large models like Chameleon-7B and Chameleon-34B faces stability challenges, especially when scaling beyond 8B parameters and 1T tokens [4]. One significant issue is the divergence caused by the softmax operation, particularly when dealing with multiple modalities [1]. To address this, Query-Key Normalization (QK-Norm) is employed to control the norm growth of inputs to the softmax within the attention mechanism [5].  The application of QK-Norm helps with the inner softmaxes within the Transformer [8].  Without QK-Norm, the training loss of Chameleon-7B diverges after approximately 20% of a training epoch ![The image is a line graph comparing the training loss of a model called Chameleon-7B, with and without a technique referred to as QK-Norm.](image5). Furthermore, uncontrolled growth of output norms is a strong indicator of potential future training divergence ![The image is a graph illustrating the growth of output norms over training steps under different conditions.](image2).

Without QK-norm, the loss begins to spike after approximately 20% of the training epoch.

Iterative retrieval alternates between retrieval and generation to provide richer context [5]. Recursive retrieval refines queries and divides problems into sub-problems, continuously solving complex issues [5]. Adaptive retrieval allows the system to decide when external knowledge retrieval is needed, stopping autonomously when necessary [2].

![Iterative Retrieval focuses on alternating between retrieval and generation to provide richer context, Recursive Retrieval on gradually refining the user query, and Adaptive Retrieval on determining when external knowledge retrieval is needed.](image5)

These processes enhance retrieval and generation differently to improve system performance and flexibility, as highlighted in modular RAG frameworks [8]. Recursive retrieval is used to improve the depth and relevance of search results by iteratively refining search queries based on previous searches [1]. Adaptive retrieval methods refine the RAG framework by enabling LLMs to actively determine the optimal moments and content for retrieval [2].

In summary, iterative, recursive, and adaptive retrieval processes differ in their approach to refining queries and determining when to retrieve external knowledge within a RAG system.

Adversarial training and the type of evaluation data significantly impact model performance, as evidenced by experiments on datasets like HOTPOT QA [1, 9]. When models are trained using adversarial distractors, their performance varies depending on whether they are tested on original or adversarial distractor sets [4, 8].

The table ![The table shows a comparison of performance metrics (scores) for different combinations of evaluation and training data](image4) illustrates this impact, showing that models trained on original data achieve 67.08 F1 when evaluated on original data, but only 46.84 F1 when evaluated on adversarial distractors.  However, models retrained on adversarial distractors can recover some of their original accuracy [2, 4]. Specifically, the F1 score increases to 60.10 when the adversarially trained model is tested on adversarial distractors [4, 8].

Filtering by entity type can further degrade performance, with the original model's accuracy dropping significantly (e.g., to 40.73 F1), but adversarial training helps the model recover, increasing the F1 score to 58.42 [5]. This indicates that adversarial training can improve a model's robustness when faced with more challenging or carefully chosen distractor paragraphs [6].

The diagram ![This image is not a table, but rather a diagram illustrating a process involving the BERT (Bidirectional Encoder Representations from Transformers) model](image1) shows the architecture of BERT model, which takes question and paragraph as input, and outputs whether the paragraph contains answer or not. The distractors are selected based on the lowest score, where the model thinks the paragraph contains the answer [7]. This selection of distractors makes the adversarial training more robust.

Overall, adversarial training enhances a model's ability to generalize across different types of evaluation data, particularly when the evaluation data contains adversarial distractors or is filtered by entity type.

The WMT19 Metrics Shared Task evaluated various metrics, including reference-based metrics and reference-less metrics, to score the outputs of translation systems [7]. These metrics were assessed at both system and segment levels, using direct assessment (DA) as the manual evaluation method [7]. At the system level, several metrics demonstrated high Pearson correlations across different language pairs [3].

The YiSi metric series stands out for achieving the highest correlations in several language pairs [9]. Specifically, YiSi-1, which measures semantic similarity using contextual embeddings from BERT, achieved high system-level correlations, such as .947 for Chinese-English and .936 for English-German [3, 10]. Furthermore, metrics like chrF and sacreBLEU-chrF, though expected to yield similar scores due to identical parameters, exhibited some differences leading to varied correlations [5].

The presence of gold paragraphs and distractors significantly influences the F1 scores of multi-hop question answering models. In the distractor setting, a single-paragraph BERT model achieves an F1 score of 67.08 [1]. However, the accuracy declines to 46.84 F1 when evaluated on new distractors [4].

Retraining the model on these adversarial distractors improves the accuracy to 60.10 F1 [4]. This is further supported by data showing that when the evaluation data includes "+ Type", the score is 40.73 with original training data but increases to 58.42 with adversarial training data ![Adversarial training improves model accuracy on "+ Type" evaluation data.](image2).

In open-domain settings, the impact of gold paragraphs is notable.  The F1 score is 39.12 given 500 retrieved paragraphs, but increases to 53.12 when additional gold paragraphs are provided [10]. This highlights the importance of retrieving relevant gold paragraphs for multi-hop questions [10]. Even with 500 distractors, single-paragraph BERT achieves an F1 score of 53.12, which suggests that a large number of distractors alone is insufficient [5].

The table clearly illustrates that the inclusion of a "Gold Paragraph" in the "Open-domain 500 Paragraphs" setting significantly boosts the F1 score from 39.12 to 53.12 ![Adding a gold paragraph significantly improves the F1 score in the open-domain setting.](image5). This demonstrates that while distractors can pose challenges, access to relevant gold paragraphs substantially enhances model performance.

The inclusion of gold paragraphs significantly improves F1 scores, while distractors can reduce performance unless the model is specifically trained to handle them.

The components marked as 'Word LSTM-B' and 'Word LSTM-F' in the neural network architecture serve to process word-level representations by capturing contextual information from both directions within the sentence ![The architecture illustrates a neural network model for named entity recognition, combining character-level and word-level representations processed by bidirectional LSTMs and a CRF for structured output labeling.](image5). Similar to character-level processing, bidirectional LSTMs, specifically 'Word LSTM-B' (Backward) and 'Word LSTM-F' (Forward), handle sequences of words, such as "Best" and "Buy" [5]. This is done to allow the model to understand the context of each word in relation to the words that come before and after it in the sentence [image5]. This approach builds upon character-level embeddings and representations, which are combined to form word-level representations [image5]. The use of bidirectional LSTMs at the word level is a common technique in sequence labeling tasks, enhancing the model's ability to capture complex dependencies and improve accuracy in named entity recognition [2, 9].

'Word LSTM-B' and 'Word LSTM-F' capture contextual information at the word level, processing the word sequence in both forward and backward directions to improve named entity recognition.

The distribution of query types within the dataset is divided into three rungs, each representing different levels of causal reasoning [5, 10]. Rung 1 focuses on basic probability distributions, while Rung 2 includes causal inference queries like ATE and Adjustment Sets, and Rung 3 encompasses more complex causal queries such as counterfactuals, NDE, NIE, and ATT [10].

The dataset roughly balances across the query types, with some query types having slightly lower representation due to compatibility with a subset of graphs ![The pie chart shows the distribution of query types in the dataset, divided into three rungs: Rung 1 (Cond. Prob., Marg. Prob.), Rung 2 (ATE, Adjust. Set), and Rung 3 (Counterf., NDE, NIE, ATT).](image3). Rung 1 includes marginal and conditional probabilities, which deal with the overall and conditional distribution of variables, respectively [9]. Rung 2 includes ATE, which assesses how changing a treatment affects an outcome, and adjustment sets, which determine which variables should be adjusted to eliminate spurious correlations when estimating causal effects [3, 10]. Rung 3 involves more complex queries, such as counterfactual probabilities, ATT, NDE, and NIE. These queries explore the likelihood of outcomes under different hypothetical scenarios or investigate direct and indirect causal effects through mediators [2, 10]. The "balanced" benchmark contains roughly the same number of questions for each distinct story-graph-query combination, and balances the distribution of correct answers, ensuring an equal number of "yes" and "no" answers [6].

![The pie chart illustrates the distribution of query types across the three rungs, including Cond. Prob., Marg. Prob., ATE, Adjust. Set, NIE, NDE, ATT, and Counterf.](image5)

The distribution of query types across the three rungs includes probability distributions (Rung 1), causal inference queries (Rung 2), and counterfactual and interventional queries (Rung 3).

Step-Back prompting enhances the performance of large language models by enabling them to derive high-level concepts and principles from specific instances [1]. This approach leads to significant improvements in reasoning-intensive tasks [1]. For example, on TimeQA, baseline models like GPT-4 and PaLM-2L achieved accuracies of $45.6\%$ and $41.5\%$ respectively, but Step-Back + RAG improved the accuracy to $68.7\%$ [2].  The value of abstraction before addressing a question is significant [3].

On the TQA Easy benchmark, different methods were evaluated. ![The table shows the performance of different methods on four benchmarks: TimeQA, TQA Easy, TQA Hard, and SituatedQA.](image1) The results show that PaLM-2L + Step-Back + RAG achieved the highest performance on TQA Easy [image1]. This highlights the effectiveness of combining abstraction with retrieval augmentation [2].

The PaLM-2L model, when combined with Step-Back prompting and RAG, achieved the highest performance on the TQA Easy benchmark with an accuracy of $75.2\%$ [image1].

The ranking prompt example showcases a process for few-shot image classification, which involves correctly identifying an object within a set of retrieved images and associated labels. The method leverages a combination of visual and semantic analysis to refine the classification [7, 8]. An image of a car labeled "Mercedes-Benz E-Class Sedan" is provided, and the task is to correctly identify it from a series of retrieved car images with different model names ![This image shows a ranking prompt example, with a Mercedes-Benz E-Class Sedan correctly identified as the top result.](image4).

The process involves sorting the categories based on their relevance to the input image, ultimately generating a top-k list that ranks the likelihood of each category being the correct match [5]. This approach contrasts with traditional methods that rely solely on the initial retrieval order; instead, advanced analysis is employed to assess the contextual appropriateness of each class name [7]. Fine-tuning is done to improve ranking ability and follow the format of prompts [4, 6]. Even with a small-scale classification dataset, fine-tuning enhances the MLLM's ability to provide results as required [4].

The correct type of the car provided in the ranking prompt example is Mercedes-Benz E-Class Sedan.

The integration of coreference links significantly impacts the performance of information extraction and knowledge graph construction. Using coreference reduces the frequency of generic phrases while increasing the frequency of specific phrases, which helps to disambiguate phrases when generating a knowledge graph ![Linking entities through corefer- ence helps disambiguate phrases when generating the knowledge graph.](image5)

The precision of systems is high, but systems with coreference links have significantly higher recall [3]. This is further supported by human evaluations of constructed knowledge graphs, where the system with coreference linking shows a higher curve, indicating enhanced performance ![The graph indicates that the Area Under the Curve (AUC) is 0.751 for the curve with coreference and 0.695 for the one without, suggesting better performance with coreference.](image5). The area under the curve (AUC) is 0.751 with coreference and 0.695 without it [3]. Multi-tasking with coreference resolution significantly benefits overall performance [1, 10]. Specifically, relation extraction benefits from multi-tasking with coreference resolution [1]. The system with coreference links has significantly higher recall [3].

Including coreference in human evaluation leads to higher precision and recall, improving the quality of knowledge graph construction.

The Translation Ranking model uses a pre-trained cross-lingual encoder to process its inputs [6]. The model architecture receives four segments: a source, a reference, a "better" hypothesis, and a "worse" hypothesis [6]. These segments are independently encoded using the cross-lingual encoder, followed by a pooling layer to obtain sentence embeddings for each segment [6].

![The Translation Ranking model processes four segments (source, reference, better hypothesis, and worse hypothesis) using a cross-lingual encoder and pooling layer to obtain sentence embeddings, and it optimizes the embedding space using triplet margin loss.](image5)

The model optimizes the resulting embedding space to minimize the distance between the "better" hypothesis and the anchors (source and reference) using the triplet margin loss [6]. The input tuple χ = (s, h+, h−, r) is passed through the encoder and pooling layer to get sentence embeddings for each segment [10].

Therefore, the Translation Ranking model encodes the source, reference, and hypotheses, and then refines the embeddings to reflect the relative quality of the translations.

The dataset CL ADDER contains causal questions grounded in symbolic questions and ground truth answers [6]. The CL ADDER dataset includes a variety of causal queries across the three rungs of the Ladder of Causation: associational, interventional, and counterfactual [6]. The dataset is designed to broadly cover all rungs of the ladder of causation and uses binary variables to produce questions which are identifiable from the outset [9].

The data-generating process for the CL ADDER dataset involves sampling a causal graph from options like confounding, mediation, collision, chain, and fork, and sampling a query type such as association, intervention, or counterfactuals ![The data-generating process includes sampling causal graphs and query types](image1).

The dataset includes 10,112 samples with an average of 3.38 edges per graph ![The dataset contains information on the size, questions, answers and explanations](image5). Different causal graphs can have several causal graph template elements (CGTEs), such as the confounding structure, which has three CGTEs: confounding, mediation, and collision in the triangle form [8]. The distribution of query types in the 10K data includes conditional and marginal probabilities for Rung 1, ATE and adjustment sets for Rung 2, and NIE, NDE, ATT, and counterfactuals for Rung 3 ![The distribution of query types is categorized into three rungs](image2). The Causal Chain-of-Thought (CausalCoT) model extracts the causal graph, determines the query type, formalizes the query, and gathers relevant data to deduce and calculate the estimand, providing a final answer to the initial question ![The Causal Chain-of-Thought model is a methodological framework for answering causal inference questions](image4).

Without specific information on the number of directed edges in a chain-type causal graph, the provided information focuses on the general characteristics and construction of the CL ADDER dataset, and the methodology for causal reasoning.

The DSGAN pipeline can operate independently of the relation prediction of entity pairs, allowing it to be used as a true-positive indicator [1]. This helps in filtering noisy distant supervision datasets before relation extraction, leading to improvements [1]. The use of a generator to filter the distant supervision training dataset and redistribute false positive instances into the negative set provides a cleaned dataset for relation classification [2].

![The table shows that adding DSGAN to different models improves their performance, as indicated by the bolded values in the "+DSGAN" column.](image4)

The performance of models such as CNN+ONE, CNN+ATT, PCNN+ONE, and PCNN+ATT is enhanced with the addition of DSGAN, as shown in the table; the p-values indicate that these improvements are statistically significant [1]. DSGAN consistently helps achieve higher F1 scores, demonstrating its effectiveness in improving model performance over increasing epochs ![DSGAN consistently achieves the highest F1 scores, as demonstrated in the line graphs comparing different learning strategies across various categories.](image2).

![The graph illustrates that models incorporating DSGAN, particularly PCNN + ATT + DSGAN, generally maintain higher precision at different recall levels compared to other configurations.](image3)

The precision-recall curves also demonstrate that models incorporating DSGAN generally achieve better performance [1]. The accuracy of the discriminator decreases as the training epoch increases, indicating that the generator learns to produce more accurate true positive samples, which means the generator becomes more robust during the adversarial learning process [8]. The training process is stopped when the model reaches a critical point where the generator is robust enough [8].

In summary, the addition of DSGAN generally improves the performance of various models by providing a more robust true-positive generator and a cleaner dataset for relation classification.

The introduction of repetition control reduces the question-asking rate, even at the highest control level [4]. When conditional training is used to control question-asking, increasing the control variable *z* from 0 to 10 leads to a wide range of question-asking rates [4].

However, this rate is reduced when repetition control is introduced. Specifically, the *z* = 10 setting, which should ideally produce 100% questions, only produces 79.67% questions [4]. This reduction occurs because the weighted decoding feature `extrep bigram` discourages bigrams that have appeared in previous utterances, which prevents the model from producing common question-related bigrams such as "do you" and "what is" [4]. To counteract this, a boost setting *z* = 10 (boost) is introduced, which disables the `extrep bigram` feature during beam search but uses it for reranking candidates, resulting in a 99.54% question-asking rate [4].

 ![The line graph illustrates that the Question-controlled CT with repetition control line shows a more gradual increase in question percentage, reaching a lower maximum percentage near 80% as the control level increases.](image4)

As shown in the image, the "Question-controlled CT with repetition control" line, representing the model with both question control and repetition control, reaches a lower maximum question percentage compared to the "Question-controlled CT" line [4]. This difference highlights the impact of repetition control in reducing the question-asking rate, even when the question-asking control level is set to its maximum value [4].

The introduction of repetition control reduces the question-asking rate at the highest control level.

The original Argument Reasoning Comprehension Task (ARCT) presented a challenge in evaluating true argument comprehension due to models exploiting spurious statistical cues within the dataset [1]. BERT, in particular, initially showed a peak performance of 77% , which was surprisingly close to the average untrained human baseline [1].

![The table shows performance metrics for BERT and other models, highlighting BERT's initial high performance and subsequent drop after adversarial training.](image1)

However, this performance was misleading.  It was discovered that BERT's high accuracy was largely due to the exploitation of dataset-specific cues rather than actual argument understanding [1, 10].  To address this, an adversarial dataset was created by negating the claim and inverting the label for each data point, effectively mirroring the distribution of statistical cues [3].

![The table presents adversarial examples that invert claims and warrants, while keeping reasons constant.](image4)

When models were trained and validated on the original data but evaluated on the adversarial set, their performance dropped below random, indicating overfitting to the cues in the original training set [5].  Crucially, when BERT was trained from scratch on this adversarial dataset, its peak performance plummeted to 53%, with the mean and median accuracies hovering around 50% [3, 5].  This significant drop demonstrates the effectiveness of the adversarial dataset in eliminating the spurious cues [5].

![The table displays the reduced performance of BERT models on the adversarial test set after adversarial training, with scores close to random chance.](image5)

This outcome aligns better with the intuition that without genuine understanding of the underlying arguments, high performance should not be achievable [5].  The ability to reduce BERT's performance from near-human levels to essentially random underscores how heavily the model relied on statistical artifacts rather than true comprehension [9]. Therefore, BERT's performance drastically decreases to almost random levels on the adversarial dataset, indicating that it primarily learned to exploit statistical cues rather than comprehending arguments.

CodeBERT is trained using both bimodal and unimodal data [4]. Bimodal data consists of natural language-code pairs, while unimodal data includes codes without paired natural language texts and natural language without paired codes [4]. Specifically, the training data is sourced from Github repositories, where each bimodal data point is an individual function with paired documentation, and each unimodal code is a function without paired documentation [7].

The training dataset includes 2.1M bimodal datapoints and 6.4M unimodal codes across six programming languages: Python, Java, JavaScript, PHP, Ruby, and Go [10]. The total amount of bimodal data used for training CodeBERT is 2.1M, and the total amount of unimodal data is 6.4M across all six programming languages [10].

The dataset contains a total of 25,000 users, but only 22,938 users are included in the training set ![The dataset contains 25,000 users, 38,501 news articles, and 393,191 impressions, with additional details on negative/positive sample ratios and average title word count.](image5). This means some users were intentionally excluded during model training [2]. The exclusion of some users from the training data is a strategy to ensure the model's robustness when dealing with new or unseen users [2]. Approaches like LSTUR are designed to handle situations where long-term representations are unavailable, employing techniques such as masking user representations during training to simulate this [2]. Both LSTUR-ini and LSTUR-con methods effectively improve news recommendation performance by incorporating both long-term and short-term user representations ![LSTUR-ini demonstrates superior performance in AUC and nDCG@10 metrics compared to LTUR, STUR, and LSTUR-con for news recommendation.](image4).

Therefore, 2,062 users were not included in the training set.

In an examination of different querying methods, a collapsed tree approach, which evaluates nodes collectively across all layers to find the most relevant ones [3], was found to perform better than tree traversal [9]. The collapsed tree method offers greater flexibility [9].
![The graph indicates that the collapsed tree querying method peaks at 2000 tokens with the best F1 score in the QASPER dataset.](image5)
